At Cora Cora, Hector Ludena and Luisa Jimenez take guests on a tour of Peru’s vivid and robust cuisine.
At Saigonese, traditional Vietnamese dishes are offered in large portions for the health and taste conscious, with seasoning that is unlikely to offend.
Spending money to aid charity, with a purchase as a bonus.
Sun Noodle, with its gleaming 6,000-square-foot Teterboro factory and “ramen lab,” makes and sells 100,000 servings a week of more than 30 varieties of noodles.
As head writer for “The Americans,” Joseph Weisberg makes good use of his time in the C.I.A.
Hard-working under-age performers disrupt our sense of childhood as a period of all play and no work.
Music from Steve Coleman and Five Elements and Charles Bradley are among new releases.
Bridal gowns that recall the look of “The Great Gatsby” are growing increasingly popular this wedding season.
There are many styles that differ from the traditional white shoe for the bride.
While New Yorkers will see the usual Lotto-winner fantasies at the auto show, which opened to the public on Friday. the most important debuts run to entry-price luxury cars and mainstream models.

The 2014 Acura RLX, on display at the New York auto show, has a feature that Acura calls Precision All-Wheel Steer, which is intended to improve handling by adding steering capability to the rear wheels.

A new application of so-called drive-by-wire technology, to be available on the 2014 Infiniti Q50 sedan, may attract some attention. Except during emergencies, that car’s steering wheel will have no mechanical connection to the front wheels.
Jeremy Piven, who plays the lead role in the eight-part PBS series “Mr. Selfridge,” says he relates to the pathbreaking department store founder.
The silhouette of these vintage gowns and the variety of options for accessories are the attraction.
The 2013 Ford Explorer Sport is a seven-seat S.U.V. that  lives up to its name, with more power and better handling than the base Explorer.
Boxy, rough-riding S.U.V.’s have faded in favor of car-based crossovers aimed at younger, more suburban customers. To keep up with that trend, Jeep gave its 2014 Cherokee a softer look.
Jeep says the look of the new Cherokee reflects two sides of the brand’s personality. The upper half is sleek and streamlined, the lower tough and rugged.
The authors of “The Merciless Book of Metal Lists,” Howie Abrams and Sacha Jenkins, preview their choices for the most embarrassing pieces of art for heavy-metal album covers.
Young people “sick of the irony, rudeness and snark that is so prevalent in their online lives” are making a return to the world of manners.
Bobbi Brown says she doesn’t feel comfortable in high-end clothing and slips back into T-shirts and jeans whenever possible.
The Chicago White Sox value the hitting approach of Jeff Keppinger, whose career average of 15.64 plate appearances per strikeout is the best among active American Leaguers.
Strikeout rates have been trending upward for most of the past century, but what has happened in recent years seems to indicate something more. What is the cause?
Towering peaks, rustic inns and views that span countries on a trek through the Balkans.
In the once-tense border region separating Albania, Kosovo and Montenegro, a new trail offers a path for travelers to explore the area’s dramatic beauty.
Amid the city’s countless historic treasures, several modern-day architectural projects are worth seeking out.
Actors like Viggo Mortensen, who is fluent in Spanish, are joining Kristin Scott Thomas in working in films performed in a foreign language.
Images of Hollywood actors in non-English films.
Danny Boyle’s “Trance” centers on a triangle made up of an auction house employee (James McAvoy), a criminal (Vincent Cassel) and a beleaguered hypnotherapist (Rosario Dawson).
Sara Schechner and Kenneth Launie bonded over a shared love of science and history.
Basic information can substantially increase the number of low-income students who apply to, attend and graduate from top colleges.
A selection of cultural events.
A condo in Hell’s Kitchen with private outdoor spaces, a Greenwich Village loft in a prewar cast iron building and a Boerum Hill row house with an upper-floor rental.
A restored home from 1712, the oldest in Newark, N.J., and a four-bedroom clapboard colonial in Nassau County, Long Island.
A triplex at the distinctive apex of the Pierre Hotel, with cathedral windows replicating a Versailles chapel, has a record asking price of $125 million.
A look inside what is considered one of the most important and historic luxury apartments in the country.
New Yorkers will jump through all kinds of hoops, and even play a few tricks, in order to share a home with a beloved pet.

Still reeling from an acid attack on its artistic director, the Bolshoi Ballet is preparing to look back on a drama of a different sort: a daring, and shocking, 1913 performance of “The Rite of Spring.”
Alice Coote, known for her range and agility in male parts, will sing the role of Sesto in David McVicar’s production of Handel’s “Giulio Cesare” at the Met.
Rachmaninoff’s “All-Night Vigil” was recorded by the Latvian Radio Choir under the direction of Sigvards Klava.
Jan Lisiecki, a Canadian piano prodigy, recorded two Mozart piano concertos.
In A. B. Yehoshua’s novel, an Israeli film director travels to Santiago de Compostela for a tribute to his work.
“Fellow Traveler: The Complete String Quartet Works of John Adams,” recorded by the Attacca Quartet, finds the musicians rearranging the movements to their liking.
Novelists can peer into places like North Korea, with help from Google Earth.
Alejandro Zambra’s novel considers the legacy of Pinochet.
An investigative journalist examines a juvenile justice scandal, and a maverick defense lawyer recounts his most fraught case.
New books by Petra Reski, Sam Roberts, Walter Stahr and Jessica Grogan.
Alexander Stille looks at the discordant strains of his parents’ marriage.
This biography reveals a fiercely determined activist behind the mild-mannered lady in a hat.
The rocker and frontman for the Voidoids ruminates on his life, loves and his rift with a collaborator.

A Revolutionary War veteran and his slave are locked in an intimate battle of wills in Margaret Wrinkle’s first novel.
Andrea Stuart pursues the history of both sides of her Caribbean family.
Disguised as a self-help book, Mohsin Hamid’s novel traces a nameless hero’s journey from impoverished boy to corporate tycoon.
Sandra Day O’Connor offers an overview of the Supreme Court’s history.
He has starred with Chris Rock, Al Pacino and Alec Baldwin. And now he’s getting the best parts.
Karen O and her bandmates have never seemed comfortable as rock stars. Which has only made them that much more compelling.
Paperback books of particular interest.
Readers respond.

I thought I’d left the habit behind — until I ran into my ex-husband.
Sure, I want my kid to learn how to share. I also want her to learn how to thrive.
Weight loss; the Abbie Hoffman rule.

Junior rodeos in the Texas Panhandle.

When John Swan and Sarah Masel searched for a rental apartment to share, a usable living room was a priority.
A mother recalls a long-ago morning in a family where an autistic child pushes against the world, and everyone must cope.
With more than 500 styles, Worldtone Dance has been a destination for theatrical and competitive dancing shoes for more than 40 years.
Worldtone Dance in Manhattan is a popular spot to buy shoes for the dancesport community, a mix of social and competitive styles, like ballroom and salsa, as opposed to jazz, tap and ballet.
William Bunker Tubby was the go-to architect of the Pratt family of Brooklyn.
Successful real estate developers have a healthy appetite for risk and a sixth sense for what will ultimately sell.
Moving From a Sublet; Cracks in a New Condo Unit; An Absent Co-op Director.
Counseled borrowers were deemed nearly a third less likely to fall behind in payments 90 days or more in the first two years after closing.
The protagonist of William Gass’s “Middle C” is a fraudulent academic who obsessively catalogs the world’s evils in the “Inhumanity Museum” in his attic.
Cynthia Ozick says an author’s age shouldn’t be the subject for a book review.
Single and 40, I met a man with a child I learned to love as my own. Breaking up was not what we had planned.
Questions about a possible office affair; bad party politics; Internet dating ad nauseam; and being in the “12 items or less” line, multiplied by 2.
A retrospective on Barry McGee, tracing his roots as a graffiti artist, opens April 6 at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston.
The artist once known as Twist straddles streets and galleries.
From old movies to vaudeville acts, Douglas Carter Beane drew on many swishy real-life performances in writing “The Nance.”
For Nathan Lane and the playwright Douglas Carter Beane, “The Nance” involved not only historical research but also a reckoning with memories of growing up gay.

Jim Dwyer, a friend and competitor to Mike McAlary, the subject of Nora Ephron’s “Lucky Guy,” recalls the circumstances behind the play.
From the hard past of Chinese laborers in Trinidad, fusion cuisine of the highest order.
Seven people were killed at a nondescript nursing school in Oakland one year ago. Should it matter that the shooter was a Korean immigrant? It does to Koreans.
A look at some of the ineffective album cover art from “The Merciless Book of Metal Lists.”
A reimagining of the 1981 horror classic “The Evil Dead” stirs mixed reactions from the original’s fans.
Sometimes traveling 37 hours and 12,000 miles to witness an event that lasts mere minutes makes perfect sense.
Stanley Kubrick’s longtime assistant, Leon Vitali, says various theories about hidden meanings in “The Shining,” proposed in the documentary “Room 237,” are just “balderdash.”
Can you eat well in a region sometimes known as the “Redneck Riviera”? You can, if you know where to look, and you’re willing to drive.

ANDERSON--Richard G.,died March 22, 2013 in Wakefield, RI. Born in 1927 in New York City to Edwin and Ruby Arthur Anderson. Survived by his wife Jeanne Murdy Anderson; daughters Christine Anderson, Alicia Conlon, Gail Anderson, Karen Hackett; son David Anderson; daughter-in-law Peggy Anderson; sons-in-law Doyle Daniel and Chuck Hackett, and ten grandchildren. He served in the Navy in WWII then attended Pace College, graduating Cum Laude in 1951. Richard later became Treasurer of the Old Dominion and the Bollingen Foundation, where he also enjoyed a role in managing the Publication Program, helping to fund culturally significant works. He was most proud of his accomplishments as Financial Officer for Planned Parenthood and Chief Financial Officer for the Alan Guttmacher Institute, the research and development division of Planned Parenthood. He was recognized as a financial expert in the management of not-for-profit organizations, highly regarded for his personal integrity, dedication and tireless efforts. He loved the ocean, fishing, and his prized boat "September," named to celebrate the month of his wedding. He also enjoyed listening to Yankees games and opera, and attending the ballet and theatre. For more Info, visit: averystortifuneralhome.com.

JAFFIN--Janet. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Janet Jaffin who, along with her late husband, George, lived a life of generosity and compassion. She expressed a deep commitment to strengthening the Jewish community and people in need. Our condolences to her children, Doris, Lois, and David, and the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President; Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

KUTSHER--Helen. Owner of Kutsher's Country Club, Monticello, NY, Passed away March 19, 2013. She is survived by her son, Mark (Carla) daughters, Mady Prowler and Karen Wilson (Jeffrey), seven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

MIGDAL--Eleanor Jackson Burt, passed peacefully on March 28th in New York City. Born on May 5th, 1924 to James Oscar Jackson and Eleanor McCarson in Pittsburgh, PA, she was educated in local schools and graduated from the Winchester Thurston Academy and Carnegie Mellon University. Her first marriage to David Sill Burt, which ended in divorce, produced four children. She is predeceased by two of these children, Marcy Burt Butz and James Jackson Burt. Eleanor is much loved and dearly missed by her loving husband of 39 years, Lester Migdal, her daughters Kaethe Burt-O'Dea and Sarah Jackson Burt Chennault, stepchildren, Joanna, Eliza and David, her twelve grandchildren and six, soon to be seven great-grandchildren, as well as her brothers James and Charles Jackson, their children and grandchildren. Eleanor was a photographer and writer, who worked with the noted photographer Margaret Bourke-White. Throughout her life she cultivated a talent for capturing the magnificent in the mundane. Her photographs have been exhibited at the Greenwich New York Library and other venues, but it was through the way she lived in the present and her devotion to relationships, family and friends, that she fully expressed her generosity of spirit, strength of character and extraordinary capacity for resilience. A memorial will be held for Eleanor on April 6th at 2pm at the Harvard Club, 35 West 44th Street, New York City. Donations in lieu of flowers, may be made to: The East Harlem School, 309 E. 104th St., New York City, NY 10029.

The people at Vice nudge their version of a media empire a bit closer to the mainstream when “VICE,” a newsmagazine with what its creators hope is attitude, has its premiere on Friday night on HBO. The program certainly has a lofty view of itself. “The world is changing,” the introductory voice-over says. “No one knows where it’s going, but we’ll be there, uncovering the news, culture and politics that expose the absurdity of the modern condition.” 
 
The absurdity of the modern condition, of course, is not that hard to recognize, and the reports that constitute the first installment aren’t exactly exploring new territory. One involves political violence in the Philippines , which has been covered by mainstream outlets for years. Another focuses on the Taliban’s use of children as suicide bombers, something that groups like Human Rights Watch have been calling attention to for some time.

Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, proposed a Cruise Ship Passenger Bill of Rights this month in response to “a string of horrifying and dangerous incidents aboard international cruise ships.” (Below, the Carnival Triumph is pulled into port at the Alabama Cruise Terminal in Mobile last month, after a fire disabled the ship, stranding 4,200 people onboard.) The guidelines, for passengers on cruise ships, even ones registered in foreign countries, are modeled on those in the airline passenger bill of rights that is currently law. They include access to backup generators, staff members traed in emergency and evacuation procedures, and full refunds for cruises abruptly canceled because of mechanical failures, plus three other guidelines.

The Phoenix Coyotes’ ownership situation, which has been unsettled for nearly four years, could finally be resolved soon. According to published reports and to officials familiar with the situation, the N.H.L. either will sell the Coyotes to the last in a long line of prospective buyers who pledged to keep them in Glendale, Ariz., or will decide as soon as next month to allow the team to relocate. 
 
Although a move might stem the club’s big financial losses, it could cause other problems. If the team relocates to Quebec, the league’s carefully constructed realignment plan would be scuttled. When asked Friday if the league had a Plan B in case the team moved, Bill Daly, the deputy commissioner, responded by e-mail: “No contingencies have been made. We are planning on the Coyotes being in Phoenix next year.”

DINCIN--Jerry. Brooklyn born, died Highland Park, IL, March 26. Director 37 years Thresholds; advocate Final Exit. Survived by wife Susanne Streicker, sister Zola, four children, seven grandchildren.

LEE--Dr. Hyung Mo "H.M.," Dr. Hyung Mo "H.M." Lee, 86, died March 24, 2013, in Richmond, VA. Recognized internationally as a pioneer in organ transplantation, Professor and former Chair of the Division of Vascular and Transplant Surgery at the Virginia Commonwealth University Medical Center, and past president of the American Society of Transplant Surgeons. Memorial service at 11am, Saturday, April 6, St. Stephen's Church, Richmond, VA. Memorial donations may be made to MCV Foundation, PO Box 980234 Richmond, VA 23298-0324, for the Dr. H.M. Mr. Abrams has no polite words for the cover for the second album by this British band. “This is one of the worst cover choices to ever be conceived and approved and realized on a commercially available album,” he said.

Helen Kutsher, the matriarch of the last of the grand Catskill resorts, who greeted guests with a “Welcome home,” made sure the regulars got rooms facing the lake, entertained them with comedians and filled them with blintzes and stuffed cabbage, died on Tuesday in Philadelphia. She was 89 and lived most of her life in Monticello, N.Y., in a house on the grounds of the hotel. 
 
Her daughter Karen Wilson confirmed the death.

HEFFNER--Nancy Baum, aged 68, passed away on March 26, 2013. Nancy was a beloved wife, mother, grandmother, daughter and sister. Her greatest love was her family. Her beloved husband of 42 years, Harvey; her children, Andrea and Simon; her son-in-law and daughter-in-law, Ari and Nicole; her grandchildren, Aaron Benjamin, David, Charlotte and Oliver; her father, Seymour, her brother and sisters, James, Gail and Vivian love her and will miss her immensely. She filled the hearts of all of those who knew her with love and warmth and will be missed by all. A teacher for over thirty years of three year old students at Temple Emanu-El Nursery School. She was widely acclaimed as a nurturing educator who developed children beautifully and left a lasting imprint on hundreds of students, whose families often remained her friends for decades. Outside of school, she was actively involved in supporting Mt. Sinai Hospital. Services were held March 28.

OSMAN--Albert, of Forest Hills, NY on March 29, 2013 at the age of 87 years. World War II Veteran having served in the U.S. Navy. Beloved husband of Claire. Devoted father of Ronni Osman, Jane Kirschner and Steve Osman. Loving grandfather of eight grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Two sisters also survive. Funeral service Sunday 1pm at the Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. Interment at Mount Carmel Cemetery (Knollwood Park Section), Ridgewood, NY.

‘Metal Massacre VI’ (1985) 

 
Metal Massacre was a well-regarded series of compilations, released by Metal Blade Records, that featured unknown and unsigned bands. Starting with the first release in 1982, the records are credited with introducing Slayer, Metallica and other successful bands. It’s unclear whether the artwork for this album, which featured Dark Angel’s “Welcome to the Slaughterhouse” and Possessed’s “Swing of the Axe,” was “meant to be intentionally cheesy,” Mr. Abrams said.

New York City this month introduced a Web guide called Neighborhood x Neighborhood , which highlights areas outside of Manhattan on the city’s tourism site. The first featured guide was for Brooklyn, focusing on haunts in Bushwick, Fort Greene and Williamsburg (above) that are not on the well-worn tourist path. Fans of Fette Sau, prepare for an even longer wait.

An article accompanying the cover article last Sunday about the effects Hurricane Sandy had on Fire Island and other coastal areas omitted part of the name of a real estate agency on the island. It is Island Properties of the Pines, not Properties of the Pines.

Last month, researchers at University College London made public a database that describes in illuminating detail one of the largest government bailouts in modern history. In 1833, Britain paid 20 million pounds to compensate 3,000 Caribbean slaveholders for the emancipation of their slaves. The payments constituted about 40 percent of total governmental expenditures that year. Conversation about the database in Britain centered on the recipients of these reparations for slaveholders, among them the ancestors of George Orwell, Graham Greene and David Cameron.
 
Apart from a few hundred slaveholders in the District of Columbia, no one in the United States received such compensation for the loss of their human property. According to Abraham Lincoln, at least, the cost of emancipation in the United States was to be reckoned in blood. In his Second Inaugural Address, Lincoln said he feared God would will the war to continue “until every drop of blood drawn with the lash shall be paid by another drawn with the sword.”

JODY--Ruth, died March 25, 2013. Beloved mother of Nina and Michael, mother-in-law of Robert Soloway, and loving grandmother of Sophia and Luke. Born in Germany in 1923, she escaped in 1939 to England and then to the United States. Ruth was an adored and loving friend to an unimaginable number of people across the globe. She was interested in everything and everyone. Beautiful, graceful, adventurous and joyful, she will be remembered for her infinite willingness to help others, to see the potential in everyone and for the way she brought people from all walks of life together. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, April 21 at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St., New York, NY at 4pm.

WATSON--Maureen Larkin, passed away at her home in Brooklyn, NY on March 28, at the age of 80. She is survived by her husband of 53 years Gerard; her daughters: Mary, Margaret, Tracey and Maureen; and her grandchildren: John, Huntly, and Mac. Friends may call at McLaughlin and Sons Funeral Home, 9620 Third Ave. Brooklyn, NY on Monday, April 1 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. A funeral mass will be held at St. Patrick's Church, 9511 Fourth Ave., Brooklyn, NY on Tuesday, April 2 at 11am. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be sent to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 633 3rd Ave., New York, NY 10017 or St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 1603 Brooklyn Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11210 - Attn. Fr. Joseph Nugent.

‘Evil in the Night’ (2007 rerelease) 
 
The cover for a rerelease of this California band’s album was designed by Ed Repka , an artist known for grisly horror-themed illustrations for Megadeth. Mr. Abrams said Mr. Repka is well regarded among metal fans but this cover for “Evil in the Night” comes across as more comical than muscular.

‘Neverending Destiny’ (1990)

 
For a French thrash metal band that formed in the ’80s, “this album is not terrible,” Mr. Abrams said. What is terrible “is how they spelled their name,” he added. Mr. Jenkins said the cover made the list in part because it is a “horrific rip-off” of the artwork of a more popular metal band, Voivod, known for its “very otherworldly outer space meets biomechanic style.”

The lineup of Birds of Maya, the deep, dark Philadelphia psychedelic power trio, has spawned a couple of weird new entities: Spacin’ , led by Jason Killinger, and Purling Hiss , led by Mike Polizze. They’ll appear together this week on a bill at 285 Kent. (Rounding out the bill is Axis:Sova, from Chicago.) 
 
Both started as one-man, low-fidelity projects, from which we might infer that their touring-band iterations are re-enactments of some deep subconscious matter.

The Big Profile By Dave Itzkoff
 
Juno Temple enjoyed a unique childhood as the daughter of the movie and music-video director Julien Temple, whether she was dancing on stage with Joe Strummer or benefiting from her dad’s horticultural skills. “I was obsessed with ‘Alice in Wonderland,’ ” says the actress, a star of films like “Killer Joe” and “The Brass Teapot,” “and he made this giant garden hedge for me, which is short at one end and grows taller, so when I used to run up and down it, I’d feel like I was growing and shrinking.”

VERRILL--F. Glenn, 89, who led the Southeast's largest advertising agency, BDA/BBDO, throughout the 1970's and 1980's, and served on the BBDO International Board of Directors when it launched The Omnicom Group, now the world's second-largest advertising and marketing holding company, died March 25 in Atlanta, GA of pneumonia. Born December 17, 1923, New York City, NY; Stuyvesant High School for the Arts, 1941; U.S.A.A.F., Pacific Ocean Theater, World War II, 1943-1946; Married Jean Demar, 1946; A.B., Adelphi College, 1949; A.M., Harvard University, 1950. Copywriter, Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, 1952; V.P., Creative Director, Burke Dowling Adams, Inc., 1964; Executive Vice President, General Manager, 1970; President, BDA/BBDO, 1971-1988; Director, BBDO International; Director, The Omnicom Group. Created award-winning campaigns for clients, including Gillette, Schaefer Beer, TWA, Air France, Standard Oil, C&S Bank, Dodge Motors and Delta Air Lines, including Delta's long-running "Delta Is Ready When You Are." Authored three editions of Kleppner's Advertising Procedure. Jean, Glenn's wife, passed in 2004. Survived by son Gary, daughter Joan and husband Kari Seppala; two grandchildren, Kristofer and Sergei, and brother Ralph. Services by H.M. Patterson & Son, 404-876-1022. For online condolences, please visit: hmpattersonspringhill.com. Visiting hours: 5-7pm, Monday, April 1, H.M. Patterson & Son, Spring Hill, GA. Memorial Service, 2pm, Tuesday, April 2, St. Anne's Episcopal Church. Donations, in lieu of flowers, St. Anne's Episcopal Church, 3098 St. Anne's Ln. NW, Atlanta, GA 30327.

Charter flight passengers are more likely to slow down airport screening than scheduled passengers, suggests a study of a European regional airport by Kirschenbaum Consulting, an Israel-based security firm. Among the findings: a lower percentage of scheduled passengers among those interviewed carried prohibited items compared with charter passengers, and a lower percentage of scheduled passengers than charter passengers needed to be re-examined by security employees.

When Rockefeller Center opened in 1939 after a decade of construction, it was not received with the glory we shower on it now. Newspapers were filled with letters calling it one of the ugliest complexes in the city. The building of what today is considered one of the crown jewels of the Manhattan skyline is a saga of big money, intriguing power brokers and one of the most glamorous periods in the city’s history. 
 
The story is told artfully and addictively in Daniel Okrent’s “Great Fortune: The Epic of Rockefeller Center,” a Pulitzer Prize finalist for history in 2004. Join us for an online discussion with Mr. Okrent and the novelist and culture critic Kurt Andersen, author of the best-selling novel “Heyday” and most recently “True Believers.”

An article last Sunday about the reincarnation of the South Korean capital Seoul misspelled the name of the corporation that owns Korean Air, among other entities. It is Hanjin, not Hanji. The article also described the history of organized civilization in Korea incorrectly. It dates back about 1,350 years, not about 2,000 years. And because of editing errors, the article referred incorrectly to two buildings in Seoul. The construction of City Hall took four years and five months, not merely five months; and the Leeum, Samsung Museum of Art opened in 2004, not “two years ago.”

CONCANNON--Richard J.,Richard J. Concannon, a leading expert in the field of health care law, died on March 28 in Rye, NY, from Alzheimer's disease. He was 80 years old. Mr. Concannon spent his entire legal career of more than 50 years at the law firm of Kelley Drye & Warren where he was a senior partner. He was instrumental in building the firm's health care practice, which, over the years, served a number of the nation's leading hospitals and medical institutions. Due to his expertise in the field, he was appointed to The New York State Task Force on Life and the Law by Governor Mario Cuomo and was involved in formulating many of the state's laws and regulations on such issues as health-care proxies, do-not-resuscitate orders and palliative care. He addressed a number of international conferences on those issues, including the 1985 World Congress of Catholic Hospitals and Health Care Institutions held in Vatican City. Mr. Concannon served on the Boards of Marymount Manhattan College (where he became Chairman), St. Michael's College, The Wartburg Adult Care Community and the Center for Christian and Jewish Understanding. In addition, he was a member of the Legal Advisory Committee of the Catholic Archdiocese of New York, served on the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity and on the Finance Committee of Catholic Big Sisters. He was a member of the Knights of Malta and the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulcher. Mr. Concannon was born in Massapequa Park, NY, received a B.A. degree from St. John's University and a J.D. degree from St. John's University Law School, where he was on the Law Review. He served in the U.S. Navy during the Korean War. A long-time resident of Larchmont, NY, Mr. Concannon is survived by his wife of 49 years, Maura Mara Concannon; daughters Christine Geithner (David) of Larchmont, Kate Anderson (David) also of Larchmont and Sheila Melvin (Taylor) of Scottsdale, AZ; and grandchildren Peter, Clare, Caroline, Jack, Timmy, Molly, Christopher and Elizabeth. Friends may visit the Fox Funeral Home at 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY, on Tuesday, April 2, from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at Saints John & Paul Church, 280 Weaver Street in Larchmont on Wednesday, April 3, at 10am. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to either the Catholic Charities of New York, 1011 First Avenue, New York, NY 10022 or to the Alzheimer's Association New York Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave, New York, NY 10017.
THURER--Diane. Cherished and dear friend of 45 years. You will be in our hearts forever. Deepest sympathy to Jerry and the family. Shirley & Seymour

WHITAKER--Caleb Clarke, III, of Palm Beach, FL and Cincinnati, OH died March 10 at age 87. Born in Camden, SC, he graduated from Woodberry Forest School and Princeton University. During WWII, he flew B-17 combat missions in Europe. He worked for Gulf Oil, Waller Petroleum and Standard Brands, becoming VP in charge of Planters Peanuts in 1963. He spent 17 years as manager of business and international development for the S.C. State Development Board. In 1984, he moved to Palm Beach and sold real estate until retirement. Mr. Whitaker married Dorothy "Bunny" Wood Price in 1987. Besides his wife, Mr. Whitaker is survived by daughter Amanda; son Caleb; brother Francis; stepdaughter Elizabeth; and three grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made to the Foundation for PSP (Progressive Supranuclear Palsy), 30 E Padonia Rd, Ste 201, Timonium, MD, 21093 or another charity.

Remember the old days, when the contemporary classical music scene in New York was divided into opposed camps, uptown and downtown? Happily, that is fast becoming a dim memory thanks to a détente forged by intrepid new-music groups like Alarm Will Sound , which will perform a characteristically boundless mix of new and recent pieces at Zankel Hall on Saturday night.
 
It’s not just that the conductor Alan Pierson and his band of virtuosos disregard the schism between uptown complexity and downtown eclecticism, but that they’ve always seen through the purported dichotomy. The program includes “Big Spinoff” by the formidable modernist Charles Wuorinen, who has always had his funky side, and “increase” by David Lang , a downtowner and a founder of Bang on a Can who hardly avoids rigor in this insistently percolating work.

A Look at Where Things Stand in Westeros

 
HOUSE STARK

A report last Sunday about the marriage of Alexa von Tobel and Michael Ryan Jr. referred incorrectly to the Renco Group, the employer of the groom’s father. It is a private investment holding company founded in 1975 by Ira Rennert; it is not owned by the groom’s family.

Manager Terry Collins was in a jovial mood before the Mets played their spring training finale against the Baltimore Orioles. His roster was nearly set and despite a spate of injuries, two of his stars, David Wright and Daniel Murphy, appeared to be on the mend.
 
The lineup Collins chose on Saturday in Sarasota, Fla., is very likely to start Monday, when the Mets open the season against the San Diego Padres at Citi Field. It included Wright and Murphy joining Ike Davis and Ruben Tejada in the infield, Lucas Duda, Collin Cowgill and Marlon Byrd in the outfield, and John Buck catching.

“The U.S. addressed the problems of the financial crisis faster and with much more ferocity than the rest of the world.”

 
Edward M. Clissold, a market strategist at Ned Davis Research, after the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index rose above its 2007 peak to a record high. Stock markets in nearly every other large economy are still well below their previous records.

GETOFF--Louis, died March 16, 2013 at age 89 in his home in Sedona, Arizona after a long life full of self-examination, intellectual pursuits and social action. He graduated from P.S. 4 and Morris High School in Bronx, NY and City College of NY class of 1944. Raised by Russian immigrant parents, he obtained a PhD in Clinical Psychology from Columbia and practiced psychotherapy and psychoanalysis for over 60 years in Manhattan, Southold, Westbury, and Sedona, as well as taught and supervised other psychotherapists and psychoanalysts for over 40 years. He was proud that his life's work was to "help people live with less suffering." He was instrumental in the founding of the Sedona Jewish Community, the first synagogue in Sedona. He served on the boards of several Sedona community organizations and played tennis until two months before his death, recently beating players 20 years his junior. He was a powerful and courageous man who lived, and died, on his own terms and will be missed by life partner Ethel Schelz, children David, Michael, Maria, and Sarah, step-daughters Ellyn and Mary-Jane, and grandchildren Dara, Molly, Sofia, Evan, Alex, and Michael. He was preceded in death by brother Hyman and sister Hannah. An on-line guest book is available at: westcottfuneralhome.com

MANDELSTAM--Gloria Messinger, 83, of Manhattan and North Salem, NY, died on March 26, 2013, after a brave battle against a fierce enemy, cancer. Her life ended as it had always been lived: Gloria was strong, uncomplaining, and ceaselessly focused on others. To the end she inspired family, friends, and doctors alike with her grace. Gloria was born on November 28, 1929 in New York City. She was raised in the Bronx. An impassioned Yankees fan who learned from her father to keep a box-score as a child, she attended public school and graduated from William Howard Taft High School. She went on to Smith College (where no Taft graduate had ever before matriculated). At Smith her academic record earned her a place at Yale Law School -- in an era when legal education was still a male preserve -- and in the autumn of 1951 Gloria began her legal studies. She fell in love with the law -- and with her future husband, Charles Lawrence Mandelstam. As befits two intellectuals, they met at Yale's Sterling Law Library. Gloria took her legal diploma into the working world in the summer of 1954. She received many job offers from law firms... to work as a secretary. One organization -- and one alone -- asked her to join its ranks as a lawyer: The American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers (ASCAP). The country's leading music copyright society, ASCAP became the only place Gloria ever worked. For 39 years she devoted herself to the organization she loved, serving as a staff attorney, assistant general counsel, and, eventually, managing director for 12 years -- the first and only woman in ASCAP's history to hold its top position. Intellectual property and copyright law presented Gloria with endless, welcome challenges. In the United States and in negotiations world-wide, Gloria brought passion and expertise to the mission of defending the rights of the creators of music, from Sting to Stravinsky to George Gershwin to Stevie Wonder. After retiring from ASCAP in 1993, Gloria kept one hand in the law by becoming an arbitrator who specialized in copyright cases. She also gave her time to non-profit organizations, serving on the boards of directors of the Yale Law School Fund; the Theatre for a New Audience; and the Brooklyn Philharmonic. In addition, she was a member of the board of directors of the Dreyfus Mutual Funds. More than for her estimable professional accomplishments, Gloria was revered for her human qualities: kindness, generosity, and a readiness to help family, friends, and colleagues. She was unselfish and modest. She had a lively sense of humor and could talk with pop-music celebrities and city bus drivers with equal ease. She had an unerring sense of style and elegance. Among Gloria's greatest joys were travel, theatre, food, and wine. She came to know Paris almost as a second home, and enjoyed few things as much as wandering its lesser-traveled byways and discovering a spectacular cheese shop in the company of her beloved husband. In 1970, together with several American friends, Gloria and Charles bought an interest in a Cote Rotie wine vineyard in France's Rhone Valley that went on to win numerous awards. Closer to home, Gloria's love of the land found full expression in her deep attachment to her weekend home in North Salem, NY. To preserve North Salem's natural beauty, Gloria and Charles were founding members of the North Salem Open Land Foundation (which Charles served pro bono as general counsel for three decades). Gloria was deeply loved by Charles, her husband of 50 years and soulmate (who died in 2007); her daughter Emily Mandelstam; her son Peter Mandelstam; her son-in-law Paul Engelmayer; her daughter-in-law Dawn Drzal; her grandchildren Caroline Engelmayer, William Engelmayer, and Andrew Mandelstam; and the many friends who adored her. At the end of her life Gloria was blessed to be surrounded by her family and the many loving friends whose visits brought laughter and respite. She was especially grateful for the extended gatherings with her beloved law-school roommate, Zipporah Wiseman, who traveled from Texas, and Zipporah's husband Fred Wiseman, who came from France, to be by her side. Like Charles, Gloria will be missed by scores of dear and admiring friends. Gloria's family wishes to acknowledge the extraordinary care that she received from the staff at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Doctors, nurses, members of the janitorial staff -- everyone there was kind and compassionate. The medical treatment Gloria received was outstanding. Gloria's family would also like to thank the four angels who saw Gloria through hospice care at home. Burial will be private. Gloria's life will be celebrated at a gathering on Friday, May 10, 2013 at 6:30pm at the Yale Club (50 Vanderbilt Avenue in New York City). No RSVP is necessary as we honor a remarkable woman. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Theatre for a New Audience or the North Salem Open Land Foundation.

ROSOW--Malcolm B.,died on March 28 at the age of 91. He is survived by his loving wife Carol, his sister and his three children, seven grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Contributions may be made in his honor to the Southern Christian Leadership Conference.

When I heard that a musical about Imelda Marcos was in the making, the first thing I wondered was, how many shoes will be onstage? Or maybe the whole show take place inside a shoe. So I was surprised to read in Vogue that David Byrne, the former Talking Heads singer who wrote the lyrics and composed the songs with Fatboy Slim, makes no mention of footwear in the musical.  
 
Directed by Alex Timbers (“Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson” ), “Here Lies Love” seems to be aiming not so much for knowingly mocking the former Philippine first lady as for recounting her rise and fall in an immersive staging. Like ‘The Donkey Show,” the production does not have a traditional stage and will take place amid the audience members at the Public Theater. Audience members are free to dance to the songs if they would like. The musical takes its title from what Ms. Marcos, who liked going to nightclubs, once asked to be inscribed on her tombstone.

With “The Weimar Touch,” the Museum of Modern Art continues a collaboration with the Deutsche Kinemathek of Berlin that began with “Weimar Cinema, 1919-1933: Daydreams and Nightmares.” 
 
The first week of this eclectic series, which considers the diasporic influence of Weimar cinema, includes “Viktor und Viktoria” (1933) and Edgar G. Ulmer’s richly strange “Black Cat,” a hit for Universal in 1934. “The Black Cat” stars Bela Lugosi as a slightly demented Hungarian psychiatrist just out of a prison camp and Boris Karloff as his enemy, a more than slightly demented Austrian architect. (Bedtime reading: “The Rites of Lucifer.”) Karloff has built his dream house in the Carpathians, and what a house! Above ground it’s all sleek if somewhat sinister Art Deco, but below lies a darker vision of the modern: a bunker littered with embalmed corpses where satanic rites are performed and presented in echt Expressionist style (claustrophobic angles, a jutting set, distended shadows). With its talk of prison camps and hidden mass graves and that house — a veneer of civilization over a roiling id of a basement — the movie seems full of ominous European portent. (April 3 to May 6, moma.org )

The parent company of the design-driven furniture maker IKEA and the untrendy Marriott International announced this month that they are teaming up to create Moxy, a chain of budget hotels across Europe, news that strikes many travelers as an odd coupling. (And inspires questions, like, will you have to put together your nightside table with an Allen wrench?)
 
But there are even stranger bedfellows for hotels, which use the term “partner” as liberally as people use “friend” on social networking sites.

An article last Sunday about an ad campaign by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in support of federal regulations to curb gun violence misidentified the type of firearm that an actor playing a hunter holds in a commercial. It is a shotgun, not a rifle.

The Mets said Johan Santana would have surgery Tuesday on his left shoulder. Given the gravity of the injury — a tear of the capsule in the left-hander’s shoulder — there is no chance he will pitch this season. 
 
The Mets are expected to buy out the remaining year on Santana’s contract next season, so if he pitches again, it would probably be for another team.

KREBS--Henry, on March 16, Fair Lawn, NJ. Holocaust survivor, Born in Jaslo, Poland. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle. His memory will be cherished by his loving family.

LIVINGSTON--Helen Whiting, 89, February 28, 2013, in Peterborough NH. Formerly of Summit NJ, she leaves three daughters, five grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren. Burial at Newton MA Cemetery April 13th 2PM.
SHIKORA--Martin. Husband of the late Ruth. Father of Andra and Mindy. Devoted grandfather of David, Jaffe, Justin, Jarett, Zak, Matthew and seven great-grandchildren.

SISLER--Donald Grant. Died peacefully from natural causes on March 4, 2013. He had just celebrated his 97th birthday with his family. He was born, reared and educated in Washington, DC. During WW II he was stationed at the United States embassies in Santiago, Chile, and in Montevideo, Uruguay, where he became fluent in Spanish. In 1946 he joined Coca-Cola Export Corporation and was assigned to Germany as a Technical Observer. The following year he was transferred to Buenos Aires, Argentina, subsequently serving in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, where he learned Portuguese, and then Lima, Peru, as manager of the Andean Region. In 1962 Don was elected a Vice President of The Coca-Cola Export Corporation. In 1967 he was appointed manager of the Western European Area and lived in Brussels, Belgium, then in Paris, France. He retired in 1976 to finally live in his favorite city, New York. Paris was his second favorite city where he owned an apartment on Avenue George V with a fabulous view of the Tour Eiffel. Soon after World War II, in July 1946, his only brother, Vincent Ambrose Sisler, who served as a submarine commander in the Pacific, was killed in an automobile accident, leaving three small daughters. Don was a loving, caring uncle to his nieces and their families throughout his life. He took great pleasure in showing his family, friends and visitors from abroad the wonders of New York City. He was a great supporter of the performing arts, especially the Metropolitan Opera, where he was an Advisory Director, and underwrote ten of its PBS telecasts. Putting on his tux and striding across Central Park from his home on 5th Ave to the Met was a great joy for him. He was a wonderful raconteur, with a terrific sense of humor and an infectious laugh. His joie de vivre set an example for his family and friends. Charming, kind and caring to everyone, he was a gentleman of the old school an extraordinary man who lived an extraordinary life. He is survived by his nieces, Anne Sisler Latta and Tonia Sisler, nephew Dr. Adrian Sherman, great-nephews Jeffrey Latta and Michael Jacobs, great-niece Katherine Jacobs, and great-great nephew, Holden Latta.

The New Man The men’s fashion revolution is in full swing, with looks ranging from ’30s styles to a revival of grunge and mouth grilles. The jacket has morphed into what used to be deemed women’s wear. Hats are being worn at rakish angles. Even classic styles are tweaked: prints of tailors’ scissors; basting stitches; a necktie halved, then joined with safety pins. This Easter Sunday, the men may very well eclipse the women.

FARRAH--Albert L. Sr.,95, of Kittery Point, ME, March 26, 2013, joined beloved wife of 65 years, Jeanne who died March 8, 2013. Funeral mass April 2, 2013 at 10am at St. Anthony Church, Lawrence, MA.

SAMUELS--Cheryl Troy. Cheryl Troy Samuels left this world for another on March 23, 2013 in Rockville, Maryland after battling Ovarian cancer for over five years with courage, strength and grace. Cheryl was born on October 1, 1945 in Brooklyn, NY where her father was stationed at the Brooklyn Navy Yard as a U.S. Navy ferry pilot during World War II. Though she was raised in Toledo, OH, Cheryl remained fiercely proud of her Brooklyn roots. After high school, Cheryl earned her certificate of dental hygiene and a Bachelor of Science degree in education from The Ohio State University; a Master of Science degree in dental hygiene education from the University of Michigan; and her Doctor of Philosophy degree in policy sciences from the University of Maryland Baltimore County. Her career was spent in higher education. For 17 years Cheryl served as Chair of the Department of Dental Hygiene at the University of Maryland Dental School in Baltimore. Later, Cheryl served as Dean of the College of Allied Health and Nursing at Minnesota State University in Mankato, MN; Dean of the College of Health Sciences at Old Dominion University in Norfolk, VA as well as Provost and Vice President for Academic Affairs at both Texas Women's University and Indiana University of Pennsylvania. An intrepid world traveler, avid reader, tenacious debater, academic visionary and mentor to young women, Cheryl had zest for life as anyone who knew her infectious laugh will tell you. Educated, accomplished, sophisticated and beautiful -- beauty and brains -- that was Cheryl! Cheryl is survived by her devoted husband Jeff, loving daughter Courtney, son Blair, parents Richard and Wanda Troy of Toledo, OH, sister Gay Escobar also of Toledo, OH and sister Connie Troy of Safety Harbor, FL. Cheryl's joyful, indomitable spirit will live on in all who knew and loved her.

STEMPEL--Marvin H.,86, passed away on March 27. He was President of McKettrick Williams, Inc., and a long time resident of Great Neck, NY. Predeceased by his beloved wife Ellen after 57 years of marriage. Devoted father of Lee, Andrew, and Barry and dedicated grandfather of Cameron, Jonathan and Jake. Also survived by brothers Jay and Robert. Caring and committed family patriarch, generous gastronome and enthusiastic storyteller. Funeral services at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck on Sunday at 11:00am.
GREEN--Jeannine Ann Shivers. A memorial celebration of Jeannine's life will be held at the Roxbury Town Hall, 29 North Street, Roxbury, CT, on Sunday, April 14 from 2-4pm.

On the habit of referring to people who are neither lead singers in rock bands nor galvanizing entertainers as “superstars” and “rock stars”: It has gone too far. A cursory search of the Internet reveals that people and things referred to in the media as “rock stars” include Rand Paul, the archbishop of Canterbury, the Samsung Galaxy S 4 smartphone, the Swedish mystery writer Camilla Lackberg and Pope John Paul II. Clearly, it’s high time we bought the term a watch and retired it. 
 
The problem is not just overuse. It’s the callous exceptionalism it not only condones but also celebrates. In a recent Times article about exploited interns, for instance, the author of a book on intern exploitation referred to the “rock-star professions” — those that expect free labor in exchange for a brief bask in the aura. Similarly, when Marissa Mayer is referred to as a “superstar” in a New York magazine profile, the label is intended to free her, in part, from the burden of empathizing with fellow humans.

There was a time when Kallio, a working-class district north of central Helsinki and somewhat akin to the old, grittier iteration of the Bowery in Manhattan, was considered off-limits to visitors. But today, those who venture across the Siltasaarensalmi strait, which divides Kallio from the rest of the Finnish capital will find a sizzling sector percolating with exotic cafes, sleek restaurants and clubs serving fine cuisine, and inviting walk-in studio-boutiques — all nestled in the shadow of Lars Sonck’s landmark 100-year-old church. Of course, there is still a chance of stumbling into one of the grotto-like dives for which the area is renowned, but that is part and parcel of the Kallio
 
experience. Gordon F. Sander

‘Fistful of Metal’ (1984) 
 
Mr. Abrams said hapless illustration and anatomical misjudgment mar the debut album by the New York band Anthrax, which joined Metallica, Slayer and Megadeth as the big four of thrash metal. “The tongue is in the wrong place,” he said of the cover drawing, which helped put “Fistful of Metal” in the list’s No. 1 spot. “The way the guts are coming out is weird.” Mr. Jenkins said it “looks like Davy Crockett is eating a mean Michael Jackson’s hand.”

An article on March 17 about the turbulent life of Lisa de Kooning misstated the given name of her daughter at several points. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, she is Lucy de Kooning Villeneuve, not Lily.

BAER--Elisabeth, Scheitlin. On February 16th, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Ernesto Baer. Devoted mother of Alex Scheitlin. Memorial Mass on Friday, April 5th, 6:15pm at St Vincent's Ferrer R.C. Church, 66 St and Lexington Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations in her name can be made to Guiding Eyes for the Blind.

LIGHTSTONE--Ronald, 74, beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, son and friend passed away on March 28, 2013. He is survived by his wife Nancy (Lehrer), daughter Dana, son-in-law Jeff Bernstein, three grandchildren & mother-in-law Isabel Fortunoff as well as numerous other friends and relatives. He will always be remembered for his lust for life and great success with everything he touched. There will be a private family funeral.

WINSON--Abbie. Died peacefully with her daughters at her side on March 26th, 2013. She was 87. Abbie Winson was born on January 1, 1926 to Bertha and Norton Franks in Pittsburgh, moving to Philadelphia, then to the Washington Heights neighborhood of New York City. Abbie's vast and varied early education included Music and Art High, the Arts Students League, Queens College, and the Sorbonne in Paris where she studied medicine, shifting her interests to anatomy and medical illustration. She spoke fluent and nuanced French. She studied painting with Vaclav Vytlacil and Hans Hoffmann in New York and was greatly influenced by the modernists and abstract expressionists, but developed her own dynamic and calligraphic style. Abbie was always a progenitor in her intellectual, artistic, and personal pursuits. She did mixed-media paintings before the term was coined. She learned typesetting from Sy Winson, another pioneer in a new field with whom she had three children and eventually married. She then got a pair of master's degrees, one in Fine Arts, the other in an emerging category, Special Education. She taught Art, Science, Math, and learning disabled children. She worked at grade schools, high schools and in Universities. She became involved with computer graphics in its infancy, on early model mainframe computers, working with systems so complex that Abbie became the traveling worldwide user guide. Primarily, Abbie loved to paint and returned often to large acrylic canvases and watercolors with collage. She has exhibited in group and solo shows in New York City with much acclaim. In her 70's she took up Chinese calligraphy and the Mandarin language. In her 80's she frequently travelled to the south of France to paint, collaborated with small press magazines on cover art for poetry books and projected her paintings over dancers and acrobats as part of the Nouveau Cirque movement. Abbie managed to live life as a persistent scholar, an innovative painter, a woman of enormous wit and charm, a femme fatale, and truly one of the great original thinkers of her time. She is survived by her daughters Suzi Winson of New York, Julie Winson of New Mexico and her granddaughter Isabel Winson-Sagan. Her son Robert, husband Sy, and her siblings Julian Franks and Doris Goldman predeceased her. Abbie will have a year-long posthumous retrospective of 70 years of work at a new gallery which is being developed to honor her, Art and Circuses, in Long Island City, NY. Donations in Abbie's memory can be made through artandcircuses.com.

WINSTON--Ruth Lipkin, 93, March 22, 2013, Beloved wife of Herbert, cherished mother of Robert, Bradley, Paul, Debbie. Grandmother of Samantha, Alexandra, Nick, William, Andrew, Laurie, Michael, David. Ruth was unique, indomitable, full of life, love, humor, compassion, the soul of her family, a treasured loyal friend of a lifetime. Though she will live forever in our hearts, losing this larger than life spirit is a sadness that lies too deep for tears.

The Mark Morris Dance Group is celebrating eccentricity in three works new to New York, the oddest of them being “A Wooden Tree,” an ensemble piece for seven dancers, including Mikhail Baryshnikov , who has appeared with the company several times in the past. The piece is set to poetry and music by Ivor Cutler (1923-2006), a Scottish poet, humorist, songwriter and actor (he appeared with the Beatles in their film “Magical Mystery Tour” in 1967). Known for unconventional behavior as well as offbeat verse, Cutler would ride everywhere on his bicycle in his plus fours, handing passers-by stickers with goofy phrases on them. He advised recipients, for example, to “Kindly disregard” and “To remove this label take it off.” He loved playing games with his name, telling people that he collected ivory cutlery. 
 
Mr. Morris’s other premieres, both with live music, are “Crosswalk,” to Carl Maria von Weber, and “Jenn and Spencer,” to Henry Cowell. (Through April 14, 7:30 p.m. Wednesday through Saturday; 2 p.m. and 7 p.m., Sunday; Mark Morris Dance Center, 3 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (866) 811-4111, markmorrisdancegroup.org ; $75.)
Queen Elizabeth II marking the 150th anniversary of the London Tube. Those who ride regularly can view historic posters at the Transport Museum.

An article last Sunday about emerging wine regions in Chile misstated the length of the Central Valley; it is 250 miles long, not 2,000 miles. The article also gave an incorrect address for the Puro Chile wine shop, in New York City; it is at 161 Grand Street, not at 221 Centre Street. And an accompanying map located Viña Vik, a Chilean winery, incorrectly; it is northeast of Lapostolle Residence, not south. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/travel .

What does photography even mean anymore as the 21st century deepens and we find ourselves overwhelmed by a flood of images, both still and video? Maybe the Museum of Modern Art show “XL: 19 New Acquisitions in Photography,” which opens on May 10, can give us a clue or two. It’s meant to assess photography’s role in contemporary art — and maybe in our lives. The 19 artists include Yto Barrada, Robert Frank, Birgit Jürgenssen, Stephen Shore, Taryn Simon and Lynn Hershman Leeson, whose chromogenic color print “Roberta’s Construction Chart #2” (1976) is above. ( moma.org )

Building High Anxiety

Reader responses from nytimes.com , some of them condensed, are below.

Flipping through a recent issue of The New Yorker, I noticed an ad for a handsome-looking bag in brown tooled leather. What caught my eye was the low-key design and dark hue but also the brand: the King Ranch of Texas.
 
The King Ranch is something of legend — one of the largest in the United States (825,000 acres, mainly in South Texas and Florida), and privately held since it was started in 1853 by Richard King and Gideon Lewis. It produces beef, pecans, citrus, sod — and, to my surprise, handbags. Rose Morales, general manager of the King Ranch Saddle Shop, said the ranch began making saddles for customers in 1867, when people admired Captain King’s tack. The first King Ranch handbag, La Bolsa, was made about 40 years ago, she said.

An old friend and mentor of mine, Ernan McMullin , was a philosopher of science widely respected in his discipline.  He was also a Catholic priest.  I don’t know how many times fellow philosophers at professional meetings drew me aside and asked, “Does Ernan really believe that stuff?”  (He did.) Amid all the serious and generally respectful coverage of the papal resignation and the election of a new pope, I often detect an undertone of this same puzzlement.  Can reflective and honest intellectuals actually believe that stuff?
 
Here I sketch my reasons for answering “yes.”  What I offer is neither apologetics aimed at converting others nor merely personal testimony.  Without claiming to speak for others, I try to articulate a position that I expect many fellow Catholics will find congenial and that non-Catholics (even those who reject all religion) may recognize as an intellectually respectable stance.  Easter is the traditional time for Christians to reaffirm their faith.  I want to show that we can do this without renouncing reason.

WEST POINT, N.Y. — It was two days before the start of a potentially fraught regular season for the Yankees, and still, baseball here felt beside the point.
 
The Yankees made the hourlong drive north from the city on Saturday to the idyllic grounds of the United States Military Academy to play an exhibition game against Army. In the 23rd meeting of the teams — the first one since 1976 — the Yankees won, 10-5.

LEWIS--Anthony. The Officers of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences acknowledge with sadness the passing of distinguished journalist, columnist, author and Academy Fellow Anthony Lewis. A courageous voice for individual rights and freedom of the press, he won two Pulitzer Prizes for national reporting, including his transformative work for the New York Times in making the proceedings of the U.S. Supreme Court more understandable to the public. President Bill Clinton honored him with the Presidential Citizens Medal in 2001. We extend our condolences to his wife, the Honorable Margaret H. Marshall, and to his children and grandchildren. Tens of thousands of co-op and condominium owners across New York City are facing a tax increase this year after the recent tweak of tax-abatement regulations. 
 
On Jan. 30, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed into law a bill passed by the New York State Legislature amending a property tax break for residential co-ops and condos. These buildings have relied on the abatement for over 15 years to help offset a disparity in the tax burden between their units and single-, two- and three-family homes. Before the law changed, the abatement was at least 17.5 percent and applied to nearly all owners in qualified properties. The new legislation allows owners to claim the tax break only on a primary residence. Pieds-à-terre, or units held solely in a trust or by a limited-liability company, no longer qualify.

Sadly, the Museum of Comic and Cartoon Art closed its doors in SoHo last summer, but its collection and its name live on in a dedicated gallery at the Society of Illustrators on East 63rd Street in Manhattan. And the society is making sure that the annual Mocca Arts Festival , or Mocca Fest, now in its 12th incarnation, will be held on Saturday and Sunday at the 69th Regiment Armory at Lexington Avenue and 26th Street. If a few weeks without a fair has left you feeling out of sorts, immersion in the planet’s most popular art form could be the cure, and more. 
 
Instead of art dealers with fancy booths, some 300 casually attired artists, small (and a few large) publishers of comics and graphic novels, and students will display their efforts on tables. The majority will be artists, some of whom self-publish in print or on the Internet, with some Europeans in their ranks. With luck, a good sense of the thriving, not-so-underground underground comics scene — home to some of the best drawing anywhere — will be had by all.  (11 a.m. to 6 p.m., 212-838-2560,   societyillustrators.org ; $6 to $12.)

Classes will be at the House of Glenmuick, an estate on 14,000 acres in the Scottish Highlands, from April through June.

Stress. Our bodies are engineered to cope with a certain amount comfortably, but sustained, intense stress is an entirely different matter. It can negatively impact our minds, our hearts, and our body’s largest organ, skin. “Its effects are particularly harsh, causing premature aging and advancing the symptoms of every common skin condition from sensitive skin to eczema and psoriasis,” says Dr. Cynthia Ackrill, a fellow at the American Institute of Stress. 
 
To combat and correct stressed-out skin, Kiehl’s introduced an exclusive service and product duo: the Stress Minimizing Hydrating Facial and Skin Rescuer Daily Hydrator. The facial quickly squashes the visible effects of stress – think blotchiness, redness and flare-ups – through deep cleansing, gentle exfoliation, and a unique treatment infused with oxygen, which promotes circulation and clarity. The fragrance-free and quick-absorbing moisturizer, fortified with a potent blend of classic and innovative ingredients, lets you continue the good work at home. Camomile extract and olive-derived squalene calm and hydrate. Rosa Gallica extract, sourced from the flower petals, acts as an anti-inflammatory agent while mannose, derived from a rare sugar, bolsters and strengthens compromised skin.

With just three weeks left in the regular season, there are plenty of interesting playoff races to keep an eye on. But another race worth watching is the one for rookie of the year: Damian Lillard of the Portland Trail Blazers, Bradley Beal of the Washington Wizards and Anthony Davis of the New Orleans Hornetshave separated themselves from the pack.
 
Lillard got off to an auspicious start by joining Oscar Robertson and Isiah Thomas as the only players to register 20 or more points and 10 or more assists in their first N.B.A. game. And for the most part, Lillard has lived up to the promise he displayed in his debut.

Vans, a favorite of surfers and skaters, goes for an Asian punk brightly colored look this season. The Kenzo designers Humberto Leon and Carol Lim emblazoned the canvas kicks with motifs culled from their spring 2013 collection, which was inspired by a trip to Thailand. While the collection’s colorful leopard spots and bursts of floral prints may be a challenge to pull off on a head-to-toe look, the exuberant pops of pattern on these Vans feel just right. $125; openingceremony.us (beginning Monday).

A sprawling duplex co-op on prim Park Avenue that had been owned by Hassan Nemazee , who apparently lived a tad too large before being sentenced in 2010 to 12 years in prison for $292 million in bank fraud, was sold by the federal government for $17.75 million, the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.
 
Mr. Nemazee, the chairman of Nemazee Capital, was a prominent donor to the Democratic Party and a national finance chairman of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s 2008 presidential campaign. His ample assets, including the terraced 15-room apartment, No. 14/15A at 770 Park, a 2008 Maserati and residential property in Katonah, N.Y., and TriBeCa, were seized by the government to repay his debts; the co-op was originally listed at $28 million in 2011 but attracted no takers. After several reductions, its most recent asking price was $19.5 million.

The American playwright and director George C. Wolfe, who has won Tonys for “Angels in America: Millennium Approaches” and for “Bring in ‘da Noise/Bring in ‘da Funk,” is the director of “Lucky Guy,” opening at the Broadhurst Theater on April 1. It is the last play Nora Ephron wrote before her death last year, and stars Tom Hanks as Mike McAlary, the Pulitzer Prize-winning newspaper journalist who covered the police beat in New York in the 1980s and ’90s. A resident of the city during those years, Wolfe was drawn to the pulse of Ephron’s script and the challenge of recreating such a dynamic time in New York’s history.
 
Q.

“Do you have a solve for this problem?” “Let’s all focus on the build.” “That’s the take-away from today’s seminar.” Or, to quote a song that was recently a No. 1 hit in Britain, “Would you let me see beneath your beautiful?”
 
If you find these sentences annoying, you are not alone. Each contains an example of nominalization: a word we are used to encountering as a verb or adjective that has been transmuted into a noun. Many of us dislike reading or hearing clusters of such nouns, and associate them with legalese, bureaucracy, corporate jive, advertising or the more hollow kinds of academic prose . Writing packed with nominalizations is commonly regarded as slovenly, obfuscatory, pretentious or merely ugly.

A picture on March 17 with the Check In column , about the Kerry Hotel in Beijing , was published in error. The photograph showed a room at the Gradiva Hotel in Istanbul , reviewed March 10 in the Travel section; it was not of the Kerry. And because of that error, the accompanying credit was incorrect; the picture was by the Gradiva Hotel, not by the Kerry Hotels.

When I meet a young woman, sometimes one of my students, sometimes a baby sitter, always creative, a little insecure, I often think of the day I found my wedding dress. 
 
Picture Manhattan, the last early summer of the 20th century, the seventh floor at Bergdorf Goodman. Picture the Bridal Specialist — let’s call her Rachel — clutching her clipboard. Picture several Russian seamstresses with pins in their mouths — two at the hem, one overseeing. Picture the Mother — mine — and me: young, happy, tense. I’m in the Dress.

A picture caption last Sunday with an essay by the shoe designer Christian Louboutin about his love of Indian cinema misidentified an actor shown at a publicity event. He is Arjun Rampal, not Arju (and he was not really biting her neck).

J. Singler, not Kyle. (Kyle Singler, E. J.’s older brother, played college basketball at Duke and now plays for the N.B.A.’s Detroit Pistons.)

Before an estimated 250,000 people jammed into St. Peter’s Square, Pope Francis also deplored a world “divided by greed looking for easy gain.”

Readers react to Dr. Ezekiel J. Emanuel’s suggestions for improving cancer care.
Facebook, Twitter and YouTube have been required by government officials to hide some posts, under a law that critics say paves the way for broader censorship.
Bassem Youssef, a popular television host, is accused of insulting President Mohamed Morsi and denigrating Islam.
Oregon State Hospital features a museum that pays tribute to the movie “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest” and explores mental health treatments of the past.

The baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky performed works by Rachmaninoff and Sviridov at Carnegie Hall.
E-commerce companies that make everything from bedding to eyeglasses are trying to build premium brands at discount prices by cutting out middlemen and going directly to manufacturers.
Led by Journey, the game of the year, independent studios outgunned majors for attention at the Game Developers Conference in San Francisco.
The attackers appeared to number perhaps 10 or 15, said the French military spokesman, Col. Thierry Burkhard. “A half-dozen” were confirmed killed, he said.
The Celtics’ Paul Pierce, 35, is considered one of the league’s stalwart and sage big-game veterans. His delayed rise might reflect the best-case career trajectory for the Knicks’ Carmelo Anthony.
Ursula Eagly and Abby Block wore skin-tone outfits in Ms. Eagly’s duet “Self Made Man Man Made Land,” at the Chocolate Factory.
The Moving Sidewalks reunited for their first gig in nearly 44 years on Saturday night at B. B. King Blues Club and Grill.
The winners of the Lebhar IMP Pairs were Kent Mignocchi and Joel Wooldridge of New York City.
With a proliferation of channels competing for a diminished number of total viewers, media companies have looked elsewhere for growth.
The enigmatic sounds of two nearly dead languages came to life in performances of two works by the trombonist Kevin James that mixed recorded voices, ambient sounds and electronica with a live score.
The summer camp friends in “The Interestings” by Meg Wolitzer find their later years not unfolding quite as they imagined.
The Wolverines took apart the Gators with equal parts patience and raw power, advancing to the Final Four for the first time since 1993.
After earning his fourth trip to the Final Four, Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim said he was in no hurry to retire.
Online advertising, once seen as the great hope for the future, has begun leveling off, which is accelerating the push for new Internet business models.
Andy Murray fended off a match point and defeated David Ferrer in an exhausting final that lasted 2 hours 45 minutes in Key Biscayne, Fla.
Marketers are being drawn to digital realms like social media, in which agencies in New York — home to Silicon Alley as well as Madison Avenue — are increasingly proficient.
Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan of New York said that the Roman Catholic Church could be more open to gay men and lesbians, but that it would not change its teachings.

The highlight of the week’s data releases will come on Friday, with the United States employment report for March.

More stock trades, about 40 percent on some days, are being conducted outside public exchanges.

After the assassination of his deputy, Mike McLelland, the district attorney in Kaufman County, responded with a flash of angered bravado. He and his wife were found dead on Saturday.
Consider the bowl, the most common of household objects. We asked readers to send images of their favorite bowls and tell us what makes them special.
Serving more than the four favorite species of fish is wise advice for the home cook trying to eat more seafood.

It was 1959, and a painter and actress from Greenwich Village posted an “open letter to the people of New York” around Manhattan, warning that a plan by the formidable Robert Moses, then the city parks commissioner, jeopardized Shakespeare in the Park. Moses eventually dropped the plan. At the top of the letter, which Doris Diether still keeps, appear the handwritten words “start of my civic career.”
 
Soon, Ms. Diether joined Manhattan’s Community Board 2, a platform she used to become kind of a one-woman shame squad against crooked landlords, reckless renovators and haughty developers all over the city.

The N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament has reached the Final Four, and to hear the sports report is to believe all the March Madness hoopla. Viewership of last year’s tournament, with Kansas and Kentucky in the final, above, matched or topped many sports events. 
 
The 2012 N.B.A. finals, for example, averaged 16.9 million for the five-game Heat-Thunder matchup, and an average of 12.1 million viewers watched the Giants sweep the Tigers in the 2012 World Series. The 2012 Super Bowl holds the all-time single-game record, with 111.3 million viewers.

SEATTLE — Nestled in the driver’s seat of a Mini, one of the stylish, pint-sized coupes, Bryan Trussel fiddled with an app called Glympse that allows people to share their locations with others for short periods. 
 
Rather than staring down at the screen of his iPhone , Mr. Trussel’s eyes were locked on the dashboard, where the app was displayed on a large, circular screen. Glympse is part of a wave of smartphone apps breaking free of small screens to get onto dashboard displays so they become a bigger part of people’s lives.

A picture caption on Feb. 6 with the continuation of an article about the inherent hazards of the quasi-secret campaign of targeted drone killings that the United States is waging against suspected militants in Yemen, Pakistan and Somalia misstated the date an American drone strike destroyed a building in Shabwa Province in southeast Lebanon. It was Oct. 14, 2011 — not Sunday, Feb. 3, of this year. (This correction was delayed because the error was not pointed out until early March and then editors did not follow through on the complaint.)

MIGDAL--Eleanor Jackson Burt, passed peacefully on March 28th in New York City. Born on May 5th, 1924 to James Oscar Jackson and Eleanor McCarson in Pittsburgh, PA, she was educated in local schools and graduated from the Winchester Thurston Academy and Carnegie Mellon University. Her first marriage to David Sill Burt, which ended in divorce, produced four children. She is predeceased by two of these children, Marcy Burt Butz and James Jackson Burt. Eleanor is much loved and dearly missed by her loving husband of 39 years, Lester Migdal, her daughters Kaethe Burt-O'Dea and Sarah Jackson Burt Chennault, stepchildren, Joanna, Eliza and David, her twelve grandchildren and six, soon to be seven great-grandchildren, as well as her brothers James and Charles Jackson, their children and grandchildren. Eleanor was a photographer and writer, who worked with the noted photographer Margaret Bourke-White. Throughout her life she cultivated a talent for capturing the magnificent in the mundane. Her photographs have been exhibited at the Greenwich New York Library and other venues, but it was through the way she lived in the present and her devotion to relationships, family and friends, that she fully expressed her generosity of spirit, strength of character and extraordinary capacity for resilience. A memorial will be held for Eleanor on April 6th at 2pm at the Harvard Club, 35 West 44th Street, New York City. Donations in lieu of flowers, may be made to: The East Harlem School, 309 E. 104th St., New York City, NY 10029.

PROZNITZ--Phyllis Mauer, born May 13, 1916, died March 25, 2013. Beloved and devoted wife of the late William D. Prosnitz, mother to Ellen (Robert) and Donald (Fern), grandmother to David (Wendy), Laura, Jason, and Taryn (Brian), and great-grandmother to James, Elena, and Zachary. A dyed-in-the-wool New Yorker, she will be remembered for her selfless volunteerism. Her proudest achievement was her 51 years of volunteer service at Long Island Jewish Medical Center. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park.

Dear Diary:
 
I was recently spending my Sunday morning trudging along the beat-up pavement of 34th and Sixth, idolizing pastel-print cottons hugging porcelain mannequins, daringly dressed for spring.

As the dirt and grass at Citi Field received some final manicuring before opening day, the Mets gathered at the stadium Sunday for a player-organized voluntary workout.
 
The Mets begin the regular season Monday afternoon against the San Diego Padres with expectations around the team lower than in any recent season. But as usual for such occasions, the clean slate allowed for some enthusiasm.
