GOLDING--Ruth Jane, nee Adelson, died peacefully at home on Sunday, March 31 at the age of 98. She was born in New York City on February 12, 1915 and was married for 51 years to Sidney Golding. She is survived by two sons, David (Joan), New York and James (Nancy), Chicago. She was the proud grandmother of Tracie (Brian), Dana (Richard), Andrew and Phillip. The proud great-grandmother to Maxine, Nathan, Sara, Cate, Conrad, Spencer and Tatum. Also, her beloved deceased sister Rita's children Rosemary Edelman and Kate Edelman Johnson. Memorial Services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st Street on Wednesday, April 3 at 1:30pm sharp. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Rabbi Jacob Joseph School, 350 Broadway, Room 1205, New York, NY 10013.

McNAMARA--Patrick Joseph, age 71, of Emerson on March 31, 2013. Beloved husband of Elizabeth (nee Cosgrove). Devoted father of Bridget O'Connor, Michael McNamara and his wife Niurka. Loving son of the late Michael and Bridget McNamara. Dear brother of Nora, Michael, Joseph, John, Kathleen, Bridget and Ann. Cherished grandfather of Sean and Ciara O'Connor, Elizabeth, Kaitlyn and Patrick McNamara. Patrick was born in Crovraghan, Kildysart, County Clare in Ireland and came to New York in 1958. He met Elizabeth and they married on September 2, 1967. They lived in the Bronx and moved to Rutherford, NJ in 1977. Mr. McNamara relocated his family to Emerson in 1985. He was a paper handler for the NY Times, NYC for 30 years retiring in 2005. Prior he worked in construction in New York City. He was an avid golfer, enjoyed his frequent trips back to Ireland and listening to Irish music. Family will receive friends at the Beaugard Funeral Home 869 Kinderkamack Rd., River Edge, Wednesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A mass of Christian burial will be at The Church of The Assumption on Thursday at 9:30am then to Maryrest Cemetery for interment.

MELTZ--Louis Solomon, passed away on April 2, 2013, after a courageous battle with cancer. Until just a few days ago, his doctors were hopeful that the treatments he was undergoing would be successful. His passing has been a sudden shock to all of us. A founding partner of the law firm Seham, Seham, Meltz & Petersen, he will be remembered by all who knew him for his keen mind, steadfast friendship, and unwavering civility. Louis was born in Pretoria, South Africa on Jan. 20, 1961. He earned his law degree from the University of Witwatersrand and served in the South African military for two years before coming to the United States in 1985. At Seham, Louis managed the firm's extensive work in the maritime industry, creating American Maritime Safety, a non-profit corporation providing legal support and safety training to the shipping and cruise ship industries. Louis was a renaissance man: a Latin scholar, an avid student of Torah, a marathon runner, and, above all, a dedicated family man. He is survived by his devoted wife, Joann, his three children of whom he was so proud -- Joseph, Lauren, and Danielle -- and beloved sister Sharon Janovic. A funeral will be held on the morning of April 4, 2013, at the Yorktown Funeral Home at 945 East Main Street, Shrub Oak, New York. To confirm time please call 914-773-0030.

An obituary on Feb. 20 about Petro Vlahos, who developed the blue-screen and green-screen special-effects process, referred incorrectly to the use of blue-screen technology in the movie “Ben-Hur.” It was used in the scenes depicting a sea battle and its aftermath, not in the scene depicting a chariot race. The obituary also referred incorrectly to the visual-effects supervisor Bill Taylor, who commented on Mr. Vlahos’s contributions. While he has won a scientific and technical award and a medal of commendation from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, he has never won an Oscar. This correction was delayed for research.

The lawsuit detailed the firm’s version of events related to the relationship between the two.

President Obama plans to return part of his salary in solidarity with federal workers who are going to be furloughed as part of automatic budget cuts, an official said Wednesday.
Prices have dropped 10 to 20 percent since the global economic downturn.
Stem-cell face-lifts are stirring a debate, with the procedures called fat grafting by some doctors, but youth restoring by others.
T-Mobile, the smallest of the Big Four cellphone carriers, steps away from the two-year, unbreakable contract that Sprint, Verizon and AT&T live by.
By tracking one patient’s immune response, scientists have discovered how a series of mutations led to an antibody that could defeat many H.I.V. strains.
NBC confirmed that Jimmy Fallon would take over from Jay Leno as host of “The Tonight Show” after the conclusion of the Winter Olympics in February 2014.

A sauce similar to a vegetable ragout works over any firm white fish.
Owners of small and midsize businesses talk about customer-relationship management software that has worked for them.

Astronomers said they might be on the verge of finding out what makes up the matter that gives shape to universe’s visible structures.
Mike Rice’s dismissal after the release of a video did little to quiet critics, who called for the jobs of university officials and asked why Mr. Rice was not fired sooner.
The view that Medicare recipients get only what they have paid for through taxes, premiums and medical co-payments has challenged lawmakers as they try to limit spending.
Defense lawyers for David Tarloff, who killed a woman in 2008, must meet a tough standard to prove insanity, even though he has received a diagnosis of schizophrenia.
Wall Street shares slipped about 1 percent after reports on the service sector and on private-sector jobs came in worse than expected.
Talks aimed at overcoming ethnic divisions in Kosovo ended without an agreement Wednesday, a potential blow to Serbia’s aspirations to join the European Union.

In a way, it’s every architect’s dream – to re-envision Penn Station and Madison Square Garden in New York. The Municipal Art Society of New York is giving four design firms that chance with a challenge to be announced Thursday.
 
The four firms — Santiago Calatrava,  Diller Scofidio + Renfro , SHoP Architects and SOM — will have until May 29 to propose new designs that will be unveiled to the public that day at the TimesCenter on West 41st Street (registration required at http://mas.org/ ). “We’re really trying to unlock people’s imaginations about the very real potential of a new arena and of a new Penn Station,” said Vin Cipolla, the society’s president, in an interview.

An article on March 21 about the renovation of a parish house in Cennano, Italy, referred incorrectly to the history of a neighboring Catholic church. Only the foundation dates back to at least A.D. 715, not the church. (Most of the visible portion of the church dates from 1285, when it was extensively rebuilt.) And the year the church was consecrated as Catholic is not known, though it did not occur in 1285.

In its quest to keep fans in the stands, and give them a reason not to view games in high definition in their livings rooms, the N.F.L. will put cameras into all home team locker rooms next season. Then they will encourage the teams to use the video on their stadium scoreboards, to give fans who buy tickets an inside look at what goes on in the teams’ inner sanctums. 
 
The N.F.L. is mandating the cameras, not making them optional, said Eric Grubman, the league’s executive vice president, during the opening panel of the IMG World Congress of Sports. Sports Business Daily first reported Grubman’s announcement from the panel.

While the billionaire Steven A. Cohen has come under mounting scrutiny related to insider trading, he had reason to believe that a nasty court battle with his former wife was behind him.
 
But on Wednesday, a federal appeals court revived the lawsuit that Patricia Cohen, Mr. Cohen’s ex-wife, had filed against him. The development adds another layer of difficulty to his already complicated life, with continuing legal issues and purchases of multimillion-dollar art and real estate.

MAILICK--Mildred D. Passed away in NYC April 3, 2013 eight days before her 86th birthday after a brief illness, surrounded by her loving family. Beloved mother of Marsha (Albee) and Daniel (Lydia). Extraordinary Grandma of Beth (Arie), Rebecca (Harry), Adina, and Rachel. Fiercely loyal friend and cousin of many. Predeceased by her husband, Sidney, to whom she was married for 56 years, and by her brother Herbert. She received her undergraduate and a master's degree in Social Work from the University of Chicago, and her doctorate in Social Work from Columbia University. She had a long and distinguished career as a Professor of Social Work at the Hunter College School of Social Work. She also was a member of the faculty of the Mount Sinai Hospital Department of Social Work and the New York Academy of Medicine. One of the Social Work "Pioneers", she was strongly admired by her colleagues, students, and patients. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel (180 W. 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave.) on Thursday at 10am, followed by a graveside ceremony at Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. Our hearts are broken - she will be deeply missed by all.

SAPAKOFF--Eleanor (nee Schildkret), born September 13, 1921, died peacefully in her sleep on April 1, 2013, at the age of 91, in New York City. An alumnus of Hunter High School and Hunter College, she was a teacher in the New York City Schools for 30 years, a profession she loved. An avid bridge player, she was a Life Master who enjoyed teaching the game to others even in the last years of her life. She spent most summers in Silver Bay, on northern Lake George. It was there that she developed an enduring appreciation for nature and the natural beauty of the Adirondack mountains. She is survived by two daughters, Sandy Radke, of Bellingen, Australia, and Laurie Sapakoff, of White Plains, New York, son-in-law, Evan Cohen, and grandchildren, Max and Janie. She will be deeply missed. Services 9:30am, Sunday, April 7, 2013, at Plaza Jewish Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., at 91st St. Burial to follow at Cedar Park Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Lake George Land Conservancy, 4905 Lake Shore Drive, P.O. Box 1250, Bolton Landing, N.Y. 12814, www.lglc.org.

Keeping the open browser tabs on a computer in sync with the browser on a mobile device can save a lot of time and e-mailing when you are on the go and need to keep working. The Google Chrome browser can keep tabs in sync between its desktop and Android mobile versions when all the devices are signed into the same Chrome account. Google’s site has detailed instructions . (Mozilla has a similar Firefox Sync feature for computers and other devices that can run its Firefox browser; information on using Firefox Sync can be found here .)
 
On the Mac side, Apple’s OS X 10.8 (Mountain Lion) system can synchronize tabs with the Safari browser on the computer and mobile devices (the iPad, iPod Touch and iPhone) running iOS 6. To keep tabs in sync, you must also have an iCloud account; Apple’s site has steps for setting up iCloud Tabs . To see browser tabs open on the mobile devices from the computer, click the iCloud Tabs button in the Safari toolbar. With Safari on an iOS device, tap the Bookmarks icon, then tap iCloud Tabs to see a list of open browser tabs on all the computers and gadgets logged into that iCloud account.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about the burial of Merton D. Simpson, the painter and influential art collector, after a delay stemming from a dispute among relatives, friends and a court-appointed guardian, referred incorrectly to the organization that provided a grant for the burial. The report also erroneously attributed the incorrect reference to the guardian, Ann Pinciss Berman, and rendered the organization’s name incorrectly. The grant came from the Artists’ Fellowship — not the Artist’s Fellowship — a New York-based charitable foundation that provides financial assistance to artists and their families; it was not provided by the South Carolina Arts Commission (which has its own Artist Fellowship program).

PELZ--Robert Leon, was born November 18, 1918 in New York City and died on March 30, 2013. His was a big life dedicated to his family, the practice of law and numerous charities. He was educated at Columbia College and then Columbia Law School. Upon graduation from Columbia Law School, he entered the Army and served in England until 1945, when, since he was a captain and a lawyer, he was immediately thrust onto the world stage, working on the defense team for General Homma, the Japanese general who was charged by the US Military Court as being responsible for the deaths of many US servicemen during the Bataan Death March in the Philippines. The story of the defense of General Homma was immortalized in the best-selling book Tears in the Darkness in 2009, and Mr. Pelz was extensively quoted in the book. After his military service, he returned to the practice of law. He worked at Loeb and Loeb for 50 years, many of them as managing partner of the New York office. He was deeply involved in charity work with the American Jewish Committee and the Federation for Jewish Philanthropies. He was also on the board of the magazine Commentary. He married Mary Jane Gips in 1949 and was happily married for 59 years until 2008 when she passed away. He is survived by his two loving children, Katie Pelz-Davis of Ann Arbor, Michigan, and Robert L. Pelz, Jr., of Boulder, Colorado, his daughter-in-law, Erna Maj, and his five grandchildren, Rebecca and Michael Davis and Ian, Duane and Bruce Pelz. Services will he held Monday, April 8 at 12:00pm noon at Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 W. Stevens Ave., Hawthorne, NY 10532. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, the Cancer Support Community of Greater Ann Arbor or the Bridge House in Boulder, CO. Arrangements entrusted to Assuma-Shankey Funeral Home, 34 N. Summit St., Pearl River, NY 10965 845-735-4849.

BEIJING — In the first three months of this year, levels of two major air pollutants increased by almost 30 percent here in the Chinese capital, over the same period in 2012, according to a report on Wednesday by a Chinese news organization.
 
The pollutants — nitrous dioxide and particulate matter that is between 2.5 and 10 micrometers in diameter, called PM 10 — appeared to have surged sharply in January, showing levels 47 percent higher than the same month last year, according to the report by Beijing News that was translated into English by The Economic Observer . The report cited as its source Chen Tian, the head of the Beijing Municipal Environmental Protection Bureau.

7:43 p.m. | Updated LONDON — The push to change Barclays from a predominantly British retail bank to a global financial giant over the last two decades created a culture that put profit before customers, according to an independent report released on Wednesday.
 
That review, which was ordered by the bank’s top management after a rate-rigging scandal last year, highlighted an “at all costs” attitude, particularly in the company’s investment bank, that was reinforced by a bonus system that encouraged taking risks over serving clients.

Bethany Mayer, who owns the Surf Bazaar shop at Surf Lodge, the beachside hot spot in Montauk, N.Y., has just opened a shop in, of all places, the recently refurbished Paramount Hotel off Times Square. Ms. Mayer looks upon this hotbed of tourists as “the last undiscovered neighborhood of Manhattan” and stocked the shop, called Free & the Brave, with beachy summertime wares: swimwear and rash guards from Pret-à-Surf, striped shirts from Edith A. Miller and, for men, jackets from Levi’s Vintage Clothing. But she added plenty of city pieces, as in current collections from A Détacher, Suno and Ace & Jig. There are also great gift items like Joya candles, Rin Tanaka books and C&T Adorn pouches. The shop will make an unexpected stop for the after-theater crowd, but locals would do well to drop by before heading out of town for the weekend.
 
Free & the Brave, 235 West 46th Street, (212) 221-1775.

HARTFORD — With memories of the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School as fresh as an open wound, the Connecticut Senate passed on Wednesday what members called the nation’s most comprehensive package of gun control legislation. The House was expected to approve it early Thursday. 
 
The vote came in a deeply divided Capitol packed with angry and frustrated gun owners who arrived in buses and vans carrying signs reading “Connecticut the Un-Constitution State,” “N.R.A. Stand and Fight” and “Shall Not Be Infringed.” And it came in a state that has historically been at the heart of the American gun manufacturing industry.

Private consultants and federal regulators are facing a fresh round of scrutiny in Washington after botching a broad review of foreclosures and failing to thwart financial misdeeds.
 
A new report by the Government Accountability Office will take aim at the Federal Reserve and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency for creating a bureaucratic maze that delayed relief to homeowners in foreclosure, according to a draft of the 74-page document provided to The New York Times. The regulators, the report found, designed a flawed review of troubled loans that the consultants carried out and mishandled.

HULL--Magda, 101, passed away at her home April 3, 2013. Trained in Berlin and at the Sorbonne in Paris, she was certified as an interpreter. A refugee from Nazi Germany, she worked in 1934 at the Club Heinrich Heine in Paris as a volunteer to help political refugees, married her husband, Max, in 1935, and emigrated with him to the United States in 1937, eternally grateful to her adopted land for the opportunity to begin life again. She was a devoted daughter, who, through force of will and with the help of John Foster Dulles, Congressman Sol Blum, and Averill Harriman, got her parents released from internment camps in Vichy France. Always concerned about those less fortunate, she tutored disadvantaged children, volunteered at the Institute for International Education, worked for Selfhelp aiding Holocaust survivors much younger than she, and annually provided for the transportation of refugees to benefit concerts. Predeceased by her husband, Max, she is survived by her children, Roger H. Hull and Cathy M. Hull, son-in-law Neil Janovic, three grandchildren, Roberto F. Hull, Lincoln M. Hull, and Julie Janovic Brooks, and two great-grandchildren, Victoria and Harrison Brooks. In lieu of flowers, donate to the charity of one's choice. Funeral services will be held April 4th, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel located at 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street at 12:30pm.

TRANSITION The Toronto-Dominion Bank, which is pursuing an aggressive expansion into the United States, said on Wednesday that the head of its American operation would become its chief executive late next year.
 
Bharat B. Masrani, left, will take over the bank when W. Edmund Clark retires as president and chief executive in November 2014. To smooth the transition, Mr. Masrani will return to the bank’s head office in Toronto and become chief operating officer on July 1. IAN AUSTEN

7:08 p.m. | Updated A former Goldman Sachs trader suspected of fabricating huge positions pleaded guilty to criminal actions on Wednesday, escalating a case that until now had led only to civil charges.
 
Matthew M. Taylor, whose trading caused unexpected losses for Goldman, pleaded guilty to one count of wire fraud at a court hearing in Lower Manhattan. Mr. Taylor, who more recently worked for Morgan Stanley , admitted to entering fabricated trades that concealed an $8.3 billion position to protect his bonus.

After a week of not-so-subtle hints on billboards around the country, the Rolling Stones announced on Wednesday that the band will do a tour of nine cities in North America this summmer, starting in Los Angeles in May. That concert, at the Staples Center, will be followed by performances in Oakland; San Jose, Calif.; Las Vegas; Anaheim, Calif.; Toronto; Chicago; Boston; and Philadelphia.
 
New York City is not on the route.

It is Americans for Responsible Solutions, not Americans for Sensible Solutions.

When is it time for a great entertainer to say goodbye to the stage? Watching Elaine Stritch, 88, in the opening-night show of her five-night farewell engagement at the Café Carlyle on Tuesday, I reflected that in cabaret, a genre that venerates the wisdom and experience of great ladies of a certain age, nobody wants to stop. As long as people are willing to pay to see them, why shouldn’t they continue?
 
A legend like Ms. Stritch, who is moving to Birmingham, Mich., to be near her nephews and nieces, has earned her adorers. In New York’s theatrical-cabaret axis, teeming with larger-than-life personalities, Ms. Stritch is one of the most formidable. Like Carol Channing and Liza Minnelli she epitomizes traditional show business brass and resilience: a “give it all you’ve got” dedication to entertaining. Everyone in the room was keenly aware that this might be the last hurrah of a blazing, cranky, funny stage personality who is, in a word, irreplaceable.

While the billionaire Steven A. Cohen has come under mounting scrutiny related to insider trading, he had reason to believe that a nasty court battle with his former wife was behind him.
 
But on Wednesday, a federal appeals court revived the lawsuit that Patricia Cohen, Mr. Cohen’s ex-wife, had filed against him. The development adds another layer of difficulty to his already complicated life, with continuing legal issues and purchases of multimillion-dollar art and real estate.

Lois Smith and Frances Sternhagen, stage veterans with recent major Off Broadway roles, are joint recipients of the lifetime achievement Obie, The Village Voice announced Tuesday. The Obies have been presented by The Voice since 1956, and the shared lifetime achievement award is a first.
 
Meryl Streep will present the award at a ceremony on May 20 at Webster Hall in the East Village. The co-hosts will be Jessica Hecht and Jeremy Shamos. Tickets go on sale April 10.
For Lisa Gimmy, the key to landscape architecture is making it seem as if she were never there.

GRIMM--John E. "Jack" III, 90, a retired business executive, died peacefully at his home in North Palm Beach, FL, on March 31, 2013 with his loving wife, Ann R. Grimm, and his beloved dog Lily by his side. He is also survived by a sister, Nan M Freeman. He was preceded in death by brothers, C. Peter Grimm and Robert D. Grimm. He was a loving uncle to Carl H. Grimm, N. Ellen Eifert, Laurie Steelsmith, Susan Wilmot, John Moorhead, James Moorhead, Dean Grimm, Tana Aurland, Tara Grimm, Jill Aurland., and many great nephews and great nieces. Jack was born July 7, 1922 in Dayton, OH to Helen Aurland Grimm and John E Grimm, Jr. His family moved to the New York area where he attended Scarsdale High School. Jack graduated from Dartmouth College in 1944, and The Amos Tuck School of Business. He attended Midshipman School at Northwestern University, Chicago and served in the U.S. Navy as Navigator, First Lieutenant, and Executive Officer, from 1942 to 1946. After his naval service, Jack began his career in the training program at Macy's. Later, he had the idea to make a recording of General Douglas Macarthur's' speech to Congress with the oft quoted phrase, "Old soldiers never die, they just fade away". He sold the record to department stores, including Macy's. The recording became the largest selling record for a two-day period, in Macy's history. Life Magazine ran a feature article with the headline, "Amateur Scoops Record Industry". With this success, he was hired by Lever Brothers and then by Sterling Drug, becoming a corporate vice president. In 1961, he accepted a position as a corporate vice president at the Colgate-Palmolive Co. where he worked for 24 years, retiring in 1984. In 1985 he founded Midbrook, Inc., a business consulting firm. He resided in Southampton, NY, and had been a resident of New York City for over 50 years. He was a member of Gypsy Trail Club in Carmel, NY, The Meadow Club and Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, Southampton, NY, The Racquet and Tennis Club in New York City, and The Lost Tree Club in North Palm Beach, FL. Jack was active in business and philanthropic endeavors, serving as President and Chairman of Madison Square Boys and Girls Club of New York City, Vice President of the Board, and Vice Chairman of the Executive Committee of The Southampton Hospital, and a former member of the Skin Cancer Foundation Board. He also co-authored "My One Big Break", a book of inspiring stories of successful business and professional leaders. Jack was an avid golfer and tennis player and was considered by all who knew him as true gentleman. Above all, Jack shared his life with an incredible group of loyal friends. Funeral Services will be private. A celebration of Jack's life will be held at a later date. The family asks that remembrances in Jack's name be made to the Madison Square Boys and Girls Club of New York City, or The Southampton Hospital, Southampton, NY.

Sometimes even a four-inch smartphone screen may not seem enough. If so, would 200 inches do?
 
The iPower Sight can — according to the manufacturer, iPowerUp — take what is on your phone, tablet or computer screen and enlarge it, projecting an image up to 200 diagonal inches from a device that is itself pocket-size.

A federal judge dealt a devastating blow to a lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase that accused the nation’s largest bank and its affiliates of duping investors into buying troubled mortgage-backed securities.
 
In a ruling on Tuesday, Judge Jed S. Rakoff dismissed claims from Dexia, a Belgian-French bank that had sued JPMorgan over losses on $1.6 billion in 65 residential mortgage investments, according to court documents.

It was to elevators what the phrase “Mr. Watson, come here” was to telephones: “Cut the rope.”
 
Elisha Graves Otis said it. His assistant sliced through the thick piece of hemp that raised and lowered Otis’s newfangled elevator. The elevator dropped a bit, and stopped. Otis’s safety brake had done its job.

Gigi Burris will tell you that she fell in love with millinery while studying in Paris. Inspired by Coco Chanel and Jeanne Lanvin, both of whom started their careers as hatmakers, the young milliner, who grew up in Florida, is carrying on the Old World craft in daringly modern style. Her chapeaus are more high fashion than royal-friendly — imagine a transparent woven horsehair bowler embellished with pleated tulle — and her spring collection includes some statement-making headbands. The ones shown above, made of feathers knotted onto leather cord, look like barbed wire, $270. The double band below is set with a sparkling multicolor agate druzy, $290. They’re cool and sophisticated, for when you want to bring the drama. At gigiburris.com .

An article on March 23 about the hundreds of amendments that Senate Republicans proposed after Democrats unveiled their budget referred incorrectly to a ban on large sugary drinks in New York City, the subject of an amendment by Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, who wanted to make sure money was available to prevent such a regulation. The ban was blocked by a state court in New York, not by a federal court.

Justin Timberlake’s comeback album, “The 20/20 Experience” (RCA), holds at No. 1 for a second week on the Billboard chart, beating a slew of new releases by Lil Wayne, Blake Shelton, the pop band OneRepublic and others.
 
“The 20/20 Experience,” Mr. Timberlake’s first new LP in almost seven years, sold 318,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. That is a 67 percent drop from its blockbuster opening but was still far above the sales for the runner-up this week, Lil Wayne’s “I Am Not a Human Being II” (Cash Money/Republic), which had 217,000. In its two weeks out, Mr. Timberlake’s album has sold almost 1.3 million copies, becoming the first this year to cross the one million mark, Billboard reported.

YOUNG--John E. died April 1, 2013 at his home in Manhattan, surrounded by his loving wife Mary and family, of complications from Parkinson's Disease. John was born in 1935 in Tulsa, Oklahoma to Russell E. and Frances Young and grew up in Casper, Wyoming where he was graduated from Natrona County High School in 1952. John went on to receive his undergraduate degree at the California Institute of Technology (CalTech) and law degree magna cum laude in 1959 from Harvard Law School where he was a member of the Law Review. He spent most of the year following graduation from law school traveling the world on a Sheldon Traveling Fellowship from Harvard. Upon his return, John joined the law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore in New York where he became a partner on January 1, 1968 and had a diverse corporate practice, principally in the areas of securities offerings and private financings, both domestic and international. John was a recognized expert in representing underwriters and issuers in public debt and equity offerings, as well as institutional investors in railroad equipment financings. He headed Cravath's Paris office in 1971-1973 and its London office in 1990-1995, when he retired from the Firm. John served as a trustee of the Brearley School and the National Young Arts Foundation and was chairman of the Royal Oak Foundation, the United States arm of the National Trust of England, Wales and Northern Ireland, a conservation foundation, among his many charitable endeavors. John read avidly and widely. He loved travel, classical music and art. In retirement, John took up boating and with his wife Mary and many friends cruised the Erie Canal, the Florida Keys and the Intracoastal Waterway on his boat "Mobius." John was also a life-long progressive, beginning with his support, while a young man, for Adlai Stevenson and ending with his joy at being able to witness the election of Barack Obama. John was an extraordinarily generous man who cared deeply about his friends and family. In addition to his wife of 46 years, Mary, he is survived by his daughter Cynthia Young (George Eberstadt) and her daughters Esme and Maya, his daughter Abigail Young (Jonathan Moses), and her daughters Charlotte and Eleanor, and his sister-in-law Joan Nason. We will miss him deeply. Donations in John's memory may be made to the Mt. Sinai Visiting Doctor's Service, which provided him such compassionate care, or the Metropolitan Museum of Art or Museum of Modern Art, both of which John frequently visited in his later years taking part in their wonderful programs for people suffering from illnesses such as his. A memorial service will take place on Tuesday, April 9 at 11am at The Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan.

KONTOKOSTA--Emanuel M.,82, Archon of the Ecumenical Patriarchate, died peacefully at his home in Manhattan on Sunday, March 31, 2013 surrounded by his loving family. Kontokosta, the son of Michael and Anna (Gregos) Kontokosta from Kardamyla, Chios, Greece, was born in New York City in 1931. Kontokosta, a professional engineer, was the head of the New York City based architectural and engineering firm of Kontokosta Associates for over 50 years. Kontokosta is survived by his wife Patricia; their children Michael, Constantine and Anna; six grandchildren and his sisters Caliope and Alice Kontokosta. The family will receive visitors Friday, April 5th, from 2pm to 5pm and from 7pm to 9pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York, NY. A service will be held on Saturday, April 6th, at 10am at the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 337 East 74th Street, New York, NY. Interment will follow at the Sterling Cemetery, Greenport, Long Island, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to: Greek Orthodox Church of the Hamptons Building Fund, 111 Saint Andrew's Road, Southampton, NY 11968 or Kimisis Theotoku Church, 224 18th Street, Brooklyn, New York 11215.

A report in the Currents column last Thursday about home-furnishing boutiques coming to some JC Penney stores gave an incorrect name for the boutiques. Each one will be named after its merchandise collection, like Design by Conran and Michael Graves Design; they will not be called The Street, which is the name for the widened corridor along which they will be located.

A picture caption on Feb. 6 with the continuation of an article about the inherent hazards of the quasi-secret campaign of targeted drone killings that the United States is waging against suspected militants in Yemen, Pakistan and Somalia misidentified the date on which an American drone strike destroyed a building, the ruins of which were shown. And a correction in this space on Monday misidentified the country in which the drone strike occurred. The strike was in southeastern Yemen, not Lebanon, and it occurred on Oct. 14, 2011 — not on Sunday, Feb. 3, of this year.

An article on Tuesday about the death of Pattycake, the first gorilla born in New York City, misstated the relevance of the age 37 for gorillas. That age is the median life expectancy for female gorillas in North American zoos, not the median age of gorillas in North American zoos.

A picture on Tuesday with an article about Iran’s announcement that its double-digit inflation had worsened in March for the sixth consecutive month was published in error. It showed a spice shop in the Deira section of Dubai, United Arab Emirates, not one in Deira, Iran. (There is no Deira in Iran.) The article also misspelled the middle name of Iran’s foreign minister in some editions. He is Ali Akbar Salehi, not Akhbar.

HULL--Magda. Selfhelp Community Services mourns the passing of Magda Hull, a dear friend and long-time supporter. She was active in our Spring concert events, and annually made it possible for Holocaust survivors to attend, which warmed their hearts and lifted their spirits. She was also a longstanding member of Selfhelp's Nazi Victim Services Program Advisory Committee, and volunteered in many capacities. As a victim of Nazi persecution herself, she truly understood the needs of our clients, and was a dedicated advocate for them. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her. YOUNG--John E. died April 1, 2013 at his home in Manhattan, surrounded by his loving wife Mary and family, of complications from Parkinson's Disease. John was born in 1935 in Tulsa, Oklahoma to Russell E. and Frances Young and grew up in Casper, Wyoming where he was graduated from Natrona County High School in 1952. John went on to receive his undergraduate degree at the California Institute of Technology (CalTech) and law degree magna cum laude in 1959 from Harvard Law School where he was a member of the Law Review. He spent most of the year following graduation from law school traveling the world on a Sheldon Traveling Fellowship from Harvard. Upon his return, John joined the law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore in New York where he became a partner on January 1, 1968 and had a diverse corporate practice, principally in the areas of securities offerings and private financings, both domestic and international. John was a recognized expert in representing underwriters and issuers in public debt and equity offerings, as well as institutional investors in railroad equipment financings. He headed Cravath's Paris office in 1971-1973 and its London office in 1990-1995, when he retired from the Firm. John served as a trustee of the Brearley School and the National Young Arts Foundation and was chairman of the Royal Oak Foundation, the United States arm of the National Trust of England, Wales and Northern Ireland, a conservation foundation, among his many charitable endeavors. John read avidly and widely. He loved travel, classical music and art. In retirement, John took up boating and with his wife Mary and many friends cruised the Erie Canal, the Florida Keys and the Intracoastal Waterway on his boat "Mobius." John was also a life-long progressive, beginning with his support, while a young man, for Adlai Stevenson and ending with his joy at being able to witness the election of Barack Obama. John was an extraordinarily generous man who cared deeply about his friends and family. In addition to his wife of 46 years, Mary, he is survived by his daughter Cynthia Young (George Eberstadt) and her daughters Esme and Maya, his daughter Abigail Young (Jonathan Moses), and her daughters Charlotte and Eleanor, and his sister-in-law Joan Nason. We will miss him deeply. Donations in John's memory may be made to the Mt. Sinai Visiting Doctor's Service, which provided him such compassionate care, or the Metropolitan Museum of Art or Museum of Modern Art, both of which John frequently visited in his later years taking part in their wonderful programs for people suffering from illnesses such as his. A memorial service will take place on Tuesday, April 9 at 11am at The Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan.

It’s no longer just a dream in the hearts of “Arrested Development” fans, a wild scheme in the mind of the series creator Mitchell Hurwitz or a question for its cast members to answer in every interview they have given since 2006. A new season of “Arrested Development” will be released on Netflix on May 26, it was announced on Thursday.
 
Netflix said in a news release that it would post 15 new episodes of “Arrested Development,” constituting a fourth season of that cockamamie comedy series, all at once at 12:01 a.m. Pacific time on May 26 in every territory where the service is available.

Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former Enron chief executive serving a 24-year sentence for his role in the fraud that led to the energy giant’s collapse, could be released early from prison under a possible agreement with the government, according to a notice posted late Wednesday on the Justice Department’s Web site.
 
Lawyers for Mr. Skilling are in talks with prosecutors to reduce the term he was sentenced to for his role in helping to bring down Enron, which before its collapse in 2001 was the world’s largest energy trader and one of America’s most heralded companies.

New York City Center will be home this summer to a new series of Off Broadway musicals reincarnated by contemporary artists and intended to attract young audiences with tickets priced mostly at $25 and free preperformance events.
 
Called “Encores! Off-Center,” the series will feature three shows under the artistic direction of the composer Jeanine Tesori (“Caroline, or Change”).  It begins July 10-13 with “The Cradle Will Rock,” a tale of exploited workers written by Marc Blitzstein, directed by Sam Gold and choreographed by Chase Brock. The show, originally developed in 1937 with funds from the Federal Theater Project, a branch of the Works Progress Administration, was brought to City Center by Leonard Bernstein in 1947.

Trevor W. Morrison, a Columbia Law School professor and constitutional law scholar, will be the next dean of New York University Law School, the president of N.Y.U. announced on Thursday. 
 
Mr. Morrison will succeed Richard L. Revesz, whose 11-year tenure will end on May 31.

OVERHOLSER--Charles E.,age 87, formerly of Mamaroneck, died at his home in Kennett Square, PA on April 2, 2013. Following service during WWII in the U.S. Navy he graduated magna cum laude with the Harvard Class of 1947. He had a distinguished career as Director of Research and Strategic Planning at Young & Rubicam and at Kenyon & Eckhardt, and was past President of the Market Research Council, served as a Director of the Advertising Research Foundation and on the Research Committee of the Association of Advertising Agencies, and was a member of the American Marketing Association and the Harvard Club of New York City. His many interests included chamber music and jazz, birding, politics, and the New York Giants. Survivors include his wife Renee (nee Value), son Charles E. and wife Barbara (nee Rosenthal), daughter Margaret V. and husband Charles Patrick Fox, and son George M. and partner Carla Brodley, and by three grandchildren, Christopher R., Jesse M., and Matthew E. Even while accusing Jon S. Corzine and other former MF Global executives of “negligent conduct” that may have fueled the brokerage firm’s collapse, a bankruptcy trustee has agreed to postpone a lawsuit against them.
 
Instead, Mr. Corzine’s lawyers will enter mediation next week with the trustee, Louis J. Freeh, according to people briefed on the talks who were not authorized to speak publicly.

An article on Thursday about Mike Sandlock, the oldest living Brooklyn Dodger, Boston Brave and Pittsburgh Pirate, misidentified a city in which he played minor league baseball. It is Bradford, Pa., not Bradford, N.Y.

The on-again, off-again romance between Marnie and Charlie on the HBO comedy “Girls” is very much off. Christopher Abbott, the actor who played Charlie on that series, will not return for its third season, HBO said on Thursday, confirming a report that appeared in the Page Six column of The New York Post . 
 
“Girls,” a New York coming-of-age comedy created by and starring Lena Dunham, and produced by Ms. Dunham, Judd Apatow and Jenni Konner, has become one of HBO’s most talked-about series since its debut in 2012. It has rapidly made stars of its young actors , including Mr. Abbott (“Martha Marcy May Marlene”), who played Charlie, a seemingly aimless young man who, after a bad breakup with Marnie (Allison Williams), finds success by creating a popular iPhone app.

The Gotham column on Tuesday, about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s anger at two state senators from Brooklyn who blocked his request for red-light cameras in the city, misstated the political affiliation of one lawmaker. (The other state senator who blocked Mr. Bloomberg’s plan is Martin Golden, a Republican.)

MEXICO CITY — When Banco Santander held the $4.13 billion public stock offering of its Mexico subsidiary here last September, a mariachi band and Mexican folk dancers set the festive mood for a media breakfast in a sun-filled dining room atop the stock exchange’s skyscraper.
 
The offering — the largest ever in Mexico and trailing only initial public offerings from Facebook and Japan Airlines in terms of size in 2012 — was just one sign of the strong revival of the nation’s financial services sector.

STEPPING DOWN Stephen Friedman, a director of Goldman Sachs and chairman of the board’s risk committee, plans to retire, the firm announced on Thursday. Mr. Friedman, 75, left, is required to retire by Goldman’s corporate governance guidelines, which set 75 as the maximum age for directors.
 
A onetime leader of Goldman who worked at the firm for nearly 30 years, Mr. Friedman is stepping down on May 22, the day before Goldman’s annual shareholder meeting. He will be succeeded by Adebayo O. Ogunlesi, who joined the board last fall. WILLIAM ALDEN

One of the largest collections of jazz photographs in the world, an archive painstakingly assembled over six decades by the record producer and writer Frank Driggs, has been donated to Jazz at Lincoln Center .

CARDEN--John Richard, Ph.D. 90, of Chapel Hill, NC, passed away on April 2, 2013 at The Davis Community in Wilmington, NC. He was born on August 24, 1922, in Chicago, IL to the late William H and Irene Raycraft Carden. John was a loving husband, brother and uncle, with a strong sense of humor and loved by all who knew him. He proudly served his country in the US Army in World War II and was a member of American Legion Post 1, Paris France. Dr. Carden was a College Professor, radio newscaster and wire service news writer for the Associated Press in New York City. In 1968 he married the love of his life, Betsy Lane Martin. After their retirement he and Betsy relocated from Brooklyn, NY to Chapel Hill and Bantry Bay, Republic of Ireland. From here they traveled the world in search of new adventures. He was preceded in death by his parents and wife. He is survived by his brother Robert and wife Marie of Reading, MA and Bloomington, IL. A graveside service will be planned for later this month in Danville, VA. We would like to thank the staff at Davis for their kindness and caring. Online condolences may be listed for John on the www.wilmingtoncares.com website. Wilmington Funeral & Cremation is assisting the family with arrangements.

Officials said that the move was practical, motivated by the fear that many students would skip the exams in favor of seeing Mr. Bieber.

Hugh McCracken, a virtuoso guitarist who was in such demand as a studio musician that he could afford to turn down Paul McCartney’s invitation to join the band Wings in 1971, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 70.
 
The cause was leukemia, his wife of 43 years, Holly, said.

Bank of America is introducing new automated teller machines that evoke the bridge of the starship Enterprise, where captain and crew spoke remotely with others in outer space.
 
The bank’s “teller assist” A.T.M.’s let customers get on-screen help from a remote bank teller over a live video link for transactions like check cashing. Unlike the intergalactic characters on “Star Trek,” though, the bank’s on-screen tellers are sitting in call centers in Florida and Delaware.
FELDMAN--Leo, 92 years of age, of Coconut Creek, Florida. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, brother and uncle. A blessing to all who knew him.

An article on Wednesday about a run on gun shops in Connecticut after the General Assembly reached a deal on gun-control legislation misstated a change under the bill. The legislation, signed into law on Thursday, includes a ban on the sale of magazines that hold 11 or more rounds and requires that owners of such magazines register them; it is not the case that the ban includes the sale of magazines carrying “10 or more” rounds and their registration. (The error was repeated on Thursday in an article about the passage of the bill in the state Senate.)

ROSENSON--Hyman, April 5, 2013. Pre-deceased by wife Harriet. Survived by children Nancy (David) Owens, Eric (Debbie) Rosenson, Valerie (Russell Robbins); grandchildren; great-grandchildren; Elaine Rosenson, Estelle Kutner. Service Sun, Apr 7, 2013, 1:00 PM Riverside Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

The latest burst of Broadway star casting will come from Britain this fall: The actors Daniel Craig (a k a the reigning 007) and Rachel Weisz (an Oscar winner for “The Constant Gardener” ), who are married in real life, will play the husband and wife in Harold Pinter’s “Betrayal,” press representatives for the producer Scott Rudin said Friday. The Tony Award winner Mike Nichols will direct.
 
Pinter’s 1978 play explores the frailties of marriage and long-term friendship and the fall-out from an extramarital affair, and is perhaps best known for its innovative structure – many scenes are in reverse chronological order, with the drama starting in 1977 and ending in 1968.

She is survived by daughters, Eve Musette Michel, Ann Elizabeth Michel, granddaughter Ava Elizabeth Milanese, and four sisters. An article on Thursday about a legal dispute between Steven A. Cohen, the founder of the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors, and his former wife gave outdated information about the ex-wife’s lawsuit. An amended complaint seeks $10 million and does not accuse the hedge fund of having committed crimes; it does not seek $300 million in damages and claim that SAC was “a racketeering scheme,” which an earlier complaint contended.

The Miami rapper Rick Ross sent Twitter messages to his fans and to his sponsors on Thursday apologizing for a lyric in his song “U.O.E.N.O.” that seems to condone rape. 
 
The twin apologies came after the lyric drew criticism from the women’s group UltraViolet and from other rappers , who said Mr. Ross seemed insensitive when he spoke in the song about drugging a woman and taking her home.

A day after MF Global’s bankruptcy trustee hinted he might sue top executives for “negligent conduct,” his separate plan to liquidate the firm secured court approval, ushering in a final phase of a case that rattled Wall Street and prompted a federal investigation.
 
At a hearing in bankruptcy court in Manhattan on Friday, nearly 18 months after the brokerage firm imploded, Judge Martin Glenn cleared the way for Louis J. Freeh, the trustee, to sell the firm’s remaining assets and return money to creditors. For Mr. Freeh, a former director of the F.B.I. who is liquidating MF Global’s estate, the ruling was a major step toward ending the largest Wall Street bankruptcy since the financial crisis.

Fisker Automotive, the maker of a $100,000-and-up plug-in hybrid luxury sedan, said on Friday that about three-quarters of its workers had been let go to “allow the company to work through its current financial challenges.”
 
The statement was issued on behalf of Fisker by Sitrick & Company, a Los Angeles public relations firm that Fisker, a start-up automaker, retained late last week.

I usually dread shopping in stores. Trying on clothes is tedious, and sometimes completing the actual purchase is, too. Retailers like to ask for all sorts of information as they’re ringing up your merchandise, like your e-mail address and ZIP code. I just want to pay and be on my way, and they give me the third degree. Read more »

You do not want to mess with Arnaldo Rivera on Kelly Street. He had heard plenty about this crescent-shaped block off Longwood Avenue in the South Bronx. Drug dealers and addicts had holed up in filthy, crumbling apartments scattered among five buildings that were among the city’s worst.  He was ready.  He had a gun.
 
A caulking gun.

MILLER--Helen Keppler, of Laguna Hills, CA on January 9, 2013 at age 100. Widow of Raymond, leaves sons, Donald (Allison) and Richard (Jennifer), grandchildren, Lawrence (Cathy) and Anna, great-grandson, Noah.

A dance entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the Indian dancers Surupa Sen and Bijayini Satpathy, at N.Y.U.’s Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, scheduled for tonight and Sunday, misstated the times of preshow lectures. The half-hour talks will start at 7 p.m. tonight (followed by an 8 p.m. performance) and at 2 p.m. Sunday (followed by a 3 p.m. performance); the talks are not a half-hour before each performance.

The Vineyard Theater has announced that it will produce two premieres as part of its 2013-14 Off Broadway season. This fall brings the musical “The Landing,” with a score by the Tony Award-winning composer John Kander and book and lyrics by Greg Pierce. In the spring of 2014, the theater will mount “Too Much Sun,” a new play by Nicky Silver (“The Lyons”), with direction by Mark Brokaw. Run dates and casting were not announced for either show.
 
“The Landing,” to be directed by Walter Bobbie, is the first collaboration between Mr. Kander, who with the lyricist Fred Ebb wrote the musicals “Chicago” and “Cabaret,” and Mr. Pierce, whose play “Slowgirl” was the inaugural production at Lincoln Center Theater’s new Claire Tow Theater last year. “The Landing” is Mr. Pierce’s debut as lyricist and book writer. Consisting of three musical tales of love and obsession, the show returns to the Vineyard for a full production after having a developmental production there last year. The Vineyard’s relationship with Mr. Kander dates to 1987, when it produced a revival of “Flora the Red Menace,” which had a book by George Abbott and Robert Russell, music by Mr. Kander and lyrics by Mr. Ebb. In 2010, the Vineyard produced the premiere of the Kander and Ebb musical “The Scottsboro Boys,” which transferred to Broadway.

OVERHOLSER--Charles E.,age 87, formerly of Mamaroneck, died at his home in Kennett Square, PA on April 2, 2013. Following service during WWII in the U.S. Navy he graduated magna cum laude with the Harvard Class of 1947. He had a distinguished career as Director of Research and Strategic Planning at Young & Rubicam and at Kenyon & Eckhardt, and was past President of the Market Research Council, served as a Director of the Advertising Research Foundation and on the Research Committee of the Association of Advertising Agencies, and was a member of the American Marketing Association and the Harvard Club of New York City. His many interests included chamber music and jazz, birding, politics, and the New York Giants. Survivors include his wife Renee (nee Value), son Charles E. and wife Barbara (nee Rosenthal), daughter Margaret V. and husband Charles Patrick Fox, and son George M. and partner Carla Brodley, and by three grandchildren, Christopher R., Jesse M., and Matthew E. Overholser. Memorial service at Crosslands, Kennett Square, on Sunday, April 21 at 3 pm. For those who wish, contributions to Neighborhood Hospice, nvnacc.com.

A music review last Saturday about two concerts by the Los Angeles Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall, led by the conductor Gustavo Dudamel, and a correction in this space on Friday misstated the date that works by Claude Vivier and Claude Debussy were performed. It was Thursday night, not Wednesday night.

The High & Low Finance column on Friday, about alternative options to the London interbank offered rate, or Libor, as the determinant of floating interest rates, described the federal funds rate incorrectly. It is the rate at which banks lend reserves to one another, not the rate at which the Federal Reserve lends to banks.
GOLD--Sidney. April 6, 1972. Dad, you are always in our hearts and thoughts. Your loving daughter & family.

ALMATY, Kazakhstan — North Korea is more than 2,500 miles from the resumed nuclear negotiations that got under way here Friday between Iran and the six big powers, but North Korea’s nuclear-arms bombast and the cautious foreign response are hanging over the negotiations in unsettling ways.
 
For the first time since Iran and the six powers restarted their dialogue a year ago after a long lapse, North Korea, which had held similar talks in the 1990s that collapsed in betrayal and mistrust, is simultaneously demonstrating an outcome that Iran may find enviable, nonproliferation experts said. North Korea’s arsenal of nuclear weapons, however small, has nonetheless emboldened it to challenge the United States and other nuclear-armed powers, which have responded with caution and — from North Korea’s vantage point — some degree of respect.

Mark Knopfler canceled two concerts in Russia on Thursday to protest what he sees as the government’s harassment of human rights groups there, the BBC reported . 
 
Mr. Knopfler, the former Dire Straits frontman, said he was calling off his performances planned for June in Moscow and St. Petersburg because Russian authorities had searched the offices of several organizations, among them Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International. He called the searches a “crackdown.”

Four-fifty West 41st Street, a rundown blue-tiled former warehouse by the Lincoln Tunnel, is the unimpressive sort of city architecture that you walk by without noticing. A shaky elevator ride up to the sixth floor, and the rooms behind the white door hold a trove of bland metal desks overflowing with papers and office plants growing down a shelf of books.
 
There are dusty carpets, a broken toilet, a stained brown couch and no potable water. But to musicologists professional and amateur, this is sacred space: home of the cryptically named Association for Cultural Equity , better known as the Alan Lomax archive for the folklorist who traveled to the Soviet Union, Haiti, the Deep South and points across the globe to preserve musical traditions on tape, film and paper.

JPMorgan Chase is working behind the scenes to avert a major potential embarrassment.
 
In anticipation of a crucial vote at next month’s annual meeting, board members are planning to sit down with some of the bank’s biggest shareholders to make their case that JPMorgan’s influential chief executive, Jamie Dimon , should keep his chairman title, according to several people briefed on the plans.

BEAUJOUR--Michel Husband of Elizabeth, father of Thomas, and father-in-law of Maria McKenna, died on Wednesday at home. He is survived as well by his sister, Annette Bajac, and her husband Jean-Loup, his brothers Alain-Yves and Jerome, his nieces Emmanuelle Bajac, Anne Binabout, and his nephew Quentin Bajac. Born in Paris in 1933 and agreg d'anglais, he served in the Chasseurs Alpins, was a professor of French at NYU for 46 years, and co-founded the university's Institute of French Studies. Services will be held from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. NYC. 212-288-3500. In lieu of flowers, please donate to Lenox Hill Hospital.

STUART--Caroline Evans, 93, died April 1 at her home at Meadow Lakes Retirement Community in Hightstown, NJ. Her passing was peaceful, with family by her side. Born March 18, 1920 to Herbert and Adella Evans, Caroline had two brothers: Franklin and Herbert Evans Jr. She graduated Ohio University in 1942 (BS in Education), and completed her Masters Degree at Columbia University in 1948. In 1970, she married the love of her life James B. Stuart. She became a beloved stepmother to his children, and grandmother to their children. In retirement, Caroline established the "Education Award Fund," which provides tuition assistance to Meadow Lakes employees who are also college students. Caroline is survived by her nephews: Peter Evans, David Evans, and Lance Evans, her stepchildren Robert Stuart, Diane Westman, Laird Stuart, and Bruce Stuart, as well as eight grandchildren, 17 great-grandchildren, and one great-great grandchild. A memorial will be held April 13 at 11am at Meadow Lakes Retirement Community in Hightstown, NJ. In lieu of flowers, Caroline requested contributions be made to: Meadow Lakes Education Award Fund, 300 Etra Road, East Windsor, NJ 08520.

An article on Thursday about a new report showing that in the first three months of this year the levels of two major air pollutants increased by 30 percent in Beijing over the same period in 2012 misstated part of the name of one of the pollutants. It is nitrogen dioxide, not nitrous dioxide.

8:46 p.m. | Updated Anheuser-Busch InBev said on Friday that it had reached an agreement in principle to win government approval for its $20.1 billion deal to buy control of Grupo Modelo, the maker of Corona.
 
The Obama administration sued on Jan. 31 to block the takeover, arguing that the deal would give Anheuser-Busch InBev too much control over the American beer market, potentially reducing choice while raising prices.

JHABVALA--Ruth Prawer. A great talent, dear friend, loving and loved wife, mother, grandmother and writer. A brave spirit. Our hearts mourn with Jhab and their splendid daughters. The world is colder now. Dan and Joanna Rose
SELIGER--William (Bill) April 5, 1930 - April 6, 2010 You are missed and loved every day. Marie, Bill, Weezie and Susan

An obituary on March 23 about the former Knicks player and broadcaster Bud Palmer referred incorrectly to a story he told about sharing a hotel room with Sweetwater Clifton, one of the first black players in the National Basketball Association. Mr. Palmer did not specify the time frame for his anecdote, but he could not have roomed with Mr. Clifton “as a Knick” because the two were never on the team at the same time. (Mr. Palmer’s last season with the Knicks was 1948-49; Mr. Clifton’s first was 1950-51.)

In this brave new world of serialized television dramas every minute counts. Miss the closing moments of your favorite show and you could lose out on crucial plot details that send its story spinning off in new and unexpected directions. But when your beloved FX cold war-era spy drama is cut off before its conclusion by your overeager DVR, whom do you blame? The C.I.A.? The K.G.B.? HBO?
 
Before an international incident could break out, FX swallowed its own cyanide capsule and took the blame for an error that prevented many viewers from seeing the last seven minutes of the most recent episode of “The Americans.”

SHANGHAI — The Swiss banking giant UBS made a $5.5 billion loan early this year to help a Thai company acquire a 15.6 percent stake in China’s Ping An Insurance Group, according to people briefed on the deal.
 
The loan helps explain how the Charoen Pokphand Group, an agribusiness giant based in Thailand, was able to complete one of the biggest deals ever in China, a $9.4 billion acquisition of shares in Ping An. The stake had long been held by the British bank HSBC , which had decided to sell to streamline its businesses.

LOUISVILLE VS. WICHITA STATE
 
Saturday’s first national semifinal features the top-seeded team in the tournament, the Cardinals, and the most surprising member of the Final Four, the Shockers. How appropriate. Chief among Wichita State’s concerns? Louisville’s pressure defense, the one that cooked Syracuse, Oregon and Duke in recent weeks. Mike Krzyzewski said that Louisville “can boom you.” Perfect description. The Shockers are no slouches, having toppled Gonzaga and Ohio State. Louisville, meanwhile, will try to win for guard Kevin Ware, who suffered a hard-to-watch broken leg against Duke, without being overcome by emotion.

SHAFFER--Dr. Dorothy Browne Shaffer, passed away in Stamford, CT on April 3, 2013. Born in Vienna in 1923, she emigrated in 1938, and graduated from Bryn Mawr College in 1943. Her husband of 35 years Lloyd Hamilton Shaffer died in 1978. She received her PhD from Radcliffe College in 1962, and was a Professor of Mathematics at Fairfield University for 30 years. Dr. Shaffer is survived by three daughters Deborah, Diana and Dorothy Tien Shaffer, and three grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at St. Francis Episcopal Church, 503 Old Long Ridge Road in Stamford at noon on Monday, April 8, followed by interment at Long Ridge Union Cemetery, Erskine Road, Stamford. For further information please visit: www.boutonreynolds funeralhome.com.

Back in January, I fulfilled a New Year’s resolution by setting up automatic online transfers for my children’s weekly allowances. So far, so good — or, so I thought.
 
Last week, I got a stern e-mail from Capital One 360 (formerly ING Direct), warning me that I was making too many withdrawals from my savings account. If I didn’t stop, they’d have to close the account, “since this isn’t your first offense,” the e-mail said. I could practically see the finger wagging.

A hamlet in central New Jersey that offers a diverse housing stock, much of it expanded in the last two decades, along with a good school district and commute to New York.

LEVINE--Abner. Our Uncle Abby was available to all with his wisdom, advise, love and support, but especially to his family. He will always live in our hearts. His life as a proud, charitable and moral Jew will be an ever lasting inspiration to us. We loved him and will miss him dearly. Our deepest sympathies to our loving Aunt Mildred and our cousins Larry and Megan, Michael and Sandy and Ellen and Rick and all their children. With all our love, David, Jayne, Simone and Asher Swersky.

NEMIROFF--David G.,69, retired psychologist, died suddenly March 23 after a long struggle with Parkinson's Disease at Hebrew Rehabilitation Center, Roslindale, MA. Predeceased by his wife, Helene; survived by his son, Larry, his sisters Sandra, Judy, Maggie and their families. David will be remembered for his disarming humor, intelligence, and loving friendship. He is deeply missed. A celebration of his life will be held in June.

STUART--Caroline Evans, 93, died April 1 at her home at Meadow Lakes Retirement Community in Hightstown, NJ. Her passing was peaceful, with family by her side. Born March 18, 1920 to Herbert and Adella Evans, Caroline had two brothers: Franklin and Herbert Evans Jr. She graduated Ohio University in 1942 (BS in Education), and completed her Masters Degree at Columbia University in 1948. In 1970, she married the love of her life James B. Stuart. She became a beloved stepmother to his children, and grandmother to their children. In retirement, Caroline established the "Education Award Fund," which provides tuition assistance to Meadow Lakes employees who are also college students. Caroline is survived by her nephews: Peter Evans, David Evans, and Lance Evans, her stepchildren Robert Stuart, Diane Westman, Laird Stuart, and Bruce Stuart, as well as eight grandchildren, 17 great-grandchildren, and one great-great grandchild. A memorial will be held April 13 at 11am at Meadow Lakes Retirement Community in Hightstown, NJ. In lieu of flowers, Caroline requested contributions be made to: Meadow Lakes Education Award Fund, 300 Etra Road, East Windsor, NJ 08520.

ZOMMICK--Anita, passed away on April 3, 2013. She was born in New York on October 19th, 1924. Anita became an accountant after graduating from Hunter College in 1946. Anita is survived by her sister, Iris Caplowe - and several cousins, nieces and nephews. Services are at Mount Carmel Cemetery on Monday, April 8th at 11:30am. Please send contributions to: Alzheimer's Association, www.alz.org/or a charity of your choice.

WIESNER--The Reverend Elizabeth "Lee." St. Andrew's-in-the-Valley Church, Tamworth, NH will hold a Memorial Service April 20, 2013 at 1pm for the Rev. Elizabeth Lee Wiesner. She died August 27, 2011, at the age of 94. Lee was predeceased by her husband in 2002 and is survived by her children, Jonathan, Andrew, Elizabeth Quincy Wiesner, and Margaret Sargent, and two grandchildren, Britta Wiesner D'Anna, and Spencer Wiesner.
MONTE--Pat C.,1928-2009. It is four years today that we are without you. You're terribly missed and forever in our hearts. Maryann and Family.

If you’re going to Asia, expect to see that glowing W emblem more often. The hotel chain has just opened a hotel in Guangzhou — its first in mainland China — and plans to open 10 more properties in cities including Shanghai (above), Mumbai and Kuala Lumpur, doubling its footprint in Asia.

An article on March 24 about the Spanish ultrarunner Kilian Jornet Burgada misstated the time it takes for Jornet to run a short, vertical-kilometer mountain race. It is about a half-hour, not two hours.

A March 24 article on preparing a holiday feast misidentified the state from which Cheerwine, a cherry-red soft drink, originates. It is North Carolina, not South Carolina. And an accompanying recipe for braised lamb omitted instructions for three ingredients. An onion, roughly chopped, along with a tablespoon of minced garlic and a tablespoon of minced ginger, are to be included when the dried fruit is added to the pot containing the meat in Step 1. In addition, an accompanying feature transcribed incorrectly a comment from Callie Khouri, creator of the television drama “Nashville,” about what she would put on her Easter playlist. Khouri said she would include music by Pops Staples, the late patriarch of the singing family the Staple Singers. She did not say she would include “pop staples.”

An article last Sunday about efforts to revive the jazz scene in Harlem erroneously included one musician among those who jammed and experimented in the neighborhood in the early 1940s. The musician, John Coltrane, did not arrive in New York until the late 1940s, so he could not have played with musicians like Dizzy Gillespie earlier in the decade.

A little pocket of Los Angeles County tucked into the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains reflects a crucial facet of suburban life. There’s tiny, wealthy Bradbury, a town that prides itself on having one of the richest ZIP codes in Los Angeles, where a house is on the market for $68.8 million. A couple of miles to the east is Azusa. This modest suburb is more than two-thirds Latino, a town of working families whose incomes and home values are a sliver of the wealth nearby.
 
These towns represent extremes of social inequality, but in Los Angeles and other areas, they reflect a defining pattern of contemporary suburban life. Nationwide, rich and poor neighborhoods like these house a growing proportion of Americans, up to 31 percent compared with 15 percent in 1970, according to a recent study by Sean F. Reardon and Kendra Bischoff. Meanwhile, iconic middle-income suburbs are shrinking in numbers and prospects.

SUTTER--Edith Margaret (EM - nee Keppler), on March 17th. Beloved daughter of Rudolph and Emily Muller Keppler, sister of Betty Boucher, aunt of Robin Boucher Benet and her children Celine and Alexander. Cherished friend, world traveler and much accomplished executive. YOUNG--John E. died April 1, 2013 at his home in Manhattan, surrounded by his loving wife Mary and family, of complications from Parkinson's Disease. John was born in 1935 in Tulsa, Oklahoma to Russell E. and Frances Young and grew up in Casper, Wyoming where he was graduated from Natrona County High School in 1952. John went on to receive his undergraduate degree at the California Institute of Technology (CalTech) and law degree magna cum laude in 1959 from Harvard Law School where he was a member of the Law Review. He spent most of the year following graduation from law school traveling the world on a Sheldon Traveling Fellowship from Harvard. Upon his return, John joined the law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore in New York where he became a partner on January 1, 1968 and had a diverse corporate practice, principally in the areas of securities offerings and private financings, both domestic and international. John was a recognized expert in representing underwriters and issuers in public debt and equity offerings, as well as institutional investors in railroad equipment financings. He headed Cravath's Paris office in 1971-1973 and its London office in 1990-1995, when he retired from the Firm. John served as a trustee of the Brearley School and the National Young Arts Foundation and was chairman of the Royal Oak Foundation, the United States arm of the National Trust of England, Wales and Northern Ireland, a conservation foundation, among his many charitable endeavors. John read avidly and widely. He loved travel, classical music and art. In retirement, John took up boating and with his wife Mary and many friends cruised the Erie Canal, the Florida Keys and the Intracoastal Waterway on his boat "Mobius." John was also a life-long progressive, beginning with his support, while a young man, for Adlai Stevenson and ending with his joy at being able to witness the election of Barack Obama. John was an extraordinarily generous man who cared deeply about his friends and family. In addition to his wife of 46 years, Mary, he is survived by his daughter Cynthia Young (George Eberstadt) and her daughters Esme and Maya, his daughter Abigail Young (Jonathan Moses), and her daughters Charlotte and Eleanor, and his sister-in-law Joan Nason. We will miss him deeply. Donations in John's memory may be made to the Mt. Sinai Visiting Doctor's Service, which provided him such compassionate care, or the Metropolitan Museum of Art or Museum of Modern Art, both of which John frequently visited in his later years taking part in their wonderful programs for people suffering from illnesses such as his. A memorial service will take place on Tuesday, April 9 at 11am at The Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan.

For her first designer collaboration, the textile designer Emily Kroll has teamed with the fashion designer Araks Yeramyan to create limited-edition quilts with repurposed materials from the Araks fall/winter 2013 collection. The quilts are an ode to traditional American craftsmanship, made in Sugar Valley, Pa., by Amish artisans who pieced together the panels of hunter-green neoprene, lavender silk and cobalt-blue wool by hand. These Bauhaus-like canvases can be mounted on the wall as a piece of art or simply draped over the bed for a chic night’s sleep. The Araks/Emily Kroll limited-edition quilt is $3,400 and available for pre-order at shop.araks.com . 
 
MALINA JOSEPH GILCHRIST

The Big Deal column on Feb. 17, about the rapid development of the South of Fifth neighborhood in Miami Beach, described incorrectly a 45-acre site in the area at the time it was bought by Thomas Kramer, a German businessman, in the early 1990s. It no longer had a dog track; a kennel and track that were once located there had closed about a decade before. The error was pointed out to the editors only recently.

An article in some editions last Sunday about Serena Williams’s victory over Maria Sharapova in the final of the Sony Open tennis tournament misidentified the opponent and the round of the match in which Williams lost the first set, 2-6, and was trailing, 1-4, in the second. It was against Dominika Cibulkova in the fourth round, not against Li Na in the quarterfinals.

10 P.M. (13) DEFIANT REQUIEM: VOICES OF RESISTANCE (2012) In 1944 a chorus of 60 inmates at the Terezin concentration camp in Czechoslovakia performed Verdi’s Requiem, led by the conductor Raphael Schächter and accompanied by a single piano, for senior Nazi officers and members of the International Red Cross. (Above, a re-enactment of the performance.) The men and women were singing what they dared not say, reimagining the Catholic work’s Latin text — which promises divine judgment against evil — as a condemnation of their captors. This documentary, in honor of Holocaust Remembrance Day, follows the conductor Murry Sidlin as, 60 years later, he realizes his dream of bringing his chorus and orchestra to Terezin to honor Mr. Schächter and others who were imprisoned. 
 
10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK Dan Pfeiffer, a senior adviser to President Obama, appears here and on “Fox News Sunday,” at 10, to discuss topics including tensions on the Korean Peninsula; a disappointing new jobs report; the president’s budget proposal, which includes cuts to Medicare and Social Security; and gun legislation. Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina and a member of the bipartisan Senate group known as the Gang of Eight, which is overseeing immigration legislation, continues the discussion on “Meet the Press,” at 10:30 on NBC. Senators Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and John McCain, Republican of Arizona, hold forth on the same topics on “Face the Nation,” at 10:30 on CBS.

A picture caption on March 24 with an article about the mood of apprehension in Detroit as the city awaited the arrival of a state-appointed emergency manager misidentified the area of the city shown. And because of an editing error, a correction in this space last Sunday misidentified the picture that carried the erroneous caption. The photograph was of several rundown buildings and they were in midtown Detroit, not in downtown; the erroneous caption was not with a picture of a police officer patrolling on horseback. (That was another photograph with the article, and its caption was correct.)

HOLBROOK--Dean. Dearly loved husband and father, Dean Holbrook, passed away on March 28, 2013 at the age of 78. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Christina Flander Holbrook, three children and four grandchildren. A graduate of Princeton University and Yale Law School, he practiced law for 50 years in New York City. An avid runner, he ran over 20 marathons and competed in races into his 70's. He was a member of the Rotary Club and active in several animal welfare organizations. He will be missed by all who knew him. Memorial Service: April 10th, Faith Lutheran Brethren Church, 480 Pleasantville Road., Briarcliff Manor, NY. Greeting at 10:30am, Service at 11:00am.

SCHWAB--Hermann C. Hermann C. Schwab, known as "Gus" to many, died April 1, 2013 peaceably at his apartment in Manhattan at the age of 93 after a full life. Born on January 8, 1920 to Hermann C. and Ruth Bliss Schwab, he is survived by his wife of 58 years, Meteer, his sister Anne Bleeker Corcos, his children Henry Schwab, Lesley Forman, and Margery Weekes from his prior marriage of 12 years to Lesley Ripley, and his children George Schwab and Tatine Kimmick, as well as thirteen grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Sadly he was predeceased by his son Stuart Schwab in 2005. Mr. Schwab graduated from St. Mark's School in 1937 and Yale College in 1941 and served in France during WWII as a second lieutenant. After the war he became a nationally ranked doubles squash player, playing with John Humes until 1969. Mr. Schwab served in several positions at Hanover Bank and then Empire Trust Company from 1946 to 1967. In 1967 he joined the Schroder Trust Company, later becoming an officer and director of Schroder Capital Management and Schroder Capital Funds, and of various Schroder mutual funds. He retired from Schroder in 1998 and was named Director Emeritus. He served as the Mayor of the Village of Oyster Bay Cove from 1973-1985 and village trustee from 1965-1998. He was a trustee of St. Luke's Hospital from 1969-1999, as well as Treasurer for several years, and oversaw (with many others) its successful merger with Roosevelt Hospital in 1979. For his work at St. Luke's Hospital, he was honored with an appointment as a Knight of the Most Venerable Order of the Hospital of St. John of Jerusalem. Mr. Schwab also served as Trustee of Newstead Farm in Upperville, Virginia from 1974 until its dispersal sale in 1985. Newstead Farm was a thoroughbred horse breeding farm which sold its horses at the August Saratoga horse sales and raced its fillies under the tutelage of legendary trainer Woody Stephens. During his tenure, Newstead successfully raced Lareda, a multiple Grade 1 stakes race winner and Miss Oceana, who ran in the Breeders Cup after winning six Grade 1 stakes in two years, finishing as runner up for both American Champion Two-Year-Old Filly and Three-Year-Old Filly in 1983 and 1984. Mr. Schwab was previously a longtime member of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, Piping Rock Club, the Mill Reef Club (Antigua), and the Jester's Club (England); at his death he was a member of the Knickerbocker Club. An avid sailor, he sailed in the Newport to Bermuda race twelve times and on the New York Yacht Club Cruise twenty-one times. He traveled widely with his wife Meteer, both for work and for pleasure. We will remember him for his self-deprecating sense of humor. An avowed Anglophile, he charmed many with stories of his frequent visits to the United Kingdom and his many friends there. A connoisseur of Bordeaux red wine, and a home-schooled chef who loved giving dinner parties with Meteer, he shared his favorites liberally with many friends. A memorial service will be held at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, NY, NY (between 71st and 72nd Street), on April 19 at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Mark's School, Alumni Office, 25 Marlborough Road, Southborough, MA 01772 or St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital, c/o Continuum Health Partners, Inc., Development Department, 555 W. 57th Street, 18th Floor, NY NY 10019.

A roundup review of audiobook mysteries on Nov. 25 misstated the age-appropriateness of “Gun Games,” by Faye Kellerman. Strong language, explicit depictions of sex, and references to drug use and other disturbing themes disqualify the book from being considered in any sense “G-rated,” and in an overwhelming majority of cases, it would not be an appropriate selection for a “good-guy dad who just wants to keep the family from having a meltdown on the endless drive to Disney World.”
