KROLL--Douglas 7/67 4/8/02 Your love and wisdom continue to guide and inspire us. You are in our hearts and in our thoughts every day. Missed and Loved Always - Mom, Pamela, family and friends

WASSERBERGER--Nathan. Born June 24, 1928 in Chrzanow, Poland, died April 23, 2012, in his beloved New York City. He arrived in the US in 1947 as a teenage survivor of Buchenwald and became an award-winning student at the Art Student's League where he studied with Ivan Olinsky and Byron Brown. His luminous paintings of nudes, geishas, clowns, rabbis and ordinary people were sold at the former Park South Gallery in the Carnegie Hall building. They are part of many private collections in the US and Europe. A book of his work was published by Soho gallery-owner Louis Meisel's Eminent Publications. With his beautifully drawn paintings of figures and faces, suffused with light and color, he steered away from the darkness and depravity he experienced as a child. He is survived by his widow, Keiko Miura Wasserberger, nephews and nieces, and many friends, including his former wife, Marleen Nienhuis. He is buried at Mount Hebron Cemetery in Queens where the unveiling of his headstone will take place Sunday, April 7, 2013.

Philadelphia might claim Benjamin Franklin as its own, but I can think of two ways he’s more closely tied to Boston. First, he grew up there. Second, I just spent a weekend in Boston for the value of the bill that bears his portrait.
 
For the latest in my series of $100 weekends (nytimes.com/100dollarweekends has more), I darted from fancy food trucks to old-school pizza joints, took in a morning church service and an evening of neighborhood storytelling, held the Freedom Trail true to its first syllable and connected all the dots via the early-to-bed transit system known as the T. (There’s even an upside to that: in a city where the subway nods off shortly after midnight, entertainment budgets shrink accordingly.)

Free hotel Internet service may be reaching a tipping point. The InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG) is offering free Internet to its 71 million loyalty program members over the next year. Elite members of the IHG Rewards Club will get free Internet access beginning in July when staying at any of the company’s nine hotel brands, including InterContinental Hotels & Resorts, Hotel Indigo, Crowne Plaza, Staybridge Suites and Holiday Inn. The rest of the program’s members will get the free service starting in early 2014.

It may sound ridiculous to declare six better than four or five, but when it comes to playoff seedings in the Eastern Conference, you could certainly make the argument that it would be better to be worse.
 
The imbalance of power between the East and the stronger West in the N.B.A., other than at the top, is still a major factor. But in the East’s field of one favorite, the Miami Heat, the playoff seedings present a chance for teams to make LeBron James and his Heat someone else’s problem. For some teams, including the Nets, that may make losing a few games as the regular season winds down seem awfully appealing.

COLLINS--Louis A. Louis A. Collins, 89, died after a short illness on April 3, 2013. He lived most of his life in and around his beloved New York City. He spent early years in Yonkers; married and fatherhood years in Garden City and Katonah. He graduated from Columbia University in 1946 majoring in English and captivated by the lectures of his teacher Lionel Trilling. He married Eileen (Hellawell) and they had three children: Monica A., L. Andrew, and Edwin H. He worked in publishing and public relations as an early "Mad Man" at the former BBD&O and Donald Degnan & Associates. He spent the later bulk of his career at the New York City Transit Authority as an information officer. He retired to Montauk, NY where he played tennis, attended daily Mass and puttered in his tomato garden. He leaves his three children, their spouses, Leslie (Daman), Anne (Blackwell) and two grandchildren, Kyle and Patrick, sons of L. Andrew and Leslie. Donations in his memory can be made to Tennis Development Program, Columbia University Community Service, 304 Earl Hall, MC2025, NY, NY 10027.

INFANTINO--Carmine, on April 4, 2013. Beloved son of the late Pasquale and Rose. Loving brother of the late Jim Infantino and uncle of James and John. He was a noted comic book artist of the silver age and will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call Wednesday, April 10, 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral private

SISKO--John F.,80, was called home by the Lord on April 5, 2013, after a 15-month struggle with glioblastoma brain cancer. John was born in Brooklyn, NY on August 14, 1932, to Madeline and Frank Sisko. Though he lived in River Vale, NJ for nearly 40 years, he remained a New Yorker at heart. A scholar athlete, John attended St. John's Prep on a baseball scholarship. As a senior, he was recruited by the minor league system of the St. Louis Browns (now Baltimore Orioles). Following his father's sound advice, he declined the offer and continued his education at St. John's University, also with a baseball scholarship. While there, he was a member of the Sigma Rho fraternity and sang in the glee club. After college, John served his country with pride as a member of the occupying forces following the Korean War. He was a First Lieutenant in the United States Marines. Upon returning from active duty, John began graduate school in the field of Education at Brooklyn College. While registering for classes, he met his beloved wife Evelyn of 52 years. After teaching middle school social studies for several years, he took the reins of his uncle's magazine and book distributing business - the perfect post for a voracious reader. John was a gifted storyteller who embodied joie de vivre, warmth and generosity. He owned and bred thoroughbred horses, enjoyed golf, loved vacations in Cape Cod, but most of all he adored his family and friends to whom he was fiercely loyal. Services by Becker Funeral Home, Westwood, NJ, 201-664-0292.

Any visit by the conductor David Robertson brings the promise of adventure, and his engagement this week with the New York Philharmonic will be no exception. Mr. Robertson, the music director of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, is among the world’s most gifted advocates for contemporary composers. He combines the analytical skills of an engineer with the soft-spoken zeal of a Midwestern evangelist; you’re awed by his precision and drawn in by his unassuming charm.
 
 For this visit Mr. Robertson will have a kindred spirit onstage: the pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard, whose brilliant technique and approachable manner parallel the conductor’s. At Avery Fisher Hall, Mr. Robertson and Mr. Aimard will collaborate in Tristan Murail’s “Désenchantement du Monde,” a new concerto partly commissioned by the Philharmonic, and Mozart’s Piano Concerto No. 23. Messiaen’s “Offrandes Oubliées” opens each concert, and Beethoven’s Symphony No. 2 is the closer. (7: 30 p.m. Thursday and 8 p.m., Friday and Saturday, Lincoln Center, 212-875-5656, nyphil.org .)

This week brings the start of the fifth Disappearing Act, a festival of European films that haven’t had much exposure in the United States, and the opening movie reminds us once again that problems that we may have thought of as uniquely American are not.
 
Bullying seems to be on the minds of parents, teachers and policymakers all over the United States, but “Play,” by the Swedish director Ruben Ostlund , shows that it is a concern elsewhere too. In it black youths harass several whites and Asians through intimidation that is more psychological than physical. Touching issues of race and immigration while exploring the bullying phenomenon, the film caused a stir in Sweden. Mr. Ostlund is scheduled to be on hand when it opens the festival on Wednesday at 7 p.m. at the IFC Center (323 Avenue of the Americas, at Third Street, Greenwich Village, ifccenter.com ; $15).

Julius Caesar is expanding his empire again. Once most likely to be found on high school English reading lists, the title character of Shakespeare’s tragedy of pride and politics has been showing up in the darnedest places recently, including two prisons (a real one near Rome in which the Taviani brothers filmed their movie “Caesar Must Die” and the women’s penitentiary in which Phyllida Lloyd set her all-female version at the Donmar Warehouse in London last year). Now he who bestrides the world like a colossus has colonized modern Africa in the Royal Shakespeare Company production of “Julius Caesar,” which opens at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday. 
 
Gregory Doran’s high-adrenaline interpretation, set in a newly formed African dictatorship, is said to seethe most convincingly with portents, prophecies and a convulsive spirit of revolution. Coinciding with the announcement that Mr. Doran would be succeeding Michael Boyd as the artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, last year’s British debut of this volcanic “Caesar” was hailed by critics as a highly favorable auspice for his forthcoming reign. (Through April 28, Harvey Theater, 651 Fulton Street, Fort Greene, 718-636-4100, bam.org .)

HULL--Magda, 101, passed away at her home April 3, 2013. Trained in Berlin and at the Sorbonne in Paris, she was certified as an interpreter. A refugee from Nazi Germany, she worked in 1934 at the Club Heinrich Heine in Paris as a volunteer to help political refugees, married her husband, Max, in 1935, and emigrated with him to the United States in 1937, eternally grateful to her adopted land for the opportunity to begin life again. She was a devoted daughter, who, through force of will and with the help of John Foster Dulles, Congressman Sol Blum, and Averill Harriman, got her parents released from internment camps in Vichy France. Always concerned about those less fortunate, she tutored disadvantaged children, volunteered at the Institute for International Education, worked for Selfhelp aiding Holocaust survivors much younger than she, and annually provided for the transportation of refugees to benefit concerts. Predeceased by her husband, Max, she is survived by her children, Roger H. Hull and Cathy M. Hull, son-in-law Neil Janovic, three grandchildren, Roberto F. Hull, Lincoln M. Hull, and Julie Janovic Brooks, and two great-grandchildren, Victoria and Harrison Brooks. In lieu of flowers, donate to the charity of one's choice. Funeral services will be held April 4th, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel located at 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street at 12:30pm.

O'HERRON--Jonathan. Jonathan O'Herron, of Darien, Connecticut, and Woods Hole Massachusetts, passed away peacefully on April 4, 2013, after a short illness. John was born on October 28, 1929, in Pittsfield, Massachusetts to Helena (nee Coughlin) and S. John O'Herron. He attended the Cranwell School in Lenox Massachusetts as a day student, then graduated from Williams College in 1951. He later attended Harvard Business School, where he received his MBA in 1957. After college, Jonathan served briefly in the U.S. Navy, achieving the rank of Lieutenant JG. His professional career began at General Electric Company, followed by Buckeye Pipe Line Company where he rose to Executive Vice President. Crucial to his business career was his short time spent as Treasurer of Buckeye's parent company, the Penn Central Transportation Company. He moved to the position at the behest of Felix Rohatyn of Lazard Freres & Co., as Lazard led Penn Central through its well known 1970 bankruptcy. Hired by Lazard soon thereafter, John's business career is most remembered for his investment banking work there over forty years, most of the time as a Partner and Managing Director, positions that he never officially retired from. At Lazard, in addition to being involved in dozens of noteworthy mergers, acquisitions, and financings, he was known for always finding the time to serve as a mentor to many future investment bankers. He constantly stressed to them the importance of balancing work with their family life. His character stood out in the business community where he was held in universal high regard for his integrity, and his modest "salt of the earth" personality. His family, along with his many friends, were his greatest devotion. He was never happier than playing golf or dining with them at Woodway Country Club, in Connecticut or Woods Hole Golf Club on Cape Cod. Also, Jonathan was deeply committed to his faith and to giving to others who were less fortunate than he. Although his free time was scarce, his participation with the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York went beyond his formal role as Trustee and Chair of the Finance Committee. According to Executive Director Monsignor Kevin Sullivan, "In addition to everything else, we loved John for his asking time and time again, what more was there that he could do." John was a Trustee of the American Red Cross in Greater New York, Kolbe Cathedral High School in Bridgeport, CT, New York Medical College, St. Joseph Medical Center in Stamford CT, and the Inner-City Scholarship Fund of the Archdiocese of New York. He was also an integral member of The National Leadership Roundtable on Church Management. He was made a Knight of St. Gregory by Pope John Paul II in 2004. John also spent considerable time supporting education. He established two scholarship funds at Williams College (one under his mother's name) and a scholarship fund at Fordham University, where Shirley had been a Trustee. He spent 15 years as a Trustee, then as a Trustee Emeritus of Middlebury College, where he was secretly a supporter of the athletic teams, rivals to Williams. He and his family recently launched a new internship program for Middlebury students who commit to doing service for others. Also, out of deep gratitude for his children's and grandchildren's time at St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire, he established a scholarship fund and was a Trustee there for nine years. John is survived by his son Jonathan O'Herron Jr., his daughters Anne Burleigh (Jon Burleigh) and Sarah Casey (C. Alec Casey), 11 adoring and adored grandchildren, and his brother William J. O'Herron. John's wife of 48 years, Shirley, predeceased him in 2004. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held privately at St. John's Church in Darien, followed by interment at Spring Grove Cemetery. A Memorial Mass will be held at 11am on Wednesday, April 10 at St. Thomas More Church, 374 Middlesex Rd, Darien. The Rev. Gerald Blaszczak S.J. will officiate. In lieu of flowers, the family is asking that donations be made to: The O'Herron Family Foundation, PO Box 4816, Stamford, CT 06907.

An article last Sunday about the new version of the horror movie “Evil Dead” misidentified the actor who will star in the remake of the 1980 slasher film “Maniac.” He is Elijah Wood, not Daniel Radcliffe. Guitar Heaven may be more a state of mind than an actual location, but it has precise coordinates Friday and next Saturday: Madison Square Garden, home to the third iteration of Eric Clapton’s Crossroads Guitar Festival. This benefit for the Crossroads Center, a rehabilitation facility established by Mr. Clapton in Antigua, will feature an imposing assemblage of elite guitarists, many hailing from the blues and blues-rock terrain that he calls home: B. B. King and Buddy Guy, Jeff Beck and Robert Cray, John Mayer and Jonny Lang. 
 
But there will also be emissaries from the lands of country (Vince Gill, Keith Urban), gospel (Robert Randolph), indie-folk (Citizen Cope), even jazz (John Scofield, Kurt Rosenwinkel, Earl Klugh). The Allman Brothers will be there, as will Los Lobos — and, taking what amounts to a victory lap, Gary Clark Jr., whose definitive breakout took place during the festival’s 2010 edition. Naturally, to ensure that any mortal can entertain visions of guitar-god stature, the arena will be crowded with interactive kiosks sponsored by the likes of Gibson and Fender. (7:30 p.m., $75 to $300; crossroadsguitarfestival.com .)

A duplex penthouse distinguished by a pair of romantic Moorish-style arched brick terraces near the top of the Barbizon/63, at 140 East 63rd Street, sold for $10,182,500 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.
 
The condominium, PH2, had boomeranged on and off the market since 2007, when its initial asking price was $12.5 million, and despite a brief stint as a $35,000-a-month rental, it has never been lived in. The most recent listing price of the unit, which shares the 17th and 18th floors of the Barbizon with PH1, a similar terraced duplex bought by the Italian jeweler Nicola Bulgari, was $10.75 million.

Next up in the Metropolitan section’s Q. and A. series with New Yorkers who have behind-the-scenes jobs that keep the city running is Robert Sanft, the chief executive of the Office of Student Enrollment in the city’s Education Department. 
 
Mr. Sanft and his team oversee the limited number of prekindergarten spots, gifted-and-talented admissions and the high school matching process, placing tens of thousands of students a year.

In spring 1939 Gilbert Kraus, a lawyer in Philadelphia, bid farewell to his wife, Eleanor, and their son and daughter and set sail for Nazi Germany. His plan: to save 50 Jewish children on the eve of the Holocaust by bringing them back home for safekeeping — the largest kindertransport to the United States.
 
“This is really crazy,” Eleanor replied when Gilbert first described his scheme. “I’d be too scared to put a foot in that country, assuming the storm troopers would even let me in.”

MYITKYINA, MYANMAR — When residents of this northernmost region of Myanmar talk about the tremendous changes of the past two years, they are not referring to the media freedoms or the economic liberalization transforming other parts of the country.
 
They mean the radicalization of the Kachin ethnic group, whose members inhabit the foothills of the Himalayas near the borders with China and India and have become more militant than at any time in living memory, Kachin leaders say.

In the wake of horrible family rows, short of leaving my father, my mother would do something that shook the foundations of my childhood. She would step into our living room and, spurred by rage, spite and last-ditch efforts to restore order in her life, she would single-handedly move all the furniture around. The sofa was relegated to the place held by an imposing bookcase. The bookcase would be shunted over to a corner that belonged to an unassuming cabinet, now demoted to another corner where it sat in the dark under the terrified gaze of two leather armchairs squatting in the maelstrom.
 
To the outside world my mother was furiously rearranging furniture. To those who knew better she was trying to take control and putting a new face to her life. Since she couldn’t change much of anything and had no intention of buying new furniture, perhaps she was just trying to give her life a new look. It was madness, but it taught me that if changing the layout of your problems doesn’t necessarily solve them, it does make living with them easier. It also taught me that what came in the wake of any change, however terrifying, couldn’t have been more thrilling.

Ground Cover Over several chilly days in late March, the photographer Benjamin Lowy set out to walk across Brooklyn to document the change in seasons. Starting out in Dumbo, Lowy made his way to Vinegar Hill, Williamsburg and Greenpoint, then down to Fort Greene, Prospect Heights, Park Slope, Gowanus and Windsor Terrace, winding back through Ditmas Park and Prospect Lefferts Gardens. “And then I had to split all the blisters on my feet,” he said. We asked Lowy to create pictures that showed the intersection between the urban and natural world — images that were a lot easier to find on foot, he explained, “because sometimes you just see things.”

The small town of Connersville, Ind., has closed the books on the Carbon Motors Corporation, an Indiana start-up that had moved to town in 2009 to manufacture and sell police vehicles, but was turned down last year for an Energy Department loan.
 
“I assume that they are done here,” Mayor Leonard Urban of Connersville said Wednesday morning in a telephone interview. He said the company’s lease with the town on a 1.8-million-square-foot building had expired on Sunday, and Carbon employees had packed up last month.

“When we smell a perfume, it gives us images in our heads, like a landscape or a scene,” said Céline Verleure, a 20-year fragrance industry veteran based in Paris. A few years ago, she decided to explore this relationship further by asking perfumers to collaborate with photographers on a series of eau de parfums inspired by the visual artists’ works. Thus, Olfactive Studio was born, and this French brand’s five highly concentrated unisex scents arrive in the United States on Monday.
 
Her current favorite in the lot is Lumière Blanche, a milky yet fresh and spicy scent from Sidonie Lancesseur, who was inspired by Massimo Vitali’s photo of sunbathers on the ivory-hued Scala dei Turchi cliff in southern Sicily (pictured). To experience the link between the visual and olfactory

When Rockefeller Center opened in 1939 after a decade of construction, it was not received with the glory we shower on it now. Newspapers were filled with letters calling it one of the ugliest complexes in the city. The building of what today is considered one of the crown jewels of the Manhattan skyline is a saga of big money, intriguing power brokers and one of the most glamorous periods in the city’s history. 
 
The story is told artfully and addictively in Daniel Okrent’s “Great Fortune: The Epic of Rockefeller Center,” a Pulitzer Prize finalist for history in 2004. Join us for an online discussion with Mr. Okrent and the novelist and culture critic Kurt Andersen, author of the best-selling novel “Heyday” and most recently “True Believers.”

A news analysis article last Sunday about detained immigrants’ right to counsel misspelled the surname of a legal policy analyst for the Center for Immigration Studies, a research organization that advocates for reduced immigration. He is Jon Feere , not Freere.

Critics say that the painter John Singer Sargent owned a world-class talent but made bad decisions about what to do with it. Even so, for sheer technical bravura, his work is wonderful to behold, whether in oil or in watercolor, in which he was as skilled if not as soulful as Winslow Homer. For Sargent fans “John Singer Sargent Watercolors,” at the Brooklyn Museum, should be like heaven. The exhibition brings together 93 of his watercolors and 9 oil paintings from the Brooklyn Museum and the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. Both institutions acquired significant quantities of his work early on, the Brooklyn Museum from Sargent’s career debut show in New York in 1909 and the Boston museum from a solo show there in 1912. 
 
The beauty of Sargent’s watercolors is in how seemingly effortlessly yet exactly he captured outdoor light and complicated man-made and natural forms. In landscapes, close studies of fruit and flowers and portraits of women you see at once the supremely deft action of the brush and the illusions of a sun-drenched halcyon world that it conjures. Prepare for bedazzlement. (Through July 28, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park; 718-638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org .)

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Dorrie Sibley’s reason for bringing her son Breslin, 16, to learn how to drive a car equipped with a manual transmission, a so-called stick shift, had nothing to do with the reason the instructional event was being held. But it was a very good reason nonetheless.
 
“He might be out with a drunk friend one day,” Ms. Sibley said.

In last Sunday’s Metropolitan section, Kia Gregory profiled three businessmen with competing projects and the same dream: reopening a historic jazz club in Harlem. Reader comments from nytimes.com , some of them condensed, are below.

It takes a lot of nerve to start a dance company in New York. There’s no money for young artists, and rehearsal space is expensive. But groups do emerge, full of energy and creativity. Such is Summation Dance , formed by Sumi Clements and Taryn Vander Hoop, graduates of New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts. Ms. Clements, the main choreographer, has a fiercely physical style and wears her heart on her sleeve but has mature command of pattern and form. 
 
For its season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Fishman Space , Summation offers two new pieces, “Pathological Parenthetical Pageantry” and “New Work,” to a score by Kyle Olson of Minneapolis. Publicity materials offer some descriptions of the dances (“Pathological” is “rife with obsession, love, hate and fear”; “New Work” “questions perceptions of reality”). But don’t worry about that. Go see the dancing. (8 p.m. Thursday to Saturday, 321 Ashland Place, Fort Greene, summationdance.org ; $25.)

OVERHOLSER--Charles E.,age 87, formerly of Mamaroneck, died at his home in Kennett Square, PA on April 2, 2013. Following service during WWII in the U.S. Navy he graduated magna cum laude with the Harvard Class of 1947. He had a distinguished career as Director of Research and Strategic Planning at Young & Rubicam and at Kenyon & Eckhardt, and was past President of the Market Research Council, served as a Director of the Advertising Research Foundation and on the Research Committee of the Association of Advertising Agencies, and was a member of the American Marketing Association and the Harvard Club of New York City. His many interests included chamber music and jazz, birding, politics, and the New York Giants. Survivors include his wife Renee (nee Value), son Charles E. and wife Barbara (nee Rosenthal), daughter Margaret V. and husband Charles Patrick Fox, and son George M. and partner Carla Brodley, and by three grandchildren, Christopher R., Jesse M., and Matthew E. Overholser. Memorial service at Crosslands, Kennett Square, on Sunday, April 21 at 3 pm. For those who wish, contributions to Neighborhood Hospice, nvnacc.com.

ROGATO--Charlotte Marie, Born November 15, 1940, died April 4, 2013. Survived by her husband, Jim Talleos, sister, Marilyn Benson, sisters-in-law, Alexandra Gikas and Margaret Rouskas, brothers-in-law Gus Talleos, Chris Talleos, and many friends and 40 nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. Volunteer work played a large role in Charlotte's life, from helping newcomers to San Francisco to preparing tax returns for low-income taxpayers in New York. Charlotte always said she led a lucky life. She survived near-fatal illnesses at ages 30, 51, and 64. As she said, she never expected to reach 50, let alone qualify for Medicare! Charlotte lived in San Francisco for 15 years, and she and Jim met there in 1967. After Jim's return to New York a year later, they stayed in touch. Little did she know how her family would expand after her move to New York in 1977. Both West Coast and East Coast families and friends brought much joy and laughter into her life. And it was Jim whose wit brought the most laughter. They married in 1992. In 1999, Charlotte and Jim spent a week in Ash with eight other Americans. When she made a pew cushion for the church, she embroidered the names of the Americans on the cushion. It was presented to the church on Easter Sunday 2001; that day was also Greek Easter and was an especially joyous one for Charlotte. Beginning in 1999, she honored her mother's memory with a scholarship at her California high school. She also led the efforts to create the school's alumni scholarship, reaching alumni through the Internet "Charlotte's Web," indeed. Charlotte always enjoyed walks through Wave Hill and told Jim that it was the last place she wanted to see. Donations in her memory may be sent to: Wave Hill, 675 West 252nd Street Bronx, NY 10471-2899. To take a tour, go to www.wavehill.com. Shechose not to have a funeral service. She wanted all family and friends toremember her as she lived.

Ambra Medda, a founder of the Design Miami fairs, has a new gig: Web entrepreneur. Next month, Ms. Medda and her business partner, Oliver Weyergraf, will unveil L’ArcoBaleno (Italian for “The Rainbow”), which bills itself as “a content and marketplace site devoted to collectible design.”
 
The site, at larcobaleno.com , will feature content like designer interviews, travel stories and videos, among other things. On the e-commerce side, through its “presenting galleries,” like Galerie Kreo, Demisch Danant and Galerie Patrick Seguin, users will be able to buy blue-chip design, ranging from 20th-century classics like one of Jean Prouvé’s prefab houses to works by emerging designers like Jean-Baptiste Fastrez (whose Dogon mirror is shown here).

. . . going behind the counter at the vegan joint that portends the fast-food industry's future (Page 26), eavesdropping on a butcher who thinks we don’t eat enough pig’s head (Page 36),peering into the kitchen when the cook learns a fire broke out (Page 34), braving a bar in the Australian outback (Page 40) and figuring out just how many people it takes to run a celebrity chef’s Harlem restaurant (Page 48). Powerful beliefs about both have led a winemaker to search for the perfectly imperfect gewürtztraminer (Page 42) and have turned a tiny German town into the world’s most unlikely culinary capital (Page 50). But they’ve got nothing on a guy who sells 41 spice blends for 12 hours a week on 11th Avenue (Page 64).

Not much has changed for Kurt Warner as he goes from Super Bowl champion to host of a USA reality series, “The Moment,” in which contestants get a shot at their dream gigs. But now he reviews his performance with his wife, Brenda, instead of a coach. “She’s always telling me, ‘Don’t use your hands so much,’ ” he says. “I’ll try to work on that, and then on ‘The Moment,’ they’ll say, ‘Go ahead and use your hands more.’ I’m trying to find the balance, because I have big hands and I’m a big guy.”
An article in some editions last Sunday about the University of Florida basketball player Mike Rosario misstated the given name of a senior guard for the Gators. He is Kenny Boynton, not Mike.

An obituary last Sunday about the Motown songwriter and producer Deke Richards referred incorrectly at one point to the founder of Motown, Berry Gordy Jr. As the obituary correctly noted elsewhere, he is Mr. Gordy — not, of course, “Mr. Berry.”

The European Commission has recently proposed a number of measures that would strengthen the rights that passengers have while flying in the European Union. The rules would ensure that travelers have better information, treatment and rerouting assistance. One measure, for example, would give passengers whose flights have been rescheduled by their carrier less than two weeks before their original departure the same benefits as people whose flights were canceled or delayed. The proposals require approval by the European Parliament and member states before becoming law, a process that normally takes 18 months.

BEAUJOUR--Michel. The French Department and the Center for French Civilization and Culture of New York University are deeply saddened by the death of our longtime colleague and friend, Professor Michel Beaujour, one of the most eminent figures in the field of French literature. In his 46 years in our department, Michel played a key role in bringing it to the nation's top rungs, and by co-founding our innovative Institute of French Studies, he helped open new directions for the study of French. His wise counsel, usually dosed with irony and wit, helped carry us forward and upward. No one worked harder with students and no professor was more appreciated by them than he. In recent years, his great academic contributions were complemented by his most generous support for fellowships. Michel Beaujour cannot be replaced in our department but his spirit and his intellectual legacy will remain with us. Our heartfelt condolences go to his dear wife, Elizabeth, to his son and daughter-in-law, Thomas and Maria McKenna, and to his family in France.

CHAMBERLAIN--Mariam K.,a driving force behind the development of women's research and studies, died April 2, 2013 just short of her 95th birthday. Founding President and Resident Scholar at the National Council for Research on Women at the time of her death, she began her career at the OSS during WWII. She received her PhD in economics from Harvard, served as program officer at the Ford Foundation where she funded the nascent academic women's movement, and continued during her long career to support feminist scholars and institutions. She is survived and honored by her niece, nephew, great- nephews, and a wide circle of friends and colleagues. She will be deeply missed.

DRENCH--Daniel, 91, of Verona, NJ, passed away on April 5, 2013 Born in the Bronx in 1921, Dan graduated from CCNY in 1943, and served in World War II ('43- 45) with the 104th Infantry Division. He founded Artisan Electronics Corporation, based in Parsippany, NJ, and was a leader in the New Jersey Jewish community. He was a mentor and friend to many, and was a proud husband, father, grandfather, and great-grandfather.

GRIMM--John E. "Jack" III, 90, a retired business executive, died peacefully at his home in North Palm Beach, FL, on March 31, 2013 with his loving wife, Ann R. Grimm, and his beloved dog Lily by his side. He is also survived by a sister, Nan M Freeman. He was preceded in death by brothers, C. Peter Grimm and Robert D. Grimm. He was a loving uncle to Carl H. Grimm, N. Ellen Eifert, Laurie Steelsmith, Susan Wilmot, John Moorhead, James Moorhead, Dean Grimm, Tana Aurland, Tara Grimm, Jill Aurland., and many great nephews and great nieces. Jack was born July 7, 1922 in Dayton, OH to Helen Aurland Grimm and John E Grimm, Jr. His family moved to the New York area where he attended Scarsdale High School. Jack graduated from Dartmouth College in 1944, and The Amos Tuck School of Business. He attended Midshipman School at Northwestern University, Chicago and served in the U.S. Navy as Navigator, First Lieutenant, and Executive Officer, from 1942 to 1946. After his naval service, Jack began his career in the training program at Macy's. Later, he had the idea to make a recording of General Douglas Macarthur's' speech to Congress with the oft quoted phrase, "Old soldiers never die, they just fade away". He sold the record to department stores, including Macy's. The recording became the largest selling record for a two-day period, in Macy's history. Life Magazine ran a feature article with the headline, "Amateur Scoops Record Industry". With this success, he was hired by Lever Brothers and then by Sterling Drug, becoming a corporate vice president. In 1961, he accepted a position as a corporate vice president at the Colgate-Palmolive Co. where he worked for 24 years, retiring in 1984. In 1985 he founded Midbrook, Inc., a business consulting firm. He resided in Southampton, NY, and had been a resident of New York City for over 50 years. He was a member of Gypsy Trail Club in Carmel, NY, The Meadow Club and Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, Southampton, NY, The Racquet and Tennis Club in New York City, and The Lost Tree Club in North Palm Beach, FL. Jack was active in business and philanthropic endeavors, serving as President and Chairman of Madison Square Boys and Girls Club of New York City, Vice President of the Board, and Vice Chairman of the Executive Committee of The Southampton Hospital, and a former member of the Skin Cancer Foundation Board. He also co-authored "My One Big Break", a book of inspiring stories of successful business and professional leaders. Jack was an avid golfer and tennis player and was considered by all who knew him as true gentleman. Above all, Jack shared his life with an incredible group of loyal friends. Funeral Services will be private. A celebration of Jack's life will be held at a later date. The family asks that remembrances in Jack's name be made to the Madison Square Boys and Girls Club of New York City, or The Southampton Hospital, Southampton, NY.

JOHNSON--Barbara Piasecka, a humanitarian, philanthropist, and collector of fine art. Following a long and complicated illness, Mrs. Barbara Piasecka Johnson passed away on April 1, 2013. A long-time resident of the Principality of Monaco, Mrs. Barbara Piasecka Johnson was born in Staniewicze, Poland in 1937. Having obtained the Bachelor-cum-Master of Arts degree in art history from the University of Wroclaw, she immigrated to the United States via Rome in 1968. In 1971, Barbara Piasecka married J. Seward Johnson, Sr., son of the founder of Johnson & Johnson. Throughout her life, Mrs. Johnson continued her numerous charitable, philanthropic, art-related, and business activities in which she was always deeply and personally involved. Among others, in 1990, she offered to make a multimillion dollar investment in the financially troubled Gdansk Shipyard, the birthplace of Solidarity. The largest public exhibition of her art that Mrs. Johnson organized, Opus Sacrum, was staged at the Royal Castle of Warsaw, Poland in 1990 and in Liechtenstein in 1991. Currently, a selection of paintings and other objects from Mrs. Johnson's Collection is on display at the Musee de la Chapelle de la Visitation in Monaco as well as at the National Museum of Poland in Poznan. By special arrangement, selected paintings are on occasion loaned to museums worldwide. Mrs. Johnson conducted her charitable activities through the Barbara Piasecka Johnson Foundation, which was established in 1974. The Foundation reaches out to the needy worldwide, however, since Mrs. Johnson's native Poland was always very close to her heart, The Foundation--in a large measure-- assists students and professionals from Poland in continuing their studies in the United States. Over the years, Mrs. Johnson also extended significant support to the Solidarity movement, the victims of martial law in Poland, various nursing homes, homes for single mothers, selected health care facilities, and a number of other important humanitarian projects. Mrs. Johnson always emphasized that she assisted the weak, the sick, and the poor simply because they needed help, and she was in the position to offer them a helping hand. For her selfless charitable work Mrs. Johnson's was recognized with many prestigious awards. During the last years of her life, Mrs. Johnson focused on a program of assistance to children and young adults with autism. Mrs. Johnson donated to the Foundation her extensive collection of paintings by Polish masters and other works of art, with all proceeds from its sale being designated to finance a long-range program to increase awareness and understanding of autism and to create a center of excellence in early autism intervention in Poland that will give autistic children the chance for normal lives. As part of this mission, the Foundation established The Institute for Child Development (Instytut Wspomagania Rozwoju Dziecka) in Gdansk, Poland (www.iwrd.pl)--a non-profit organization, which now offers world-class science-based therapy to children with autism and assistance to their families, conducts scientific studies of autism therapy, and offers training for professionals specializing in autism. The Institute is modeled on and closely cooperates with the Princeton Child Development Institute in the United States, a world leader in the field. She was an amazing woman and a genuinely remarkable human being who will be sorely missed by her family and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Barbara Piasecka Johnson Foundation can be sent to 4519 Province Line Road, Princeton, NJ 08540, USA.

Angry Birds, the popular video game that involves catapulting birds at fortresses constructed by enemy pigs, now has a greater purpose than killing time at the checkout line. It’s the subject of a 4,485-square-foot exhibit at the Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex in Florida that is meant to teach children physics.
 
Though Angry Birds has inspired theme-park attractions like the one at Sarkanniemi Adventure Park in Tampere, Finland, the Kennedy Center exhibition, which opened last month, is the first attempt to extract some educational value out of the seemingly mindless game. “Angry Birds Space Encounter,” above, a collaboration between NASA and the game’s creator, Rovio Entertainment, features six interactive stations, including a laser-beam obstacle course set on the Red Planet and Eggsteroid slingshots that children can use to launch birds at evil pigs. Which, of course, is a lesson about parabolic trajectories.

Guan Tianlang of China, the reigning champion of a competition conceived by Augusta National in 2008 to develop amateur golfers, will bring his budding game there for the Masters this week.

A judge on Tuesday will decide whether to grant the N.F.L.’s request to dismiss more than 200 cases filed by more than 4,000 former players who claim the league hid information about the dangers of head trauma.
Storm runoff is the primary source of water pollution in Southern California, but cities are being encouraged to capture rainwater to bolster groundwater supplies.
Clergymen from the developing world are increasingly settling in France, where the number of Catholic priests is declining and the hope is that the new priests will energize the church.

An administrative judge ruled that the Justice Department had violated its own procedures when it suspended Joseph Bottini and James Goeke for their conduct in the corruption trial against Senator Ted Stevens.
Notorious for flubbing acquisitions, Yahoo has bought six small companies under Marissa Mayer in an attempt to cultivate innovative engineers and technologies.
The Rev. Matt Malone, editor of the Jesuit weekly America, argues that some of the world’s problems can be solved only through “radical love and forgiveness.”
A big part of what Roger Ebert left behind was a remarkable template for how a lone journalist can become something much more.
When shoppers buy two Clarins items at Macy’s, Clarins will donate $1 to an antihunger group, the equivalent of paying for 10 school meals.
Reports include retail sales for March; and Alcoa, JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo are among the companies set to release quarterly earnings.
Daybees lets people fine-tune searches for things to do, using keywords, location or time and date.
Beyoncé and Jay-Z spent part of last week in Havana, celebrating their fifth wedding anniversary.
Mark Whitaker will write a biography of Bill Cosby, to be published by Simon & Schuster in the fall of 2014.
The publisher Other Criteria will issue a comprehensive catalog of the paintings this spring.
Star D.J.’s have been defecting from Pacha, a decades-old disco on Ibiza, as the hedonistic party scene shifts to places like Las Vegas.
Seeing Robert Lepage’s production of “Das Rheingold” at the Met and Elina Garanca in concert at Carnegie Hall on the same day showed that both need to get beyond superficial expression.
C. C. Sabathia, who allowed four earned runs in five innings in his opening day start last week, rebounded with a strong performance.
Daniele Gatti led the Boston Symphony Orchestra in musical works close to the heart of James Levine, the former music director, whose position remains unfilled.
The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.

In his first trip to Europe as Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew will try to persuade finance ministers of other nations to pursue more growth and less austerity.

Tensions on the Korea peninsula remain high with a spokesman in Seoul saying the South expected a missile launch later this week.

An article on Thursday about the power struggle that is gripping Iran ahead of the presidential election in June misstated the number of months before the end of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s second and last term in office. It is four months, not three. (His successor will take office in August.)

NAHMIAS--Julius, 88 years young on April 6, 2013. Loving husband to his late wife Marilyn. Beloved father to Marcia (Michael) Turletsky and Jeffrey (Sandy) Nahmias. Cherished grandfather to Jason, Elissa and Ilana. He was an incredible man who will live in our hearts and minds forever. Graveside service, Monday at 11:30am, Wellwood Cemetery. Services entrusted to: Star of David Memorial Chapel, 631-454-9600. Online at: jewish-funeral-home.com.

Several late-night TV hosts have recently been in the news, including Conan O’Brien, who signed a contract extension with TBS through November 2015, and Jimmy Fallon, whose succession of Jay Leno on “The Tonight Show” was announced last week.
 
The share of visits to a talk show’s site is affected by its popularity and what it offers ardent viewers. Jon Stewart, above, frequently continues interviews beyond “The Daily Show’s” 30-minute mark and posts them online. Fans are also going online to follow “Nightline,” which has moved to a 12:35 a.m. time slot. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Every Friday evening over NBC radio airwaves – or short-wave overseas – homesick troops during World War II were told to “drop in at the canteen” for comforting chat and songs by a pretty, young actress named Phyllis Jeanne Creore. 
 
“Here is your Canteen girl, Phyllis Jeanne,” a voice would say, and then Ms. Creore’s tender voice would croon the comforting lyrics to her signature (and self-written) song “This is My Wish.”

An article on March 11 about Saudi Arabia’s consideration of firing squads as an alternative means of execution to public beheadings referred incompletely to the Saudi legal system. Saudi Arabia, which has no constitution, follows an interpretation of Islamic law that is based on the Koran and on the Sunna, not just the Koran.

BEAUJOUR--Michel. The French Department and the Center for French Civilization and Culture of New York University are deeply saddened by the death of our longtime colleague and friend, Professor Michel Beaujour, one of the most eminent figures in the field of French literature. In his 46 years in our department, Michel played a key role in bringing it to the nation's top rungs, and by co-founding our innovative Institute of French Studies, he helped open new directions for the study of French. His wise counsel, usually dosed with irony and wit, helped carry us forward and upward. No one worked harder with students and no professor was more appreciated by them than he. In recent years, his great academic contributions were complemented by his most generous support for fellowships. Michel Beaujour cannot be replaced in our department but his spirit and his intellectual legacy will remain with us. Our heartfelt condolences go to his dear wife, Elizabeth, to his son and daughter-in-law, Thomas and Maria McKenna, and to his family in France.

COLLINS--Louis A. Louis A. Collins, 89, died after a short illness on April 3, 2013. He lived most of his life in and around his beloved New York City. He spent early years in Yonkers; married and fatherhood years in Garden City and Katonah. He graduated from Columbia University in 1946 majoring in English and captivated by the lectures of his teacher Lionel Trilling. He married Eileen (Hellawell) and they had three children: Monica A., L. Andrew, and Edwin H. He worked in publishing and public relations as an early "Mad Man" at the former BBD&O and Donald Degnan & Associates. He spent the later bulk of his career at the New York City Transit Authority as an information officer. He retired to Montauk, NY where he played tennis, attended daily Mass and puttered in his tomato garden. He leaves his three children, their spouses, Leslie (Daman), Anne (Blackwell) and two grandchildren, Kyle and Patrick, sons of L. Andrew and Leslie. Donations in his memory can be made to Tennis Development Program, Columbia University Community Service, 304 Earl Hall, MC2025, NY, NY 10027.

O'HERRON--Jonathan. Jonathan O'Herron, of Darien, Connecticut, and Woods Hole Massachusetts, passed away peacefully on April 4, 2013, after a short illness. John was born on October 28, 1929, in Pittsfield, Massachusetts to Helena (nee Coughlin) and S. John O'Herron. He attended the Cranwell School in Lenox Massachusetts as a day student, then graduated from Williams College in 1951. He later attended Harvard Business School, where he received his MBA in 1957. After college, Jonathan served briefly in the U.S. Navy, achieving the rank of Lieutenant JG. His professional career began at General Electric Company, followed by Buckeye Pipe Line Company where he rose to Executive Vice President. Crucial to his business career was his short time spent as Treasurer of Buckeye's parent company, the Penn Central Transportation Company. He moved to the position at the behest of Felix Rohatyn of Lazard Freres & Co., as Lazard led Penn Central through its well known 1970 bankruptcy. Hired by Lazard soon thereafter, John's business career is most remembered for his investment banking work there over forty years, most of the time as a Partner and Managing Director, positions that he never officially retired from. At Lazard, in addition to being involved in dozens of noteworthy mergers, acquisitions, and financings, he was known for always finding the time to serve as a mentor to many future investment bankers. He constantly stressed to them the importance of balancing work with their family life. His character stood out in the business community where he was held in universal high regard for his integrity, and his modest "salt of the earth" personality. His family, along with his many friends, were his greatest devotion. He was never happier than playing golf or dining with them at Woodway Country Club, in Connecticut or Woods Hole Golf Club on Cape Cod. Also, Jonathan was deeply committed to his faith and to giving to others who were less fortunate than he. Although his free time was scarce, his participation with the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York went beyond his formal role as Trustee and Chair of the Finance Committee. According to Executive Director Monsignor Kevin Sullivan, "In addition to everything else, we loved John for his asking time and time again, what more was there that he could do." John was a Trustee of the American Red Cross in Greater New York, Kolbe Cathedral High School in Bridgeport, CT, New York Medical College, St. Joseph Medical Center in Stamford CT, and the Inner-City Scholarship Fund of the Archdiocese of New York. He was also an integral member of The National Leadership Roundtable on Church Management. He was made a Knight of St. Gregory by Pope John Paul II in 2004. John also spent considerable time supporting education. He established two scholarship funds at Williams College (one under his mother's name) and a scholarship fund at Fordham University, where Shirley had been a Trustee. He spent 15 years as a Trustee, then as a Trustee Emeritus of Middlebury College, where he was secretly a supporter of the athletic teams, rivals to Williams. He and his family recently launched a new internship program for Middlebury students who commit to doing service for others. Also, out of deep gratitude for his children's and grandchildren's time at St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire, he established a scholarship fund and was a Trustee there for nine years. John is survived by his son Jonathan O'Herron Jr., his daughters Anne Burleigh (Jon Burleigh) and Sarah Casey (C. Alec Casey), 11 adoring and adored grandchildren, and his brother William J. O'Herron. John's wife of 48 years, Shirley, predeceased him in 2004. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held privately at St. John's Church in Darien, followed by interment at Spring Grove Cemetery. A Memorial Mass will be held at 11am on Wednesday, April 10 at St. Thomas More Church, 374 Middlesex Rd, Darien. The Rev. Gerald Blaszczak S.J. will officiate. In lieu of flowers, the family is asking that donations be made to: The O'Herron Family Foundation, PO Box 4816, Stamford, CT 06907.

PRICE--Selma Kaplan, Price Rahav Realty has lost its founder and its beacon of fast and brilliant business thinking, Selma K. Price. Through her guidance and generosity, Selma K. Price allowed the growth of our company, never ever forgetting, not even for one second her humble roots, and her strict, uncompromising rules of right from wrong, and allowable versus forbidden. Rest in peace you beautiful soul.

I’m standing with my back to the doors on a crowded uptown A train from Canal Street to Pennsylvania Station. Sitting to my left is a woman with Chinese takeout having lunch. To my right is her friend, separated by a number of bodies.

MARIANI--Ray, on April 6, 2013. Builder and developer in the New York Metropolitan Area, especially in the Throgs Neck Area of The Bronx. Beloved husband of Mary (nee Lepre). Devoted father of Paul, Linda Ramunto and Lisa Kosits-Matamoros. Dearest brother of Michael, Raymond Jr. and the late John. Loving grandfather of Kristen, Dana, Lauren and Andrea. Reposing Sisto Funeral Home, 3489 E. Tremont Avenue, Bronx, NY 10465 on Monday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10am St. Frances de Chantal Church. Entombment Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY.

ZAMBELLO--Jean Sincere, also known as Sinny, a theater, TV and film actress, died of natural causes on April 3, 2013 in Los Angeles, after a brief illness. Born in Mt. Vernon, NY on August 16, 1919, Jean was dedicated to her art from an early age and made her Broadway debut in Arsenic and Old Lace in 1941. She then served in USO during World War II and worked in the theater the rest of her life. Married in 1949 to the late Charles Carmine Zambello, Jean is survived by her daughter, opera and theater director Francesca Zambello, of New York; her son, art and antique dealer, Larry Zambello, of New Mexico; and her grandson Gabriel. Jean, a vivacious and enthusiastic lover of life, theater, opera and travel, was a devout Christian Scientist. Known for her bright red hair and her funny nature, Jean preferred Vienna to all other cities, where she could eat palachinka and schnitzel, after attending her favorite opera, Parsifal. Her message of living life to the fullest and being kind to others will live on in her children and her grandson.

Samsung Electronics is giving Apple some of its own medicine. The company will set up mini-stores this summer inside Best Buys across the United States. 
 
Samsung on Thursday said it would open 1,400 of the stores by the end of June. Called a Samsung Experience Shop, each store will be an entire section at Best Buy devoted to showcasing Samsung smartphones, tablets, cameras, laptops, televisions and accessories. It will also include customer support for Samsung products, similar to the Genius Bar at Apple stores.

An obituary on Friday about Daniel Hoffman, a scholar and critic who was the nation’s poet laureate from 1973 to 1974, misstated the surname of his deceased wife. She was Elizabeth McFarland, not McFarlane.

Dear Diary:
 
My daughter is an animal lover, and volunteers frequently at a cat shelter in Brooklyn.

Dear Diary: 
 
I am a roach coach fiend. I get my morning corn muffin and iced coffee from one just outside my office on 34th and Park. At lunch, I walk one block away from my office and grab a chicken and rice platter with the special white sauce and everything on it. And after work around 6, right outside the Port Authority, before I make my way into the station for my bus commute home through the Lincoln Tunnel into Hoboken, I frequently grab a hot dog as a pre-snack dinner from a third food cart.

Silicon Valley is not exactly known for its diversity. So when Andreessen Horowitz, the venture capital firm, wanted to make sure its job postings were reaching the most diverse audience possible, its partners did what most people in Silicon Valley do when they spot a problem. They turned to software. 
 
They used programs that analyze the language in job descriptions to catch phrases that might turn off certain types of applicants. Looking for a candidate who is “off the charts”? Chances are, not that many women will apply.

PERLMAN--Philip J.,age 93, died on April 6, 2013. He was born in Poland and emigrated to New York at age four. After graduation from CCNY, he served in the army during WWII. Upon return, he started his own advertising firm and retired in 2006. As an accomplished artist, his paintings have been exhibited at Yeshiva University, Lever House Judaica exhibition, and in many local art galleries. He is survived by his beloved wife of nearly 70 years Shirley, daughters Risa and Sherry, son-in-laws Edward and Daniel, granddaughters Rebecca, Shoshana, Deborah and Marisa. Service: Monday, April 8, 2013 at 11:30am, Riverside-Nassau North Chapels in Great Neck.

Several late-night TV hosts have recently been in the news, including Conan O’Brien, who signed a contract extension with TBS through November 2015, and Jimmy Fallon, whose succession of Jay Leno on “The Tonight Show” was announced last week.

An article on Wednesday about the observatory at 1 World Trade Center in Manhattan misstated its height ranking in the Western Hemisphere. The 102nd or top floor of the “One World Observatory” will be the third-highest observation deck (1,268 feet above the street), after the SkyPod (1,465 feet) at the CN Tower in Toronto and the Skydeck (1,353 feet) at the Willis Tower in Chicago; it will not be the second-highest after the Skydeck.

The march of mobile is following the usual evolutionary path in media — first come the eyeballs and later comes the money. People spend an estimated 10 percent of their media attention staring at their smartphones and tablets, but mobile advertising accounts for a small fraction of 1 percent of total advertising spending.
 
Yet from a small base, mobile ad spending is expected to grow rapidly. IDC estimates that mobile advertising will surge from $4.5 billion last year to $12 billion by 2015.

An article on Thursday about Patti Davis, the daughter of Ronald Reagan and his second wife, Nancy, and her view that Mr. Reagan would have supported same-sex marriage , referred incorrectly to Mr. Reagan’s political position at the time he opposed a ballot measure that would have barred gays and lesbians from working in public schools. He was a former governor of California at the time, not the governor.

PRICE--Selma Kaplan, Selma Kaplan Price passed away peacefully, on April 6, at the age of 103, at her home, in her granddaughter's arms. Selma is survived by three loving children, six grandchildren, and 14 great-grandchildren. Funeral services at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ, on Monday, April 8, at 1:00pm.
KROLL--Douglas 7/67 4/8/02 Your love and wisdom continue to guide and inspire us. You are in our hearts and in our thoughts every day. Missed and Loved Always - Mom, Pamela, family and friends

An article on Thursday about plans by the United States to speed up the deployment of an advanced missile system to protect American naval and air forces in the event of a North Korean attack referred incorrectly to two Navy missile defense warships that the Defense Department said would be positioned in the Pacific to watch North Korea. They are Aegis-equipped ships, not Aegis-class.
BATTERBERRY--Michael. Remembering my beloved Michael on his birthday. He was loved by all who knew him. Ariane

The following exchange was heard on Good Friday in line at Bed Bath & Beyond on the Upper West Side. (Really — you can’t make this stuff up!)

Every Friday evening over NBC radio airwaves – or short-wave overseas – homesick troops during World War II were told to “drop in at the canteen” for comforting chat and songs by a pretty, young actress named Phyllis Jeanne Creore. 
 
“Here is your Canteen girl, Phyllis Jeanne,” a voice would say, and then Ms. Creore’s tender voice would croon the comforting lyrics to her signature (and self-written) song “This is My Wish.”

KOHNSTAMM--Ken, 66, died peacefully on Thursday, April 4, 2013 at his home in St. Paul, MN, surrounded by family and friends after a two-year battle with pancreatic cancer. The son of the Paul and Maisie Kohnstamm, Ken grew up in Pound Ridge, NY, attended the University of Michigan Law School, and moved to Minnesota, where he worked in the Attorney General's Office for 39 years. He ended his career as manager of the Civil Litigation Division. He was a vigorous advocate of legal representation for the underserved and was honored for his efforts. Ken is survived by wife of 31 years, Naomi Perman and his sons, Adam (Sarah) and Alexander Kohnstamm, all of St. Paul, MN, five siblings, and his mother, Maisie, who now lives in Redding, CT.
ROTH--Irving, 88, WWII sub-mariner and "cop's cop" died April 1, with his loved ones at his bedside. Visit Legacy.com.

INFANTINO--Carmine, on April 4, 2013. Beloved son of the late Pasquale and Rose. Loving brother of the late Jim Infantino and uncle of James and John. He was a noted comic book artist of the silver age and will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call Wednesday, April 10, 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral private

PRICE--Selma Kaplan, The Chelsmore Apartments Organization mourns the passing of its legendary founder, Selma K. Price. With her gift for language she coined the word Chelsmore for a building she daringly bought in Chelsea, Manhattan almost 60 years ago. Her mind was an ultra fast computer machine; her soul was straight and honest to a fault; and her heart open and attentive to all the suffering in this world, on the one hand, and angry at the injustices and unfairness on the other hand. She brilliantly navigated her real estate business through the hard times of the Chelsea neighborhood in the 60's and 70's, forming the foundation for the Chelsmore Apartments Organization, all the while nurturing her hollyhocks in front of her building, and setting standards of ethical and business conduct that have guided the Chelsmore Organization ever since. Rest in peace our beloved founder.

An article on Thursday about efforts by the Hopi Indians of Arizona to stop an auction of 70 sacred masks in Paris next week misstated the number of Hopi items bought by the Musée du Quai Branly at a similar auction in Paris in December. It was one, not eight.

O'HERRON--Jonathan. Lazard Partners and employees mourn the passing of our friend and colleague Jonathan O'Herron, a prominent figure in our firm's history. As a Lazard Partner for more than 40 years, John was one of the industry's foremost advisors on corporate mergers and acquisitions that transformed American industry. We admired John for his professionalism, his loyalty to clients and the firm, and especially his generous and humble nature. John was a great banker and an extraordinary man. He was a mentor to many and a role model for all. We extend our deepest condolences to his family.

Dear Diary,
 
Penknives, corkscrews, golf clubs and hockey sticks are some of the items that airline passengers will soon again be permitted to carry aloft , but, so far, still no more than a dollop of my favorite sharp condiment: deli mustard.

I have a vision of how suitors decide how much to offer for a start-up they want to buy. Several executives go into a conference room. Each scribbles a number on a piece of paper and places it in a hat. Then the chief executive pulls out a number, and there it is.
 
It might sound like a stretch, but given the seemingly random and sometimes nonsensical amounts for which start-ups with no revenue, or no users, or even no product are bought, I might not be far off.

An article on Tuesday about the financial crisis on Cyprus misidentified the location of an airport where a sign offered guidance to chauffeurs. It is near Larnaca, not Limassol. The article also referred incorrectly to a currency term used by Charalambos Alexandrou, a roofer who, recalling the country’s flush times, talked of getting a £20,000 loan on a monthly salary of £400. His reference was to Cypriot pounds, which the country used before it adopted the euro — not to British pounds, which it used before it gained its independence from British administration in 1960.

WASHINGTON — J. David Kuo, an evangelical Christian who was a leader in President George W. Bush ’s faith initiative but who later became a critic of it, died on Friday. He was 44.
 
Mr. Kuo’s wife, Kimberly, said the cause was brain cancer, which was diagnosed 10 years ago.

DAY--Mansoor B. Day, 91, of New York, NY passed away at 1:30am on Saturday, April 6. Born on November 2, 1921 in Babol, Iran, he emigrated to the United States where he practiced as an anesthesiologist for 45 years at the New York University Medical Center. He was a scientist and a scholar, a nutrition and health advocate and pioneer far ahead of his time, a patriot, and fiercely devoted to his family and patients. He is survived by his loving wife of 53 years, Sheila Shekoofeh Day, his son, Charles Day (Amy Carron Day), his daughter, Dr. Doris Day (Dr. Kambiz Michael Ghalili), countless nieces and nephews who looked to him for guidance and support, and his grandchildren, the delights of his life, Sabrina Ghalili, Andrew Ghalili, Alexander Day, and Juliet Day.

On the way from the studio to the stage, Jessie Ware ’s songs got a big boost of funk and soul. 
 
Ms. Ware’s record, “Devotion” (Cherrytree/Interscope), which was a Top 10 album last year in her native Britain, is scheduled for American release on April 16. It is her own canny, thoroughly up-to-the-minute electronic take on the lovelorn reveries of Sade, who is an openly acknowledged influence — Ms. Ware has sometimes imitated her wardrobe, notably the large hoop earrings.

North American moviegoers bellied up to a smorgasbord of choices over the weekend: R-rated demons, animated cave people, meaty action heroes and 3-D dinosaurs all delivered solid ticket sales. “Evil Dead” (Sony) was No. 1, taking in a better-than-expected $26 million; it cost about $17 million to produce. 
 
“The Croods,” a DreamWorks Animation film distributed by 20th Century Fox, showed continuing strength in second place, with an estimated $21.1 million in sales for a three-week total of $125.8 million, according to Hollywood.com , which compiles box-office data. Tying for second place with about $21.1 million was “G.I. Joe: Retaliation” (Paramount), which has a two-week total of $86.7 million.

MORGAN--Peter Angus Morgan, 74, sadly passed away suddenly last week at his home in Scotia, NY. Known by his immediate family as Angus he was born in Locust Valley, L.I. on October 28, 1938. He was the son of the late Henry S. and Catherine (Adams) Morgan and the great-grandson of J. Pierpont Morgan. Peter attended St Bernard's School, Groton and L.I.U and then served in the Navy in the early 1960's on nuclear submarines. Peter spent his career at General Electric. After his retirement he donated much of his time with Habitat of Humanity. Predeceased by a brother Henry S. Morgan Jr., Peter is survived by his other siblings, Charles F. Morgan (Sally), Miles Morgan and John A. Morgan (Connie) as well as a number of nieces and nephews. Services will be held in Schenectady, NY. At a later date he will be laid to rest in the family plot at Cedar Hill Cemetery in Hartford, CT. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Habitat for Humanity.

YOUNG--John E. The Royal Oak Foundation mourns the passing of John E. Young, former trustee, Treasurer and Chairman, and a champion of the conservation of our built and natural heritage in the U.S. and U.K. We extend our sympathy to his family and many friends on both sides of the Atlantic.

The scientists who were recruited to appear at a conference called Entomology-2013 thought they had been selected to make a presentation to the leading professional association of scientists who study insects.
 
But they found out the hard way that they were wrong. The prestigious, academically sanctioned conference they had in mind has a slightly different name: Entomology 2013 (without the hyphen). The one they had signed up for featured speakers who were recruited by e-mail, not vetted by leading academics. Those who agreed to appear were later charged a hefty fee for the privilege, and pretty much anyone who paid got a spot on the podium that could be used to pad a résumé.

“Shoot the first anti-advertising ad” is the pitch for a contest sponsored by Adblock Plus, the popular software that whites out Web site advertisements. The winning 30- to 90-second video submission, Adblock Plus says, will receive a prize of class time or video equipment worth $5,000 from a film institute in the Philippines.
 
The contest, at thecreativechallenge.org, is accepting applications until the end of May and is part of a recent conversion of Adblock Plus into a profit-making company with the aim of making online advertising more useful and pleasant, rather than stamping it out entirely.
SCHERR--Leslie Esq. Age 74, formerly of Potomac, MD. Died April 4th, 2013. Visitation: 18 Mary Beth Drive, Suffern, NY 10901. Sunday, April 7th, 4-9pm, Monday, 3-8pm and Tuesday, 3-8pm.

An article on Monday about the death of Anne Smedinghoff, a young American diplomat in Afghanistan, misstated the number of diplomats killed along with Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens during the Sept. 11, 2012, attack on a United States diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya. Three others died, not four.

An article on Monday about fake scientific journals and conferences misstated the name of a city in Mexico that is home to a doctor who sent articles to a pseudo-academic journal. It is Celaya, not Ceyala.

Billy Payne, the chairman of Augusta National Golf Club, announced on Monday the formation of a nationwide Drive, Chip and Putt Championship for children ages 7 to 15. Inspired by the N.F.L.’s punt, pass and kick competition, and created in concert with the U.S. Golf Association and the PGA of America, the contest will consist of local and regional qualifiers in four separate age classifications for boys and girls (7-9, 10-11, 12-13, 14-15).
 
There will be no entry fee and the field of competitors will be winnowed to 88 finalists, who will converge on Augusta National on the Sunday before the 2014 Masters for a driving and pitching contest on the practice range and a putting competition on the 18th green where so many Masters have been decided. The juniors will compete in front of a gallery of spectators and the finals will be televised by Golf Channel.

HIRSCHHORN--Richard S.,age 77, of Harrison, NY, while surrounded by family, died peacefully at home on Sunday morning following a long battle with leukemia. He is survived by Hope (Kramer), his beloved and devoted wife of 54 years; his loving sons, David, Mark and Roger and his cherished grandchildren: Erica, Douglas, Dana, Reid and Paul. As an MIT graduate engineer, he joined his father as the third generation in the family steel business, where he pioneered innovative fabricating methods leading to several United States patents. As the premier provider of curbing, his product lines the streets of Manhattan while his stairs are found in many New York City icons, including the Empire State Building. Funeral services will be held at JCCH in Harrison on April 10th at 11:30am. Donations to Cancer Research & Treatment Fund, 500 E. 77th Street, Suite 1001, New York, NY 10162 are appreciated in lieu of flowers.

Want better sex? Consider getting a new hip or knee.
 
Before Mary Ann Oklesson, a Manhattan magazine publisher, had both hips replaced a few years ago, the pain of arthritis made it difficult to walk, exercise or even climb into a taxi. Her failing hips had also taken a toll on her sex life.

Baldness may indicate an increased risk for coronary heart disease.
 
The risk is associated only with male pattern baldness, the kind that starts at the top or back of the head, and not with a receding hairline, according to researchers who reviewed six studies that included 37,000 participants.

The Walkmen, Black Flag and Merchandise will be among about 350 bands that will play at this year’s Northside Festival in Brooklyn, as organizers have added two free outdoor concerts and an expo for entrepreneurs to the weeklong schedule.
 
Now in its fifth year, Northside has become Brooklyn’s answer to the better-known South by Southwest Festival in Austin, Tex., a three-pronged event featuring an indie film festival, a music festival and a conference devoted to innovative businesses. The Northside Festival runs from from June 13 to 20 and is expected to attract more than 80,000 people to Greenpoint and Williamsburg. “South by Southwest should be shaking in its boots, because the Northside Festival is the new sheriff in town,” the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, said.

The Wealth Matters column on Saturday, about the financial pitfalls of working abroad, referred imprecisely to the responsibility of Americans working abroad to pay into Social Security . While American employees of foreign companies generally are not required to pay such taxes, American employees of United States companies, or companies affiliated with them, who work abroad generally do pay such taxes. It is not the case that Americans who spend their entire career working abroad cannot contribute to Social Security.

An obituary on Monday about the fashion designer Lilly Pulitzer included an outdated reference for annual sales of the Lilly Pulitzer brand. Net sales in 2012 were $122.6 million, according to the company — not $75 million, which was the figure at the time of the brand’s sale to Oxford Industries in 2010.

An article on Sunday about former aides to Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, who became lobbyists described incorrectly a program Mr. Baucus’s spokesman cited as an example of a request from a former aide that the senator had recently rejected. It was an alternative energy grant program, not an alternative energy loan guarantee program.

DAY--Mansoor B. Day, 91, of New York, NY passed away at 1:30am on Saturday, April 6. Born on November 2, 1921 in Babol, Iran, he emigrated to the United States where he practiced as an anesthesiologist for 45 years at the New York University Medical Center. He was a scientist and a scholar, a nutrition and health advocate and pioneer far ahead of his time, a patriot, and fiercely devoted to his family and patients. He is survived by his loving wife of 53 years, Sheila Shekoofeh Day, his son, Charles Day (Amy Carron Day), his daughter, Dr. Doris Day (Dr. Kambiz Michael Ghalili), countless nieces and nephews who looked to him for guidance and support, and his grandchildren, the delights of his life, Sabrina Ghalili, Andrew Ghalili, Alexander Day, and Juliet Day.

MCMANUS-GROSS--Olivia, on April 6, 2013. Beloved wife of William Gross. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Road. Viewing hours today 12:00-1:00pm. Service in funeral home at 12:45pm. Interment to follow at Locust Valley Cemetery.

Anyone who has cared for a baby knows that it’s easy to become preoccupied with what goes in one end — with what you feed her and how — and to regard what comes out the other end with a kind of fascination, as if the diaper contained messages and auguries.
 
What you feed a baby is a reflection of your beliefs and family traditions, your cultural background and life situation. But it also means considering the advice of a good many experts, from pediatricians to nutritionists to allergists.

WORKMAN--Peter. Prep for Prep mourns the passing of our longtime Trustee Peter Workman. For 18 years, Peter tirelessly served the organization with his wise counsel, boundless generosity, and deep loyalty. "Publishing Be The Dream" to commemorate Prep's 25th anniversary was one of his most powerful contributions. He also offered valuable internships to so many of our students at his company. We will dearly miss his incisive mind and kind spirit. Our sympathies go out to his wife Carolan, daughters Katie and Elizabeth, and their husbands and children. Scott L. Bok, Chairman, Lisa Smith Cashin, President, Aileen C. Hefferren, Chief Executive
