New picture books starring a pair of goslings, animated chickens, lucky ducklings, and a boy and his bluebird.
Ahead of the 50th anniversary of President Kennedy’s assassination, museums and auctioneers are bringing out some disturbing and tangential items.
In “The Good Nurse” by Charles Graeber, a real-life murder investigation takes some odd paths.
Eric Clapton unites grimy Midtown Manhattan and the pristine Caribbean with his guitar festival benefiting a rehab clinic in Antigua.
Inside Cherry Bombe magazine’s first issue.
The steel shutters on some Lower Manhattan storefronts will provide the canvases for paintings that could truly be considered street art.
Twelve people were arrested in a plot said to be linked to Al Qaeda to attack the embassy in Ankara and other targets.
The editor, Mahmudur Rahman, was charged with sedition at a time when strikes by opposition forces have frozen travel and are crippling the country’s economy.
Supposed excerpts from a wryly conceptual “newsletter” on Khalil Rabah’s fictional Palestinian Museum of Natural History and Humankind are on view at e-flux.
Jon Kessler explores society’s — and the art world’s — obsession with Apple and with digital technology in “The Web,” a kinetic installation at the Swiss Institute.
Self-portraiture is the common thread of Agus Suwage’s show at Tyler Rollins Fine Art.
Nearly a dozen of Faith Ringgold’s better-known story quilts are on view at ACA Galleries, along with some of her paintings from the 1960s.
A 26-minute video meditation on vision — and on video itself as a mirror of perception — is the centerpiece of Mary Lucier’s show at Lennon, Weinberg.
Joshua Marsh’s sumptuous paintings of ordinary objects are on view at Jeff Bailey, and a darkly comical video by Johannes DeYoung is being screened in the gallery’s project room.
“Time and Navigation,” a new permanent exhibition at the National Air and Space Museum, charts the history of navigation — by land, sea, air and outer space — through the centuries.
Franco Bernabe, the Telecom Italia chairman, said its board of directors had received an offer from Hutchison Whampoa, and that a committee of its biggest shareholders would review it.
German diplomats made clear that they had reservations about giving the central bank such powers because it might alter monetary policy to make supervision easier.
The Knicks intend to waive the injured forward Kurt Thomas and sign James Singleton, 31, a 6-foot-8 forward who has been in and out of the N.B.A. since 2005.
Free weekend activities in New York City will include readings at Poets House and the Park Slope Food Co-op and bike lessons at Bldg 92.

The Professional Autograph Dealers Association’s annual show at the Lotos Club includes treasures like an ink portrait of Lincoln in his coffin and a check he wrote to his carpenter for work on an outhouse.
New claims for unemployment benefits fell more than expected recently, and retail executives and analysts forecast improved same-store sales in April.
Automatic federal budget cuts are playing havoc with emergency unemployment benefits.
Russia, the world’s second-largest producer of natural gas, is making a bet that methane-powered cars are an alluring market for future growth.
The Minnesota Twins’ team president said a decision on whether to play Friday’s game against the Mets would be made on Friday.
Cablevision and its Brooklyn cable installers have not settled on a contract since the workers voted 15 months ago to unionize.
A magistrates’ court in Jerusalem ruled that five women who had been detained for wearing prayer shawls and singing aloud were not disturbing public order.
Many of those arrested at a market in St. Petersburg were migrants from Central Asia and the mainly Muslim North Caucasus.
For those new to getting in shape, or returning to the treadmill after a lapse, these fitness centers in New York are considered accommodating to exercisers, regardless of their size.
The New Jersey Marathon, to be run May 5, had to be rerouted because of Hurricane Sandy, but the race’s organizer said there was never a doubt that it would be held.

Sabrina Parsons is the chief executive of Palo Alto Software, a company founded by her father in Eugene, Ore. She has tried to bring the focus of Silicon Valley to the company without its punishing lifestyle.
The popularity of Mr. Biondi Santi’s Tuscan red wine, which was invented by his grandfather in Italy, skyrocketed in the last half-century.
Claes Oldenburg is the focus of two exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art.
No artist cooked up a tastier version of the primal Pop recipe than Claes Oldenburg in the late 1950s and early ’60s, a time explored in two Museum of Modern Art shows.
Officials are grappling with what to do in the wake of the federal sequestration that led to broad cuts in military and domestic spending.
The N.H.L. has formed a partnership with a gay advocacy group to plan training and counseling on gay issues, and the N.F.L. is looking to smooth the way for acceptance.
The program would be a shift from the focus on family ties that is the main foundation of the current immigration system.
Pressed by shooting victims and relatives of Americans slain in gun violence, the Senate voted to consider new legislation that had faced the threat of a filibuster by Republicans.
For years, members of Congress from states like West Virginia and North Dakota have sought to avoid the issue, but many now say recent shootings have changed the politics of guns.
Honda, Toyota, Nissan and Mazda are recalling about 3.3 million vehicles worldwide because the passenger-side air bag could deploy with too much force.
A draft document prepared for Cyprus’s international lenders set the total cost at 23 billion euros, or about $30 billion, rather than 17 billion euros, and said Cyprus would pay the difference.
South Korea softened its tone on Thursday amid concerns that North Korean missile tests were imminent, and its president moved to calm foreign investors.
The Oscar-winning movie was pulled on its opening day despite reports that the filmmakers had edited scenes to comply with the wishes of Chinese censors.
The opposition accused Syrian military forces of massacring  60 civilians in an act of revenge during a campaign in the country’s south this week.
Hong Kong police on Thursday filed manslaughter charges against the captains of two boats that collided in October in the city’s deadliest maritime disaster in more than four decades.
A Mediterranean flatbread where walnuts and their oil stand in for olives.
Federal prosecutors in Los Angeles and securities regulators brought insider trading charges against a former top KPMG executive.
deCAMP--Michael Anderson, of Edenton, NC, 85, died Tuesday, April 9, 2013. For complete obituary, please visit: www.millerfhc.com.

GOLBY--Ralph Wesley, of New York passed away March 20th peacefully at home at the age of 89. He was born in Portland, Oregon to Max Leon Golby and Deborah Swett, and came East to attend Yale College, class of 1945. He honorably served in the Navy during World War II. He graduated Yale Law School in 1947 and returned to Portland, Oregon to practice law from 1948-1952. He joined the State Department as General Counsel of the Development Loan Fund and headed a bank program for Agency for International Development, US Government, Washington D.C. 1952-62, where he met his future wife Monique de Brabandere Poelman. They were married in Paris, 1961. He joined the Schering-Plough Corporation as Financial Executive of Overseas Operations, Senior Vice-President, travelling extensively throughout the world with his wife and later children, and dividing the ensuing 50 years between New York City and Far Hills, New Jersey. Following retirement he devoted his energy to leading the International Center of New York as Chairman of the Board for a decade. He is predeceased by his wife. He is survived by his daughter Alexandra J. Golby and son-in-law Chris Scovel of Boston, MA, and son Wesley L. Golby and Kim Bucci of Brooklyn, NY as well as three grandchildren, Phineas Scovel, Atticus Scovel, and Adele Golby. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest at 3:30pm on Tuesday, April 30th.

JONES--Caroline Anna, 40, on April 4th in San Francisco, after a two year battle with brain cancer. She was born and raised in New York City, graduated from The Brearley School and Connecticut College. Her sense of humor, forgiving manner, intelligence and enthusiasm inspired everybody whose life she touched. She is survived by her husband Devon Earl Brian Boyle, daughters Charlotte, 8 and Eloise, 5, of San Francisco and mother Magda Rydlo Jones and brother Adrian Winslow Jones (Allison). Predeceased by her father Anthony Winslow Jones. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, April 13th, at 1pm in New York City.

ROSE--Jerome G.,86, died on April 5, 2013, in his home in Princeton, New Jersey, surrounded by his loving wife and children. He was professor of urban planning and business law at Rutgers University for 27 years before his retirement in 1996. He received Rutgers University's prestigious Lindback Foundation Award for Excellence in Teaching, as well as the Rutgers School of Business teaching award. He graduated in 1948 from Cornell University, with Distinction in Government, where he was also elected to Phi Beta Kappa. He received a J.D. cum laude from Harvard Law School in 1951. He was a member of the Bar of the State of New York and a licensed Professional Planner. He is survived by his wife, Naomi; three children, Patricia Zeigler, Elizabeth Rose and Theodore Rose; and six grandchildren. A service in celebration of his life will be held at Princeton Windrows on Sunday, April 14, 2013, at 11:00am

An article on March 26 about modes of mental health treatment described incorrectly a study by Kristin von Ranson and colleagues at the University of Calgary that evaluated treatments for eating disorders . It was a previous study of how therapists make decisions — not the study by Dr. von Ranson — that found that when therapists did not use an evidence-based treatment or blended one with other techniques, patients fared worse compared with those who received a more standardized treatment. (Dr. von Ranson merely cited that study in hers.)

Jay-Z lashed out on Thursday at members of Congress who have raised questions about the legality of his recent trip to Cuba with Beyoncé, his wife. He released a scathing rap aimed at those critics and suggested he had been falsely accused of breaking the law because of his friendship with President Obama.
 
The rapper mocked the two Miami Republicans — Ileana Ros-Lehtinen and Mario Diaz-Balart — who demanded last week that the Treasury Department explain why the trip was licensed by the American government. Under the longtime embargo, Americans are not allowed to spend money in Cuba “unless authorized by a general or specific license” by the Office of Foreign Asset Control.

Msgr. Gerald Ryan, who began working as a priest in the Bronx in 1945 and went on to become the longest-serving pastor in New York and probably the country, died on Thursday at Our Lady of Consolation, a residence for ill priests, in Riverdale. He was 93.
 
The cause was stomach cancer, said Madelyn Feliciano, the office manager of St. Luke’s in Mott Haven, the parish Father Ryan led from 1966 until his death.

Hurricane Sandy damaged even what it could not touch.
 
The flooding last October was catastrophic enough at Verizon’s headquarters and switching center in Lower Manhattan. Water cascaded 90 feet below ground, fully submerging three of five subbasements. It reached four feet in the main lobby, a masterpiece of Jazz Age decorative art that’s an official city landmark. Water filled the elevator pits, too, knocking 22 of 23 cars out of service. Briefly, the 31-story tower was completely crippled.

AUGUSTA, Ga. — Minutes after his four-under par 68 made him the clubhouse leader, David Lynn said his runner-up finish at last year’s P.G.A. Championship helped him avoid any nervousness in his first Masters on Thursday.
 
“What the P.G.A. last year did for me, what it showed, was how calm I could be in that kind of situation,” Lynn said. “I’m not nervous. I don’t know exactly why that is. Maybe because I’ve been grinding away at this for 16 years. I have a lot of experience behind me.”

BELL--Phyllis Wishnack, March 12, 1923 - April 7, 2013. Loving wife to Ellis for 68 years; devoted mother of Bob (Eileen) and Ilene (Paul), and caring grandmother of Daniel and Jeremy Koegel. She valued family, human connection, and social justice, which she saw as intimately intertwined. In her professional life as a social worker, she championed subsidized adoption to help make loving and permanent homes possible for children who had experienced neither love nor permanence. Those whose lives she touched remember her with undying affection.

HOFFMAN--Hyacinthe K.,98, of Stamford, CT, wife of the late Harold E. Hoffman, died peacefully on April 10 at Edgehill Senior Living Community with her children Cynthia Livingston and Stephen, Jonathan and Peter Hoffman and their spouses, nine grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren gathered at her side. A 1937 graduate of Vassar College, Hy moved to Stamford with Harold to establish the Stamford branch of Hoffman Fuel Company. Hy was active in developing resources in Fairfield County for families and children. She served on the Board of Family and Children's Services of Stamford, Darien and New Canaan, as well as on the Community Advisory Board of UConn (Stamford) Center for Judaic and Middle Eastern Studies. She supported Temple Beth El, United Way, Stamford Jewish Federation, Young Audiences, Stamford JCC and Great Books, among other organizations. Hy was a matriarch and an inspiration for her generosity, wit and pluck. A funeral service will be held Friday, April 12, 12:30pm at Temple Beth El at 350 Roxbury Road, Stamford, CT. Contributions in her memory may be made to Family Centers of Stamford, UConn (Stamford) Center for Judaic and Middle Eastern Studies, Ferguson Library, or to the charity of your choice.

REDLER--Joel B. on April 11, 2013 of A.L.S. Beloved husband of Judie. Loving father of Douglas and Leslie. Cherished poppy of Lindsey and Noah. Services 11:30am Friday at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. boulevardriversidechapel.com

An article on Thursday about pranksters in Southern California who file false reports of horrific crimes at the homes of celebrities, prompting the dispatch of SWAT teams, gave an incorrect location from the Beverly Hills Police Department for the home of Ryan Seacrest, who was a target. He lives on Cabrillo Drive, not on Cabrillo Lane. And an accompanying picture caption misstated the time frame of a hoax call involving the home of the actor Ashton Kutcher. As the article correctly noted, the hoax was last year, not last week.

An article on Thursday about Yale and Quinnipiac’s reaching the semifinals of the N.C.A.A. men’s hockey tournament misstated the distance above sea level of Colorado Springs, where Yale played the last time it advanced to the national semifinals, in 1952. It is 6,000 feet, not 6,000 miles.

The Winklevoss twins, Cameron and Tyler — Olympic rowers, nemeses of Mark Zuckerberg — are laying claim to a new title: bitcoin moguls.
 
The Winklevii, as they are known, have amassed since last summer what appears to be one of the single largest portfolios of the digital money, whose wild gyrations have Silicon Valley and Wall Street talking. The twins, the first prominent figures in the largely anonymous bitcoin world to publicly disclose a big stake, say they own nearly $11 million worth.

GOLDBERG--Eleanor, wife of the late Joseph devoted mother of Randi and Robert. Mother in law of Steven and Emily. Cherished grandmother of Samantha, Josh, Harry and Eddy. Services Sunday 10am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Rickie Fowler carded his four-under 68 the hard way, with double bogeys on the first and 10th holes. He became the first player to shoot a sub-70 score at the Masters with at least two double bogeys since Ray Floyd in 1992.
 
“It was definitely a speed bump out of the gate,” Fowler said. “I hit it in a spot that you just can’t, to the back left pin, hit it long right, poor chip, tried to make 5, ended up with 6. Ten, just a bad swing and actually made a really good 6, if there is such a thing.”

MARCUS--Steven, of Larchmont, NY on April 9, 2013. Cherished husband of Carol. Loving father of Ari and Kim, Belinda and Tony. Adoring grandfather of Madeline, Charlie, Cate, Ariane, and Andrew. THOMPSON--Barbara Benkhart, January 18, 1928- April 7, 2013. Barbara passed away peacefully on April 7, 2013 with her loving son at her side. Barbara was preceded in death by Mac, her devoted husband of 62 years. She is survived by her son Jack, daughter-in-law Kim and granddaughters Kaitlin and Grace. Barbara, better known as "Sweetie", will forever be remembered as the perfect wife and mother and intensely loyal to family and friends alike, all the while offering a helping hand and a sunny outlook on life. She will also be remembered as a champion golfer, fervent shell collector, photographer and a pretty darn good painter. A memorial service is being planned and to be held at Trinity St. John Church, 1142 Broadway in Hewlett, NY. Date and time to be announced. The reception to be at the Rockaway Hunting Club. Beth A. Stewart doesn’t mind making waves.
 
Last year, Ms. Stewart, who runs a search firm that specializes in female directors, helped stoke the debate over board diversity by taking aim at the giant social network Facebook . As the Internet company prepared to go public in a much-hyped debut, she worked behind the scenes on a campaign to publicize the lack of women on Facebook’s board. To bolster her effort, she enlisted a women’s advocacy group, which decided to stage a protest at Facebook’s offices in New York in April.

EFFORTS by a leading gasoline brand to woo consumers in a nontraditional fashion are continuing with a lighthearted initiative aimed at discouraging a particularly annoying kind of vehicular noise pollution.
 
The initiative urges drivers to stop “honkaholism” — the incessant beeping of car horns that bothers passengers, pedestrians and other drivers. It is styled like a public service campaign aimed at eradicating a societal ill, seeking to make people aware of the problem and then offering a solution.

Imagine a cocktail party populated by recognizable guests who would otherwise probably never hang out together: some of them are highly knowledgeable about movies, some have made movies, others have appeared in movies and still others have at least seen some movies. Hold that image in your mind and tally off the boldface names in attendance, and you may come up with rosters not unlike the — shall we say, heterogeneous — juries that will preside over this year’s Tribeca Film Festival . 
 
The festival’s organizers on Wednesday afternoon announced the jurors who would choose the winners in its seven competitive categories, calling them, with some understatement, “a diverse group of 41 industry leaders.” For example, the jury for the world narrative category will consist of the writer-directors Kenneth Lonergan (“You Can Count on Me,” “Margaret”) and Paul Haggis (“Crash,” “Million Dollar Baby”); the actresses Blythe Danner and Bryce Dallas-Howard; and the cultural journalist Jessica Winter. And the winner of the world documentary category will be chosen by the documentary filmmakers Joe Berlinger (“Paradise Lost”) and Sandi Dubowski (“Trembling Before G-d”), as well as Whoopi Goldberg, Mira Sorvino and Evan Rachel Wood.

PAGE--Nancy Eaton, on April 1, 2013, of Washington, D,C passed away peacefully in her Georgetown home. Born in Detroit, MI on April 21st 1926 to Edward and Alice Cheetham. Later she was adopted by her mother's second husband, Wilbur Eaton of Bryan, OH. Nancy was raised in Swampscott, MA and attended Boston University. Soon after school she found clerical work with the Department of Defense in Washington DC. Her first duty station was on The Mall in the temporary office buildings that lined the reflecting pool between The Washington Monument and the Lincoln memorial. In 1947 Nancy was hired by the State Department and soon went to work in Tehran, Iran where her love affair with traveling and all aspects about the Middle East was born. It was in Tehran that she met her husband of 57 years, Robert Wesley Page. Nancy and Bob lived for over 15 years in the Middle East and the Netherlands with their children. Beirut, Lebanon was a special jewel to Nancy who forged a lifetime of friends there and would return to again and again. Once returning to the United States, Nancy raised her family in New York, Houston and for over two decades in Washington, DC. For many years Nancy and family spent summers in Little Compton, RI and most recently winters in Key West. Nancy was a brilliant conversationalist who embraced life with curiosity and humor. She was passionate and engaged in the creative arts, literature, politics and inspired her family in her passion. Nancy's sophistication and compassion captured the admiration and loyalties of the mighty and the meek, from laborers, to waiters, to professional athletes, to diplomats, foreign and domestic. Her respect for all cultures enabled her to be a bridge-builder in support of the many and varied interests and vocational excursions of her husband from whom she was inseparable, as well as for family and friends. She was a unique presence in countless lives, young and old, across the globe. To be with her was to truly enjoy life she will be deeply missed by many. Nancy is survived by three of her four children: David Page, Mark Page and Meg Page and three grandchildren; Keegan Page, Addie Page and Riley McIlvaine. Her eldest son, Robert Wesley Page Jr., passed away in 2007. Details on a celebration of Nancy's life will be provided at a later date.

Jacob’s Pillow , the dance festival and school in the Berkshires, will award its seventh annual Jacob’s Pillow Dance Award to Michelle Dorrance , the tap dancer and choreographer whose company, Dorrance Dance, is known for its blend of inventiveness, virtuosity and musicality. 
 
Reviewing the premiere of Ms. Dorrance’s “SOUNDspace” in The New York Times in January, Brian Seibert wrote that “the main emotion that ‘SOUNDspace’ produced was excitement: excitement about sounds, and about the development of this talented choreographer, the most promising one in tap right now.”

Bigas Luna, an iconoclastic film director who emerged after the Franco dictatorship to portray the new Spain as engagingly and perplexingly robust and later discovered the stars Penélope Cruz and Javier Bardem, died on Saturday at his home in Tarragona, Spain. He was 67.
 
Spain’s Academy for Cinematography Arts and Sciences announced the death. Reports in the Spanish news media said the cause was leukemia.

Entities that promote “work from home” opportunities could be a new source of scrutiny for Herbalife , the nutritional products company that has become the subject of a pitched battle on Wall Street.
 
The Federal Trade Commission has received scores of complaints from people who paid money to operations with names like Income At Home and Online Business Systems, according to materials the agency released under the Freedom of Information Act.

MILLER--Patricia Ann, of Brooklyn, NY. Died peacefully in her sleep on April 10, 2013. She is survived by her mother Helen (Polochick) Miller of Brooklyn, NY and is predeceased by her father Lawrence Miller. The interment will take place in Pennsylvania. A memorial Mass will be offered in the near future.

INSIDER VIEW As Jamie Dimon, below, puts the final touches on JPMorgan Chase’s latest earnings report, scheduled to be published on Friday, the bank’s own analysts are raining on his parade.
 
In a report on the global investment banking industry, the firm’s analysts cut right to the chase: many of the world’s largest investment banks are likely to offer investors paltry returns for the rest of the decade. MARK SCOTT

PETERSON--Susan Lee, 49 passed away at her home in Oakland, CA on March 16, 2013 following a courageous yearlong battle with cancer. Former buyer/merchandiser for Saks Fifth Ave, Banana Republic, Williams Sonoma and Cost Plus World Market. Private chef for family of Apple Computer founder Steve Jobs, dessert chef at Chez Panisse. Endurance athlete and conservationist. Cornell Hotel School '86, Tante Marie's Cooking School San Francisco, UC Santa Cruz Agroecology. Kappa Kappa Gamma. A life well lived and was loved by many. The school is life, the lesson is love.

An article on April 3 about a decision by the GEO Group Foundation, the charitable arm of the private prison corporation, to withdraw its $6 million gift to Florida Atlantic University for its football stadium in a naming deal, misstated the distance from the GEO Group headquarters to the university campus. It is a few miles, not one block.

Kenny Rogers, Bobby Bare and Cowboy Jack Clement will be inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum later this year, the Country Music Association announced at a news conference on Wednesday. 
 
All three helped spread country music to new audiences in their day. Mr. Rogers had several crossover hits in the 1970s and 1980s, like “The Gambler,” “Lucille” and “Lady” (produced by Lionel Richie).

On Dec. 26 the Brooklyn Nets lost to the Milwaukee Bucks, their 10th loss in 13 games after a franchise-best 11-4 start.
 
The next day, Coach Avery Johnson was fired — a mere 24 days after being named the Eastern Conference coach of the month for November — and was replaced by his assistant P. J. Carlesimo.

BALL--Hertha Baron, of Clarence, NY and Brooklyn, NY, peacefully ended her astonishing life on March 31, 2013 at 103. Wife of the late Arthur, mother of Tina J, Omi to Joanna (Joey), ageless and inspiring friend to so many...
Because of an editing error, an obituary on Thursday about the sportswriter Stan Isaacs misstated the date that his final column was published. It was Monday, April 1 — not Monday, April 8.

An article on Thursday about compliments filed to New York City about cabbies omitted, in some editions, the final passage, which described the special role that taxi drivers can play in passengers’ lives. The full article can be found at nytimes.com/nyregion .

Ed Fisher, whose culturally savvy cartoons, featured in The New Yorker for nearly 50 years, made wry sport of modern life, frequently matching images from history or folklore with captions in an up-to-date mode, died on April 3 in Canaan, Conn. He was 86.
 
His son, Mark, who confirmed the death, said Mr. Fisher had advanced dementia and had learned he had Alzheimer’s disease in 2000.

A multibillion-dollar consulting industry came under the spotlight in Washington on Thursday, as lawmakers questioned the quality and independence of companies that guide banks through regulatory scrutiny.

With luck, audiences won’t have to live forever to see a musical adaptation of “Tuck Everlasting” hit Broadway, but they are going to have to wait a little longer for it. The producers of a new musical based on that Natalie Babbitt children’s novel, about a girl who meets a boy from a family of immortals, said that its planned world premiere in Boston would be delayed because there were no theaters in New York where the musical could transfer.
 
Press representatives for “Tuck Everlasting,” which was to run at the Citi Performing Arts Center Emerson Colonial Theater in Boston from July 28 through Aug. 18, said in a statement that the production “has been postponed due to a lack of theater availability for its planned subsequent production in New York.”

Peter Workman, the founder of Workman Publishing , whose knack for landing best-selling trade books like “What to Expect When You’re Expecting,” and “The Silver Palate Cookbook” built his company into one of the few remaining independent book publishers in the country, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 74.
 
The cause was cancer, a company spokesman said.

ESTES--Barrie Landauer, died April 2, in Lebanon, NH. Born in Manhattan, April 17, 1935, to Ruth Yarbrough and James D. Landauer, a lifetime summer resident of NH, she graduated from the Madeira School '52 and Vassar College '56, and received Dance Certificates from the Mary Wigman Studio (Berlin) and Laban Inst. of Movement Arts. A dancer, choreographer, director, teacher beloved by her students, on faculty at HB Studio since 1963, she was co-founder/director of Dancers Studio, Studio 14 and The Dance Center. She also worked on programs for DTW, NYU, 92nd St. Y, La Mama and The Lee Strasberg Inst. Her acting performances included "Gypsy" with Ann Sothern, and "A Funny Thing Happened" with Dom DeLuise. Survived by husband, William L. Estes, sister, Barbara L. Widdoes, niece and nephews, Bennett W. Crocker, James L. Widdoes (Brooks H.) and William P. Widdoes, Jr. and five adored great-nieces and nephews. Memorial reception at National Arts Club, May 21, at noon. RSVP: blest2003@hotmail.com. Contributions to any of the deserving orgs. in which your lives met, appreciated.

MANN--Irwin Lawrence, 84, died peacefully at his home surrounded by his adoring wife and children. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Doris, his children, Brigadier General Michael Mann, Bev Cohen and Audrey Mann Cronin and eight grandchildren. He was a devoted family man and true friend with an inspiring work ethic and great wit. He will be dearly missed for his kindness, generosity, and zest for life.

SAFIAN--A. Chester, 79, was an optimistic humanist; a devoted family man; and an unrepentant exercise enthusiast. He passed away peacefully on April 10. He is survived by his loving wife Jennifer; children Judy, Bobby and Tommy; grandchildren Emily, Andrew, Matthew, Nicholas, Daniel and Jaxon; brother Kenneth; nieces Nancy and Patti; step-children Stephanie, Marina and David; step-grandchildren Julie, Daniel, Alexandra, Eliana, Max, Olivia, Isabel, and Mia; and children-in-law Brian, Mary, Stephen and Darren. A lawyer by training and investment adviser by trade, Chet found his calling as a co-founder of Princeton Project 55, a non-profit dedicated to creating public interest fellowships for recent college graduates, now known as Princeton Alumni Corps. Chet completed seven marathons, biked thousands of miles (logging every one), rooted valiantly for the Mets, Jets and Knicks (and in his final year, for the Brooklyn Nets). He loved West Side Story, Gilbert & Sullivan, MASH, and crossword puzzles. Even after being diagnosed with brain cancer, he called himself a lucky man, rich in the human relationships that matter most. He was a fierce believer in random acts of kindness. Memorial service on April 11 at 230pm at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th St. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Chet Safian Innovation Fund, c/o alumnicorps.org, 12 Stockton St, Princeton, NJ 08540

The On Soccer column on April 3, about the hiring of Paolo di Canio, who expressed fascist sympathies during his playing career, to coach a Premier League team in England, misstated part of the name of the team. TALLCHIEF--Maria. Peter Martins and the entire New York City Ballet family mourn the passing of Maria Tallchief, the extraordinary American ballerina who was a founding member of our Company. Maria's dazzling talent electrified audiences in the early years of our history, as she worked with George Balanchine to create some of the most enduring roles in all of ballet, including her now legendary performances in Orpheus, Firebird, Swan Lake, and The Nutcracker. Following her career onstage, Maria's role as a teacher and director was an inspiration for countless young dancers and her work will have a lasting impact for generations to come. The world of dance has lost a true giant, and she will be greatly missed. All of us at NYCB express our heartfelt condolences to Maria's sister Marjorie, daughter Elise Paschen, and her entire family.

ROCKWELL--Peter C.,1959-2013. The management and staff of Mitsubishi UFJ Trust and Banking Corporation in Japan and the New York Branch, sadly inform that their General Counsel and Senior Vice President, Mr. Peter C. Rockwell, passed away on March 27, 2013 while vacationing in Namibia, South Africa. He was 54 years old. Peter's passing brings great sadness to all who knew him as the excellent professional who served for many years as a member of the senior management at the Mitsubishi UFJ Trust and Banking Corporation, New York Branch. Peter loved life and cultivated friends throughout the world, especially in Manhattan and Japan where many valued him. He leaves behind the memory of wonderful human quality and a big heart. Our deepest condolences go out to his family members, his mother, Mary Alice (nee Cullen), his brother Charles K. Rockwell, his sister, Ann W. Rockwell-Kollman, his niece, Tamina and nephew Sinclair, brother in law and his numerous close friends.

When I was in high school, I visited France on an exchange program and stayed with a well-to-do family. When I returned home, I marveled that the household employed a maid who washed my clothes. My mother rolled her eyes. “You have a maid here who does your laundry,” she said. “Me!”
 
So it was with great amusement that I tried out the “ living with your parents ” calculator, provided by the real estate blog Movoto (covering the “lighter side” of real estate, it says). The calculator shows big savings from living at home, including the perk of having your mother do your laundry.

A jury in Seattle has found against Huong Hoang, the actress who sued the Internet Movie Database and its parent company, Amazon, for posting her age without her permission. The verdict, reached in Federal Court on Thursday, rejected a breach of contract claim against IMDB by Ms. Hoang, who uses the name Junie Hoang in her screen work. Marsha J. Pechman, a judge in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington, had already dropped Amazon from the case, and dismissed other claims. 
 
Lawyers for Ms. Hoang, now 41, argued that IMDB , a popular on-line database covering film and television, had opened the door to age discrimination against her by posting her age, which it discovered by using information she provided as a subscriber. After Ms. Hoang filed the suit in 2011, the Screen Actors Guild publicly criticized IMDB for its practice of posting performers’ ages. But the jury on Thursday found that the service had not violated its contract with Ms. Hoang, and awarded no damages.

AUGUSTA, Ga. — The talk during the first day of the Masters was how the Chinese teenager Guan Tianlang seemed so far ahead of his time. At 14, he was playing with the game and the poise of a player twice his age. But on Friday, Guan was punished for dawdling, with a one-stroke penalty for slow play after the 17th hole of his second round at Augusta National Golf Club.
 
“I respect the decision they make,” said Guan, who signed for a three-over-par 75 that included the penalty.

An article on Thursday about President Obama’s budget proposal to Congress referred imprecisely to those taxpayers who would pay a minimum federal income tax rate of 30 percent. That rate would apply to earnings above $1 million a year — not to “millionaires,” those with a net worth at that level.

Tax Day is next Monday. If you haven’t filed your taxes yet, should you be considering filing for an extension?
 
It’s easy to file for an automatic six-month extension on your federal tax return. Just fill out Form 4868 and file it by April 15. (You can also file it electronically ). You don’t have to give a reason for seeking the extra time. You’ll then have until Oct. 15 to complete your tax return.

ZALZAL--Pierre G. Lutheran HealthCare in Brooklyn, NY, mourns the passing of Pierre G. Zalzal, M.D., a neurologist at Lutheran Medical Center for 24 years and key member of the Stroke Center team and Medical and Dental Staff. Dr. Zalzal was a beloved co-worker, peer, physician and friend to many. He had a true passion for neurology and his patients and made it his mission to care for others. He was a man of style and substance and always treated his patients with grace and empathy. He was a humanist, a scholar and always humble. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, physicians and staff of Lutheran HealthCare, we send our sincere condolences to his wife Amal, his son Antoine, his daughter Youmna and their extended family and friends. Dr. Zalzal will be sorely missed. Emma Graeber Porter, Chair of the Lutheran HealthCare Board of Trustees, and Wendy Z. Goldstein, President and CEO.

After a worldwide naming contest , the stone lions snoozing outside the Riverdale branch of the New York Public Library in the Bronx have been officially christened: River and Dale.
 
The names, to be announced at a reception at the library Friday afternoon, beat out more than 350 other suggestions submitted in person and online from lion-namers as far away as Toronto, England and Australia. Finalists included Patronus and Cupitor and Leo and Rex.

Jodie Gates, a dancer, choreographer and educator who is a former principal dancer with the Joffrey Ballet, has been named vice dean and director of the new Glorya Kaufman School of Dance at the University of Southern California. Ms. Gates is a professor of dance at the University of California, Irvine, and is the founder and artistic director of the Laguna Dance Festival in Laguna Beach, Calif. She has also been a principal ballerina with the Frankfurt Ballet, the Pennsylvania Ballet and other major companies. Ms. Gates will begin her position in August at the school of dance. The school was established in November 2012 by a gift from Ms. Kaufman, a philanthropist and dance patron.

The cost of long-term care in nursing homes and assisted-living sites is increasing at a dramatic pace compared with the cost of in-home care, an annual industry survey finds.
 
The 10th annual “ cost of care ” report from Genworth Financial, a seller of long-term care policies and other insurance and financial products, collected information from 15,000 long-term care providers nationally in January and February. The cost of nursing home care has increased more than 4 percent a year over the last decade to a median annual cost of $83,950 from $65,200  annually, the company  found.

BERKLEY--Norma. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of our dearly loved Norma on Wednesday, April 10, 2013. Norma is survived by her loving life partner Beth, sons Noah and Charles, grandson Christian, and a large extended family of loved ones who will miss her greatly. We enjoyed Norma's free spirit and joie de vivre during our time together. Donations may be made in Norma's name to Gilda's Club or The American Indian Relief Council.

ZALZAL--Pierre G. Lutheran HealthCare in Brooklyn, NY, mourns the passing of Pierre G. Zalzal, M.D., a neurologist at Lutheran Medical Center for 24 years and key member of the Stroke Center team and Medical and Dental Staff. Dr. Zalzal was a beloved co-worker, peer, physician and friend to many. He had a true passion for neurology and his patients and made it his mission to care for others. He was a man of style and substance and always treated his patients with grace and empathy. He was a humanist, a scholar and always humble. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, physicians and staff of Lutheran HealthCare, we send our sincere condolences to his wife Amal, his son Antoine, his daughter Youmna and their extended family and friends. Dr. Zalzal will be sorely missed. Emma Graeber Porter, Chair of the Lutheran HealthCare Board of Trustees, and Wendy Z. Goldstein, President and CEO.

An article on Page 50 this weekend about System, a new magazine about the fashion industry, includes outdated information about its plans. After the article had gone to press, a representative from System announced that the stylist Marie-Amélie Sauvé, who worked on the first issue, will not be a member of System’s editorial board as previously announced. And a picture portfolio by Neville Wakefield planned for the first issue will be published in a later issue.

The Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival arrived at the Empire Polo Club in Indio, Calif., on Friday, the beginning of a three-day hubbub of music, art and relaxation in the desert (and one that is repeated next weekend as well). The music lineup ranges from pugnacious rappers to indie rock bands (above, Ioanna Gika of IO Echo). Festival coverage: nytimes.com/artsbeat.

ROCKWELL--Peter, 53, passed while vacationing in Namibia on March 27, 2013. The son of David and Mary Rockwell of Weston, CT, he attended public schools and Harvard University, graduating Cum Laude in 1981. He received his law degree at Georgetown University in 1987 and began his career at Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher. Currently employed at Mitsubishi Trust & Bank Corporation, he was Chief Compliance Officer. Peter is survived by his mother, Mary Alice (nee Cullen), a brother, Charles Kellogg Rockwell, a sister, Anne W. Rockwell-Kollmann, and grandchildren, Sinclair and Tamina. A memorial celebrating his life will be held on April 17th at 3:00pm at the Frank Campbell Funeral Home on Madison Avenue in New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Peter's name may be made to Carnegie Hall.

THOMPSON--Barbara Benkhart, January 18, 1928- April 7, 2013. Barbara passed away peacefully on April 7, 2013 with her loving son at her side. Barbara was preceded in death by Mac, her devoted husband of 62 years. She is survived by her son Jack, daughter-in-law Kim and granddaughters Kaitlin and Grace. Barbara, better known as "Sweetie", will forever be remembered as the perfect wife and mother and intensely loyal to family and friends alike, all the while offering a helping hand and a sunny outlook on life. She will also be remembered as a champion golfer, fervent shell collector, photographer and a pretty darn good painter. A memorial service is being planned and to be held at Trinity St. John Church, 1142 Broadway in Hewlett, NY. Date and time to be announced. The reception to be at the Rockaway Hunting Club. Please, in lieu of flowers, donations to Trinity St. John Church would be greatly appreciated.

WASHINGTON — Organizing for Action, the grass-roots group that grew out of President Obama’s campaign machine, raised just shy of $4.9 million in the first quarter of 2013, according to an e-mail to the group’s supporters.
 
The group, which began raising money in late January, is designed to help support Mr. Obama’s governing agenda by tapping into his list of campaign supporters. It has organized events and bought online advertisements about gun control and immigration issues.

SMITH--Arthur E.,5/16/27-4/13/10 "Always the curious mind." Lovingly remembered by Miriam, Israel, Julie, and Isabelle. What are you dreaming up next? We miss you.

Ralph Sanchez, a Cuban-born businessman who brought auto racing to the streets of Miami in the 1980s and later built a major speedway in a city devastated by Hurricane Andrew, died on Monday at his home in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 64.
 
His death, after a series of illnesses, was confirmed by officials of the track he founded, Homestead-Miami Speedway.

JAKARTA — Soon after midnight on March 23, a group of heavily armed, masked men forced their way inside a prison near the Indonesian city of Yogyakarta and summarily executed four recently arrived detainees with gunshots to the head.
 
The coordination of the slayings, the professional demeanor of the masked men, and their military-style weapons and communications equipment prompted immediate speculation within the Indonesian news media and among human rights groups and lawmakers that the assailants were members of the military.

One of eleven surviving copies of the Bay Psalm Book — the first book printed in what is now the United States, and one of the world’s most valuable books — will be on public view from Friday until Sunday at Sotheby’s in New York, in advance of a November auction where the book is expected to fetch more than $15 million.
 
The copy is one of two belonging to Boston’s Old South Church, which stirred fierce controversy in December with the decision to sell the book in order to pay for deferred maintenance to its current building. After the viewing in New York, the book will travel to Philadelphia, Chicago, Los Angeles and Dallas before returning to public exhibition in New York in the week leading up to Thanksgiving.

David Grainger is walking on the water again. One foot is upstream from the Manhattan Bridge and the other foot is downstream from the Williamsburg Bridge, and he is reaching over the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway to plant a yellow flag at the intersection of Pierrepont Street and Hicks Street in Brooklyn Heights.
 
His feet are covered in protective blue bootees. The bootees protect the water, which is not water at all but dark-blue paint on wood.

STERNE--Geraldine Savidge, 82, formerly of Manhattan, died Monday, April 8 after a long illness. She was a former public relations executive at Lord & Taylor and Ann Taylor and the widow of New York Times editor Michael Lyon Sterne. Mrs. Sterne is survived by her daughters, Evelyn Sterne of Newport, RI, and Christie Sterne of Cape Town, South Africa, and by four grandchildren. Her funeral will be held Saturday, April 13 in the St. Columba Berkeley Memorial Chapel in Middletown, RI. Additional information is available at memorialfuneralhome.com.

The Old Globe Theater in San Diego will open its 2013-14 season with “The Last Goodbye,” a long-in-development adaptation of “Romeo and Juliet” set to the music of Jeff Buckley .
 
Conceived and adapted by Michael Kimmel, the show had a workshop run at the Williamstown Theater Festival in 2010. Alex Timbers ( “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson,” “ Here Lies Love” ) has succeeded Mr. Kimmel as the director for the Old Globe production, which is scheduled to run Sept. 20 to Nov. 3.

An article in some editions on Friday about the effect of federal budget cuts on emergency unemployment benefits for New York State residents misstated the status of cuts to unemployment benefits in New Jersey. New Jersey officials say they did not know when payments will shrink or by how much; the payments will not “start shrinking this week by as much as $66.”

Because of an editing error, an exhibition review on Friday about “Time and Navigation,” at the National Air and Space Museum in Washington, misidentified the site where a fleet of British ships sank in 1707, a disaster that gave new urgency to the effort to improve navigation. It was off the Isles of Scilly, near the southwest coast of Britain, not off Sicily.

Riddell, the country’s largest helmet manufacturer, will pay $3.1 million to a 22-year old man who was injured in 2008 while playing high school football.
After posting an 8.44 E.R.A. in two losses, R. A. Dickey looked sharp for Toronto, which is relying more than ever on its pitching in the wake of Jose Reyes’s injury.

The Chicago Cubs put closer Kyuji Fujikawa on the 15-day disabled list with a strained right forearm and called up reliever Rafael Dolis from Class AAA Iowa.

With Paul Pierce and Kevin Garnett back in the lineup, Boston made easy work of Orlando. After losing Saturday, the Bucks will be seeded eighth and will face the Heat in the first round.

Cannon Beach, Ore.

 
My wife, three young children and I took a long flight from New York City to Oregon to see the beautiful Northwest coast for our anniversary. It was a cool August morning on Cannon Beach during low tide.  We decided to look for sea stars (as starfish are called there).  After walking for about a mile from our hotel to the sea stacks, we found pools of water surrounding a rainbow of sea stars: purple, red and orange, their arms perfectly wrapped around each other as if to stay warm in the chilly Pacific. Our children, ages 1, 3 and 5, were so amazed by them that I took this shot. CHARLES MENJIVAR, Queens Village, Queens, taken on Aug. 8, 2012

Any thought of law school vanished the moment Ferrin Bujan stepped into a classroom as a student teacher. It was her last year at Queens College, where she was majoring in math and education, and she had been a little uncertain about her future.
 
“The world turned,” she said. “This is where I wanted to be. I enjoyed helping students who were struggling and knowing I could make a difference for them.”

HOROWITZ--Dr. Eli Herman, 86, of New Rochelle, New York, passed away on April 9, 2013. He was a deeply optimistic, loving, peaceful, generous, content, unpretentious, brilliant and kind man. His loving children (Carol, Bobby, Lori and Rob), grandchildren (Nina and Sarah Horowitz, Shayna, Devon and Cole Feuer), Siblings (Thelma Simon, Sue and Dan Schliftman, Sheila Sandelman), relatives, friends and countless patients will miss him dearly. Eli was valedictorian of his high school, a high honor student at Cornell University and valedictorian of NYU Dental School. He was also an officer in the US Navy. He was married for over five decades to Lila Gang Horowitz, the love and sunshine of his life. He spent all the time he could in Montauk and Key Biscayne, enjoying the ocean and the sunsets and was the most wonderful captain of the mighty Pink Panther. The funeral service will be held at 12:30 on April 10, 2013 at Temple Israel in Rochelle. Shiva will be held from Wednesday 49pm and Friday 12-9pm at the home of Carol and Rob, and Thursday 28pm and Sunday 15pm at the house of Bobby and Lori. Memorial donations may be made to Shoals Marine Lab and The Roker Center.

KANE--Peter, on March 24, age 70. Beloved son of the late Larry and Ruth. Loving brother of Debbie and Sonia. Cherished uncle of Allegra (Florian) and Daniel (Natalie) and great-nephew Adrian. A talented photographer and videographer, Peter worked as a news editor at KTVU in Oakland, CA, and also produced the Bay Area segment of the annual MDA Telethon. He leaves behind a collection of indelible images of the 60's protest movements and the lyrical beauty he encountered on the West Coast. We were inspired by his dignity and continued enthusiasm for life after his stroke nine years ago. We are so sad to lose him. A memorial service will be held at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn on April 21 at 2pm. Donations: MDA, 1388 Sutter Street, Suite #

Newman--Henry S. Died March 30th, 2013. He died in his own home in his own bed, as per his wishes, after ailing for several years. Born on March 31, 1920 in Warsaw, Poland, the eldest son of Wolf and Dora Neuman, Henry was the only Warsaw Ghetto and Holocaust survivor from his immediate family. Henry was liberated by the U.S. Army, then assisted the army, then temporarily settled in Munich, Germany. While there he fulfilled a dream of becoming a stage director at the State Operetta at Gartnerplatz in Munich. Henry married Charlotte Miller in 1946, and their daughter Dorothy was born in Munich in 1947. The new young family came to America in 1949. Henry joined the U.S. Army Reserves, and was called to active duty in 1950. He was honorably discharged from the army in June 1951. Back in New York Henry worked in television, and sold American films in Europe. Then, ahead of his time, Henry shifted gear in the 1960's to promote environmental quality. He worked with scientists to incorporate and sell Environmental Research and Applications, Inc. and Plastomedical Sciences, Inc. By this time, Dorothy was grown, Henry was divorced from Charlotte, and he married Jolanta Zadorecki in 1977. Their daughter Aleksandra was born in 1978. Henry retired from the corporate world to his home in New Castle in 1987. Since then, the novel he wrote in the 1950's, UNWANTED JOURNEY, about freedom, was computerized by his elder daughter and published in 1998. His short story about producing a show inside a concentration camp, BUDZYN AND THE SHOW OF SHOWS, was converted to a play by dramatist Guila Kessous, and performed at the Sanders Theater at Harvard University in May 2010. Henry S. Newman is survived by his two daughters, Dorothy Newman Haley and Aleksandra Newman Krsmanovic, and by two grandchildren, Konstanty and Kristina Krsmanovic.

SERGEON--Glen R. 63, on April 7, 2013 at home in New York City surrounded by his family. Mr. Sergeon was a connoisseur of the good life and a loving and loyal presence to all who knew him. He had impeccable taste and was a world traveler, with a special appreciation for fine wines and cuisine. He led a valiant and full existence. Mr. Sergeon was born in 1949 and raised in Vaux Hall, New Jersey. Before receiving a Masters in Public Policy from the University of Wisconsin, he attended Drew University and The London School of Economics. He began his career at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in 1973. He later spent nearly fifteen years in a variety of roles at Citicorp, finishing his time there as a Managing Director of Securities Markets. Mr. Sergeon went on to join Merrill Lynch Investment Managers, and retired from Merrill as Managing Director of Public Pension Fund Sales in 2006. Never one to remain idle, he continued to consult on the placement of private equity until 2012. Over the course of his storied career, Mr. Sergeon lived in both Bedford Hills and New York City. Mr. Sergeon supported his community, and showed his passion for education, through board positions held at Phipps Houses, The Spence School and New York State Teachers' Retirement System. Mr. Sergeon remained dedicated to his alma mater and recently donated his collection of rare African-American literature to the Drew University Library. Mr. Sergeon is survived by his two daughters Julia Leigh Sergeon and Vanessa Glenne Sergeon, as well as by his devoted sister and brother-in-law Glenda and Carter Smith. Memorial service Friday, April 19, 2013, 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81 St.

VAN DYKEN--Dorothy Anne Zito, 72 after a short illness passed on April 5, 2013 in Manhattan. She was born in Jersey City and raised in Wayne, N.J. Attended Juilliard School -Dance Major in 1958. Married musician, arranger and composer Torrie Zito 1958, they have a daughter, Lisa Zito. Studied dance at Martha Graham School, Harkness School and New York School of Ballet. Debut, 1967, professional name Dorothy Zito, with the New Dance group through 1969, New Jersey Repertory Dancers. Subsequently with Pearl Lang Company 1969-1972. Last appearance with Pearl Lang Company, 1975. Her second career was as a Fashion Consultant for the following stores in NYC, Bloomingdales, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Takashimaya, Tiffany & Company, Galleria La Rue and Agatha, after attending Fashion Institute of Technology, 1980-1982. Ms. Van Dyken said that "Juilliard provided me with the foundation to pursue my Dance Career and enjoy a productive life." Cherished and devoted Mother of Lisa Zito and her son in law Stefan. Beloved companion of Vito. Daughter of the late Ruth and John Van Dyken, Loving sister of Linda, Laura and Missy and the late Jacob and Eddie. She is also survived by many nieces and nephews. A private ceremony for family members only was held at the Cathedral Church of Saint John the Divine on April 11, 2013.

AKYAVAS--Nazan, Turkish artist Erol Akyavas and Ilona Akyavas's daughter, Mirgun Akyavas's sister, Matthew O'Brien's wife, Devin O'Brien's mother, our sweet Nazan has passed away on April 5, 2013. You are in our hearts forever.

BAIRD--Annette Feder, age 89 passed away on April 5, 2013 in Summit, NJ a week before her 90th birthday. Annette was a vivacious, vibrant lover of life and humankind. She graduated from Queens College and worked as a chemist for Columbia University and General Foods before raising two children and later becoming a devoted volunteer guide at The Boston Museum of Science. There, for over 25 years, she gave tours and specialized in electron microscope demonstrations. Visiting school groups were a special treat for her. Annette enjoyed baseball, jazz, and theater - and had a lifelong love of the arts, science, literature, and learning - which she shared with her beloved husband Donald (her partner for 59-years), her children Allison Fox and Douglas Baird, and her grandchildren Katie and Julian Fox and Gregory Baird. Annette will be dearly missed and remembered always with great love.

DEWAR--Robert Earl, on 7th April 2013. Beloved husband of Alison and father of Bessie, Charlotte and the late Gavin, much loved by Alex and Ed, and Violet's dear grandpa. Memorial service to be held at Christ Church, Middle Haddam, at 2pm on May 11. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Coleman Foundation, 313 South Church St, Hudson, Michigan 49246.

GARFIELD--Lawrence, 97, of Key Biscayne, FL, died April 4, 2013. Born in Newark, NJ December 10, 1915. He served in the Navy during WWII. After the war, he had an illustrious career in commercial real estate. Lawrence was one of the first members of the ICSC and built shopping centers in New Jersey and across the country. He leaves behind his loving wife Sunny of 65 years. He is also survived by his children Steven (Judith), Debra, Lisa (Bill), six grandchildren and two great-grandsons. He will be missed by all.

KELLY--Gertrude M.,longtime resident of Bronxville, died peacefully at home on April 3, 2013. Beloved wife of Joseph L. Kelly, loving mother of Liza Kelly--Rossini, cherished grandmother of Meghan Kathleen Rossini, gracious mother-in-law of Douglas Rossini and dear friend of Rae Rossini.

ROCKWELL--Peter, 53, passed while vacationing in Namibia on March 27, 2013. The son of David and Mary Rockwell of Weston, CT, he attended public schools and Harvard University, graduating Cum Laude in 1981. He received his law degree at Georgetown University in 1987 and began his career at Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher. Currently employed at Mitsubishi Trust & Bank Corporation, he was Chief Compliance Officer. Peter is survived by his mother, Mary Alice (nee Cullen), a brother, Charles Kellogg Rockwell, a sister, Anne W. Rockwell-Kollmann, and grandchildren, Sinclair and Tamina. A memorial celebrating his life will be held on April 17th at 3:00pm at the Frank Campbell Funeral Home on Madison Avenue in New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Peter's name may be made to Carnegie Hall.
LALIQUE--Marie-Claude. Ten years ago, on April 14, 2003, she left us. She touched all who knew and loved her and is dearly missed. May our fond memories of her be everlasting.

The History channel scored a ratings triumph with its mini-series “The Bible,” which built to the Crucifixion and a heavenward glance. Now Adult Swim has gone fishing for the same faith-based audience by looking in the other direction. 
 
Ha ha; just kidding. “Your Pretty Face Is Going to Hell,” the latest bite-size series to join Adult Swim’s late-night lineup, is certainly looking for an audience, but most assuredly not that one. The series, which has its premiere Thursday night, has the same demented take on the world — or, in this case, the underworld — as the programming block’s other shows, like “Childrens Hospital” and “Newsreaders.”

Because of an editing error, a news analysis article last Sunday about the longstanding Texas drought misstated the town where Cargill, the giant food producer, idled a beef-processing plant because of drought conditions. It is Plainview, not Plainfield.

A once chubby, bespectacled kid from Atlanta who wanted to be Erik Estrada on “CHiPs,” Ryan Seacrest is now 38 and the king of all media, racing from red-carpet interviews to his traffic-cop duties on “American Idol” to producing some of television’s most cultlike reality shows. We all have Seacrest to thank for the rise of the Kardashian clan. Though he trades on celebrity excess, he has somehow remained virtually gossip-proof — save the time TMZ called him out for almost phoning in sick for “American Idol.” (He didn’t.) Ladies and gentlemen, the hardest working man in show business.

Renault unveiled a striking blue concept car by Ross Lovegrove, a British furniture and product designer, at the Salone Internazionale del Mobile di Milano furniture show on Monday. The electric city car, dubbed the Twin’Z, has center opening doors and is dotted, outside and in, with hundreds of LEDs. The project was the idea of Laurens van den Acker, the Renault design director.
 
“The aim was to break down the boundaries between the world of an object whose calling is to be in movement – the automobile – and that of furniture,” Mr. Van den Acker said of Mr. Lovegrove’s involvement in the design. “There are numerous bridges between the work of Ross Lovegrove – which combines beauty and intelligence thanks to an approach inspired by the living, natural world – and the strategy we have been working on for three years now at Renault.”

For the last several years, the coolest design schools were those, like Design Academy Eindhoven in the Netherlands, that turned out the most conceptual work, much of it laced with social commentary. But now the school whose name seems to be everywhere is the ÉCAL/University of Art and Design Lausanne . Like many of its peers, the 192-year-old Swiss institution offers an undergraduate degree in industrial design. But unlike many schools, it also has something called the Master of Advanced Studies in Design for Luxury and Craftsmanship, which was founded five years ago and has made a name for itself through its collaborations — with luxury goods companies like Baccarat, Christofle, Bernardaud and Audemars Piguet — that bring new ideas to old-line manufacturers.
 
Two years ago, a group of ÉCAL students caused a sensation during the Milan furniture fair with an exhibition of witty reimaginings of a Baccarat classic, the Harcourt crystal goblet. Last year, another group came up with a series of colorful, ornamented vases, one of which, Brick, has been produced in a limited edition by Baccarat, along with a juice-squeezer goblet from the Harcourt project. This year, students worked with Baccarat on a collection of table, wall and hanging lights that will make its debut this month during the Milan fair. Unlike previous projects, in which student designs might only be one-offs or limited editions, the lights are meant for production. ÉCAL’s director, Alexis Georgacopoulos, says, “They’re entrusting us with something that’s more commercial from the start.” Another vote of confidence is a pledge from the Swiss watch company Vacheron Constantin to sponsor the program for the next three years.

ROCKWELL--Peter C.,1959-2013. The management and staff of Mitsubishi UFJ Trust and Banking Corporation in Japan and the New York Branch, sadly inform that their General Counsel and Senior Vice President, Mr. Peter C. Rockwell, passed away on March 27, 2013 while vacationing in Namibia, South Africa. He was 54 years old. Peter's passing brings great sadness to all who knew him as the excellent professional who served for many years as a member of the senior management at the Mitsubishi UFJ Trust and Banking Corporation, New York Branch. Peter loved life and cultivated friends throughout the world, especially in Manhattan and Japan where many valued him. He leaves behind the memory of wonderful human quality and a big heart. Our deepest condolences go out to his family members, his mother, Mary Alice (nee Cullen), his brother Charles K. Rockwell, his sister, Ann W. Rockwell-Kollman, his niece, Tamina and nephew Sinclair, brother in law and his numerous close friends.

ZALZAL--Pierre G. Lutheran HealthCare in Brooklyn, NY, mourns the passing of Pierre G. Zalzal, M.D., a neurologist at Lutheran Medical Center for 24 years and key member of the Stroke Center team and Medical and Dental Staff. Dr. Zalzal was a beloved co-worker, peer, physician and friend to many. He had a true passion for neurology and his patients and made it his mission to care for others. He was a man of style and substance and always treated his patients with grace and empathy. He was a humanist, a scholar and always humble. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, physicians and staff of Lutheran HealthCare, we send our sincere condolences to his wife Amal, his son Antoine, his daughter Youmna and their extended family and friends. Dr. Zalzal will be sorely missed. Emma Graeber Porter, Chair of the Lutheran HealthCare Board of Trustees, and Wendy Z. Goldstein, President and CEO.

HOROWITZ--Dr. Eli Herman, 86, of New Rochelle, New York, passed away on April 9, 2013. He was a deeply optimistic, loving, peaceful, generous, content, unpretentious, brilliant and kind man. His loving children (Carol, Bobby, Lori and Rob), grandchildren (Nina and Sarah Horowitz, Shayna, Devon and Cole Feuer), Siblings (Thelma Simon, Sue and Dan Schliftman, Sheila Sandelman), relatives, friends and countless patients will miss him dearly. Eli was valedictorian of his high school, a high honor student at Cornell University and valedictorian of NYU Dental School. He was also an officer in the US Navy. He was married for over five decades to Lila Gang Horowitz, the love and sunshine of his life. He spent all the time he could in Montauk and Key Biscayne, enjoying the ocean and the sunsets and was the most wonderful captain of the mighty Pink Panther. The funeral service will be held at 12:30 on April 10, 2013 at Temple Israel in Rochelle. Shiva will be held from Wednesday 49pm and Friday 12-9pm at the home of Carol and Rob, and Thursday 28pm and Sunday 15pm at the house of Bobby and Lori.  “The Infinity Pool of Executive Pay,” in Sunday Business last week, examined the path of C.E.O. compensation in 2012. Though the overall pay packages of 100 top C.E.O.’s grew relatively modestly, on average, the value of their perks — from private-jet travel to club dues — jumped 19 percent.

SCHERR--Leslie, Age 74, formerly of Potomac, MD, died on April 4, 2013. Leslie was born in the Bronx, on April 17, 1938. He graduated from Queens College and received his Juris Doctor from Columbia Law School. Leslie was a first generation American, self-made man, who had a lust for life and knowledge. He was an accomplished attorney who practiced criminal, civil and adoption law based in Washington, D.C. and litigated cases around the country. Leslie was an avid reader and accumulated an eclectic library. He volunteered at local libraries, raised money for charities and was a cooking instructor at L'Academie de Cuisine. He loved the New York Times, Jeopardy, all types of music, politics and debate, college basketball, travel, crossword puzzles, chess, bridge, scrabble, and above all his family and friends. He is survived by his wife, Susan Scherr; his son, Sloan Scherr and husband Patrick Moore; his daughter, Nikki O'Connell and husband Jim; his three grandchildren, Ryan, Aidan, and Madison; his sister Norma R. Ascher and husband Harvey; his uncle and aunt, Seymour and Thelma Grossman; aunt Geraldine Grossman; his sister-in-law Dr. Anita Auerbach; his nieces and nephews; his "daughters" Helen Taylor, Kristin Abshire, Charlotte Gilbert and Cathy Quinn; and the rest of his family and friends. A Celebration of Leslie's life will be held the first weekend of May, 2013 in Washington, D.C. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Queens College Foundation, c/o The Leslie Scherr Scholarship Fund, Attn: David D'Amato, 65-30 Kissena Blvd., Flushing, New York, 11367 or on-line at http://bit.ly/HonorLeslieScherr

An article on March 31 about the 2012 massacre at Oikos University in Oakland, Calif., misstated part of the name of the transportation system that services the San Francisco Bay Area. Known as BART, it is the Bay Area Rapid Transit, not the Bay Area Rapid Transport.

Those prolific songwriters Anonymous and Traditional have a de facto showcase this week at the fifth annual Brooklyn Folk Festival , where pickers, fiddlers, pipers, bluesmen and singers of sea chanteys, Mexican son jarocho and shape-note hymns will reach into some well-seasoned repertory. 
 
More than two dozen singers and groups are booked over three days at the Bell House in the Gowanus neighborhood. They include the clarinetist and mandolinist Andy Statman, a National Heritage Award recipient who is an adept of both klezmer and bluegrass; Peter Stampfel, who has been twisting folk traditions since he started the Holy Modal Rounders in the 1960s; and Tim Eriksen, a self-described “hard-core Americana” singer and fiddler. (Friday to next Sunday, 149 Seventh Street, near Second Avenue, 718-643-6510, brooklynfolkfest.com ; afternoon shows $15, evening shows $20, all-day passes $30 and three-day festival passes $80.)

Some art books skyrocket in value just a few years after they’re published. How much cash is sitting on your coffee table?

 
After witnessing the staggering after-market success of “ Helmut Newton: Sumo ” — which cost $1,500 when it came out in 1999 and is now worth 10 times that much — the art publisher Taschen has invested in making more of its books good investments. The company’s gigantic limited-run “art editions,” many of which come with signed gelatin prints, are specifically designed to appreciate in value. Some, like Mario Testino’s 2010 book on Kate Moss — which had a $500 list price and currently resells for $2,000 — do this very quickly. But the value of more modest art and fashion books can grow exponentially in a short time, too. A 2002 retrospective on the Vogue creative director Grace Coddington , originally priced at $125, rocketed to $2,000 after the release of the 2009 documentary “The September Issue.”

Sometimes, all you need is a sign. After clerking at a grocery store and touring as a musician for 11 years, Brian Girgus decided it was time for a life change and looking back, assessed what it would take: “I realized I should cut hair. I always did it anyways for girlfriends, myself or other friends.” He committed to working long nights after class and taking out a bank loan to finance barber school, until one incredible chance encounter with lady luck. “I went thrift shopping and tried on a coat,” Girgus said, “and in that coat found all of the money I needed for school, in cash.” On the first day of classes, he paid for his tuition in full.
 
Located on a hip strip of Sunset Boulevard, where Echo Park meets Silver Lake, the New California Barber Shop embodies quiet California cool. An oversize mural of white wind turbines set against the San Jacinto Mountains and a clear, bright blue sky, along with Girgus’s sweet pup, Shelley Long, warmly greet customers. The front door is always open, quite literally, and Girgus is ever present, working and accessible. “Hopefully people are as tired as I am of the owner of a place always being some rich guy that nobody ever knows or sees.” Sun-weathered wood and cactus plants add to the easygoing, lo-fi vibe. What you won’t see here are waxed mustaches and other tired clichés associated with all too many modern barbershops. “We’re comfortable with ourselves, have good personal style, and it brings that out in the people we help. We are not a man cave,” Girgus explains.

It’s fitting that a jeweler should live in a gem, and the Paris home of Marie-Hélène de Taillac, a penthouse apartment with views over the Parisian rooftops toward Saint-Sulpice, is a lovely one: simple, clean and understated, and in a constant dance with light. If you’ve ever dreamed of an Amélie-style garret sprinkled with a generous pinch of sophistication — and who hasn’t? — here it is, perched on the top floor of a building near de Taillac’s shop in Saint-Germain-des-Prés, complete with a terrace and climbing magnolias. “I love watching the clouds,” she says. “That is why I love this flat. In the summer we are out on the terrace, and in the winter we are by the fire.”

It’s not unusual to see a hipster tooling around Silver Lake or Williamsburg in a beat-up old Mercedes. What’s rarer is to find those 35-year-old sedans, coupes and wagons restored to mint condition. That’s the particular obsession of J. G. Francis (above right), who with the help of Sean Johnstun, founded Mercedes Motoring, a boutique restoration company based in Glendale, Calif.
 
Francis says he had an epiphany after buying a 1979 300SD for $700. “I’ve heard people say somebody should make a car that will last forever,” he says. “Mercedes did that 40 years ago.” The engineering may be superior — and that diesel engine still gets competitive gas mileage — but it’s the design that attracts many of the company’s clients. The classic colors, like mint green and China blue, and a boxy profile make these cars distinct from the S.U.V.’s and egg-shaped hybrids now crowding the roads. “I have never been drawn to things that are over the top,” Francis says. “I like things that are subtly amazing.” mercedesmotoring.com.

A review on March 24 about “Falling to Earth,” a novel by Kate Southwood about a devastating tornado that struck the Midwest in 1925, misstated the date of another historic natural disaster, the great Lisbon earthquake. It occurred in 1755, not 1748.

WHAT IS IT ABOUT TASTE? A sort of defensive look crosses many people’s faces when they hear the very word. If good taste is mentioned, often the reaction of sophisticates is a counterintuitive: “Oh, yuck.” And if bad, it often yields defiant admiration: “Well, I love a bit of bad taste, actually.” Do they? Don’t they really mean they desire something with guts? Gusto, after all, in Italian, means taste, goût to the French.
 
And yet, every continent, country and capital, is awash with bland beige, unrelieved by a lot of lifeless leather, a bit of black and a throw. And that’s not just the new breed of “modern” hotels, but apartments and homes as well, for people seem to want their living spaces to look exactly like the hotel, or spa, or friend’s house they just left. This dullness of “taste” is surely a watered-down version of those coolly elegant rooms that were so eye-opening decades ago. Think of the Mercer Hotel-ification of style: those dark brown wenge-wood bookcases are now the sine qua non of ubiquitous, bland modernity. Even an icon of great taste, like Cy Twombly’s house in Rome, has been the object of much dull, middle-of-the-road copycatting. Nowadays, the tedious sameness of so much modern architecture enhanced by a dash of classicism can only make such taste insipid.
