A picture caption last Sunday with an article about a Brooklyn brownstone renovated by Cindi Leive, the editor in chief of Glamour magazine, and Howard Bernstein, a film producer, misstated the number of floors in the house in some copies. As the article correctly noted, it has four stories, not three.

The hospitality brand of the Paramount Pictures film studio has announced that it is opening its first resort, Damac Towers by Paramount, in Dubai, in 2015. The studio behind classics like “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” (above) announced last year that it would license its name to a Dubai-based investment group for its hotels, which will include private screening rooms and a library of Paramount films. Hotels are also planned for Brazil, Indonesia and other countries.

There are essentially two kinds of actors: the ones who are seen and the ones who see. The ones who play characters and the ones who study people. The performers and the informers. 
 
Julianne Moore falls squarely into the latter, more rarefied, much, much smaller camp. Indeed, however unassumingly, she is its standard bearer. What makes her work so powerful, in films as diverse as “Far From Heaven” and “The Big Lebowski,” “Boogie Nights” and the forthcoming remake of “ Carrie ,” is that, for this actress, playing a role is not about sunbathing in admiration but about admiring the rest of us, in all of our varied subjectivities. For Moore, taking on the vocal inflections, the mannerisms, the emotional undercurrents and psychic thunderstorms of another human being is essentially just a way of seeing us all more deeply. She looks deeper into her characters, inhabits them more fully, loves them more completely and with less judgment than just about any actor out there. As a result, her best work has, in some small but undeniable way, managed not just to entertain but to elevate and ennoble the rest of us.

Injecting a tinge of athletic spirit to its archive of iconic punk-cult classics, the British shoe brand Dr. Martens introduces a new line of sneaker-inspired footwear for the spring season. The Farrell style, the standout in the new collection, combines the classic Dr. Martens air-cushioned wedge sole with a sleek smooth leather upper available in three colors (black, navy and cherry). Resembling many of the chunky-soled shoes that have treaded the runway in recent collections of Raf Simons, Acne and Marni, the Dr. Martens Farrell is a fresh alternative that can be worn with as much regularity as a favorite sneaker. And for under $100, it’s difficult not to want all three.
 
Dr. Martens Farrell shoe, $85; drmartens.com .

SHAPIRO--Michael, on April 12, 2013. It is with great sadness that we announce the death of our wonderful Michael. He is survived by his wife Jodi, sons Matthew and Lucas, parents Margie and Gary, sister Brandi, a large extended family and countless loving friends whose lives he deeply touched and who will forever miss him. Services 11am, Sunday at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. boulevardriversidechapel.com

LOVEJOY--Charlotte S.,passed away peacefully April 2, 2013 at home in Arlington, VA, age 71. She leaves three daughters by former husband Thomas E. Lovejoy, Elizabeth Lovejoy, Katherine Petty, Anne Jenkins, and five beloved granddaughters. She is also survived by her companion, Martha Kiser, of Fort Myers, FL. In lieu of flowers she requested donations be made to the Lemur Conservation Foundation: www.lemurreserve.org. There will be a private celebration of her life.

JOYCE CAROL OATES has taught creative writing at Princeton for 35 years, nurturing as undergraduates future stars like Pinckney Benedict, Jennifer Weiner and Alex Gansa. Now 74, she is retiring. Her last semester at Princeton — depicted as a campus plagued by evil in her new gilded-age Gothic, “The Accursed” — will be fall 2014. “I would have preferred not to retire,” she confessed in an e-mail interview. But she wanted to take an unpaid leave this term to teach at the University of California, Berkeley, where her husband is lecturing on neuroscience (she’ll also teach next spring at New York University). In exchange, she said, “I had to agree to retire within a few semesters.” Princeton would not elaborate.
 
MS. OATES ON RETIREMENT: I can understand that any institution leans toward phasing out more senior faculty, so that younger faculty can be hired, usually at lower salaries. This is all very transparent and sensible and it would be very wrong of me to have a principled complaint about it, though naturally I feel sad, and will miss Princeton terribly. One does have a sense of being ushered, not exactly forcibly, but firmly, in the direction of an exit door that, once you step through, will lock behind you as in a comical episode in “The Simpsons.”

FOR more than a decade, the University of Colorado, Boulder, hosted the country’s largest campus smokeout. More than 10,000 — some students, most not — would pour onto Norlin Quad every April 20. They would fill the air with a pungent haze of marijuana smoke, lighting up at 4:20 p.m. on the dot with potheads worldwide for what is known as 4/20.
 
Last year, the air smelled fishy. The university had sprayed fish-based fertilizer on the quad, cordoned it off with yellow police tape and closed the campus to outsiders. Only 300 to 400 congregated, facing police in SWAT gear. Cost: $130,000 (plus $100,000 for a concert aimed to distract). This year, the university will repeat its crackdown , though after discussions with student leaders, it will not fertilize.

ROCKWELL--Peter, 53, passed while vacationing in Namibia on March 27, 2013. The son of David and Mary Rockwell of Weston, CT, he attended public schools and Harvard University, graduating Cum Laude in 1981. He received his law degree at Georgetown University in 1987 and began his career at Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher. Currently employed at Mitsubishi Trust & Bank Corporation, he was Chief Compliance Officer. Peter is survived by his mother, Mary Alice (nee Cullen), a brother, Charles Kellogg Rockwell, a sister, Anne W. Rockwell-Kollmann, and grandchildren, Sinclair and Tamina. A memorial celebrating his life will be held on April 17th at 3:00pm at the Frank Campbell Funeral Home on Madison Avenue in New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Peter's name may be made to Carnegie Hall.

SULLIVAN--Benjamin J.,died peacefully on April 12, 2013 in his 95th year at his home in Dalton, Massachusetts. Ben was the son of the late Dr. Patrick Sullivan, long time physician in Dalton, and Margaret Maher Sullivan, and was predeceased in 1996 by his wife of 46 years, Louise Hennelly Sullivan (formerly of Pittsfield, Mass) and by his sisters Jean Ogden and Eleanor Collins. Ben was born on July 6, 1918 and resided for most of his life in Dalton, graduated from Dalton High School in 1935, continued on to The Choate School where he graduated in 1936, Yale University (class of 1940) and Harvard Business School (class of 1942). Upon graduation from HBS, Ben joined Crane & Co. Inc, paper manufacturers headquartered in Dalton, and shortly thereafter enlisted in the US Navy where during his four years of World War II active duty he was stationed in Newport, Rhode Island and Yorktown, Virginia, and multiple theaters in the Mediterranean, including North Africa and Italy, in the Ron 15 PT boat squadron. Following his discharge from the Navy in 1946, Ben rejoined Crane & Co. and over more than 45 years with Crane, held various operating and management positions, including being named President in 1975 as the first non-Crane family member to lead the company since its founding in 1801. Following his retirement from day-to-day management responsibilities in 1991, he continued as Chairman of Crane for several years. Ben's was highly devoted to numerous civic and charitable causes, including serving for many years on the Dalton Town Finance Committee, the board of the W. Murray Crane Community House in Dalton, the Berkshire Medical Center (Pittsfield) where he was highly involved as a board member in the expansion of BMC's facilities in the 1970s. Ben was also a long time member of the board of directors of the First Agricultural Bank and the Berkshire Life Insurance Company, both headquartered in Pittsfield, Massachusetts. Ben was an accomplished single digit handicap golfer, and multiple winner of the Country Club of Pittsfield club championship where he and Robert T. Jones III, the great golfer Bobby Jones's son, perennially dueled for the championship. He also served as a several term President of the Country Club of Pittsfield, was a member of the Wahconah Country Club in Dalton for over sixty years and a member of the Harbour Ridge Yacht and Country Club in Florida where he also maintained a residence. Ben was also a regular at the Bay State Seniors golf gatherings right through his 80th year. Ben was a life long communicant of St. Agnes Church in Dalton and had a long time association with the Benjamin F. Sullivan American Legion Post in Dalton, which was named after his father's brother who was killed in action in World War I. Ben is survived by his only son, Ben and his wife Charlotte of Rye, New York, together with four grandchildren, who lovingly adored their grandfather, Madeleine Sullivan of New York City, Charles Sullivan of Washington, D.C., Christopher Sullivan of Boston, Mass., and Catherine Sullivan a student at UNC Chapel Hill, North Carolina. Funeral Services will be held on Monday, April 15m at 10:45am, from the Dery-Foley Funeral Home, 890 East Main Street, Dalton, Mass., with a Liturgy of Christian Burial at 11:30am, at St. Agnes Church, 489 Main Street, Dalton, celebrated by Rev. Christopher A. Malatesta, Pastor. Burial, with military honors, will follow in Fairview Cemetery, Dalton. Calling hours will be Sunday, from 4:00 to 7:00pm, at the Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Mr. Sullivan may be made to Berkshire United Way in care of the Dery-Foley Funeral Home, 890 East Main Street, Dalton, MA 01226.

I’m just mad for these candylicious resin lamps by the London-based designer Marianna Kennedy . They come in eye-popping colors like deep sea green or chrome yellow, and at about $600 each (with shade) are relatively affordable, unlike the lacquered gueridon tables and gilded mercury mirrors in Kennedy’s gallery-quality collection. The conical shades are made from antique book cloth, most of which Kennedy sources from Paris. “Isn’t it funny,” she says, “you just have to say it comes from Paris and it sounds irresistible.”

In the history of painting Diego Velázquez had a seismic effect. Now real earthquakes are bringing one of his best portraits to the United States for the first time. On Tuesday the Metropolitan Museum of Art will open a single-painting exhibition of Velázquez’s “Portrait of Duke Francesco I d’Este ,” which practically drips with the hauteur of the Duke of Modena, who had come to Madrid in 1638 to secure political support and, in the process, became immortalized on canvas. The exhibition, which runs through July 14, is timed to celebrate the Met’s reinstallation of its European paintings galleries in May. But it has happened only because the Velázquez’s home, the Galleria Estense in Modena, which has one of the best small paintings collections in Italy, is still closed because of damage from the severe earthquakes that struck the region last year.
 
The painting is “a high-water mark in the history of Baroque portraiture,” as the Met describes it, and a potent demonstration of Velázquez’s contribution to international diplomacy as well as art. (212-535-7710, metmuseum.org .)

Brenda Priddy, an auto spy photographer, is starting a camp for people who dream of joining the ranks of car paparazzi. Starting on July 7, Ms. Priddy will lead would-be car spies through the basics of her craft in a four-day camp in the Nevada desert.
 
July may sound like a miserable time to be in such a hot place, but Ms. Priddy said that it’s the busiest time of year as far as car testing goes.

An indulgent and elegant apartment on the 42nd floor of the Trump International Hotel and Tower, which was reconfigured to a two-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath aerie from the original four bedrooms and six baths by the designer Jeffrey Bilhuber, sold for $16.25 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.
 
The condominium, No. 42C at One Central Park West, had been listed last year at $19.9 million and sold after a reduction to $17.9 million; the monthly carrying charges are $12,531, and, as with most Trump properties, oodles of amenities are included with the privilege of ownership. The 4,415-square-foot residence, which has impressive views of Central Park, the Hudson River and the cityscape, sold for $5.04 million as a sponsor unit in 1997. After the owner enlisted Mr. Bilhuber to modernize and dramatize it, the property was featured in the May 2001 issue of Architectural Digest. Among other changes, he installed bamboo flooring in the foyer, created a private master suite with a limestone bath and separate dressing room, and designed an equally impressive guest suite with an elevated Japanese soaking tub made from black soapstone.

TALLCHIEF--Maria, The School of American Ballet is profoundly saddened by the loss of Maria Tallchief. Maria first entered SAB's classrooms in the mid-1940s. As a student, then as a guest teacher and later as a longtime member of the School's Advisory Council, Maria has remained an important and beloved member of the SAB family for almost 70 years. Peter Martins and the board, faculty, staff and students extend our deepest condolences to Maria's sister Marjorie and daughter Elise as we remember and celebrate the life of one of the most influential and accomplished American dancers of the twentieth century.

THOMPSON--Barbara Benkhart, January 18, 1928- April 7, 2013. Barbara passed away peacefully on April 7, 2013 with her loving son at her side. Barbara was preceded in death by Mac, her devoted husband of 62 years. She is survived by her son Jack, daughter-in-law Kim and granddaughters Kaitlin and Grace. Barbara, better known as "Sweetie", will forever be remembered as the perfect wife and mother and intensely loyal to family and friends alike, all the while offering a helping hand and a sunny outlook on life. VAN DYKEN--Dorothy Anne Zito, 72 after a short illness passed on April 5, 2013 in Manhattan. She was born in Jersey City and raised in Wayne, N.J. Attended Juilliard School -Dance Major in 1958. Married musician, arranger and composer Torrie Zito 1958, they have a daughter, Lisa Zito. Studied dance at Martha Graham School, Harkness School and New York School of Ballet. Debut, 1967, professional name Dorothy Zito, with the New Dance group through 1969, New Jersey Repertory Dancers. Subsequently with Pearl Lang Company 1969-1972. Last appearance with Pearl Lang Company, 1975. Her second career was as a Fashion Consultant for the following stores in NYC, Bloomingdales, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Takashimaya, Tiffany & Company, Galleria La Rue and Agatha, after attending Fashion Institute of Technology, 1980-1982. Ms. Van Dyken said that "Juilliard provided me with the foundation to pursue my Dance Career and enjoy a productive life." Cherished and devoted Mother of Lisa Zito and her son in law Stefan. Beloved companion of Vito. Daughter of the late Ruth and John Van Dyken, Loving sister of Linda, Laura and Missy and the late Jacob and Eddie. She is also survived by many nieces and nephews. A private ceremony for family members only was held at the Cathedral Church of Saint John the Divine on April 11, 2013.

Vienna’s Palais Liechtenstein, one of Europe’s most impressive privately owned palaces, will open for public tours for the first time in May after an extensive restoration. Once the residence of the royal family of Liechtenstein, the Baroque building was bombed during World War II and damaged further when an Allied aircraft crashed into its roof. Its four-year, $135 million face-lift restores the structure to its prewar glory, with a dramatic interior staircase, silk wall hangings and intricate parquet floors. The project was overseen by Hans-Adam II, the reigning prince of the tiny principality — who also owns another commodious palace just outside the city center, where he keeps his noted collection of Old Masters. While some of the revamped building will be marked off for the family’s private apartments, visitors will finally get a peek at many of its gilded Rococo interiors, not to mention the prince’s collection of Biedermeier and neo-Classical art and furnishings. Tours from $32; palaisliechtenstein.com.

Since taking over his father’s venerable stores last year, the designer Jasper Conran has been quietly revolutionizing the brand. At the flagship Chelsea location in London, shelves brim with Marie Daâge Limoges porcelain, vintage Blodwen Welsh blankets and linens as crisp as Granny Smith apples. There are edgier home pieces by Maison Martin Margiela, chic-beyond-chic stainless steel kitchens by Alpes Inox and divine cloud sculptures that the artist Benedetta Mori Ubaldini makes out of chicken wire. Conran has also added an entire section dedicated to the sort of children’s goodies — pink roller skates, giant buttons, paper pompoms — that you want to buy regardless of age. In May, he will reopen the Conran Shop’s location in Marylebone, complete with a Penthouse apartment, fully decorated and shoppable, and a roof terrace. “I love the idea of the store as a magazine,” Conran says. “It’s about highlighting different things, and discovering and showcasing new talent.” 81 Fulham Road, London; 011-44-20-7589-7401.

Abelardo Morell wants us to pay attention, to understand that there’s more to seeing than what we think we perceive. There’s no reason a cityscape can’t bloom on quiet, white bedsheets, or, as above, the Golden Gate Bridge can’t be shockingly found superimposed on the very ground. “Abelardo Morell: The Universe Next Door” opens June 1 at the Art Institute of Chicago with more than 100 works from 1986 to the present that sing a hymn of praise to the strange. He has experimented with a range of techniques, most recently the tent camera, a kind of portable camera obscura that throws the image of a landscape upon the ground’s surface ( artic.edu ).

Between New York City Ballet’s winter and spring seasons we can still catch a glimpse of the company’s most complexly striking ballerina, Wendy Whelan, at the Guggenheim Museum’s Works & Process series — or, to avoid the waiting list, at ustream.tv/worksandprocess , where the sold-out preview of “Restless Creature” will be streamed live on Sunday at 3 p.m. 
 
Branching out from her ballet roots and into less familiar physical territory (more fluidity in the spine, more weight into the ground), Ms. Whelan has teamed with four contemporary dancemakers — Kyle Abraham, Joshua Beamish, Brian Brooks and Alejandro Cerrudo — to create a collection of duets, which will have their premiere in full at Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival this summer. At the Guggenheim she performs excerpts from Mr. Beamish’s and Mr. Brooks’s contributions (partnered by the choreographers themselves), though all four men will be on hand for a conversation with Ella Baff, the Pillow’s executive and artistic director. Ms. Whelan also revisits a 2005 solo by the Chinese-born choreographer Shen Wei — his first work for point shoes. (3 and 7:30 p.m. Sunday, and 7:30 p.m. Monday, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, 212-423-3587, worksandprocess.org ; sold out.)

Closets, the Bigger the Better

 
The cover article last week, “Hooked by a Closet,” described how closets in New York City apartments have evolved into an important factor in real estate decisions. Following are edited excerpts of reader comments from nytimes. com:

Travelers taking the carrier Samoa Air have an incentive besides health and vanity to shed a few pounds. The airline has adopted a policy of charging its passengers according to what they weigh.
 
“It’s simple. A kilo is a kilo is a kilo,” said Chris Langton, Samoa Air’s chief executive. “And the cost of a kilo is the same for everybody.”

Wearing an apron and licking cookie batter off of her fingers, the model Karlie Kloss graces the cover of the inaugural issue of Cherry Bombe . Right away, the focus of Claudia Wu and Kerry Diamond’s new magazine is clear: food. And it’s almost exclusively up to women to talk about it, write about it and serve it up in Issue No 1: Tastemakers, which hits newsstands the first week of May.
 
Wu, the creative director, and Diamond, the editorial director, met while working at Harper’s Bazaar in 2001. With the help of an A-list lineup of contributors and subjects ranging from the filmmaker Sofia Coppola to the bestselling author and chef Gabrielle Hamilton, the pair have created a world where the simple Good Humor chocolate chip cookie sandwich comes off as a sexy indulgence, everyone from a food bookshop owner to a Tennessee BBQ pit master is female, and a chic Williamsburg dinner party happens on a $100 budget. According to Diamond, the project came about as a way to represent the “thoughtful people doing and making beautiful things” in today’s food scene with refreshing layouts (Wu has her own graphic design firm) and engaging interviews (Diamond is a Brooklyn restaurateur with an editorial background), in this biannual treat.

BAIRD--Annette Feder, age 89 passed away on April 5, 2013 in Summit, NJ a week before her 90th birthday. Annette was a vivacious, vibrant lover of life and humankind. She graduated from Queens College and worked as a chemist for Columbia University and General Foods before raising two children and later becoming a devoted volunteer guide at The Boston Museum of Science. There, for over 25 years, she gave tours and specialized in electron microscope demonstrations. Visiting school groups were a special treat for her. Annette enjoyed baseball, jazz, and theater - and had a lifelong love of the arts, science, literature, and learning - which she shared with her beloved husband Donald (her partner for 59-years), her children Allison Fox and Douglas Baird, and her grandchildren Katie and Julian Fox and Gregory Baird. Annette will be dearly missed and remembered always with great love.

COLCORD--Bradford Phillips, 82, of New York City, passed away peacefully at home on April 9th due to complications from polymyositis. Phil was born in Edwardsville, Illinois on April 5, 1931, son of Bradford Colcord and Elizabeth Phillips. He lived in Missouri, Alabama and Pennsylvania from 1931-1941. He graduated from the University School in Cleveland as Salutatorian and continued on to receive a Bachelor of Arts cum laude degree from Yale College in 1952 and JD from Harvard Law School in 1955. Thereafter he served in Army counter intelligence in Germany until 1958. Phil was married to Helen Burgess Johnson on April 7, 1962; they were married 51 years. Phil was a member of the New York, D.C. and Ohio Bars and worked as an attorney for Goodwin Savage Clare and Whitehead as an Associate and Partner before founding Colcord and Mackenty in 1976. Since 1987 he has been a sole practitioner. He had a love of European history and culture serving as President of the American Swiss Association in the 1970s, touring English country houses and collecting English silver. He enjoyed skiing and spent every summer in Maine since 1965. Later in life, travels took him to the Far East, India and Middle East. He was a dedicated Yale fundraiser and Pittsburgh Steeler fan. Devotion to his communities, common decency and curiosity governed his life to the end. Phil is survived by his wife Helen, son and daughter Avery and Hilary, and grandchildren Avery and Hayden Giles and Helena and Philip Colcord, and many friends. A gathering will be held on May 2nd in New York City and another gathering of friends will happen in late July in Maine. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be given to Doctors Without Borders, The Doe Fund, and The Central Park Conservancy.

SPATT--Dorothy G.,beloved mother, grandmother, and sister, passed away on April 13, 2013, in Manhasset, New York. Dee was an outstanding teacher and guidance counselor. However, after marrying Arthur, she devoted her life to her husband, children, and grandchildren. Dee was a warm, selfless person, who cared about her family in every way. She was an uplifting, positive person, who treated everyone as a friend, and treated everyone with respect. Her Judaism was a very important part of her life. Dee was an avid reader, and always wanted to learn. However, her family was always paramount to her. We will miss and love her forever. The funeral will be on Monday, April 15, 2013, at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck.

HEIBERGER--Edwin, A prominent Long Island-based real estate developer and lifelong entrepreneur who led the construction of a notable series of luxury custom homes throughout parts of Suffolk County, including the Hamptons, and along Nassau County's Gold Coast, and founded a prestigious racquet and yacht club in the area, died Tuesday in Commack. He was 74. A go-getter and man of many ideas, Heiberger began his first business, Turf Sprinklers, an underground lawn sprinkler company, in his late teens, operating as a pioneer in that industry for 10 years throughout his days as a high school football star and student at the University of Oklahoma. Following the sale of the sprinkler business, Heiberger opened the prominent Harbour Point Racquet and Yacht Club in Freeport, Nassau County, which he sold in 1982. A love for real estate led him to start his own luxury custom home-building project that same year, in which he oversaw the development of several ground-up residential properties, including a 24-home subdivision in East Quogue. Heiberger quickly established himself as a known and reputable builder across Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and remained in the business until recently. Edwin Heiberger was born on October 23, 1938, in Brooklyn, the son of William, a prominent New York attorney, and Irene. He was reared in Far Rockaway, Queens, where he met his high school sweetheart and wife of 53 years, Sidnie, before relocating with her to Baldwin, NY, and then on to Dix Hills in Suffolk County, where the two spent the remainder of their adult lives. A mentor and role model to friends, employees and above all, his family, Heiberger is survived by his wife Sidnie; his children Lisa, Steven and Andrew; his six grandchildren, Ashley, Alex, Samantha, Madison, Lucas and Nikki; and sisters Meta and Holly.

PALACHE--Lucy B.,85, of New York, New York, died at St. Luke's Hospital of complications from pneumonia on March 31, 2013. She was the daughter of the late John G. Palache and Eunice Underwood Palache. She is survived by her brother, John G. Palache, Jr., and his wife, Sally B. Palache, of Greenwich, Connecticut, her nephew, J. Whitney Palache of Greenwich, and her niece, Lisa P. Carey, married to Robert A. Carey and their two children, Helen A. Carey and John K. Carey, of San Francisco. She was a graduate of Kent Place School, Radcliffe College and received a Masters Degree from Columbia University, where her thesis was entitled "George Bernard Shaw and Music". Her interests were music, literature and animals. She is remembered for her generous spirit, her wit and her unequivocal opinions on most subjects. Funeral services at St. Clement's Episcopal Church in Berkeley, California, will be held at a future date. Contributions in her name may be made to The Metropolitan Opera Association, Office of Planned Giving, 30 Lincoln Center, New York, NY 10023. Her family is deeply appreciative of the care and support provided to her by the doctors and staff of Amsterdam House and St. Luke's Hospital over the past few years.

SHAPIRO--Michael Seth. Age 37. After a heroic 2 1/2 year battle with brain cancer. Husband of Jodi, Father of Matthew and Lucas, Son of Marjorie and Gary Shapiro, Brother of Brandi and Adam Goldenberg. May your eternal smile be a beacon to others for years to come. We will love you forever, Mom and Dad.

TALLCHIEF--Maria. Peter Martins and the entire New York City Ballet family mourn the passing of Maria Tallchief, the extraordinary American ballerina who was a founding member of our Company. Maria's dazzling talent electrified audiences in the early years of our history, as she worked with George Balanchine to create some of the most enduring roles in all of ballet, including her now legendary performances in Orpheus, Firebird, Swan Lake, and The Nutcracker. Following her career onstage, Maria's role as a teacher and director was an inspiration for countless young dancers and her work will have a lasting impact for generations to come. The world of dance has lost a true giant, and she will be greatly missed. All of us at NYCB express our heartfelt condolences to Maria's sister Marjorie, daughter Elise Paschen, and her entire family.

Around 400 B.C., Socrates was brought to trial on charges of corrupting the youth of Athens and “impiety.” Presumably, however, people believed then as we do now, that Socrates’ real crime was being too clever and, not insignificantly, a royal pain to those in power or, as Plato put it, a gadfly. Just as a gadfly is an insect that could sting a horse and prod it into action, so too could Socrates sting the state. He challenged the moral values of his contemporaries and refused to go along with unjust demands of tyrants, often obstructing their plans when he could. Socrates thought his service to Athens should have earned him free dinners for life. He was given a cup of hemlock instead.
 
We have had gadflies among us ever since, but one contemporary breed in particular has come in for a rough time of late: the “hacktivist.” While none have yet been forced to drink hemlock, the state has come down on them with remarkable force. This is in large measure evidence of how poignant, and troubling, their message has been.

It’s no surprise that Camille Miceli makes jewelry that is covetable and well designed. The daughter of a French stylist, Miceli began creating jewelry for Louis Vuitton back in 2004 and, since 2009, has been doing the same for Dior. Her superchic personal style has been touted by fashion heavyweights like her current boss, Raf Simons, as well as her former employer Marc Jacobs, who has called her his muse. Each piece in Miceli’s prefall collection for Dior has the ability to single-handedly pull an outfit together. These are objects that are both substantial and restrained — like the Diorama necklace, a breastplate-like collar of gold-finished metal adorned with a single, gleaming red glass stone.

That’s the number of major computer-animated movies out this summer, including “Epic” (May 24), “Monsters University” (June 21), “Despicable Me 2” (July 3), “Turbo” (July 19) and “Planes” (Aug. 9), up from three last season. Some in the industry wonder if that’s just too many: How many 3-D tickets can one family afford? But never doubt the baby-sitting power of a cartoon — or the Hollywood hard sell. Expect a superheroic sales push behind “Turbo” in particular; a spinoff television series arrives in December.

season is on.

Victor J. Blue took this picture from the front car of a C train as it pulled into the High Street station in Brooklyn. “Under the streets of the city we barrel in and out of tunnels,” he said, but — as the reflection shows — “we still manage to carve out moments of quiet, to pause and read and reflect.”

HEIBERGER--Edwin, A prominent Long Island-based real estate developer and lifelong entrepreneur who led the construction of a notable series of luxury custom homes throughout parts of Suffolk County, including the Hamptons, and along Nassau County's Gold Coast, and founded a prestigious racquet and yacht club in the area, died Tuesday in Commack. He was 74. A go-getter and man of many ideas, Heiberger began his first business, Turf Sprinklers, an underground lawn sprinkler company, in his late teens, operating as a pioneer in that industry for 10 years throughout his days as a high school football star and student at the University of Oklahoma. Following the sale of the sprinkler business, Heiberger opened the prominent Harbour Point Racquet and Yacht Club in Freeport, Nassau County, which he sold in 1982. A love for real estate led him to start his own luxury custom home-building project that same year, in which he oversaw the development of several ground-up residential properties, including a 24-home subdivision in East Quogue. Heiberger quickly established himself as a known and reputable builder across Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and remained in the business until recently. Edwin Heiberger was born on October 23, 1938, in Brooklyn, the son of William, a prominent New York attorney, and Irene. He was reared in Far Rockaway, Queens, where he met his high school sweetheart and wife of 53 years, Sidnie, before relocating with her to Baldwin, NY, and then on to Dix Hills in Suffolk County, where the two spent the remainder of their adult lives. A mentor and role model to friends, employees and above all, his family, Heiberger is survived by his wife Sidnie; his children Lisa, Steven and Andrew; his six grandchildren, Ashley, Alex, Samantha, Madison, Lucas and Nikki; and sisters Meta and Holly.

MUSSELMAN--Francis Haas. The partners of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy LLP mourn the passing of their friend and partner, Francis H. Musselman. Frank joined Milbank as an associate in 1953, became a partner in 1960 and founded Milbank's Washington D.C. office in 1980. From 1970-1984, he served as Managing Partner of Milbank and later retired in 1990. Frank was widely recognized as a leading specialist in bankruptcy law and law firm management and was a pioneer in the use of computers in law firms. Tall in stature and with a kindness of spirit, generosity and sense of humor to match, Frank was a mentor, advisor and friend to many at Milbank over his 47-year career at the Firm, and he will be sorely missed. We wish to express our deepest sympathy to Frank's four children, nine grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.

Newman--Henry S. Died March 30th, 2013. He died in his own home in his own bed, as per his wishes, after ailing for several years. Born on March 31, 1920 in Warsaw, Poland, the eldest son of Wolf and Dora Neuman, Henry was the only Warsaw Ghetto and Holocaust survivor from his immediate family. Henry was liberated by the U.S. Army, then assisted the army, then temporarily settled in Munich, Germany. While there he fulfilled a dream of becoming a stage director at the State Operetta at Gartnerplatz in Munich. Henry married Charlotte Miller in 1946, and their daughter Dorothy was born in Munich in 1947. The new young family came to America in 1949. Henry joined the U.S. Army Reserves, and was called to active duty in 1950. He was honorably discharged from the army in June 1951. Back in New York Henry worked in television, and sold American films in Europe. Then, ahead of his time, Henry shifted gear in the 1960's to promote environmental quality. He worked with scientists to incorporate and sell Environmental Research and Applications, Inc. and Plastomedical Sciences, Inc. By this time, Dorothy was grown, Henry was divorced from Charlotte, and he married Jolanta Zadorecki in 1977. Their daughter Aleksandra was born in 1978. Henry retired from the corporate world to his home in New Castle in 1987. Since then, the novel he wrote in the 1950's, UNWANTED JOURNEY, about freedom, was computerized by his elder daughter and published in 1998. His short story about producing a show inside a concentration camp, BUDZYN AND THE SHOW OF SHOWS, was converted to a play by dramatist Guila Kessous, and performed at the Sanders Theater at Harvard University in May 2010. Henry S. Newman is survived by his two daughters, Dorothy Newman Haley and Aleksandra Newman Krsmanovic, and by two grandchildren, Konstanty and Kristina Krsmanovic.

SERGEON--Glen R. 63, on April 7, 2013 at home in New York City surrounded by his family. Mr. Sergeon was a connoisseur of the good life and a loving and loyal presence to all who knew him. He had impeccable taste and was a world traveler, with a special appreciation for fine wines and cuisine. He led a valiant and full existence. Mr. Sergeon was born in 1949 and raised in Vaux Hall, New Jersey. Before receiving a Masters in Public Policy from the University of Wisconsin, he attended Drew University and The London School of Economics. He began his career at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in 1973. He later spent nearly fifteen years in a variety of roles at Citicorp, finishing his time there as a Managing Director of Securities Markets. Mr. Sergeon went on to join Merrill Lynch Investment Managers, and retired from Merrill as Managing Director of Public Pension Fund Sales in 2006. Never one to remain idle, he continued to consult on the placement of private equity until 2012. Over the course of his storied career, Mr. Sergeon lived in both Bedford Hills and New York City. Mr. Sergeon supported his community, and showed his passion for education, through board positions held at Phipps Houses, The Spence School and New York State Teachers' Retirement System. Mr. Sergeon remained dedicated to his alma mater and recently donated his collection of rare African-American literature to the Drew University Library. Mr. Sergeon is survived by his two daughters Julia Leigh Sergeon and Vanessa Glenne Sergeon, as well as by his devoted sister and brother-in-law Glenda and Carter Smith. Memorial service Friday, April 19, 2013, 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81 St.

The architect Rafael de Cárdenas has electrified Rivieras , the classic French slip-on, with a sharp new pattern available in four color combos. De Cárdenas says the shoe brand was a natural fit for him. “I like their form and shape as well as their nod to the ’60s and ’70s French Riviera summer culture,” he says. “I also like that they are called a ‘leisure shoe,’ almost as though wearing them might relax you regardless of whether you’re leisurely or not.” $100; Opening Ceremony, (212) 219-2688.

In 2011, immediately after Sean Brock opened the restaurant Husk in a restored Victorian house on Queen Street in Charleston, S.C., the young chef was hailed a savior of Southern cuisine. Brock had schooled himself in forgotten kitchen volumes like “The Carolina Housewife,” and revived strains of sesame and field peas that hadn’t been cultivated there for centuries. “If it wasn’t from the South, it wasn’t coming in the door,” he decreed. His reverence for antebellum ingredients easily could have produced a menu of heirloom dishes, a kind of reenactment restaurant. But that’s not what happened.
 
Instead Brock discovered a way to celebrate the South’s past and present at the same moment, even sometimes in the same dish. He found a guy brewing soy sauce in old bourbon barrels and concocted a “Kentuckyaki” glaze to brush over pig’s ears that had been boiled for hours, then deep-fried, then tucked, Korean style, into butter-lettuce wraps.

In “From Europe With Love ,” opening May 2 at the Cristina Grajales gallery in SoHo, the Paris-based designer Sam Baron reinterprets traditional European design with what he calls “a kind of French sense of humor.” He applies a champagne-colored lacquer to Louis XVI-style cabinets, and deconstructs the traditional process of painting these bisque porcelain birds made by the venerable Portuguese house Vista Alegre. Through July 12; 10 Greene Street.

A report in a roundup of Wheels blog posts last Sunday about a new electric roadster misstated the process by which the Detroit Electric car company obtained rights to its name, which was abandoned when the original automaker of that name went out of business in 1939. The United States Patent and Trademark Office authorized the new use; the name was not purchased from a previous owner.

Raleigh’s Warehouse District ( raleighwarehousedistrict.com ), six blocks of spacious red-brick buildings west of downtown, by the end of this year, the long-dormant area had slowly started to hum with galleries, shops and restaurants. Retailers not only offer handcrafted items, but also provide a close-up view of the production process to customers. Three films by the Cambodian documentarian Rithy Panh — “The Land of the Wandering Souls,” “S21: The Khmer Rouge Death Machine” and “Duch, Master of the Forges of Hell” — constitute the heart of the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s series Old Ghosts, New Dreams: The Emerging Cambodian Cinema. Two of those directly explore the bitter legacy of the Khmer Rouge regime, which committed mass murder (as many as 1.8 million people) when it ruled the country in the 1970s.
 
In “S21” he brings two survivors along with former members of the Khmer Rouge to the former Tuol Sleng prison (code-named S21). Vann Nath, a painter who escaped the prison, confronts former Khmer Rouge guards who recount atrocities they committed when they were as young as 12.

The artist Cyprien Gaillard recalls the moment he discovered poetry in the most unusual places: decaying landscapes, demolished building sites, even cracks in the pavement.

 
Until Cyprien Gaillard came along, the “Monument to Joe Louis” in Detroit had about as much in common with Abu Simbel temples as the ancient Egyptian structures did with high-rises in the Bronx. But “Geographical Analogies” — a series of collages that the 32-year-old artist assembled over five years from 963 Polaroids — unites sacred pyramids, failed resorts, public toilets, marble caves, modernist buildings, classical columns and other anomalous artifacts of civilization as if they were estranged members of a single family extending across all time.

Hawaiian Airlines has become the first domestic carrier to extend the concept of self-check-in to luggage. The airline recently began allowing passengers at check-in kiosks at Honolulu International Airport to weigh and tag their bags. The move is expected to cut check-in time, already down to a slim eight minutes, in half, according to Hawaiian.

With her eye for the unusual, the ancient and the brightly colored, Irene Silvagni orchestrates her Provencal retreat into a wonderfully imperfect harmony.

 
“I like the imperfections of things,” Irene Silvagni declares. And to look at the rooms of her home in Provence — with their centuries-old stone floors, worn antique furniture covered with vintage textiles and picture frames without pictures, among other things — you know she means it. The rambling, 8,000-square-foot residence, parts of which date back to the 16th century, is a never-ending project for Silvagni, 71, a former fashion editor for French Vogue (and, more recently, a creative consultant for Yohji Yamamoto, and now for Giambattista Valli). She firmly believes that a house “should never be finished. When the house is finished, you die,” she says.

To make a legendary room you have to have extreme conviction. The power decorator Juan Pablo Molyneux’s blue and white tiled vestibule at his 17th-century house in Paris, which he shares with his wife, Pilar, rates as epic. It’s a perfect example of the designer’s dedication to the vernacular of place, historical mastery and pure creative rapture.
 
Molyneux says he was ceramically inspired “by two famous examples of architecture.” One was a small pavilion at Versailles called the Trianon de Porcelaine, whose interior and exterior were covered in blue and white faience that existed for roughly 17 years. The second is a tiled palace in St. Petersburg built by a Russian Prince, Aleksandr Menshikov, in 1710.

A FEW TIMES A YEAR, Nick Pologeorgis leaves his family’s business on West 29th Street to attend the fur auctions in Toronto, Seattle and St. Petersburg, the home of the Russian sable market. His father, Stanley, started Pologeorgis Furs in 1960; after Nick graduated from Boston University in 1984 with a degree in finance, he joined the firm. His sister, Joan, works on the production side. Lately, if there’s one thing Mr. Pologeorgis has noticed at the auctions, aside from rising prices (they have doubled in the last three years), it’s the number of Chinese bidders. No doubt the two are connected.
 
I first heard about Mr. Pologeorgis from Ralph Rucci a decade ago — like almost everyone in the industry, he calls him Nick — and I got the sense that he loves a challenge and will go to any length to accomplish it. He once made knitted sable pants for Mr. Rucci (the collector Iris Apfel owns them), and he did the camouflage furs for Michael Kors’s last show. His sister had a real time making them, he said, because each piece had to be cut and dyed and then assembled. “It was like a puzzle.”

COLCORD--Bradford Phillips, 82, of New York City, passed away peacefully at home on April 9th due to complications from polymyositis. Phil was born in Edwardsville, Illinois on April 5, 1931, son of Bradford Colcord and Elizabeth Phillips. He lived in Missouri, Alabama and Pennsylvania from 1931-1941. He graduated from the University School in Cleveland as Salutatorian and continued on to receive a Bachelor of Arts cum laude degree from Yale College in 1952 and JD from Harvard Law School in 1955. Thereafter he served in Army counter intelligence in Germany until 1958. Phil was married to Helen Burgess Johnson on April 7, 1962; they were married 51 years. Phil was a member of the New York, D.C. and Ohio Bars and worked as an attorney for Goodwin Savage Clare and Whitehead as an Associate and Partner before founding Colcord and Mackenty in 1976. Since 1987 he has been a sole practitioner. He had a love of European history and culture serving as President of the American Swiss Association in the 1970s, touring English country houses and collecting English silver. He enjoyed skiing and spent every summer in Maine since 1965. Later in life, travels took him to the Far East, India and Middle East. He was a dedicated Yale fundraiser and Pittsburgh Steeler fan. Devotion to his communities, common decency and curiosity governed his life to the end. Phil is survived by his wife Helen, son and daughter Avery and Hilary, and grandchildren Avery and Hayden Giles and Helena and Philip Colcord, and many friends. A gathering will be held on May 2nd in New York City and another gathering of friends will happen in late July in Maine. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be given to Doctors Without Borders, The Doe Fund, and The Central Park Conservancy.

An article last Sunday about the Renaissance Street Singers, a group that performs sacred music in public spaces in New York but does not accept donations, misstated, in some editions, part of the name of the agency that issues public performance permits. It is the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, not the Metropolitan Transit Authority.

ATLANTA — The softball bats and golf clubs have been stored away. All is quiet, too, at the basketball gymnasium, the volleyball courts and the soccer field. 
 
Only the tennis team endures at Spelman College, and after the Great South Athletic Conference tournament the last weekend of April, it will also be done. Then Spelman, a historically black women’s college with alumnae who include former slaves and a Pulitzer Prize-winning author, will become the second college in the last decade to leave the N.C.A.A. altogether, the other being the New York City College of Technology in Brooklyn.

For centuries, travelers have streamed into Hakone, Japan, to bathe in the bubbling hot springs at traditional ryokans. Kai Hakone, a new high-design hotel and thermal spa on the banks of the Sugumo river, offers a luxuriously modern take on this relaxing tradition. Guests wear chic, black-padded kimonos with their wooden clogs and bob in a series of hot pools that all have views onto pristine woods. Deluxe rooms come with their own little tatami-floored teahouses, and the food — ridiculously fresh sashimi or spring flowers with sesame — is delicate yet nourishing. Bustling Tokyo, reachable in 45 minutes by bullet train, seems a world away.
 
Rooms from about $320 per night; hoshinoresort.com.

There’s something to be said for developing a signature style. In most areas of design it can be a great career move, but particularly in the field of architecture. Clients know what to come to you for, people know your buildings when they see them, and, as with Frank Gehry or Richard Meier, they cheer you on when you deliver the goods again and again.
 
In cinematic terms, if Renzo Piano, Gehry and Meier are the reigning Spielbergs of contemporary architecture, producing successful (or almost as successful) versions of an initial winning formula over and over, Rafael Moneo might be its Mike Leigh: highly talented and critically revered, but in the age of the star architect, in the United States, at least, we barely know his name. During a career of more than 40 years, the Madrid-based Moneo has produced buildings of startling quality, no two of which are alike. Working mainly in his native Spain, which has regarded him as something of a national hero since his National Museum of Roman Art in Mérida opened in 1986, Moneo has approached commissions with the goal of making architecture that is simultaneously an ornament to the Old World and a beacon of the new. His buildings are extremely site-specific, usually physically elegant and charged with experiential surprise, often in the plan or through internal manipulations of natural light. Always born of some well-considered relation to context, Moneo’s buildings are not objects meant to promote themselves, nor do they condescend.

I was in that prison of enforced intimacy, the elevator, when I ran into a neighbor, her face streaked with tears, who was taking her sick cat to the vet to be put to sleep. I did what New Yorkers do in such situations: avoid eye contact and make believe I was living on Krypton, as the woman stated the obvious to another neighbor: Fluffy was indeed walking, actually being carted, the last mile.

BALL--Hertha Baron, of Clarence, NY and Brooklyn, NY, peacefully ended her astonishing life on March 31, 2013 at 103. Wife of the late Arthur, mother of Tina J, Omi to Joanna (Joey), ageless and inspiring friend to so many...

How does an actress design her image? In our celebrity-obsessed culture, she usually dresses in the very latest fashion and has her photographs airbrushed into superhuman oblivion. Julianne Moore , while she indeed looks ravishing in films and on the red carpet, and even in her sweatpants at morning drop off (where I see her from time to time as our children attend the same school), is not such an actress. She is someone who rather pushes the boundaries in her acting in order to inhabit the characters she plays. For this issue she collaborated with the photographers Inez and Vinoodh and the makeup wizard Peter Philips, all artists in their own right, who seek to extend our way of seeing. Here they show us a more real, and even exaggerated side of Moore’s natural beauty. Freckled from birth (and not in a cute way, she explains in the piece), Moore’s face was sprinkled by Philips with even more spots. The resulting image, unlike most cover shots, isn’t retouched to perfection. The power comes from Moore’s striking and honest intensity, and from her scarcely made-up face, remarkable and beautiful at age 52.
 
Likewise, for the homes we often see in design magazines: perfectly appointed rooms, with electrical cords and all the clutter removed, and hardly any sense of the personalities of the owners shining through, so very unlike the way most people live. The former fashion editor Irene Silvagni’s house in the South of France is a romantic paean to patina and even decay. Claudio Luti, the C.E.O. of Kartell, cohabitates with modern, plastic furniture by the likes of Patricia Urquiola and Philippe Starck in his Milanese town house , amid a historically rich interior with references to other periods, in a way that recognizes that what is modern now is merely a moment in its continuum in the history of design. And the jewelry designer Marie-Hélène de Taillac’s tiny Parisian flat reflects her love of simple, well-made objects and the bright colors of gemstones, much like the beautiful pieces she designs.

DONNER--Matthew, on April 11, 2013. Beloved husband of Judy. Loving father of Sandy Donner Bitter and her husband Yoav, and Caroline Donner. Cherished grandfather of Ori and Dan Bitter. Loving brother of Rob Donner. He was a noted and respected advisor in Securities for many years and will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Services Monday April 15, 2013 at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Donations in his memory may be made to Williams College, Williamstown, MA.

GREENBERG--Daniel Beryl, died of cancer at age 91 on April 11, 2013, in Newton, MA. Formerly of New York City and Ft. Lauderdale, Dan was married to Beverly (Zwiren) until her death in 2007. He leaves two daughters, Nancy of Sag Harbor, NY, and Jane of Kew Gardens, NY, a son Mark and daughter-in-law Beverly, and two grandchildren, Allison and Alexander all of Newton, MA. After graduating from NYU, Dan served in the Army Air Corps. His work life spanned roles in the millinery, textile and garment industries. A music lover, singer and gifted artist, Dan will be remembered fondly for his wit and humor. A memorial service will be held at a future date.

RONDO--George, of NYC on April 5, 2013. George had a long career in theater, film and television. He was born in Paterson, NJ and served in the U.S. Navy. He is survived by his sister Gina Guinta and his brother Carmen Ragusa. He is also survived by many generations of nieces and nephews. Memorial will be held at a later date.

TALLCHIEF--Maria. Peter Martins and the entire New York City Ballet family mourn the passing of Maria Tallchief, the extraordinary American ballerina who was a founding member of our Company. Maria's dazzling talent electrified audiences in the early years of our history, as she worked with George Balanchine to create some of the most enduring roles in all of ballet, including her now legendary performances in Orpheus, Firebird, Swan Lake, and The Nutcracker. Following her career onstage, Maria's role as a teacher and director was an inspiration for countless young dancers and her work will have a lasting impact for generations to come. The world of dance has lost a true giant, and she will be greatly missed. All of us at NYCB express our heartfelt condolences to Maria's sister Marjorie, daughter Elise Paschen, and her entire family.

TAYLOR--William R.,III, January 7, 1971 - February 5, 2013. Born in Manhasset, NY to Catherine Owen and Dr. William Robert Taylor, later stepson to Albert A. Major, II. Bill grew up in Modesto, CA., studied at UC San Diego, UC Berkeley, Columbia and later called Portland, OR. home. Bill inspired many and was loved by all. http://goo.gl/sI8As

WAXMAN--Vivian (Chaya) Leah (Brenner), on April 8, 2013. Beloved wife of Irving of 62 years. Loving mother of Gary, David, and Martin, wonderful grandmother of Ilana and Paul, Aliza, and Ezra, cherished sister of Saul Brenner, Naomi Redisch, and Deena Reisman. Graduate of City College. Active member of Young Israel of West Hempstead, Young Israel of Deerfield Beach, and Amit. Artistic, creative, elegant; a beautiful, giving person who touched the lives of so many and never had a bad word to say about anyone.

PAGE--Nancy Eaton, on April 1, 2013, of Washington, D,C passed away peacefully in her Georgetown home. Born in Detroit, MI on April 21st 1926 to Edward and Alice Cheetham. Later she was adopted by her mother's second husband, Wilbur Eaton of Bryan, OH. Nancy was raised in Swampscott, MA and attended Boston University. Soon after school she found clerical work with the Department of Defense in Washington DC. Her first duty station was on The Mall in the temporary office buildings that lined the reflecting pool between The Washington Monument and the Lincoln memorial. In 1947 Nancy was hired by the State Department and soon went to work in Tehran, Iran where her love affair with traveling and all aspects about the Middle East was born. It was in Tehran that she met her husband of 57 years, Robert Wesley Page. Nancy and Bob lived for over 15 years in the Middle East and the Netherlands with their children. Beirut, Lebanon was a special jewel to Nancy who forged a lifetime of friends there and would return to again and again. Once returning to the United States, Nancy raised her family in New York, Houston and for over two decades in Washington, DC. For many years Nancy and family spent summers in Little Compton, RI and most recently winters in Key West. Nancy was a brilliant conversationalist who embraced life with curiosity and humor. She was passionate and engaged in the creative arts, literature, politics and inspired her family in her passion. Nancy's sophistication and compassion captured the admiration and loyalties of the mighty and the meek, from laborers, to waiters, to professional athletes, to diplomats, foreign and domestic. Her respect for all cultures enabled her to be a bridge-builder in support of the many and varied interests and vocational excursions of her husband from whom she was inseparable, as well as for family and friends. She was a unique presence in countless lives, young and old, across the globe. To be with her was to truly enjoy life she will be deeply missed by many. Nancy is survived by three of her four children: David Page, Mark Page and Meg Page and three grandchildren; Keegan Page, Addie Page and Riley McIlvaine. Her eldest son, Robert Wesley Page Jr., passed away in 2007. Details on a celebration of Nancy's life will be provided at a later date.

ROCKWELL--Peter C.,1959-2013. The management and staff of Mitsubishi UFJ Trust and Banking Corporation in Japan and the New York Branch, sadly inform that their General Counsel and Senior Vice President, Mr. Peter C. Rockwell, passed away on March 27, 2013 while vacationing in Namibia, South Africa. He was 54 years old. Peter's passing brings great sadness to all who knew him as the excellent professional who served for many years as a member of the senior management at the Mitsubishi UFJ Trust and Banking Corporation, New York Branch. Peter loved life and cultivated friends throughout the world, especially in Manhattan and Japan where many valued him. He leaves behind the memory of wonderful human quality and a big heart. Our deepest condolences go out to his family members, his mother, Mary Alice (nee Cullen), his brother Charles K. Rockwell, his sister, Ann W. Rockwell-Kollman, his niece, Tamina and nephew Sinclair, brother in law and his numerous close friends.

SCHERR--Leslie, Age 74, formerly of Potomac, MD, died on April 4, 2013. Leslie was born in the Bronx, on April 17, 1938. He graduated from Queens College and received his Juris Doctor from Columbia Law School. Leslie was a first generation American, self-made man, who had a lust for life and knowledge. He was an accomplished attorney who practiced criminal, civil and adoption law based in Washington, D.C. and litigated cases around the country. Leslie was an avid reader and accumulated an eclectic library. He volunteered at local libraries, raised money for charities and was a cooking instructor at L'Academie de Cuisine. He loved the New York Times, Jeopardy, all types of music, politics and debate, college basketball, travel, crossword puzzles, chess, bridge, scrabble, and above all his family and friends. He is survived by his wife, Susan Scherr; his son, Sloan Scherr and husband Patrick Moore; his daughter, Nikki O'Connell and husband Jim; his three grandchildren, Ryan, Aidan, and Madison; his sister Norma R. Ascher and husband Harvey; his uncle and aunt, Seymour and Thelma Grossman; aunt Geraldine Grossman; his sister-in-law Dr. Anita Auerbach; his nieces and nephews; his "daughters" Helen Taylor, Kristin Abshire, Charlotte Gilbert and Cathy Quinn; and the rest of his family and friends. A Celebration of Leslie's life will be held the first weekend of May, 2013 in Washington, D.C. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Queens College Foundation, c/o The Leslie Scherr Scholarship Fund, Attn: David D'Amato, 65-30 Kissena Blvd., Flushing, New York, 11367 or on-line at http://bit.ly/HonorLeslieScherr

When Rockefeller Center opened in 1939 after a decade of construction, it was not received with the glory we shower on it now. Newspapers were filled with letters calling it one of the ugliest complexes in the city. The building of what today is considered one of the crown jewels of the Manhattan skyline is a saga of big money, intriguing power brokers and one of the most glamorous periods in the city’s history. 
 
The story is told artfully and addictively in Daniel Okrent’s “Great Fortune: The Epic of Rockefeller Center,” a Pulitzer Prize finalist for history in 2004. Join us for an online discussion with Mr. Okrent and the novelist and culture critic Kurt Andersen, author of the best-selling novel “Heyday” and most recently “True Believers.”

A portly sexagenarian, Michel Djotodia had dressed for his coup d’état, donning desert camouflage, a turban and sandals like those of the rebels in his region of the Central African Republic .
 
Mr. Djotodia, a wily opportunist who has had many occupations but has rarely if ever been called a soldier, in late March rode with a rebel convoy through Bangui, the capital, just hours after President François Bozizé had fled .

“Everybody thinks it’s crazy to start a magazine today,” said Alexia Niedzielski, who is starting her third at the age of 30. We are sitting, on the morning of March 5, at Le Mini Palais, a fashionable restaurant in the same building as the Chanel show that has just ended, which is so overbooked with wealthy Chanel customers that Niedzielski has had to persuade the maître d’ to set her up with a wobbly table with no linens in what appears to be the storage room. You do not say “pas possible” to Niedzielski and her friends.
 
Seated opposite is Elizabeth von Guttman, 36, her partner in their previous publishing ventures, Industrie , the influential magazine for fashion insiders, and Ever Manifesto. Between them is Jonathan Wingfield, 39, the former editor of Numéro . Not present, but equally as involved are Thomas Lenthal, the art director of the art-and-erotica journal Paradis (and who is married to the Dior fine jewelry designer Victoire de Castellane). Collectively, the four-person editorial board represents the next generation of Annas, Graydons and Graces. Or so they hope.

ESTES--Barrie Landauer, died April 2, in Lebanon, NH. Born in Manhattan, April 17, 1935, to Ruth Yarbrough and James D. Landauer, a lifetime summer resident of NH, she graduated from the Madeira School '52 and Vassar College '56, and received Dance Certificates from the Mary Wigman Studio (Berlin) and Laban Inst. of Movement Arts. A dancer, choreographer, director, teacher beloved by her students, on faculty at HB Studio since 1963, she was co-founder/director of Dancers Studio, Studio 14 and The Dance Center. She also worked on programs for DTW, NYU, 92nd St. Y, La Mama and The Lee Strasberg Inst. Her acting performances included "Gypsy" with Ann Sothern, and "A Funny Thing Happened" with Dom DeLuise. Survived by husband, William L. Estes, sister, Barbara L. Widdoes, niece and nephews, Bennett W. Crocker, James L. Widdoes (Brooks H.) and William P. Widdoes, Jr. and five adored great-nieces and nephews. Memorial reception at National Arts Club, May 21, at noon. RSVP: blest2003@hotmail.com. Contributions to any of the deserving orgs. in which your lives met, appreciated.

PETERSON--Susan Lee, 49 passed away at her home in Oakland, CA on March 16, 2013 following a courageous yearlong battle with cancer. Former buyer/merchandiser for Saks Fifth Ave, Banana Republic, Williams Sonoma and Cost Plus World Market. Private chef for family of Apple Computer founder Steve Jobs, dessert chef at Chez Panisse. Endurance athlete and conservationist. Cornell Hotel School '86, Tante Marie's Cooking School San Francisco, UC Santa Cruz Agroecology. Kappa Kappa Gamma. A life well lived and was loved by many. The school is life, the lesson is love.

WORKMAN--Peter. Prep for Prep mourns the passing of our longtime Trustee Peter Workman. For 18 years, Peter tirelessly served the organization with his wise counsel, boundless generosity, and deep loyalty. Publishing "Be The Dream" to commemorate Prep's 25th anniversary was one of his most powerful contributions. He also offered valuable internships to so many of our students at his company. We will dearly miss his incisive mind and kind spirit. Our sympathies go out to his wife Carolan, daughters Katie and Elizabeth, and their husbands and children. Scott L. Bok, Chairman, Lisa Smith Cashin, President, Aileen C. Hefferren, Chief Executive
ETHERTON--Randall, longtime employee of the NY Times, left us Oct. 6, 2012. Today we celebrate his birthday and the memories he gave us.
SMITH--David Shiverick 15/1918 - 4/13/2012 Our joy and devotion will always be my consolation. Forever Your Mary

KANE--Peter, on March 24, age 70. Beloved son of the late Larry and Ruth. Loving brother of Debbie and Sonia. Cherished uncle of Allegra (Florian) and Daniel (Natalie) and great-nephew Adrian. A talented photographer and videographer, Peter worked as a news editor at KTVU in Oakland, CA, and also produced the Bay Area segment of the annual MDA Telethon. He leaves behind a collection of indelible images of the 60's protest movements and the lyrical beauty he encountered on the West Coast. We were inspired by his dignity and continued enthusiasm for life after his stroke nine years ago. We are so sad to lose him. A memorial service will be held at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn on April 21 at 2pm. Donations: MDA, 1388 Sutter Street, Suite #

Whenever the conductor William Christie and his ensemble, Les Arts Florissants , mount a production of a French Baroque opera, do not miss it. In this repertory Mr. Christie and his Baroque troupe are incomparable. After its exhilarating production of Lully’s “Atys” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 2011 the ensemble returns there with Marc-Antoine Charpentier’s “David et Jonathas.” First presented in 1688, this opera focuses on a biblical story of male love: between Jonathas and David, its future king.
 
The production, which updates the setting to the early 20th century, was introduced last summer at the Aix-en-Provence Festival . It is directed by Andreas Homoki , the general manager of the Zurich Opera. The tenor Pascal Charbonneau sings David; the soprano Ana Quintans sings the male role of Jonathas; the bass-baritone Neal Davies is King Saul, the father of Jonathas. (7:30 p.m. Wednesday, Thursday and next Saturday, 2 p.m. next Sunday, Howard Gilman Opera House, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene, 718-646-4100, bam.org ; $30 to $160)

Monday is tax day, but for Broadway a more important deadline looms, the April 25 cutoff for Tony Award eligibility. Seven shows are scheduled to open in the coming week and another handful the week after. (The Tony nominations will be announced on April 30, and the awards presentation is June 9.) 
 
Among the anticipated performances is Bobby Cannavale’s turn as Charlie Castle, a 1940s Hollywood star hiding a secret that could destroy his career in the revival of Clifford Odets’s 1949 drama “The Big Knife.” Mr. Cannavale , who was nominated for a Tony in 2011 for his scorching performance in “ The ___________ With the Hat ,” is opening on Broadway for the second time this season, following his fast-talking Ricky Roma in the revival of “ Glengarry Glen Ross .”

Nature inspired the spring/summer 2013 haute couture shows — not the ramshackle romance of the overgrown garden but something more delicate, formal and melancholy. The models at Dior , bodices scattered with appliquéd petals and skirts ballooning with meadow flowers, moved through a spring garden, along a maze of topiaried box trees devised for the show by the Belgian landscape designer Martin Wirtz as an allusion to Raf Simons’s childhood garden and to Monsieur Dior’s rural retreat Le Moulin du Coudret. Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pierpaolo Piccioli at Valentino drew on the actual structures of the garden: suits and skirts were embroidered with designs of borders and parterres. Dresses and capes enclosed the models within the looping patterns of wrought ironwork. And at Chanel , the early-19th-century Romantic poets Goethe and Schiller, whose verses extol the worship of untamed nature, influenced Karl Lagerfeld . His girls emerged from the shadows of an enchanted wood specially constructed for the Grand Palais, blinking into the light like Shakespearean revelers exiled from a masque, feathers framing the shoulders of their almost courtly garb, bedraggled plumes askew in their hair.

Google Maps has added information on public transportation in several cities. The service now provides up-to-date departure times for seven New York City (above) subway lines and for buses and trams in the greater Salt Lake City area, and service alerts for Washington’s Metrorail subway. Updates are available in many other major cities, including London, Madrid and San Diego.

By the time a poor child is 1 year old, she has most likely already fallen behind middle-class children in her ability to talk, understand and learn. The gap between poor children and wealthier ones widens each year, and by high school it has become a chasm. American attempts to close this gap in schools have largely failed, and a consensus is starting to build that these attempts must start long before school — before preschool, perhaps even before birth.
 
There is no consensus, however, about what form these attempts should take, because there is no consensus about the problem itself. What is it about poverty that limits a child’s ability to learn? Researchers have answered the question in different ways: Is it exposure to lead? Character issues like a lack of self-control or failure to think of future consequences? The effects of high levels of stress hormones? The lack of a culture of reading?

Despite an energy crisis , soaring sectarian militancy and preparations for national elections on May 11, these days many Pakistanis in Punjab Province seem mostly concerned about the fate of a traditional kite-flying festival.
 
The celebration, known as Basant , has been banned since 2007, ostensibly for safety reasons. Hopes for a revival were dashed this week when the interim government of the province gave up on plans to organize the festival in Lahore, unable to provide security against extremist groups that challenge the celebration.

GRAND--Attorney Richard D.,83, of Tucson, nationally recognized for his success as a plaintiff's trial lawyer, died suddenly in San Francisco on April 7 of natural causes. Grand was the founder of The Inner Circle of Advocates, a group of plaintiffs' attorneys called by The National Law Journal, "the elite of the plaintiffs' bar." Grand was born in what was then the independent nation of Danzig in 1930. He came to New York City with his parents in 1939, just before the Nazis entered his homeland. After earning his undergraduate degree from New York University and his law degree from the University Of Arizona College Of Law in 1958, Grand entered the practice of law in Tucson. In 1972, Grand recovered a jury verdict of $3.5 million which was the largest ever received at the time for a single personal injury. Following the award, Grand brought together 11 prominent plaintiffs' lawyers from throughout the country to form The Inner Circle of Advocates. Grand said it was designed to be a "think tank for the most qualified legal brain trust in the United States." It was formed as an attempt to level the playing field between the average consumer and the enormous resources of the insurance industry, the auto industry, the tobacco industry, and the pharmaceutical industry, among others. The invitation-only group is currently limited to one hundred members, and has included such well known lawyers as Joe Jamail, John Edwards, Johnie Cochran, Moe Levine and Court of Appeals Justice, Jack Fuchsberg. "It has worked as planned," said Atty. Michael Koskoff, of Connecticut, the group's current president. "Members have been in the forefront of litigation against negligent health providers, drug manufacturers and makers of defective products. "According to Koskoff, the litigation against the tobacco industry had its genesis in the Circle and was pursued by Inner Circle member Ron Motley and other Inner Circle members. "Richard Grand was a true visionary," Koskoff said. "Thanks to his guiding hand we have a highly talented group of accomplished lawyers who generously share cutting-edge ideas to allow us to better serve our clients. The cooperation is necessary to combat the enormous resources of big business and insurance companies." After forming The Inner Circle, Grand was named Honorary President of the Richard Grand Society, the premier association of personal injury attorneys in Great Britain. He also was a member of the International Society of Paraplegia and the British Academy of Forensic Sciences (Legal Section). Grand published numerous articles on case management and the presentation of traumatic injury. He was a member of the State Bar of Arizona and a certified specialist in injury and wrongful death litigation, Board of Legal Specialization of the State Bar of Arizona. Over the course of his life Grand received many honors from the University of Arizona including: Richard and Marcia Grand Alumnus of the Year Award, 2011; Distinguished Alumni Award, 2010; and Professional Achievement Award, 2002, an award given to a person who has attained prominence in his or her field. Grand was the twelfth person honored. "I was brought up during the Depression," Grand said recently. "We were taught to work and were expected to work . . .I don't play golf and I don't play tennis." Grand never retired and continued to handle cases right up to the last day of his life. Grand is survived by his wife, Marcia, and daughter, Cindy. He and Marcia were married six months after they met in 1952, a year after he moved to Tucson. Sinai Chapel, San Francisco, is handling funeral services. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the College of Art at the University of Arizona.

MUSSELMAN--Francis Haas. The partners of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy LLP mourn the passing of their friend and partner, Francis H. Musselman. Frank joined Milbank as an associate in 1953, became a partner in 1960 and founded Milbank's Washington D.C. office in 1980. From 1970-1984, he served as Managing Partner of Milbank and later retired in 1990. Frank was widely recognized as a leading specialist in bankruptcy law and law firm management and was a pioneer in the use of computers in law firms. Tall in stature and with a kindness of spirit, generosity and sense of humor to match, Frank was a mentor, advisor and friend to many at Milbank over his 47-year career at the Firm, and he will be sorely missed. We wish to express our deepest sympathy to Frank's four children, nine grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.
