ASHE--Herbert J.,born in Bamberg, Germany June 1, 1912 died at home April 11, 2013 in Stamford, CT. Founder of Ashflash Corp., former Trustee of Marlboro Music Festival and Bi-Cultural Day School. Predeceased by grandson Rafi, Herb and his late wife Ilsa survived by loving children John, James (and Lori), and Janet, grandchildren Ari (and Julie), Daniela (and Simon), and Jared, and great-grandson Noah.

AUGUSTA, Ga. — As the cheers for Tiger Woods on the first tee gave way to the relative hush of patrons hoofing it to the green, a man behind the tee box turned to his wife and said, “I didn’t hear anybody call Tiger a cheater.”
 
Woods came into his 19th Masters with his body sound, his personal life settled and his putting stroke sharp. Just when all the wrinkles had seemingly been smoothed out in his crazy quilt of a life, controversy ruffled the calm. Instead of concentrating on his pursuit of his 15th major championship, Woods awoke Saturday having to defend himself against a rules violation he committed in the second round.

GRAND--Attorney Richard D.,83, of Tucson, nationally recognized for his success as a plaintiff's trial lawyer, died suddenly in San Francisco on April 7 of natural causes. Grand was the founder of The Inner Circle of Advocates, a group of plaintiffs' attorneys called by The National Law Journal, "the elite of the plaintiffs' bar." Grand was born in what was then the independent nation of Danzig in 1930. He came to New York City with his parents in 1939, just before the Nazis entered his homeland. After earning his undergraduate degree from New York University and his law degree from the University Of Arizona College Of Law in 1958, Grand entered the practice of law in Tucson. In 1972, Grand recovered a jury verdict of $3.5 million which was the largest ever received at the time for a single personal injury. Following the award, Grand brought together 11 prominent plaintiffs' lawyers from throughout the country to form The Inner Circle of Advocates. Grand said it was designed to be a "think tank for the most qualified legal brain trust in the United States." It was formed as an attempt to level the playing field between the average consumer and the enormous resources of the insurance industry, the auto industry, the tobacco industry, and the pharmaceutical industry, among others. The invitation-only group is currently limited to one hundred members, and has included such well known lawyers as Joe Jamail, John Edwards, Johnie Cochran, Moe Levine and Court of Appeals Justice, Jack Fuchsberg. "It has worked as planned," said Atty. Michael Koskoff, of Connecticut, the group's current president. "Members have been in the forefront of litigation against negligent health providers, drug manufacturers and makers of defective products. "According to Koskoff, the litigation against the tobacco industry had its genesis in the Circle and was pursued by Inner Circle member Ron Motley and other Inner Circle members. "Richard Grand was a true visionary," Koskoff said. "Thanks to his guiding hand we have a highly talented group of accomplished lawyers who generously share cutting-edge ideas to allow us to better serve our clients. The cooperation is necessary to combat the enormous resources of big business and insurance companies." After forming The Inner Circle, Grand was named Honorary President of the Richard Grand Society, the premier association of personal injury attorneys in Great Britain. He also was a member of the International Society of Paraplegia and the British Academy of Forensic Sciences (Legal Section). Grand published numerous articles on case management and the presentation of traumatic injury. He was a member of the State Bar of Arizona and a certified specialist in injury and wrongful death litigation, Board of Legal Specialization of the State Bar of Arizona. Over the course of his life Grand received many honors from the University of Arizona including: Richard and Marcia Grand Alumnus of the Year Award, 2011; Distinguished Alumni Award, 2010; and Professional Achievement Award, 2002, an award given to a person who has attained prominence in his or her field. Grand was the twelfth person honored. "I was brought up during the Depression," Grand said recently. "We were taught to work and were expected to work . . .I don't play golf and I don't play tennis." Grand never retired and continued to handle cases right up to the last day of his life. Grand is survived by his wife, Marcia, and daughter, Cindy. He and Marcia were married six months after they met in 1952, a year after he moved to Tucson. Sinai Chapel, San Francisco, is handling funeral services. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the College of Art at the University of Arizona.

KIERSZENBAUM--Hugo S.,M.D., M.P.H., M.S., 73. Beloved by his wife Gina Aversa; daughter and son-in-law Samantha and Steve Berg; grandson Nathaniel Berg; niece Heidi Wein. Brilliant, compassionate physician. Retired Associate Professor of Clinical Psychiatry, New York Medical College, and attending staff member at Phelps Memorial Hospital. Donations in his memory may be made to Doctors Without Borders: doctorswithoutborders.org/

LEVITT--Edythe Oberfeld, passed-away April 12th. She was 74. Born and raised in Forest Hills, NY. She attended Forest Hills High School, and then was a member of the first female graduating class at the Wharton School, before her employment at IBM as a punch-card processor. Despite a recently contracted form of ALS, Mrs. Levitt led a fulfilling life, traveling the world in recent years, vacationing with her children and grandchildren, visiting with friends at her Harrison and Manhattan homes, supporting Maccabi USA/Sports for Israel, and enjoying her life-long passion, Competitive Duplicate Bridge, where she earned Silver Life Master status. Mrs. Levitt was the matriarch of the Levitt family and partner in Levitt-Fuirst Assoc. Ltd. Insurance agency, following the death in 2006 of David, her husband for 45 years. She is survived by her daughters, Valerie Levitt Schmaier and Ondrea Levitt Schiciano; four grandchildren, Samantha Schmaier, Rachael Schmaier, Logan Schiciano, and Hanna Schiciano. She was loved by all whose lives she touched. Funeral: Monday, 10am at Rye Community Synagogue, 200 Forest Ave, Rye. Shiva: Monday, following funeral until 5pm, and 7-9pm; Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5pm and 7-9pm, at the home of Edythe Levitt, 15 Justin Rd, Harrison.

VAN LEER--David Mark, beloved spouse, son and brother passed away April 3rd 2013. David was a tenured professor at University of California at Davis until his retirement; thereafter continued his great love of the theater and arts from his residence in New York City. David was born December 26, 1949 in Rockville Centre, NY. He was graduated from Cornell University, and subsequently granted his PhD. David taught at Cornell and Princeton University, before Davis. David is survived by his brother James; sister-in-law Sherrie Bowen-Van Leer, and niece Jennifer Acevedo. He is preceded in death by parents James and Marie Van Leer, and beloved companion and spouse Robert Miles Parker. A private reflection will be attended by his family. A memorial may be arranged at a later date.

BARRIE--Joseph Rollin, MD, of Harvard, MA died suddenly on April 8, 2013. He completed his residency training at Massachusetts General Hospital and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, and served his country as Lieutenant Commander, Medical Corps, in the U.S. Navy on the U.S.S. Saratoga. He established his medical practice at Emerson Hospital in Concord, MA where he was an active staff surgeon from 1969-2004. He is survived by his loving wife of thirty one years, Christine Svenson Pilkington. Devoted father to John R. Barrie and his wife Caroline E. Barrie of Wellesley, MA and Susan S. Barrie of Rye, NH. Loving grandfather of James R. Barrie and Catherine J. Barrie. A memorial gathering for friends and family will be held from noon to 3:00pm on Sunday, April 28th at the home of John and Caroline Barrie at 15 Marvin Road, Wellesley, MA. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the USO or the Yale School of Medicine, Child Studies, Autism. For online guestbook gfdoherty.com.

BELL--Phyllis Wishnack, March 12, 1923 - April 7, 2013. Loving wife to Ellis for 68 years; devoted mother of Bob (Eileen) and Ilene (Paul), and caring grandmother of Daniel and Jeremy Koegel. SULLIVAN--Benjamin J.,died peacefully on April 12, 2013 in his 95th year at his home in Dalton, Massachusetts. Ben was the son of the late Dr. Patrick Sullivan, long time physician in Dalton, and Margaret Maher Sullivan, and was predeceased in 1996 by his wife of 46 years, Louise Hennelly Sullivan (formerly of Pittsfield, Mass) and by his sisters Jean Ogden and Eleanor Collins. Ben was born on July 6, 1918 and resided for most of his life in Dalton, graduated from Dalton High School in 1935, continued on to The Choate School where he graduated in 1936, Yale University (class of 1940) and Harvard Business School (class of 1942). Upon graduation from HBS, Ben joined Crane & Co. Inc, paper manufacturers headquartered in Dalton, and shortly thereafter enlisted in the US Navy where during his four years of World War II active duty he was stationed in Newport, Rhode Island and Yorktown, Virginia, and multiple theaters in the Mediterranean, including North Africa and Italy, in the Ron 15 PT boat squadron. Following his discharge from the Navy in 1946, Ben rejoined Crane & Co. and over more than 45 years with Crane, held various operating and management positions, including being named President in 1975 as the first non-Crane family member to lead the company since its founding in 1801. Following his retirement from day-to-day management responsibilities in 1991, he continued as Chairman of Crane for several years. Ben's was highly devoted to numerous civic and charitable causes, including serving for many years on the Dalton Town Finance Committee, the board of the W. Murray Crane Community House in Dalton, the Berkshire Medical Center (Pittsfield) where he was highly involved as a board member in the expansion of BMC's facilities in the 1970s. Ben was also a long time member of the board of directors of the First Agricultural Bank and the Berkshire Life Insurance Company, both headquartered in Pittsfield, Massachusetts. Ben was an accomplished single digit handicap golfer, and multiple winner of the Country Club of Pittsfield club championship where he and Robert T. Jones III, the great golfer Bobby Jones's son, perennially dueled for the championship. He also served as a several term President of the Country Club of Pittsfield, was a member of the Wahconah Country Club in Dalton for over sixty years and a member of the Harbour Ridge Yacht and Country Club in Florida where he also maintained a residence. Ben was also a regular at the Bay State Seniors golf gatherings right through his 80th year. Ben was a life long communicant of St. Agnes Church in Dalton and had a long time association with the Benjamin F. Sullivan American Legion Post in Dalton, which was named after his father's brother who was killed in action in World War I. Ben is survived by his only son, Ben and his wife Charlotte of Rye, New York, together with four grandchildren, who lovingly adored their grandfather, Madeleine Sullivan of New York City, Charles Sullivan of Washington, D.C., Christopher Sullivan of Boston, Mass., and Catherine Sullivan a student at UNC Chapel Hill, North Carolina. Funeral Services will be held on Monday, April 15m at 10:45am, from the Dery-Foley Funeral Home, 890 East Main Street, Dalton, Mass., with a Liturgy of Christian Burial at 11:30am, at St. Agnes Church, 489 Main Street, Dalton, celebrated by Rev. Christopher A. Malatesta, Pastor. Burial, with military honors, will follow in Fairview Cemetery, Dalton. Calling hours will be Sunday, from 4:00 to 7:00pm, at the Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Mr. Sullivan may be made to Berkshire United Way in care of the Dery-Foley Funeral Home, 890 East Main Street, Dalton, MA 01226.

Because of an editing error, the Frugal Traveler column last Sunday, about a $100 weekend in Boston, misstated the days when the Uni Sashimi bar at the French restaurant Clio is open and misidentified its location. The bar is open daily, not Thursday through Saturday, though it serves only its late-night menu on those three nights. And it is in a space adjacent to the restaurant, not in the restaurant.

Francis Coradal-Cugat’s original cover art for “ The Great Gatsby ,” which Baz Luhrmann brings to the big screen next month, depicts a disembodied face floating in a night sky. It is one of the lasting images in literature, but that hasn’t kept book designers from trying to outdo it. The scholar and F. Scott Fitzgerald biographer Matthew J. Bruccoli spent his adult life stockpiling those efforts ­— pulpy paperbacks, fancy slip-covers, French-flapped foreign editions — and today his trove is not only one of the world’s most complete collections but also an illuminating cross section of 83 years of book design. Now housed at the University of South Carolina, the collection is worth several million dollars but Bruccoli, who died in 2008, claimed he was never motivated by money. “You don’t buy books as an investment,” he said. “You buy them because it gives you pleasure to read them, to touch them . . . to see them on shelves.”
 

 Slide Show: A Look Inside the Collection

David Zinczenko, the former Rodale Inc. executive with a talent for self-promotion and sculpturing physiques, has signed on with Random House to provide some juice to its health and fitness offerings.
 
At the end of 2012, Mr. Zinczenko left his prominent positions as the editor of Men’s Health magazine and the general manager of Rodale’s Healthy Living Group and Rodale Books. Though his contract was up, he also had been clashing with Rodale’s owners, who found that his talent for being in the spotlight tended to detract from their brand, according to people in the publishing industry.

The Cesis Journal article on Wednesday, about the successful use by a Cesis resident and other Latvians of the Web site ManaBalss.lv, which is at the forefront of Latvia’s efforts to increase political and governmental participation via the Internet, misstated the given name of a lawmaker who favors the Web site. She is Lolita Cigane, not Lola.

An editorial on Thursday about treatment of mental illness in California prisons misstated how the state inmate suicide rate compares with the national average. It is about 48 percent higher, not nearly twice the national average.

A points system is now being used to determine the field for the Kentucky Derby, replacing the use of graded-stakes earnings. Points are earned by the top four finishers in prep races and records are starts-win-place-show. An article on the Blue Grass Stakes and the Arkansas Derby on Saturday can be found here .

Can you imagine the N.F.L. allowing fans to change the course of the game? Not only is golf the only sport that allows fans to call in to report rules violations, but golf fans are also probably the only sports fans left using land lines. The main problem is that the average fan is not aware of all of golf’s fastidious rules. Here, for the highly judgmental, are a couple of abstract rules to look for from your living room:

An article in some editions on Wednesday about the reaction to a plan by some students at the Benjamin N. Cardozo Law School, part of Yeshiva University, to give an award to former President Jimmy Carter, referred imprecisely to the professional credentials of Richard M. Joel, the president of Yeshiva University. While he has a J.D., he does not have an M.D. or a Ph.D., and so he is not “Dr. Joel.”

A picture caption on April 4 about gains made by Syrian rebel forces in the southern portion of the country omitted part of the credit. The photograph, of a rebel guarding the eastern city of Deir al-Zour, was taken by Khalil Ashawi/Reuters — not just by Reuters. And a correction in this space on April 5 misspelled the first part of the city’s name as Deil.

Although the South Street Seaport Museum has yet to recover from Hurricane Sandy , the Museum of the City of New York has agreed to continue running the museum for another three months.
 
“We are hoping the extension will be fruitful,” said Susan Henshaw Jones, the City Museum’s president, who has been running both institutions.

The Korean pop singer known as Psy, who gained global notoriety last year when his song “Gangnam Style” became an Internet sensation , released a new single over the weekend, and many were quick to notice. In a little over a day, the video for the song, “Gentleman,” attracted more than 32 million views on YouTube after it had its premiere on Saturday during a concert in Seoul. 
 
The video features Psy, whose real name is Park Jae-sang, acting in his established ungentlemanly manner until he gets a taste of his own medicine from Son Ga-In, another K-pop star who is a member of the group Brown Eyed Girls. It also features a signature dance move to complement the horse-riding maneuver made popular by “Gangnam Style,” which has surpassed 1.5 billion views on YouTube since its debut in July.

Hollywood was predictably shocked over the weekend to find that a well-reviewed drama succeeded at the box office even though it was aimed at geriatric moviegoers (industry definition: anyone over the age of 25). The Jackie Robinson biopic “42” was a strong No. 1 at North American movie theaters, taking in about $27.3 million, according to its distributor, Warner Brothers. Legendary Entertainment spent a relatively modest $38 million to make the film, which performed best among older men, the hardest demographic for studios to reach. 
 
Sputtering in second place with about $15.2 million in ticket sales was “Scary Movie V” (Weinstein), according to Hollywood.com , which compiles box-office data. This parody movie was even cheaper — it cost about $20 million to make — but took in less than most analysts expected, especially considering the publicity generated by the stunt casting of Lindsay Lohan as herself. Perhaps this is the end of the road for the “Scary Movie” franchise. “The Croods,” “G.I. Joe: Retaliation” and “Evil Dead” rounded out the top five.

Universal Pictures is leading at the box office so far this year, with strong showings from “Les Misérables,” which has taken in $75.8 million and “Identity Thief,” at $131.5 million. It’s 2013 lead will probably be enhanced by “Oblivion,” above, with Tom Cruise, who remains a big draw at the box office, as well as sequels like “Fast and Furious 6” and “Despicable Me 2.” 
 
Other studios will offer sequels, too, like “Percy Jackson: Sea of Monsters” from Fox, “Iron Man 3” (Buena Vista), “Star Trek: Into Darkness” (Paramount) and “Grown Ups 2” (Sony/Columbia). SHELLY FREIERMAN

DEAR DIARY:
 
One early morning in late February or early March, I was waiting at the crosswalk on the corner of Bleecker and 11th Streets. A little girl about 8-years-old, with pink winter boots dangling, was the well-balanced passenger on the back of her father’s bike.

As a pilot, Alexander Richards spends a fair amount of his time on runways. But as he arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport in Queens early Sunday morning, he had a different flight plan in mind: he was going to run on the runway.
 
Those looking forward to the Boston Marathon on Monday may have missed a lesser-known event that drew Richards and 1,011 others to the airport for J.F.K.’s Run on the Runway 5K.

The New York City Center is to announce on Monday that the actress Christine Baranski (“The Good Wife”); Irina Dvorovenko, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater; and Joaquin De Luz, a principal dancer with New York City Ballet, will be among the cast in the Encores! production of Rodgers and Hart’s “On Your Toes.” Directed and choreographed by Warren Carlyle (“Follies”), the show is scheduled for seven performances May 8-12 and is to be the final Encores! presentation of the 2012-13 City Center season.

Senator Marco Rubio offered an extraordinary endorsement of legislation to overhaul the nation’s badly strained immigration system on Sunday when, after holding back for weeks, he appeared on no fewer than seven television talk shows to explain and defend a plan that he said would be “a net positive for the country, now and in the future.”
 
As Mr. Rubio, a Florida Republican who is a member of a bipartisan group of eight senators preparing to unveil their immigration legislation on Tuesday, pressed his case again and again on the airwaves, new details of the bill emerged. Prominent among them was a proposed fee of roughly $2,000 that illegal immigrants would have to pay before they could earn legal status.

Robert Byrne, an international grandmaster and United States chess champion who, as the chess columnist for The New York Times, analyzed top-flight matches from 1972 through 2006, the eras of Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov, died on Friday at his home in Ossining, N.Y. He was 84.
 
The cause was Parkinson’s disease, said Joyce Dopkeen, a friend.

Dear Diary:
 
On a Sunday night several months ago, I was driving my two daughters home to New Jersey. Our spirits were high. But as we were making a turn onto West 40th Street, heading toward the Lincoln Tunnel, a commuter bus took the same turn a little too tightly and hit my car.

The Internet might have looked very different than it does today. When Marc Andreessen and Eric Bina were building Mosaic, the browser that practically created the Web in 1993, they included the ability to annotate any page. Discussions immediately sprang up. But they quickly realized that the server to host the annotations would have had to scale to enormous size, which was not practical. So they took the feature out.
 
What would the Web have looked like if annotation had managed to stay in? Maybe a million conversations would have bloomed, and some of the furious divides that plague this country would have been bridged. Or maybe it just would have been a deafening free-for-all, cranking up all the cranks.

Dear Diary:
 
the seventh avenue local throbs beneath the sidewalk its bass-line as reassuring as the ozone odor of electrical arcing and the rhythmic de-duh de-duh de-duh de-duh that recedes into the pulse of the city as it rumbles uptown

Three prominent venture capital funds want software developers to know they are on the hunt for apps and software for Google Glass , the company’s Internet-connected glasses .
 
On Wednesday, Google Ventures, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers and Andreessen Horowitz announced the Glass Collective , an investment partnership. The three firms said they had agreed to share every pitch from start-ups related to Glass, so each firm would have the chance to invest.

Thirty minutes before Stinky Bklyn opens for business, its proprietor strolls the floor singing in a powerhouse tenor to Parmigiano-Reggiano and hickory-smoked Benton’s bacon. He is not being a ham. Patrick Watson is getting his pipes in shape to sing the national anthem at the Barclays Center, where he is better known as the supplier of Stinky Brown Butter Rice Krispy Treats and the crumbled blue cheese topping on the Nathan’s Famous hot dogs sold at the concession stand.
 
Mr. Watson, 38, is a trained opera singer but has not sung before an audience since 2006, the year he and his wife opened Stinky Bklyn, their specialty cheese shop, on Smith Street in Carroll Gardens. He has never publicly performed “The Star-Spangled Banner.”

SPATT--Dorothy G.,beloved mother, grandmother, and sister, passed away on April 13, 2013, in Manhasset, New York. Dee was an outstanding teacher and guidance counselor. However, after marrying Arthur, she devoted her life to her husband, children, and grandchildren. Dee was a warm, selfless person, who cared about her family in every way. She was an uplifting, positive person, who treated everyone as a friend, and treated everyone with respect. Her Judaism was a very important part of her life. Dee was an avid reader, and always wanted to learn. However, her family was always paramount to her. We will miss and love her forever. The funeral will be on Monday, April 15, 2013, at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck.

TITUNIK--Alan. A service of Remembrance and Thanksgiving for his life will be held at Gustavus Adolphus Church, 155 E. 22nd St., NYC at 5:30pm on May 2, 2013 which would have been his 85th birthday. All friend and past colleagues are welcome. Emily Titunik & Beth Emery

ZOLBERG--Aristide R.,the Walter A. Eberstadt Professor of Politics and University in Exile Professor Emeritus at The New School for Social Research, passed away on April 12, 2013 in New York City after a long struggle with cancer. A distinguished political scientist and one of world's preeminent scholars of comparative politics, the history of international migration, nationalism and ethnicity, and immigration policy in North America and Western Europe, he served for many years as the founding director of the International Center for Migration, Ethnicity and Citizenship at The New School. He mentored and inspired several generations of colleagues and students at The New School, where he was first appointed as Distinguished Professor of Political Science in 1983. His book, A Nation by Design, will remain one of the most authoritative accounts of immigration history in the United States and a compelling story of how immigration shaped this country. Ary's humanity and erudition will be missed by countless colleagues, students, and readers. Trustees, President, Provost, and Faculty, The New School

TALLCHIEF--Maria. The George Balanchine Foundation notes with sadness the passing of Maria Tallchief, one of the great ballerinas of the twentieth century. It is well known that Mr. B created many roles for her during her brilliant and groundbreaking performing career. Thanks to her enthusiasm for our Interpreters Archive video project, starting in 1995 we were privileged to tape her coaching some of the greatest of these roles -- those in Firebird, Orpheus, The Nutcracker, Allegro Brillante, Scotch Symphony, and others -- passing on a lifetime's worth of artistry to the dancers of today and adding another dimension to her remarkable legacy. Ave atque vale.

Dear Diary:
 
I sometimes steal across to the Central Park Zoo to watch the snow leopards on my lunch breaks. There are two leopards, named Askai and Zoe. I went recently after a fresh snow and saw tracks leading to the top of their pens. A docent once told me that the leopards can look upon horse carriages on the Central Park Drive from there.

SPATT--Dorothy G. The Judges of the Eastern District of New York and the entire Eastern District Court family mourn the loss of Dorothy Spatt, beloved wife of our cherished colleague Judge Arthur D. Spatt, and dear friend to so many of us. She will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Judge Spatt and his family.

STREIM--Edith (nee Rosen), died peacefully April 13, at her Miami Beach, Florida home, in her one hundredth year. Predeceased by her husband Harry and sister Marjorie Bayer. Survived by sister, Faith Saunders, and two children, Patricia Seldin (and Peter) and Richard Streim (and Marsha Satuloff). Loving grandmother to Marc Seldin, Amy Seldin, Nancy van der Voorn, Sanford Streim and Karen Perman. Known as G.G. by her ten adoring great-grandchildren. Graveside service 10:30am, Tuesday, April 16 at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Lindenhurst, NY.

TALLCHIEF--Maria. Maria. A force of nature, a blazing light, the strength of a diamond. A 20th Century principal dancer who objected to "alphabetical order." Her presence taught respect for the art. And one will not forget her laughter, and the way she spoke the word "George." We will remember her always. The George Balanchine Trust

Practice Fusion is a company that offers doctors cloud-based electronic medical records software for managing relationships with patients and big parts of the health care industry. It also seems like a good place to explore feelings about privacy, and the business of Big Data.
 
The company, privately held and based in San Francisco, says it has 150,000 health care providers using its free service and medical records on 60 million patients. On Tuesday Practice Fusion announced a new service, called Patient Fusion , which enables people using the system to schedule appointments with any participating doctor.

PARKER--Kathleen O. The Morris-Jumel Mansion Museum family mourns the loss of our dear friend, longtime Trustee, former President and unparalleled champion. Since 1973 "Kayo" served "her Mansion" with unflagging affection, energy and enthusiasm. She will be dearly missed. James L. Kerr, President Ken Moss, Executive Director Morris-Jumel Mansion Museum

FRIED--Curt, 89, of Boca Raton, Florida and Ardsley, New York passed away Friday, April 12 after a brief illness. Curt is survived by his loving wife of 63 years, Sally Gettleman Fried, his five children: Melanie, Arthur, Robert, Judy, and Daniel, and their spouses: Barry, Caren, Nancy, Jon and DeLaune. His legacy includes 14 grandchildren and one great grandchild. Curt Fried escaped Nazi persecution in September, 1939 when, at the age of 14, he and his 15 year old brother Irwin, boarded a train in Vienna headed for Paris. They arrived the very day France declared war on Germany and were forced to re-route to Rotterdam. They eventually made their way to Newark, NJ where they found safety with relatives. Curt attended Weequahic High School and then entered the US Army and served as a radio specialist working on the Burma Road in India and China. After military service, Fried returned to the Bronx where he co-founded H&H Photographers, a photography studio that has proudly served the New York metropolitan area for over 65 years. Soon after his return to New York, Curt met Sally, and started their beautiful family, first in the Bronx and eventually in Ardsley, NY. The Fried's have lived in Ardsley for over 55 years and all five children graduated from Ardsley High School. All five attended America's finest universities and graduate schools. Melanie is a world renowned Speech Pathologist, Arthur a successful health care entrepreneur, Robert an Academy Award winning producer and media entrepreneur, Judy a respected Urologist, and Daniel a successful film producer who has now taken over the management of H & H Photographers. Curt Fried was beloved by all that knew him for his brilliant mathematical mind, his infectious sense of humor, his perseverance and his reliability. He loved his family. He loved his Jewishness. He loved tennis, golf and kibbitzing in the bagel room at the Polo Club in Boca. And he loved America for which he was unendingly grateful. From very challenging beginnings, Curt Fried built a legacy of caring, character and consistency that is being perpetuated by his five children, 14 grandchildren and one (so far) great-grandchild. He is already missed; his memory serves as our inspiration. The funeral will take place at Greenburgh Hebrew Center, 515 Broadway. Dobbs Ferry NY on Monday, April 15 at noon, with burial to follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla.
LEVITT--Edythe. What a special accomplished woman. We will miss our wonderful sister-in-law and all the happy family times together. Betsy and Alan

SILVER--Murray, on April 13, 2013 at age 89. Beloved husband of Blanche. Loving father of Bonnie and Steven, and Nan. Cherished grandfather of Lindsey, Will, Elisabeth and Walker. Devoted brother of Frieda Goldman. Services 11:30am, Tuesday at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. boulveardriversidechapel.com

LEVITT--Edythe. The Maccabi USA Board of Directors, staff, athletes and volunteers particularly the members of the Annual Bridge Tournament Committee mourn the loss of our dear friend, Edy Levitt. She was a staunch supporter who gave so generously of her time. The impact of her caring and dedication will be felt for many years to come. Our most sincere condolences go to her daughters, Valerie and Ondrea and all her family. May her memory be for a blessing. The Maccabi USA Family

SHAPIRO--Michael Seth. Age 37. After a heroic 2 1/2 year battle with brain cancer. Husband of Jodi, Father of Matthew and Lucas, Son of Marjorie and Gary Shapiro, Brother of Brandi and Adam Goldenberg. May your eternal smile be a beacon to others for years to come. We will love you forever, Mom and Dad.

PARKER--Kathleen Oliver, on April 7, 2013, in New York, NY. Born October 22, 1925. Loving wife of the late Paul Edward Parker, Jr., "Kayo" was a vivacious lady with a great sense of humor and broad interests in the world at large. She will be greatly missed by a wide circle of devoted friends and the many charities in which she was actively involved, including Bennington College, VT; Brick Presbyterian Church, NYC; Morris-Jumel Mansion, NYC; Ellis School, Pittsburgh, PA; and Miss Hall's School, Pittsfield, MA. Service Tuesday, April 23, 2pm, Brick Church, 91st and Park Ave., NYC.

TALLCHIEF--Maria. Maria. A force of nature, a blazing light, the strength of a diamond. A 20th Century principal dancer who objected to "alphabetical order." Her presence taught respect for the art. And one will not forget her laughter, and the way she spoke the word "George." We will remember her always. The George Balanchine Trust

ARONOFF--Faith Lynn. With deep sadness, and the love for my Sister, I regret to announce the death of Faith Lynn Aronoff, 55, of New York, New York who passed away on April 7, 2013. Not a single day will pass without her being in my thoughts and in my heart. Faith was born in the state of Maine on October 24, 1957. She graduated from Bethpage High School and continued on to receive a B.A. from Boston University and a Masters Degree from New York University. Faith is survived by myself, Andrea Aronoff Jarrold of Lauderdale-By-The-Sea, Florida, our Mother, Madelaine Aronoff, and her three other siblings, Aaron Aronoff of Roslyn New York, Keith Aronoff of Delray Beach, Florida and Craig Aronoff of Merrick, New York. Faith is preceded in death by our father, Murray T. Aronoff. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be given to Harmony animal rescue fund www.animalrescuechase.com/harmony--fund and/or the United Jewish Appeal (UJA).

TITUNIK--Alan. A service of Remembrance and Thanksgiving for his life will be held at Gustavus Adolphus Church, 155 E. 22nd St., NYC at 5:30pm on May 2, 2013 which would have been his 85th birthday. All friend and past colleagues are welcome. Emily Titunik & Beth Emery

ESTILL--Fedra S.,1912-2013. For my mother who died on Saturday, April 13th, at 100, 4 months, 26 days old. Her radiant smile and beauty graced everyone with love. She was the most fabulous mother and my best friend. Every moment her heart, her spirit, her soul are with me. Loved and missed for an eternity. Dobie

ZOLBERG--Aristide R.,the Walter A. Eberstadt Professor of Politics and University in Exile Professor Emeritus at The New School for Social Research, passed away on April 12, 2013 in New York City after a long struggle with cancer. A distinguished political scientist and one of world's preeminent scholars of comparative politics, the history of international migration, nationalism and ethnicity, and immigration policy in North America and Western Europe, he served for many years as the founding director of the International Center for Migration, Ethnicity and Citizenship at The New School. He mentored and inspired several generations of colleagues and students at The New School, where he was first appointed as Distinguished Professor of Political Science in 1983. His book, A Nation by Design, will remain one of the most authoritative accounts of immigration history in the United States and a compelling story of how immigration shaped this country. Ary's humanity and erudition will be missed by countless colleagues, students, and readers. Trustees, President, Provost, and Faculty, The New School

FELDMAN--Melvyn J.,71, on April 10, 2013. Beloved husband, father and professional schmoozer. Melvyn loved his life, family and friends in New York, Chicago, and Santa Fe. Services Monday at 11am, Temple Sinai, Chicago.

ASHE--Herbert J.,born in Bamberg, Germany June 1, 1912 died at home April 11, 2013 in Stamford, CT. Founder of Ashflash Corp., former Trustee of Marlboro Music Festival and Bi-Cultural Day School. Predeceased by grandson Rafi, Herb and his late wife Ilsa survived by loving children John, James (and Lori), and Janet, grandchildren Ari (and Julie), Daniela (and Simon), and Jared, and great-grandson Noah.

AARON--Marcia F.,76, of Boca Raton, formerly of Jericho, NY, adored wife of 58 years of Stanley, beloved mother of Nancy Cohen (Joel), Michael (Fern), Neil (Gayle), and Wayne (Karyn). Loving grandmother to Brett, Ross, Alyssa, Halie, Evan, Rachel, Emily, and Zoe.

BAIRD--Annette Feder, age 89 passed away on April 5, 2013 in Summit, NJ a week before her 90th birthday. Annette was a vivacious, vibrant lover of life and humankind. She graduated from Queens College and worked as a chemist for Columbia University and General Foods before raising two children and later becoming a devoted volunteer guide at The Boston Museum of Science. There, for over 25 years, she gave tours and specialized in electron microscope demonstrations. Visiting school groups were a special treat for her. Annette enjoyed baseball, jazz, and theater - and had a lifelong love of the arts, science, literature, and learning - which she shared with her beloved husband Donald (her partner for 59-years), her children Allison Fox and Douglas Baird, and her grandchildren Katie and Julian Fox and Gregory Baird. Annette will be dearly missed and remembered always with great love.

COLCORD--Bradford Phillips, 82, of New York City, passed away peacefully at home on April 9th due to complications from polymyositis. Phil was born in Edwardsville, Illinois on April 5, 1931, son of Bradford Colcord and Elizabeth Phillips. He lived in Missouri, Alabama and Pennsylvania from 1931-1941. He graduated from the University School in Cleveland as Salutatorian and continued on to receive a Bachelor of Arts cum laude degree from Yale College in 1952 and JD from Harvard Law School in 1955. Thereafter he served in Army counter intelligence in Germany until 1958. Phil was married to Helen Burgess Johnson on April 7, 1962; they were married 51 years. Phil was a member of the New York, D.C. and Ohio Bars and worked as an attorney for Goodwin Savage Clare and Whitehead as an Associate and Partner before founding Colcord and Mackenty in 1976. Since 1987 he has been a sole practitioner. He had a love of European history and culture serving as President of the American Swiss Association in the 1970s, touring English country houses and collecting English silver. He enjoyed skiing and spent every summer in Maine since 1965. Later in life, travels took him to the Far East, India and Middle East. He was a dedicated Yale fundraiser and Pittsburgh Steeler fan. Devotion to his communities, common decency and curiosity governed his life to the end. Phil is survived by his wife Helen, son and daughter Avery and Hilary, and grandchildren Avery and Hayden Giles and Helena and Philip Colcord, and many friends. A gathering will be held on May 2nd in New York City and another gathering of friends will happen in late July in Maine. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be given to Doctors Without Borders, The Doe Fund, and The Central Park Conservancy.

SPATT--Dorothy G. The Judges of the Eastern District of New York and the entire Eastern District Court family mourn the loss of Dorothy Spatt, beloved wife of our cherished colleague Judge Arthur D. Spatt, and dear friend to so many of us. She will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Judge Spatt and his family.

SHAPIRO--Michael Seth. Age 37. After a heroic 2 1/2 year battle with brain cancer. Husband of Jodi, Father of Matthew and Lucas, Son of Marjorie and Gary Shapiro, Brother of Brandi and Adam Goldenberg. May your eternal smile be a beacon to others for years to come. We will love you forever, Mom and Dad.

SPATT--Dorothy G.,beloved mother, grandmother, and sister, passed away on April 13, 2013, in Manhasset, New York. Dee was an outstanding teacher and guidance counselor. However, after marrying Arthur, she devoted her life to her husband, children, and grandchildren. Dee was a warm, selfless person, who cared about her family in every way. She was an uplifting, positive person, who treated everyone as a friend, and treated everyone with respect. Her Judaism was a very important part of her life. Dee was an avid reader, and always wanted to learn. However, her family was always paramount to her. We will miss and love her forever. The funeral will be on Monday, April 15, 2013, at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck.

STREIM--Edith (nee Rosen), died peacefully April 13, at her Miami Beach, Florida home, in her one hundredth year. Predeceased by her husband Harry and sister Marjorie Bayer. Survived by sister, Faith Saunders, and two children, Patricia Seldin (and Peter) and Richard Streim (and Marsha Satuloff). Loving grandmother to Marc Seldin, Amy Seldin, Nancy van der Voorn, Sanford Streim and Karen Perman. Known as G.G. by her ten adoring great-grandchildren. Graveside service 10:30am, Tuesday, April 16 at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Lindenhurst, NY.

SILVER--Murray, on April 13, 2013 at age 89. Beloved husband of Blanche. Loving father of Bonnie and Steven, and Nan. Cherished grandfather of Lindsey, Will, Elisabeth and Walker. Devoted brother of Frieda Goldman. Services 11:30am, Tuesday at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. boulveardriversidechapel.com

TALLCHIEF--Maria. The George Balanchine Foundation notes with sadness the passing of Maria Tallchief, one of the great ballerinas of the twentieth century. It is well known that Mr. B created many roles for her during her brilliant and groundbreaking performing career. Thanks to her enthusiasm for our Interpreters Archive video project, starting in 1995 we were privileged to tape her coaching some of the greatest of these roles -- those in Firebird, Orpheus, The Nutcracker, Allegro Brillante, Scotch Symphony, and others -- passing on a lifetime's worth of artistry to the dancers of today and adding another dimension to her remarkable legacy. Ave atque vale.

LEVITT--Edythe Oberfeld, passed-away April 12th. She was 74. Born and raised in Forest Hills, NY. She attended Forest Hills High School, and then was a member of the first female graduating class at the Wharton School, before her employment at IBM as a punch-card processor. Despite a recently contracted form of ALS, Mrs. Levitt led a fulfilling life, traveling the world in recent years, vacationing with her children and grandchildren, visiting with friends at her Harrison and Manhattan homes, supporting Maccabi USA/Sports for Israel, and enjoying her life-long passion, Competitive Duplicate Bridge, where she earned Silver Life Master status. Mrs. Levitt was the matriarch of the Levitt family and partner in Levitt-Fuirst Assoc. Ltd. Insurance agency, following the death in 2006 of David, her husband for 45 years. She is survived by her daughters, Valerie Levitt Schmaier and Ondrea Levitt Schiciano; four grandchildren, Samantha Schmaier, Rachael Schmaier, Logan Schiciano, and Hanna Schiciano. She was loved by all whose lives she touched. Funeral: Monday, 10am at Rye Community Synagogue, 200 Forest Ave, Rye. Shiva: Monday, following funeral until 5pm, and 7-9pm; Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5pm and 7-9pm, at the home of Edythe Levitt, 15 Justin Rd, Harrison.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Saturday with the continuation of an article about a battle for leadership at the Roosevelt Island Garden Club misidentified, in some copies, the photographer and his publication. The picture of the two successive presidents of the club was taken by Kurt Wittman of The Main Street Wire, not by Ángel Franco of The New York Times.

The Your Money column on Saturday, about an easing of terms for home mortgages at some regional lenders, misstated in some copies, the surname of a homebuyer in Seattle at several points and misspelled his given name in a picture caption in some copies. As the column correctly noted in the first reference, he is Phillip Ratliff, not Philip Ratcliff.

An article on Monday about personnel moves at Katie Couric’s syndicated talk show “Katie” and at CNN Worldwide misstated, in some copies, the surname of a host hired from ESPN to work at CNN. She is Rachel Nichols, not Nelson.

An obituary on April 6 about the comic-book artist Carmine Infantino referred incorrectly to his work on the DC Comics character the Flash. The original Flash series was discontinued in 1949, and Mr. Infantino and the writer Robert Kanigher were assigned to create a new version of the character in 1956; the title was not “selling poorly” and “threatened with cancellation” at that time. And a caption with a picture of Mr. Infantino carried an erroneous credit. The photograph was taken by Bill Crawford, not by Marc Witz.

An article in some editions on Saturday about carriage horses as an issue in the mayoral race misstated, in some copies, the surname of a founder of a group that wants to ban horse carriages and also misstated, in some copies, part of the name of a television show on which a ride was featured. The advocate is Steve Nislick, not Nilsack, and the show was “Sex and the City,” not “Sex of the City.”

Energy Future Holdings, the Texas energy giant that was taken private in 2007 in a record-breaking $45 billion buyout, disclosed Monday a potential bankruptcy plan to its creditors.
 
The proposal to restructure about $32 billion in debt is the opening move in what many say could be a long and contentious battle between the company and its largest creditors.

A report in the Media Decoder on Monday about Random House’s hiring of the editor and executive David Zinczenko to operate a new imprint rendered incorrectly, in some editions, part of the names of Mr. Zinczenko’s former employer and the company he founded after leaving that employer. His former employer is Rodale Inc., not Rodale Press, and his new company is Galvanized Brands, not Galvanized Media.

An article on Monday about a comment by Secretary of State John Kerry that the United States was prepared to reach out to North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, if Mr. Kim made the first move to abandon his country’s nuclear weapons program misspelled, in some editions, the surname of Japan’s foreign minister. As an accompanying picture caption correctly noted, he is Fumio Kishida, not Kishid.

A listing of credits on Monday with a theater review of “Motown: The Musical,” at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, misstated Schele Williams’s role with the production. She is associate director, not associate producer. Because of an editing error, the credits also misstated one of the roles played by Raymond Luke Jr. and Jibreel Mawry. It is the young Berry Gordy, not “Chucky Berry.”

Dave Frieder sees a connection between two of his passions: The bridges that tie the city to the rest of the world, and Erector Sets.
 
The connection is Othmar H. Ammann. He designed some of the bridges and, according to Mr. Frieder, also loved Erector Sets, with their prefabricated parts — which, to a Jersey-bound commuter at the end of a difficult day, look like careful little copies of the box beams on the George Washington Bridge that cannot go by soon enough.

A picture caption on April 4 with a critic’s notebook article about the Humana Festival of New American Plays at the Actors Theater of Louisville, Ky., carried an erroneous credit supplied by the theater. The photograph of a scene from “Gnit” was taken by Kathy Preher, not by Alan Simons. (He took an accompanying picture, of a scene from “Appropriate.”)

A TAKEOVER DEAL ... The scientific equipment maker Thermo Fisher Scientific agreed on Monday to buy a rival, Life Technologies Corporation, for $13.6 billion.
 
Thermo Fisher Scientific, led by Marc N. Casper, left, is offering shareholders $76 for each of their shares in Life Technologies, 12 percent above the company’s closing stock price on Friday. The company said it would also assume about $2.2 billion in debt. MARK SCOTT

The new Broadway play “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” will close on Sunday after 17 preview performances and 38 regular performances, the producers said on Monday. The play, adapted by the Tony Award winner Richard Greenberg (“Take Me Out”) from the Truman Capote novella, opened on March 20 to largely negative reviews .
 
The production stars Emilia Clarke (HBO’s “Game of Thrones”) as Holly Golightly and Cory Michael Smith (“Cockfight Play”) as the narrator, Fred. Ticket sales held fairly steady in the first days after the bad reviews, but they started to dip recently – especially as several other new plays and musicals began performances on Broadway.

The Labyrinth Theater Company , a downtown ensemble devoted to producing new plays with multiracial casts, said on Monday that the costume designer Mimi O’Donnell will become its new artistic director – an appointment aimed at stabilizing the company after three years of uneven output.
 
During that period, which included critical disappointments like “Radiance” and “The Atmosphere of Memory,” Ms. O’Donnell had been one of Labyrinth’s three artistic directors – along with the playwright Stephen Adly Guirgis and the actor Yul Vazquez. They served on a volunteer basis and juggled Labyrinth along with their own projects: Mr. Guirgis, for instance, made his Broadway debut in 2011 with “The ___________ With the Hat,” which earned a Tony nomination for best play.

Laura Ward, 41, had always attributed her excess pounds to the drugs she takes for major depression. So Ms. Ward, who is 5-foot-6 and once weighed 220 pounds, didn’t try to slim down or avoid dietary pitfalls like fried chicken.
 
But in a clinical trial, Ms. Ward managed to lose more than 30 pounds doing low-impact aerobics three times a week . During the 18-month experiment, she was introduced to cauliflower and post-workout soreness for the first time. She and the other participants attended counseling sessions where they practiced refusing junk food and choosing smaller portions. She drank two liters of Diet Dr Pepper daily instead of eight.

Gold prices tumbled 9 percent on Monday, the sharpest drop in 30 years, heightening fears that investors’ faith in the safe haven has been shattered.

Chelation therapy has been used as an alternative treatment for heart disease since the 1950s, but with scanty evidence to support the practice, most medical doctors have long dismissed it as little more than quackery.
 
But now a prestigious medical journal has published the results of a large, long-term clinical trial of chelation in heart disease patients. While critics were quick to point out the study’s myriad irregularities, the findings have dumbfounded cardiologists: The results suggest chelation, originally used to treat lead poisoning , just might help heart patients.

8:34 p.m. | Updated 

 
 Citigroup beat earnings expectations on Monday as net income surged by 30 percent in the first quarter of 2013. But beneath the banner results, the bank is grappling with a sluggish economy and skittish American consumers who are still wary of shouldering fresh debt.

Alcohol consumption is known to increase the risk for breast cancer. But a new study suggests that moderate drinking has little effect on survival after diagnosis, and may reduce deaths from cardiovascular disease.
 
Researchers, writing online in The Journal of Clinical Oncology , studied 22,890 women with breast cancer, recording information on alcohol intake before diagnosis and, for a subset of 4,881 of them, after diagnosis as well.

Representatives of the Anne Frank House on Monday praised Justin Bieber for his visit to the museum after a weekend in which a message he left on a guestbook there set off a maelstrom of criticism. 
 
A short note posted Monday on the Facebook page of the Anne Frank House said: “The Anne Frank House was pleased to welcome Justin Bieber to the Anne Frank House last Friday. We think it is very positive that he took the time and effort to visit our museum. He was very interested in the story of Anne Frank and stayed for over an hour. We hope that his visit will inspire his fans to learn more about her life and hopefully read the diary.”

A new study suggests that adolescent obesity could be decreased if teenagers got more sleep, and the heaviest would benefit most.
 
For a study published last week in Pediatrics , researchers surveyed 1,429 ninth graders, gathering data on height and weight. The children reported their sleep habits on weekdays and weekends to the nearest 15 minutes. The researchers followed the students with interviews every six months over the next four years, updating their data.

The Richard Tucker Foundation said on Monday that the mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonard had won its award named after the American tenor. The award, which comes with a $30,000 prize, is conferred on singers who the foundation deems are about to plunge into major international careers, and it often makes good calls. Past winners include Angela Meade, Joyce DiDonato, John Relyea, Matthew Polenzani, Deborah Voigt and Renée Fleming.
 
 Ms. Leonard , 31, has become a regular at the Metropolitan Opera, performing in a half-dozen productions. They include three Mozart operas: “Don Giovanni,” “The Marriage of Figaro” and “Così Fan Tutte.” She will be back at the Met in May with Poulenc’s “Dialogues of the Carmelites,” but not before appearing on “Sesame Street” later this month.

A new study using the patterns of Google search queries suggests that mental illnesses flourish in winter and decline in summer.
 
In both the United States and Australia, researchers found distinct seasonal patterns, high in winter and low in summer, in searches pertaining to anxiety, obsessive compulsive disorder, bipolar disorder, eating disorders, depression, suicide, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and schizophrenia. The study appears in the May issue of The American Journal of Preventive Medicine.

On a recent Sunday afternoon, a 75-year-old Philadelphia man with a fever of over 102 degrees was unable to reach his doctor. So his daughter took him to an emergency room, where the two sat for hours until he was examined by a physician who found no reason for the fever and decided to admit him overnight.
 
The man was given oxygen, a chest X-ray , a blood test and, finally, a urine test, which revealed a urinary tract infection . The problem was solved with a prescription for an antibiotic , but at a cost of thousands of dollars to Medicare .

9:35 p.m. | Updated 

 
Smartphones, tablets and computers all pull data from the Internet, but people still pay two different bills: the high-speed connection they get at home and the wireless connection they get outside. Dish Network, the pay-TV operator, wants to bridge that gap.

BUENOS AIRES — As Concepción Martínez, her husband and two daughters pulled into the last subway station here, cheers and clapping erupted from the throngs of people, some wearing turn-of-the-20th-century dress, waiting on the platform.
 
Camera flashes lighted the tunnels as passengers took their final rides in the saloonlike wagons — with their wooden benches, frosted glass lamps and manually operated brass doors — of South America’s first subway line.

Two new experiments, one involving people and the other animals, suggest that regular exercise can substantially improve memory, although different types of exercise seem to affect the brain quite differently. The news may offer consolation for the growing numbers of us who are entering age groups most at risk for cognitive decline. 
 
It was back in the 1990s that scientists at the Salk Institute for Biological Studies in La Jolla, Calif., first discovered that exercise bulks up the brain. In groundbreaking experiments, they showed that mice given access to running wheels produced far more cells in an area of the brain controlling memory creation than animals that didn’t run. The exercised animals then performed better on memory tests than their sedentary labmates.

McKEE--Richard D.,Richard D. McKee, on April 14, 2013. 71, of Manlius, NY, passed away peacefully. He was born in Hagerstown, MD to the late Charles and Frances Burton McKee. After graduating from Choate in 1960, he received his BA in music from Yale University and his Masters in music from the University of Illinois. He had a long outstanding career as a leading bass baritone singing and directing with professional opera companies in the US and abroad including the New York City Opera Company. Among the many roles in his repertoire, Leperello in Don Giovanni, the title role in Falstaff and Pooh-Bah and Mikado in Gilbert & Sullivan's The Mikado were his favorites. He retired in 2007 as Artistic Director from Syracuse Opera. He is survived by his family, Carolyn F. McKee, Lyn Holzman, Janet M. Shields and Kevin Shields; grandchildren, Morgan and Brenna Shields; sister, Jane M. Rozes; nephews and niece, Charles Rozes, Jennifer Rozes and Jonathan Rozes; and many friends at Syracuse Opera. There will be a memorial service to be announced at a later date. Contributions may be made to Syracuse Opera, P.O. Box 1223, Syracuse, NY 13201-1223. For a guest book, please visit: www.scheppfamily.com. Services by Newell-Fay Manlius Chapel of Schepp Family Funeral Homes, Manlius, NY.

PERLMUTTER--Walter Marc, died on Thursday, April 12th in Highland Park, Illinois. He was 86 years old. Walter was born to Grace and Arthur Perlmutter of Long Beach, New York on October 26, 1926, and is survived by his brother David Perlmutter, his three children, Amy Frankel, Nell Kisiel and Andrew Perlmutter and his three grandchildren, Grace, Arthur, and Jane Frankel. Walter served in the US Navy during WWII. He graduated from Utica College and enjoyed a long and successful career in the toy business. In his retirement, Walter returned to his long time loves of boating and journalism. Memorial donations can be directed to the Grace and Arthur Perlmutter Scholarship Fund (Utica College Office of Advancement, 1600 Burrstone Road, Utica, NY 13502.)

SCOTT--Deborah Flagg, resident of Lyme, CT, formerly of New Canaan, died on April 13, surrounded by her children, after a long battle with Alzheimer's. She was 83. Debbie grew up in Oradell and Englewood, NJ. She graduated from The Ethel Walker School, 1948 and attended Smith College and earned her B.A. degree from Manhattanville College. In 1951, she married S. Spencer ("Bud") Scott, Jr. (who predeceased her in 2002). She served as Board Chair of The Ethel Walker School (CT), the Dynamy Program (MA), the Hurricane Island Outward Bound School (ME) and CORO (NY), as well as serving on the national boards of Outward Bound and CORO. In 2008, she received the prestigious "Kurt Hahn Award" from the directors of Outward Board for outstanding service to the Outward Bound community and was honored in 2007 by CORO (NY) with the "Lewis Rudin Award". The daughter of the late Irene Richardson and John H. Flagg of Englewood, NJ, she is survived by her brothers Dr. Stephen V Flagg of Hamden, CT and Thomas R. Flagg of Reading, CT, her children, Dr. Samuel Spencer Scott, III of Cumberland Foreside, ME, Steven Flagg Scott of Lyme, CT and Suzette V.S. Hearn of Ft. Washington, PA, her eight grandchildren Carter Scott, Story Miraldi and S. Spencer Scott IV, Cameron and Caroline Scott and George, Louise and James Hearn and two great grandchildren, Oliver Huggins and Alex Miraldi--all of whom loved her and were inspired by her. Her life was a light that burned with intensity and will forever serve as a guide to those she left behind. Services Saturday, April 20, at 1:00 PM, at the First Congregational Church, 2 Ferry Road, Old Lyme, CT. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to CORO (NY) or the Hurricane Island Outward Bound School.

CONNANT--Charles E.,M.D., P.A., of Short Hills, New Jersey, passed away on Saturday, April 13, 2013 at the age of 93. Dr. Connant earned his Graduate Degree in Internal Medicine with NYU Bellevue Medical Center, and his degree in OB-Gyn with the University of Pennsylvania. He did his residency in Ob-Gyn with Bellevue Medical Center in New York, and St. Francis Hospital in the Bronx, New York. He served as a Fellow in Cervical Dysplasia and Pathology at Brookdale Medical Center in Brooklyn. Dr Connant spent most of his career in Jersey City, at the Margaret Hague Maternity Hospital, and as Assistant Director of Ob-Gyn at Christ Hospital. Since 1977, he has been a Clinical Professor of Ob-Gyn at UMDNJ in Newark. A Fellow of the American College of Surgeons and American College of Ob-Gyn, Dr. Connant also co-authored "Minimal Access Gynaecology" in 1995. A Funeral Service will be held on Wednesday, April 17, 2013 at 11am at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church 250 Gallows Hill Rd., Westfield. Interment to follow at Fairview Cemetery, Westfield. There will be a visitation on Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9pm, with a Trisagion Service at 7:30pm at the Bradley, Smith & Smith Funeral Home 415 Morris Ave., Springfield, NJ 07081. For more info, or to send condolences to the family, visit bradleyfuneralhomes.com. Those who wish to make a donation in Dr Connant's memory may do so, to: Penn Medicine Development and Alumni Relations, Attention: Irene I. Lukoff, University of Pennsylvania, 3535 Market Street, Suite 750, Philadelphia, PA 19104-3309. www.med.upenn.edu/cndr/ inmemoriam.shtml

HELLER--Jacob W. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of our esteemed General Counsel, but most of all, a most cherished friend. Jacob's wise counsel and guidance, coupled with his commitment to the welfare of Boys Town and its students, has enabled the school to fulfill its mission of turning young boys from limited backgrounds into young men with limitless futures. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family and prayers that they will be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Josh S. Weston, Honorary Chairman Robert Kaswell, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Ronald Gray, Exec. VP

DRAGO--Betty. Betty (Elizabeth) Louise (Brisgal) Drago, age 92 of Bonita Springs, FL (and longtime resident of Woodlawn in The Bronx, NY), passed away peacefully at Life Care Center of Estero, FL among family on Saturday morning, April 13, 2013, marking an inspiring life of love, perseverance and care as wife, mother, daughter, sister, friend, grandmother, and great grandmother. Predeceased by her husband, Dr. Rosario P. Drago, and by three younger sisters, Helen Rybarczyk, Katie Bazzoli, and Margaret Henderson, all of Dover, OH. Survived by her children, Dr. Joseph Drago (Diane), Dr. Mariann Casarella (Charles), Dr. Carl Drago, Rosario "Bud" Drago, Dr. John Drago (Lorraine), Dr. Eleanor Drago-Severson (Dr. David Severson), and Dr. Paul Drago; 19 grandchildren, Andrea, Daniella, Dr. Denise, Jennifer, David, Rosaria "Aria", Kyle, Stephanie, Matthew, Elliott, Brian, Keith, Michael, Vincent, Stephen, Thomas, Carl, Luke and Gigi; and 14 great-grandchildren. Graduated from Canton School of Nursing and completed post-graduate training in obstetrics at University of Chicago. Betty Drago was also an accomplished violinist and lifeguard at Atwood Lake in Dover, Ohio! At age 57, Betty earned a Bachelor of Science degree in nursing at College of Mount St. Vincent in Riverdale, NY. A registered nurse who, in private practice with her pediatric physician husband, served some of the neediest families of The Bronx for over 40 years. Betty Drago was highly cherished and dear friend to many and could always be relied upon to share rich stories and cheerful life experiences as a loving mother of seven children, children of whom no mother could be more proud, more supportive and more encouraging. Betty Drago's life is charted by an unrelenting care for all, a love for children and an inspiring perseverance that was presented with consistent cheer, optimism and accommodation. Betty was vivacious in her love and gift giving and in her attention to celebrating with friends and family alike the events and passages important to them. Viewing Thursday April 18, and Friday April, 2-4 and 7-9pm at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc. Funeral Home, 732 Yonkers Ave., Yonkers, NY. (www.ruggieroandsonsfh.com). Requiem Mass will take place at 10:45am Saturday, April 20th, at St. Barnabas Church, 409 East 241st Street, Bronx, NY. Entombment will follow at Woodlawn Cemetery, 517 East 233rd Street, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Betty Drago to St. Joseph's Catholic Church, 613 North Tuscarawas Ave., Dover, OH 44622.

GERSON--Morton M.,90 of New York City passed away Sunday April 14 at the Springs Nursing Home, Sarasota, FL. He was born and raised in Brooklyn and was a lifelong resident of New York City. He was a US Army veteran. He served during WWII and was awarded the Bronze Star in 1948. He was owner Plymouth Typographers Inc. and ALP Graphics both of NYC, NY. Surviving is his loving wife of 30 years Tobe nee Friedman Gerson, beloved father of Ann Flynn and her husband Jeffrey of Scotch Plains, Loren Gerson, NY City, and Paulette Gleit and her husband Larry of Avon, CT, and step father of Barry Aplert and his wife Judy of Pittsburg, Mark Alpert and his wife Hillary of Penlynn, PA, John Alpert and his wife Laura of Mountainside, Jeff Alpert and his wife Lisa of Ross, CA and Bess Molnar and her husband Edward of Scotch Plains, loving grandchildren Matthew Flynn and Zachary and Matthew Gleit and step grandchildren Diane, Leslie, Hallie, Josh, Lorie, Craig, Kayla, and Dylan Alpert. Graveside services are private. Funeral services are under the direction of Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suberban Funeral Chapels, Livingston.

CROTHERS--Samuel H.,75, Tony Award-winning producer of a number of groundbreaking Broadway musicals and films, passed away quietly on Saturday, April 13, 2013 in his Boynton Beach, Florida home after a battle with Lymphoma. The son of Lucy Aurora (Tutunjian) Crothers and Samuel H. Crothers, Sam was a native of Newark, NJ. He served in the U.S. Navy as a medical corpsman, graduated from Rutgers University in 1962, and went on to work in a variety of jobs, including stints in the New York Times obituary department and at Palmes Del Mar Resort in Puerto Rico, before his love of theater led him to The Producer Circle Co. in 1975, where he became Managerial Partner. For years, Sam was known throughout the theatrical community as the backbone of the company, serving as the driving force for many of its innovative projects. His extensive list of Broadway credits includes the Tony Award-winning Sweeney Todd starring Angela Lansbury, La Cage aux Folles (both the original production and the 2004 revival), and The Will Rogers Follies - as well as his sentimental favorite, the musical Roza, starring Georgia Brown. His movie credits include Fort Apache The Bronx, The Boys from Brazil, The Shining, and the Academy Award-winning Chicago. "The Old Dog", as he cheerfully referred to himself, is forever immortalized by a caricature that hangs at Sardi's. Sam was a tremendously generous, loyal, and devoted friend and family man. He loved the beach and swimming in the ocean, and was an avid Winston Churchill scholar. Sam cherished his Armenian heritage and is survived by his brother, David Crothers; his sister, Diane Scholz; his aunt, Virginia Tutunjian, and a huge extended family of nephews, nieces, cousins, and good friends who he considered family. Many glasses of Johnnie Walker Red will surely be raised in his honor. Per his request, no services are planned

BALL--Anne Firestone, 79, of Greenwich, CT.,died on Friday, April 12, at Bridgeport (CT.) Hospital of complications following surgery. She was a long-time community volunteer and philanthropist. Anne Idabelle Firestone was born in Akron, Ohio, on November 10, 1933, to Harvey S. Firestone, Jr., and Elizabeth Parke Firestone. She was a granddaughter of tire industry pioneer Harvey S. Firestone, who founded The Firestone Tire & Rubber Company in Akron in 1900. She attended elementary school at Our Lady of the Elms in Akron and high school at Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT. She earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, NY. While on spring break in Miami from Miss Porter's School, Anne Firestone was introduced by a cousin to her future husband John F. Ball, then a student at Princeton. After a seven-year courtship, they were married in 1957. They had homes in Greenwich and in Northport Point, MI. Mrs. Ball was active in Greenwich community affairs for decades, serving as a director and chairman of the board of Family Centers of Greenwich, which provides education and human services for children, adults and families. She also had been a trustee for Miss Porter's School and a trustee for Atwill Memorial Chapel in Northport Point. She was preceded in death by her parents, her brother Harvey S. Firestone III and sister Elizabeth Firestone Willis. In addition to her husband, other survivors include sons John F. Ball, Jr., (Linda) of Winnetka, Ill., and David F. Ball (Lucy) of Darien, Conn., and daughter Sheila B. Burkert (Randall) of New York City; eight grandchildren, and sister Martha F. Ford (William Clay) of Grosse Pointe Shores, MI. The family will receive friends on Friday, April 19, from 4:00 until 7:00pm at Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT. 06830. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, April 20, 2013 at 11:00am at St. Michael the Archangel Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT., 06830. There also will be a memorial service this summer at Atwill Memorial Chapel in Michigan. Memorial contributions may be made to Family Centers of Greenwich, 40 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT., 06830 or Atwill Memorial Chapel, 105 N. Northcott Drive, Northport, MI. 49670. Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, Greenwich, CT. (203) 869-1513 leopgallaghergreenwich.com

BRISTOL--Alfred, a longtime resident of Rockland County, NY, died peacefully on April 13, 2013 with his caring family at his side. Al was born in Newark, NJ on November 5, 1911. After serving in the South Pacific during World War II, he was honorably discharged from the US Army as a 2nd Lieutenant. Al resided in Shanks Village in Orangeburg, NY, Flushing in Queens and finally settled in Tappan, NY where he became prominently active in the community. He was instrumental in the merger of Parke-Bernet and Sotheby's, where he was responsible for creating exhibits for the auction galleries. After 65 years, Al retired as a Vice President and until recently was a consultant assisting the auctioneers. Al is survived by his wife of 72 years, Carolyn (nee Itokazu); his niece Kristan MacIntyre and her husband Walter; and longtime family friend, Pat Civitello. He was predeceased by his son, Kim, who died unexpectedly in 1967 and his two sisters and two brothers. Devoting his time and heart to his community and profession, Al will be missed by the many friends and colleagues that he made over the many years. A Funeral Service will be held Friday, 10am, at the Moritz Funeral Home, 98 Route 303, Tappan, NY 10983 (845-359-0890 or www.moritzfh.net). Burial to follow at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. Visiting hours will Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9pm. Memorial contributions may be made to the Tappan Library, 93 Main St., Tappan, NY 10983 or United Hospice of Rockland (hospiceofrockland.org or 845-634-4974).

BROOKS--Barbara, 60, passed away on April 12, 2013 at home after a long battle with breast cancer. A scholar of Japan and professor of History at the City College of New York and the CUNY Graduate Center, Barbara received a B.A. and M.A. from Yale University and a Ph.D from Princeton University. The mother of Isadora Brooks Jaffee and spouse of David Jaffee, she is also survived by her parents William and Margaret Brooks, her sister Sarah Brooks, and her brother Tom Brooks. Barbara took great joy in learning, writing, and teaching about Japan, working on her garden, and taking care of Oscar the dachshund. Her keen intelligence, boundless curiosity, and deep devotion to her students, friends, and family will be sorely missed by all of those whose lives she touched.

An article on Saturday about an experiment to improve the health of Medicaid beneficiaries and lower the rate of spending growth for medical care misstated, in some copies, part of the name of the organizations that are carrying out the experiment. They are Coordinated Care Organizations, not Community Care Organizations.

Looking at scenes of the Boston sidewalk a few hours after Monday’s bombing — torn clothing, bloodstains, shards of glass — I found my mind going back to a similar sidewalk in Tel Aviv in September 2003. A Hamas suicide bomber had blown himself up at a bus stop outside the Tsrifin army base, and by coincidence I was nearby and got there to witness the immediate aftermath. As I wrote then, parts of the bomber were still on the street, including his hairy leg. His shoe had been blown off, but his brown sock was still daintily on his foot. Israeli rescue workers calmly carried away the dead on stretchers, with an odd mix of horror and routine. But what I remember most was something the police spokesman said to me: “We will have this whole area cleaned up in two hours. By morning, the bus stop will be repaired. You will never know this happened.” 
 
We still do not know who set off the Boston Marathon bombs or why. But we do know now, after 9/11, after all the terrorism the world has seen in the last decade, what the right reaction is: wash the sidewalk, wipe away the blood, and let whoever did it know that while they have sickeningly maimed and killed some of our brothers and sisters, they have left no trace on our society or way of life. Terrorists are not strong enough to do that — only we can do that to ourselves — and we must never accommodate them.

An art review on April 5 about “Roman Vishniac Rediscovered,” at the International Center of Photography in Manhattan, contained several errors.
 
No evidence exists that Vishniac spliced negatives to create images of events that never happened, according to the center.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Thursday about the Irish actress Helena Carroll described incorrectly the character she played in the 1987 movie “The Dead.” Her character, Aunt Kate, was the hostess of the dance that is the centerpiece of the film — not an “elderly songstress.”

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the Run on the Runway 5K at John F. Kennedy International Airport misstated the name of North Carolina city that also holds an airport runway race. It is Greensboro, not Greenpoint.

A television review on Monday about the new Syfy series “Defiance,” developed at the same time as a video game of that name, described the game incorrectly. It is a third-person-shooter game, not one with a first-person perspective.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about former President George W. Bush’s welcoming his first grandchild and completing his presidential library misstated his age in some editions. He is 66, not 62.

BRUSSELS — The authorities in Belgium raided 48 homes nationwide on Tuesday and detained six men implicated in what prosecutors described as a jihadist recruitment drive for the insurgency in Syria , where an increasingly international array of rebels is fighting to topple President Bashar al-Assad .
 
The raids, the result of an investigation that began last year, reflected Syria’s growing allure to militant Islamist fighters who see Syria as a prime battleground. The foreign jihadist element in the insurgency has alarmed Western powers that want to see Mr. Assad step down but do not want him replaced by an Islamist militant government or stateless mayhem.

An obituary on April 9 about the former British prime minister Margaret Thatcher overstated what is known about one aspect of a 1986 bombing of Libya carried out by the United States with the Thatcher government’s support. Although initial news reports, in The Times and elsewhere, said Col. Muammar el-Qadaffi’s baby daughter was killed in that attack, her death was never confirmed, and reporting in recent years has shown that Qadaffi most likely lied about her death. Therefore it is probably not the case that the bombing “killed one of his children.”

DRAWING IN INVESTORS The asset management giant BlackRock reported on Tuesday that profit rose 10 percent in the first quarter on gains from renewed investor interest in the stock market.
 
Investors put $39.4 billion of new money into BlackRock products, which helped the firm increase assets under management by 7 percent from the period a year earlier. “We witnessed cash coming off the sidelines and being put to work,” the firm’s chief executive, Laurence D. Fink, above, said in a call with analysts. NATHANIEL POPPER

Until recently, Fairway was not much more than a popular market on Manhattan’s Upper West Side, where residents went for goods like smoked salmon, medjool dates and cheeses.
 
Today, it is a fast-growing 12-store grocery chain with ambitions of opening 300 outlets across the country.

After fierce industry lobbying and internal bickering, the Securities and Exchange Commission is moving closer to overhauling the money market fund industry.
 
Just days after Mary Jo White became its chairwoman, the agency’s spokesman, John Nester, said on Tuesday that “the staff expects to have something for the commission’s consideration in the near future.”

8:30 p.m. | Updated A judge has approved a settlement between the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors and securities regulators that allows the firm to pay a $602 million fine to resolve a civil insider trading case without admitting any guilt, but he conditioned his ruling on a pending ruling from the Federal Appeals Court.
 
In an opinion released on Tuesday, Judge Victor Marrero of Federal District Court in Manhattan said he had serious concerns with the “neither admit nor deny” language contained in the agreement but said that he would await guidance from a case involving Citigroup .

Thanks to a renewed appreciation of China’s rustic culinary roots, eating animal heads has become fashionable in Beijing, as Craig Smith writes in this week’s Dining section . There are restaurants solely devoted to the preparation of fish, rabbit and duck heads. In New York you may search long and hard without finding such a restaurant. Look carefully, though — not only in the warrens of a mall in Flushing, Queens, but also on Restaurant Row in Manhattan — and you may be surprised to see what’s looking back. Though the cooking process may render an entire head a nearly uniform brown, there’s no mistaking a rabbit’s incisors or a duck’s bill.
 
Here are a few places that offer the whole-head experience.
