An art review on April 12 about “Great and Mighty Things: Outsider Art From the Jill and Sheldon Bonovitz Collection,” at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, misstated the name of a museum in Washington in citing some institutions that have received donations of outsider art. It is the Smithsonian American Art Museum, not the Smithsonian Museum of American Art.

New musicals involving Steve Martin and Edie Brickell, the authors Michael Chabon and Ayelet Waldman, and the composer Lin-Manuel Miranda will be part of the Powerhouse Theater ’s season June 21 to July 28, according to the producers, New York Stage and Film and Vassar College. 
 
The lineup includes two fully staged productions of works-in-progress: Seth Zvi Rosenfeld’s “Downtown Race Riot,” about young guys stirring up trouble in Washington Square Park, and Mozhan Marno’s “When the Lights Went Out,” about six New Yorkers during the Northeast blackout of 2003.

The singer-songwriter Somi, the choreographer Faye Driscoll, the Trusty Sidekick Theater Company and the multidisciplinary artists Ralph Lemon and Okwui Okpokwasili, and the visual artist Alex Dolan have been named as the Park Avenue Armory’s 2013 artists in residence. The residencies were established in 2010 and include space at the armory for the research and creation of new projects. 
 
The resident artists are associated with the armory’s “Under Construction” series, in which artists present works that they continue to shape based on the responses from the armory’s audiences. This season’s “Under Construction” series begins with “The Lagos Music Salon,” a program created by Somi during a 15-month sabbatical in Lagos, Nigeria, on May 17.

The Advertising column on Friday, about “Imagine a Future,” a documentary backed by Procter & Gamble that aims to empower black women, misstated the year P.& G.’s My Black Is Beautiful campaign began. It was 2006, not 2008. And the column, using incorrect information from a news release, misstated the scheduled screening date for “Imagine a Future” on BET. It is July 5, not July 7.

The Bronx High School of Science has produced more scientific leaders than many countries, including eight Nobel Prize winners in physics and chemistry.
 
But when New York City’s premier science magnet school decided to honor its legacy, it spent more than a dozen years and $1 million on a project that had no connection to string theory or the periodic table: a Holocaust museum.

Bryan Cranston, a multiple Emmy winner for playing Walter White on TV’s “Breaking Bad,” will star this fall as President Lyndon B. Johnson in the American Repertory Theater production of Robert Schenkkan’s “All the Way,” the theater has announced.
 
The drama covers Johnson’s tumultuous first year as president, which included his battle to enact civil rights legislation and the expansion of the Vietnam War. It will begin performances at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., on Sept. 13, a few weeks after the series finale of “Breaking Bad” is aired.

In response to the bombings at the Boston Marathon on Monday, the playwright Richard Greenberg revisited the text of his new play, “The Assembled Parties,” and excised several lines that referred to Boston and to a student bomb maker at Harvard.
 
The lines, which in the original are spoken in passing and have no bearing on the play’s plot, were deleted before the play opened at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater on Wednesday evening. It had been in previews since March 21.

The first time Raul Gonzalez and his bandmates in Barra Libre sat down to discuss recording with Giorgio Gomelsky, they spent hours talking – about everything but music. He told them – as he has everyone from the Rolling Stones to Jeff Buckley – that they had to be sure they were doing it for the music, not the money.
 
“He makes you work a lot,” Mr. Gonzalez said. “He’s tough about that. He always told us if you give to music, music will give back to you. But you have to put a lot of work into that.”

Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, “ The Behavior Gap, ” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog .

 
It’s tempting to think that the next new investment product is the solution to our behavioral problems. So it’s no surprise that I’m getting this question a lot: Do I need to invest in exchange-traded funds?

When it comes to bank accounts, less may be more if your goal is to save money, new research finds.
 
The report, from researchers at the University of Utah and the University of Kansas, found that test participants who had multiple bank accounts saved less than subjects who had a single account, suggesting that consolidating accounts may help you spend less.

A bit more turmoil has come to the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco . Earlier this week a former curator sued the institution saying she was wrongfully fired because she was a union supporter and whistleblower.
 
In the suit, Lynn Orr, who spent 29 years working at the institution’s de Young and Legion of Honor museums, says she was told she was being fired for performance-related reasons despite having had sterling evaluations. She charges her dismissal is related to her appearance at a union protest and to objections she raised about the changing of an appraisal that she “believed fraudulent and unlawful.”

The 18th edition of the Vision Festival , New York’s annual celebration built around the lineage of free improvisation and jazz’s non-mainstream languages, will take place from June 12 to 16, according to Arts for Art, the festival’s producers.  As it did last year, the festival will be staged at Roulette, in downtown Brooklyn.
 
The drummer Milford Graves is the festival’s Lifetime Achievement Award recipient this year; he will perform in three different bands on the first night, one including the Cuban musicians David Virelles, Román Diáz and Román Filiú; one with the pianist D.D. Jackson and the tenor saxophonist Kidd Jordan; and one an ensemble bringing together the tenor saxophonist Charles Gayle, the trombonist Roswell Rudd, the bassist William Parker and the poet Amiri Baraka.

Always far flung, the Tribeca Film Festival reaches north and east this year, to MoMA PS1 in Queens, site of “Alberi,” an installation by the celebrated Italian artist and filmmaker Michelangelo Frammartino .
 
Mr. Frammartino’s feature-length “Quattro Volte” was a critics’ favorite in 2011 — my colleague A.O. Scott called it “idiosyncratic and amazing” — and the 25-minute “ Alberi ” (it means trees in Italian) bears a strong family resemblance to the earlier film. It is free of dialogue but full of sound, and the VW Dome at PS1 wraps the viewer in wind, footsteps, rustling leaves and the indistinct hum of distant human chatter. It takes place in and around a village perched in the hills of southern Italy, and it gives equal, if not preferential, billing to its nonhuman characters: trees, streams, ancient stone buildings.

Say you’re a 70-year-old retiree, and you’d like some help managing your finances. Should you hire an adviser who is an A.R.A., an A.R.P.C., a C.S.A. or a C.R.F.A.?
 
Good luck figuring what any of that means. Right now, older Americans looking for financial guidance encounter professionals using a bewildering array of letters after their names. There are more than 50 “senior certification” designations now in use, according to a new report from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s Office of Older Americans.

PHILLIPS--Gifford. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the death of longtime Trustee Gifford Phillips. Gifford joined the Board of Trustees in 1966 and served on a myriad of committees over his four decade association with the Museum. He served first as Vice-Chair, then as Chair of the Painting & Sculpture Committee (1977-1989), and served on the Executive, Building and Exhibitions Committees. Additionally, Gifford was a member of the International Council since 1961. Together with his wife, Joann, Gifford was not only a generous philanthropist, but an active and passionate collector of art. Over this extraordinary period Gifford also helped build MoMA's collection by giving important works of art to the Museum such as Richard Diebenkorn's "Berkeley, 46", Willem de Kooning's "Valentine" and Ad Reinhardt's "Abstract Painting, Red". We send our condolences to his wife, Joann, their son James and daughters Marjorie Elliot and Alice Swistel. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

RIDDER--Jane Delano, of Ocean Ridge, FL and San Mateo, CA died April 10th at the age of 94 after a short illness. She was at home surrounded by her five loving children. Jane raised all of her children in Duluth MN and St. Paul MN and looked back on those years with great affection. Jane attended The Brearley School in NYC and Greenwood School in Baltimore. She was raised in NYC and at the family residence, Steen Valetje on the Hudson River near Rhinebeck, NY. Her father, Lyman Delano was Franklin Delano Roosevelt's first cousin. She was predeceased in 2002 by her husband of 63 years, Bernard H. Ridder Jr. He was CEO of Ridder Publications at the time of their merger with Knight newspapers in 1974. Her greatest pleasure was spent being with her family of four generations. She is survived by her children Robin Ridder of Healdsburg, CA, Tony Ridder of Pebble Beach, CA, Jill Ridder of Healdsburg, CA, Peter Ridder (Cathy) of Long Beach, CA and Laura Evans (Ned) of Ocean Ridge, FL and Grosse Pointe, MI, nine grandchildren and 23 great grandchildren all of whom looked to her for guidance and support. There has been a private memorial gathering. Contributions may be made to the charity of one's choice.

TRUMPBOUR--Edward A.,Jr. on April 17th, 2013 of Forest Hills, NY. Loving husband of Frances (nee Leton). Dear father of Edward A. and his wife Georgine, Suzanne Trumpbour and her husband Alan Wang, John and his wife Susan, Jacqueline Anne Marie Trumpbour and the late Simone Marie Trumpbour. Also survived by his loving grandchildren Vivienne, Edward, Jason Tyler and John Rocco. Retired Sales Executive and Board Member of C.R. Daniels, Inc. Former President Fredward, Inc., a family investment company. Graduate of Forest Hills High School and Williams College. Services entrusted to Fox Funeral Home, Inc. 98-07 Ascan Avenue Forest Hills, NY (www.foxfuneralhome.com) Visitation Saturday, April 20, 5 to 8pm and Sunday, April 21, 3 to 5 and 7 to 9pm. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church (Corner Queens Blvd. and Ascan Ave.) Monday April 22 at 10:30am. Interment St. John Cemetery, Middle Village NY.
SCHWARTZ--David. April 20, 1913. Dear Dave/ Daddy, on your 100th we love and miss you. The Family

WARSHAW--Robert S. The Brain & Behavior Research Foundation, formerly the National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression (NARSAD), mourns the passing of our long term member of the Board of Directors. Bob Warshaw provided support and guidance in our program to enhance the lives of people suffering from mental illness through research. He was honored with our 2010 Visionary Philanthropist Award, especially for his work with the Hofmann Trust. His leadership role went beyond offering his skills as a lawyer to his articulate reviews of our staff and structure. He will be missed as a vital force for our mission. Jeffrey Borenstein, M.D., President Constance E. Lieber, President Emerita Stephen A. Lieber, Chairman, Board of Directors

WARSHAW--Robert S.,passed away on April 18, 2013 at 88. Loving husband of Elaine Stein Warshaw, beloved father of Hallie, Ronnie and Mark; grandfather of Thomas and Rosa. Bob was born in Boston and received degrees from Harvard College, Graduate School and Law School. He served in the United States Army in WWII in Europe. His legal career began at the law firm of Donovan Leisure. He then became a founding member of Javits, Moore and Trubin with New York Senator Jacob K. Javits. He later practiced independently managing the estates of several well-known artists, including abstract expressionist painter Hans Hoffman and Spanish abstract expressionist Esteban Vicente. He was director and founder of the Museo de Arte Contemporaneo Esteban Vicente in Segovia, Spain and the Vicente Gallery of the Parish Museum in Water Mill, NY. His philanthropic work involved the Israel Art Museum and the Jerusalem Foundation. He served as a director of the Brain and Behavior Research Foundation. Among his many passions were playing tennis, which he played into his 80s, his beautiful garden in Larchmont, and playing with his grandchildren. Services will be held at Larchmont Temple, on Sunday, April 21, at 1:30pm.

PHILLIPS--Gifford. The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art is saddened to learn of the passing of our distinguished member Gifford Phillips. A member since 1961, he was a true advocate of the role of modern art in transcending national barriers. Among his many key associations with the Council and The Museum of Modern Art was his chairmanship of the Council's Program Committee, which he led with great intelligence and energy. He and his wife Joann travelled widely with the International Council, making friends throughout the world. Our most sincere condolences are expressed to Gifford's wife Joann Phillips; his children James, Alice Swistel, and Marjorie Elliott; and eight grandchildren. Duke Franz von Bayern, Brian Urquhart, Chairs Emeriti Agnes Gund, Chair Jo Carole Lauder, Jeanne C. Thayer, Presidents Emerita Sharon Percy Rockefeller, President Lewis B. Cullman, Beatrix Medinger, Vice Chairs William L. Bernhard, Secretary The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

MONTGOMERY--Robert Langford Jr.,85, died at his home in Newport Beach, CA on February 26, 2013 after a long illness. Raised in Connecticut, he graduated from St. Paul's School and served in the Navy during World War II. He graduated magna cum laude from Harvard College in 1950, and after a Fulbright Fellowship in France, returned to Harvard where he received his PhD in 1956. He then taught at the University of Texas at Austin, and at Williams College, before joining the University of California Irvine, two years after its founding, as a professor of English and comparative literature. He retired in 1994. He leaves his wife of almost 62 years, Margaret (Peggy) Kimball, a daughter Alexandra, two sons, Robert III and Carleton, four grandchildren and his sister, Diane Ferris. Memorial gifts in his name may be made to the Pinelands Preservation Alliance, 17 Pemberton Rd, Southampton NJ 08088; or to Harvard Graduate Student Support Fund for the English Department Attn: Neida Jimenez, 124 Mt. Auburn Street, 4th floor, Cambridge MA 02138.

MALLORY--Pauline. The Mystic Seaport Board of Trustees, staff, and community mourn the loss of Pauline Mallory, longtime friend and benefactor, and widow of the late Clifford D. Mallory, Jr. Like no others, the Mallory family have been the core of Mystic Seaport from its beginning, and the legacy continues through the extended Mallory family. Pauline, a true gentlewoman. Our heartfelt condolences to the family.

DePAOLA--Dominick P.,DDS, PhD. It is with profound sadness that the faculty, students, and staff of the New York University College of Dentistry record the passing of one of its most distinguished, respected, and beloved alumni, Dr. Dominick P. DePaola, Class of 1969. Dr. DePaola served most recently as academic dean of Nova Southeastern University College of Dental Medicine. He served previously as president and CEO of The Forsyth Institute in Boston. Dr. DePaola was the first person to serve as president of both the American Dental Education Association (ADEA) and the American Association for Dental Research (AADR). Earlier in his career he served as dean of three of our nation's dental schools, dean of a graduate school of biomedical sciences, and president of two academic campuses. Dr. DePaola was widely regarded as a visionary leader in health professions education and was a frequent consultant to non-profit boards, the academic community, the public sector and private industry. Beyond all of his professional accomplishments, Dom DePaola was an inspiring, captivating, and gracious person, whose kindness, warmth, and collegiality touched all who were privileged to know him. To his wife Rosemary and their entire family, we extend profound sympathy on his loss. Charles N. Bertolami, DDS, DMedSc Herman Robert Fox Dean New York University College of Dentistry

KRAMER--Morris J.,On April 18, 2013. With great sadness, the partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the loss of our partner Morris Kramer, a cornerstone of the firm's M&A practice for more than 40 years. He was 71. Mr. Kramer joined Skadden in 1972. Working closely with Joe Flom, he was a principal player in the development of the modern takeover era. He helped the firm capture a large share of this new market, working on many of our defining takeovers. A strong advocate for the globalization of Skadden's practice, Mr. Kramer helped launch the firm's London office. A brilliant tactician, Mr. Kramer was known for his incisiveness. Over his four-plus decades at Skadden, he represented clients such as Allied Signal, Inc., ALLTEL Corporation, American General Corporation, Norfolk Southern Corporation, Prudential plc and XM Satellite Radio Holdings Inc. He advised many investment banks in the development of their M&A practices, including most notably First Boston (now Credit Suisse). Mr. Kramer grew up in Brooklyn and attended Dartmouth College ('63) and Harvard Law School ('66). He also served on the board of American General. Mr. Kramer is survived by his sons, Jeremy and Oliver; daughter-in-law, Kaye; and grandchildren, Jules, Maxime and Oscar. We extend our deep condolences to Morris's family.

CROSS--Bernard, 89 of Elkins Park, PA, died at his home on April 18, 2013. He was President Cross Bro's Meat Packers, the largest kosher meat packing company in the east coast. Bernard was a chairman of UJA, board member of Jewish Theological Seminary and Solomon Schechter, and President of Beth Shalom of Elkins Park. Penn State alum, he attended West Point and served in WWII as First Lt. Bernard "Spanky" is survived by his wife of 65 years Polly, his children Susan Liebman (Samuel), Patty Cross, and Ben Cross (Stacey), seven grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren.

BUCKLEY--Gerard (Gerry) P. Mutual of America and its Board of Directors, together with its officers and employees, wish to express our deep sense of loss at the passing of our colleague and friend, Gerry Buckley, who served as Senior Field Vice President of Mutual of America's Boston Regional Office. Mr. Buckley joined Mutual of America in 1973 and retired after 20 years. Throughout those years, Mr. Buckley maintained a strong commitment to the Mission of Mutual of America and freely shared his experience and knowledge with others, inspiring those who worked with him with his humor, strength of character, abiding optimism and dedication to service. Our sincere condolences to his niece, Claudia Galvin, and to his many friends and loved ones. William J. Flynn, Chairman Emeritus Thomas J. Moran, Chairman, President and CEO Mutual of America

GRANETT--Solomon, a NYC attorney, of Mamaroneck, NY, passed away at the age of 100. Predeceased by his wife Ruth, survived by his children, loving grandchildren and great-grandchildren Jeffrey (Catherine), Barbara (Jerry), Jason, Julie (Marc), Benjamin and Sophia. Funeral Service Sunday 1pm Zion Memorial Chapel 785 E. Boston Post Rd. Mamaroneck. 914-381-1809. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

JOSEPH--Leepee, 96, a left-wing activist and longtime theatrical assistant, died of lung cancer on April 2nd in her Greenwich Village apartment. The youngest of four sisters in a deeply radical family, she was first arrested for picketing at age 12. She worked as a secretary for the theater section of the WPA, The Group Theater, the publicist Ben Washer, theatrical producers Cheryl Crawford and Irene Selznick, and performers Perry Como and Mary Martin. In 1940, Ms. Joseph married songwriter and lyricist Arthur Herzog, Jr. (God Bless' The Child). They divorced in 1953. In 1961 she married J. J. Joseph, who had been blacklisted. With Mr. Joseph she traveled to Cuba to help deliver humanitarian supplies. Ms. Joseph later volunteered for Congresswoman Bella Abzug. Through her 90s, Ms. Joseph could be found leafleting in Union Square. Recently, she became known to theater audiences through the plays "After The Revolution" and "4000 Miles", written by her granddaughter, Amy Herzog. Her frank talk stood out in more guarded times. Ms. Joseph is survived by her sister Jessie Smith, her son Gregory Herzog, her step children Paul, Andrei, and Anne Joseph, their spouses Elaine Herzog, Linda Schiffman, Pam Rogers, and Phil McGlave, her nephew Russell Smith, her nieces Shirley Kirsten, Susan and Ilse Mende, and Jane Fire. A memorial will be held 4:00pm, May 26 at the Judson Memorial Church, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations to jeffersonmarketgarden.org, The Rosenberg Fund for Children (rfc.org/) or peace-action.org suggested.

GOLDBLATT--Larry Stewart, MD, devoted husband, loving father, adoring grandfather, and dedicated psychiatrist, passed away Wednesday April 17, 2013 after a long battle with cancer. He is survived by his wife of 37 years, Betty; son Brian; daughter Laura; son-in-law Caleb Clark; grandson Shaw Clark; sister Joni Krieg, and niece Nicole Pique. Dr. Goldblatt brought passion to all his endeavors, from cattle farming to a genealogical search taking him around the globe. His devotion to his family was matched only by his commitment to his patients. Funeral at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., at Amsterdam, on Tuesday, April 23 at 1:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donate to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, New York.

BARST--Dr. Robyn. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its devoted member and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Lisa Messinger, President Jonathan E. Blake, Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor

BARST--Robyn, 62, of Scarsdale. Survived by her loving husband Samuel of 32 years; was the adoring mother of Nomi (David) Berenson, Lindsey (Jason) Gumer and grandson Tobias Berenson; her sister Lynn Hofstra and mother Ruth. Professor Emeritus at Columbia University, Robyn was recognized in her lifetime as the pre-eminent leader in the field of Pediatric Pulmonary Hypertension. Funeral services will be held Sunday April 21 at 1pm at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd, Scarsdale, NY. The family request, in lieu of personal gifts, contributions be made to the Robyn J Barst, Pediatric Research and Mentoring Fund for Pulmonary Hypertension at PHA, 801 Roeder Road, Suite 1000, Silver Spring, MD 20910.

Next week, the Metropolitan section’s Q. and A. series will feature Syndie Molina, a rescue paramedic at the Fire Department’s Emergency Medical Services Station 4 in Downtown Manhattan.
 
Ms. Molina is hazardous material certified and is trained to enter dangerous situations — with more than 70 pounds of gear on her back. When the most challenging emergency calls come in, she responds: to a worker on scaffolding who has had a heart attack; to a person pinned under a subway train; to a building or floor collapse. Recently, she was called uptown to help with the rescue of a man trapped in the muck of the Second Avenue subway project, 75 feet underground.

The Slap Shot hockey column in some editions last Sunday, about possible candidates to win the Hart Trophy as the N.H.L’s most valuable player, misidentified a position John Tavares holds with the Islanders. He is an alternate captain, not the captain. (Mark Streit is the captain.)

An article last Sunday about similarities between a case of meningitis in California and an outbreak of meningitis among gay men in New York City misstated the number of victims in New York. Four men, not 13, have contracted meningitis this year. (Thirteen contracted it last year.)

A picture credit on March 31 with an entry in the Playlist column about Steve Coleman’s latest CD misidentified the photographer who took the picture of Mr. Coleman. He is Michael Weintrob, not Seth Rosner.

A picture caption on April 7 with an article about the return of Dance Theater of Harlem carried an erroneous credit. The photograph of Arthur Mitchell, a founder of the company, and Diana Adams, was by Martha Swope/New York Public Library; it was not supplied by New York City Ballet.

An article on April 7 about the conductor John Eliot Gardner misstated the reason Mr. Gardiner released 27 CDs to record the Bach Cantata Pilgrimage in 2000. It was to celebrate the 250th anniversary of Bach’s death, not his 250th birthday. (He was born in 1685 and died in 1750.)

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the artist Claes Oldenburg, who has a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, misstated the year when one of his signature works, “U.S.A. Flag,” was completed. It was 1960, not 1961.

An article last Sunday about whether it is beneficial to enroll low-income children in schools located in wealthy communities like Greenwich, Conn., referred incorrectly to the home Steven A. Cohen, the hedge-fund billionaire, owns there. His property no longer features a private rink; it was dismantled in 2010.

An article last Sunday about Anthony Weiner misspelled the surname of a fictional character to whom Weiner referred. It was Chauncey Gardiner, not Gardner. The article also described incorrectly Weiner’s reaction to a debate in the House of Representatives in July 2010 on the 9/11 health and compensation act. Weiner went berserk because he believed that Representative Peter King, Republican of New York, was trying to scuttle that day’s vote, not because King was trying to scuttle the act. King supported the act, which later passed.

An article in some editions last Sunday about the new eight-team National Women’s Soccer League misstated the given name of a Japanese star player who is not being pursued by the league, which is focusing on North American players. She is Homare Sawa, not Hope.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the food scene in Charleston, S.C., misstated the given name of the chef at the Ordinary, a seafood restaurant. As the article correctly noted, he is Mike Lata, not Mark.

Members of the audience called her a “liar,” an opponent relentlessly attacked her, and the moderator at one point had to beg the scornful crowd to let her speak.
 
On Saturday, a forum of five Democratic mayoral candidates on the topic of public housing turned into a startling show of hostility toward the woman regarded as the front-runner in the New York race, Christine C. Quinn. The audience at the forum — sponsored by Teamsters Local 237 and the nonprofit Community Service Society — seemed to regard Ms. Quinn, the City Council speaker, as a doppelgänger of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, and directed its anger about his housing and policing policies toward her.

An article last Sunday about the migration of American Indians to urban areas over the past several decades quoted incorrectly from comments by Bill Ziegler, the president and chief executive of the Little Earth of United Tribes housing complex, in describing efforts to halt the cycle of poverty. He said, “It’s like the Lakota hunters bringing down a buffalo. It wasn’t one shot. It was a series of arrows that led to success. And it’s going to take a series of arrows to bring down the beast” — not “a series of errors.”

An article in some editions last Sunday about the Rangers’ 1-0 overtime victory over the Islanders misidentified the Rangers player whose stick was slashed on a penalty by the Islanders’ Kyle Okposo with one minute left in regulation. He is Dan Girardi, not Henrik Lundqvist.

A picture caption in some editions last Sunday with an article about the exhibition “Drawn to Nature,” in the Glyndor Gallery at Wave Hill in the Bronx, misstated part of the name of a work by Samm Kunce. As the article correctly noted, it is “Ljubljana 9-07,” not “Libljana 9-07.”

‘You can ask “what if” after every tournament that we lose. 
 
I guess this is another one.’

An article last Sunday about Secretary of State John Kerry’s visit to China to seek that country’s help in dealing with an increasingly recalcitrant nuclear-armed North Korea misidentified, in some editions, the Chinese official who said that the denuclearization process on the Korean Peninsula should be “resolved peacefully through dialogue and consultation.” He is State Councilor Yang Jiechi, not Foreign Minister Wang Yi.

The five most viewed articles on nytimes.com/sports from April 12 to 18.
 
1. TIGER WOODS PENALIZED FOR ILLEGAL BALL DROP AT AUGUSTA He could have been disqualified, but a rule was invoked that allows a penalty of disqualification to be waived or modified in exceptional cases.

An obituary on April 7 about Edith Schaeffer, the author of books that helped define conservative Christian family values for a worldwide evangelical audience, misstated the date and place of her death. She died on Saturday, March 30, at her home in Gryon, Switzerland — not on Sunday, April 1, in Huemoz, Switzerland.

Barclays Center has a somewhat forbidding atmosphere for visiting teams. The music pumped through the arena’s loudspeakers, hand-selected by the mix-tape artist J. Period, has an aggressive attitude. The black-clad Brooklynettes dance team has a decidedly adult attitude. And the Nets, in black home uniforms that are in stark contrast with typical N.B.A. fashion, certainly look tough, even if their game is based on offensive execution more than any sort of intimidation.
 
For the Nets’ first-round playoff series against the Chicago Bulls, the arena will grow even darker, with the team distributing black T-shirts to fans in hopes of creating a “blackout” in the crowd.

During the weekly exchange of peace handshakes several months ago at the small church around the corner from where I live in Chicago, a fellow congregant met my extended hand with a firm grip and said, “I heard that you lost your job — you must be scared.” Then she followed up with a “Peace be with you” and moved on to another parishioner.
 
It was true. When the large bank I had worked for underwent “restructuring” a few months before, I quickly became one of nearly 12 million unemployed people in the United States. That’s about the same number of people who watched the zombie drama “The Walking Dead” this season, and more than the entire population of Ohio.

DURING its heyday, Titusville, Fla., enjoyed the distinction of being the capital of Florida’s Space Coast. For decades, technicians, engineers and scientists helped send astronauts into space from the Kennedy Space Center. On July 16, 1969, Apollo 11 lifted off from there, carrying the men who would become the first to walk on the moon. 
 
But after the Space Shuttle program ended in 2011, and 8,000 people lost their jobs, this boomtown born of the space race started to lose its footing. NASA says it still has “a robust program of exploration, technology development and scientific research that will last for years to come,” but the shuttle program was crucial to Titusville’s and Brevard County’s economy. Now private employers are creating jobs to help make up for the loss. The shuttle Atlantis, meanwhile, which once charged into outer space, is in permanent retirement at the Kennedy Space Center Visitor Center.

An Upper East Side town house that in 1981 received the dreaded thumbs-down designation of being “a no-style structure” from the Landmarks Preservation Commission because of an unloved mid-20th-century revamping, sold for $27 million after undergoing a 21st-century rejuvenation, in the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.
 
The five-story town house at 12 East 76th Street, built in 1882, attracted such intense interest from buyers seeking a state-of-the-art residence with a classical exterior — in the course of a gut renovation that began in 2008, red brick was replaced with Italian limestone — that it was never formally listed on the market. It traded after just three viewings, in a whisper sale.

Fred R. Conrad used a long exposure and a hand-held flash to photograph the Survivor Tree at the 9/11 Memorial. “I must have looked like a madman running around the tree firing my strobe into its branches,” he said. “Such is spring in New York.”

East of West Egg Even F. Scott Fitzgerald could not have imagined the extravagance of Tiffany & Company’s Blue Book Ball Thursday night to introduce its collection of jewelry inspired by the jazz age and the new movie version of “The Great Gatsby.” Tiffany built a blue box over the skating rink at Rockefeller Center, with suspended aerialists and the Rockettes. The buffets were almost unimaginable. And, a rarity at New York high-profile events, most of the women wore their own dresses and jewels. Many guests were Asian, some in native dress. Tiffany’s focus on the era coincides with a forceful trend in men’s wear, a 21st-century take on the Gatsby style, bottom row, seen on men passing the store’s facade, marked with “fountains” of tape. On April 17, the store held a reception, bottom left and right, for the new designs, and young people dressed in the spirit. Not to be missed are the windows, each one a glittering gem, by Christopher Young.

More than 100 readers submitted comments to nytimes.com about last Sunday’s cover profile of Jenna Marbles, “The Woman With a Billion Clicks.” Here is a sampling.

 
An Internet Video Star
Some retire, while others carry on.
The Vows column last Sunday, about Myriah Hampton and Jacob Kulin, misidentified the organization for which the bride works. It is Hebrew SeniorLife, not Jewish Senior Life.

Even in an environment as man-made as New York City’s, nature stubbornly persists — in park woodlands, empty lots, and between the cracks of the sidewalk. In an occasional series, Dave Taft, a senior-level park ranger in New York City with the National Park Service, will be offering close-in portraits of the city’s plants and animals. 

 
Cherry blossoms get the fanfare this time of year, but watching the less-heralded bloodroot (Sanguinaria canadensis) bloom offers the instinctive thrill of seeing yet another spring unfurl.

A report last Sunday about the marriage of Jessica Leight and Amir Satvat referred incorrectly to the groom’s work at the EMC Corporation. He helps the company invest in data storage companies; he does not sell data storage.

“THE TUDORS,” with its ruffs and tufted silks; “The Borgias,” all gilt and jeweled vestments; and, of course, “Game of Thrones,” with its boiled-wool cloaks and armored corsets, have inspired a flurry of fashion stories and runway interpretations. “Da Vinci’s Demons” is but the latest costume extravaganza poised to charm the fashion set.
 
The series, which bowed with a flourish on the Starz network on April 12, offers a tapestry of faux Renaissance costumes so rich yet approachable that you might suppose the producers had an eye to future merchandising deals. That thought occurred to Annie Symons, the creator of the lavish gowns, doublets and a beat-up leather jacket — a kind of Renaissance biker coat worn by the swashbuckling Da Vinci. “A line based on the show: that’s something I would be really interested in pursuing,” she said.

When Rockefeller Center opened in 1939 after a decade of construction, it was not received with the glory we shower on it now. Newspapers were filled with letters calling it one of the ugliest complexes in the city. The building of what today is considered one of the crown jewels of the Manhattan skyline is a saga of big money, intriguing power brokers and one of the most glamorous periods in the city’s history. 
 
The story is told artfully and addictively in Daniel Okrent’s “Great Fortune: The Epic of Rockefeller Center,” a Pulitzer Prize finalist for history in 2004. Join us for an online discussion with Mr. Okrent and the novelist and culture critic Kurt Andersen, author of the best-selling novel “Heyday” and most recently “True Believers.”

What do spring fever and the much-anticipated film “The Great Gatsby” have in common? Rising hemlines and lowering inhibitions. In honor of the May release of Baz Luhrmann’s new flick, raise a champagne coupe while wearing these flapper-inspired pieces that sparkle as brightly as the Art Deco architecture that they evoke.
The What I Wore column last Sunday, about Amy Fine Collins, misquoted her on her fashion tastes. She said, “I like a strong line versus surface ornamentation,” not “circus ornamentation.”

The On the Runway column on March 31, about male politicians who needlessly call attention to a woman’s appearance, misidentified the woman the chairman of the Beaufort County, S.C., Republican Party was referring to when he said: “She’s not a bad-looking lady, she is a good speaker and she’s got some money. In politics, these things are important.” She is Elizabeth Colbert Busch, Mark Sanford’s Democratic opponent in a South Carolina congressional race — not María Belén Chapur, Mr. Sanford’s fiancée.

Mercedes-Benz is going smaller and sportier with its Concept GLA, a compact crossover aimed at younger buyers. The GLA, to be unveiled at the Shanghai Motor Show this weekend, has a long, muscular nose, large wheels and squat haunches. The mechanical bits include a turbocharged 2-liter 4-cylinder gasoline engine, making 208 horsepower, a 7-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission and 4Matic all-wheel drive.
 
A production version may be available in the United States in late 2014, though it is likely to lack some of the baubles of the show car, like the kitschy frameless doors reminiscent of an old Subaru. But one can hope that the high-definition cameras mounted to the roof rails – which could be removed and attached to a ski helmet or dog collar — and laser-beam lights that double as movie projectors will make the cut.

Early next month, the latest products of John Derian’s ongoing collaboration with the French ceramic tableware company Astier de Villatte will be available in the United States. They include a mug and teapot with an image of an eye that was taken from a 19th-century medical book, as well as a plate called Starfish at Night and a serving bowl covered with a coral-like pattern in blue. Unlike the designer’s famous decoupage plates, these pieces are dishwasher-safe (on the gentle setting). “I love the fact that they’re user-friendly,” Derian says.
 
$82 to $405; (212) 677-3917.

When ‘Affordable’ Is Just a Word

 
In last Sunday’s Big City column, Ginia Bellafante asked whether the phrase affordable housing had lost its meaning in the era of $90 million penthouse apartments. Readers responded on nytimes.com ; a selection of their comments is below.

A nod to the lifestyles of the creative types of yore who weren’t afraid to pair intimate apparel with formal dress — the David Hockneys and Pablo Picassos of the world — the new “not-quite-ready-to-wear” label Sleepy Jones launches this week. Designed by Andy Spade, the fashion-world veteran who helped start Kate Spade (his wife’s namesake line) before opening the New York storefront and branding agency Partners & Spade, the colorful collection of men’s and women’s crisp pajama separates and jaunty underwear is meant to encourage luxuriating in the kinds of things that comfortable nightclothes inspire one to do. “Essentially, we’re designing an everyday uniform for reading, writing, painting, pondering and playing — whether you’re in the bedroom or not,” Spade says. With practical and stylish boxers features like a coin pocket for the men and Liberty of London fabric for the women, you may soon find yourself answering the door in your underwear.
 
Sleepy Jones socks, underwear and pajama separates, $24 to $154; sleepyjones.com .

He died after a brief illness, said Mayra Nieves, special adviser to the president of John Jay.

The Exclusive column last week, about a five-bedroom apartment at 1020 Fifth Avenue that is on the market for $25 million, misstated the given name of the owner’s son. He is Ari Ackerman, not Avi.

YANGON, Myanmar — Five years ago, when Myanmar was still under military rule, some Western and Chinese friends asked me how there could be such oppression in a country where Buddhism, which preaches nonviolence, is the predominant religion.
 
I was in self-imposed exile at the time, studying journalism at the University of Hong Kong, and I would answer that the country’s military leaders were immoral, Buddhists in name only. I would also point out that Myanmar’s pre-colonial monarchical rulers — they, too, nominally Buddhist — also had committed great crimes. In other words, nothing was wrong with the religion itself; the problem was with the politicians who were flouting it.

Amaryllis Knight, a globe-trotting, British-born designer, has left her aesthetic fingerprints all over her adopted home of Los Angeles: in the homes, gardens and offices of private design clients; in her own house ; and soon, in the smartly appointed restaurant that chef Josef Centeno is opening this summer (Orsa & Winston). Now, with the opening of Altai — the retail store (which opens April 18) and online platform for her consultancy and furniture studio — Knight’s eclectic vision is, at last, shoppable. “It’s a lot more than a store,” she says. “It’s a way to further explore my work and interests while contributing to a conversation in Los Angeles about varied worlds of design and how they intersect.” Situated on a stretch of 3rd Street that’s a retail desert — but a quick skip to LACMA and Regen Projects — the light-drenched, vaulted-ceilinged space sells everything from $14 Santa Maria Novella lozenges to a $600,000 1948 Vincent 1000cc Rapide Series B motorcycle with a legendary racing pedigree. (“It’s a wild machine,” Knight says.)
 
Equally thrilling is Altai’s selection of men’s fashion, which includes exclusives from Raf Simons and Christophe Lemaire and lesser-known standouts like the Belgian designer Tim Coppens and the British label Casely-Hayford. Knight’s own furniture pieces — which share a fabrication facility in back with The Falcon Ten (a collection by her fiancé, Ian Barry) — sit alongside Issey Miyake’s lamps for Artemide and blown-glass objets d’art by Andi Kovel and Justin Parker. The in-house design consultancy has extended its services to include personal styling for men and women, run by the fashion director Teena Sahebi. There’s a blog, too, edited by the curator Corinna Peipon, to reflect Knight’s taste in travel, art and food. It all feels new and special, which is a feat in today’s hyper-linked retail scene. “It’s reductive, and yet warm and comfortable,” says Knight of the Altai aesthetic. “I strive to design environments that encourage presence — in one’s self, in one’s life, in a place, in a moment.”

WHITE MARSH, Md. – Electric cars can take a while to charge. In part, that’s because the alternating current electricity that comes from the grid has to be converted to direct current before a car’s batteries can store it, and the capacity of the electronics that make the A.C.-to-D.C. conversion is a bottleneck.

Visits to New York by the superb dramatic soprano Nina Stemme are eagerly awaited by fans who admire her powerful, emotive voice. On Thursday, she joins the Swedish Chamber Orchestra, conducted by Thomas Dausgaard, for an eclectic program featuring songs by Grieg, Sibelius, Wagner, Weill, Berlioz and Strauss. Mr. Dausgaard will also conduct the ensemble in Brahms’s Symphony No. 1 and selections by Ravel, Beethoven, Schubert, Sibelius and Elgar. (7:30 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, 212-721-6500, lcgreatperformers.org ; $25-$75.)
 
David McVicar’s vivacious production of Handel’s “Giulio Cesare” made a splash at its Glyndebourne festival opening in 2005. Fortunately, the Metropolitan Opera has imported the colorful staging, which is repeated on Monday and Saturday. Witty touches, including Bollywood dances, enliven the action, set here in the Victorian era. Harry Bicket works wonders in the pit; the strong cast includes Natalie Dessay as Cleopatra, Alice Coote as Sesto, Christophe Dumaux as Tolomeo and David Daniels in the title role. (7 p.m. Monday, noon Saturday, Lincoln Center, 212-362-6000, metoperafamily.org .)

When Souleymane Badolo — a wall of sturdy muscle — steps onto the stage, he fills not only the spot he inhabits but also all of its crevices. It’s no wonder that his nickname is Solo — this African dance artist is a powerful sight. Born in Burkina Faso, Mr. Badolo explores his African heritage in “Buudou, Badoo, Badolo,” one of two works he unveils at New York Live Arts in a shared program with the choreographer Cynthia Oliver. In the other, “Barak,” which translates loosely into “gratitude” in Gurunsi, Mr. Badolo pays homage to those who helped him in his move to the United States in 2009. 
 
The evening also features Ms. Oliver’s “Boom!,” a new duet featuring Leslie Cuyjet and herself that, according to Ms. Oliver’s Web site, “wreaks havoc with stereotypes of womanhood, friendship, race and the mythologies of ‘effort’ and ‘belief’ and their assumed payoff.” As usual, the bold Ms. Oliver tells it like it is. (7:30 p.m., Thursday through Saturday, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea; 212-924-0077, newyorklivearts.org ; $15-$20.)

The story begins in 1943 in Bletchley Park, in Britain, where four ordinary women are putting their extraordinary talents to use at the country’s code-breaking headquarters during World War II . Flash-forward nine years, as London is swept by a wave of murders and Susan (Anna Maxwell Martin), now a homemaker and mother of two, thinks she has detected a pattern. After wangling an entry into Scotland Yard, she persuades detectives to scour a rubbish site for a victim she believes has gone undetected. 
 
But when the police don’t find a corpse and dismiss her theory as poppycock, she turns for assistance to her former colleagues — Millie (Rachael Stirling), conversant in 14 languages and good with maps; Lucy (Sophie Rundle), with her photographic memory; and Jean (Julie Graham), their onetime supervisor — who have returned to civilian life and kept their intelligence work secret from even those closest to them.

Britain is a land of walkers. Ambitious trails abound from the year-old, 870-mile Wales Coast Path, to the new 470-mile Gore-Tex Scottish National Trail from the English border to the northern Highlands. There are paths for foodies, art lovers and history buffs. And in one pocket of rural Scotland, there are paths for stargazers.
 
As of 2009, the Galloway Forest Park, in the rural Dumfries and Galloway region, is home to Europe’s first International Dark Sky Park, a designation bestowed by the Tucson-based International Dark-Sky Association as determined by the relative lack of light pollution. On clear nights, stargazers gather in clearings at trailheads near the park’s visitor centers. But some of the best viewing, like the best hiking, lies in the remote highlands area accessed by the Queens Way road, where hikers can wander over spongy meadows or along the edge of Clatteringshaws Loch under a canopy of stars.

The Jura Mountains hardly count as mountains by Swiss standards, not when you have the Alps right next door. Their forested swales roll for about 225 miles along the Swiss-French border northeast from Geneva and are softer than their Alpine kin in every regard. 
 
Yet whatever the Jura lack in awesome, icy grandeur is offset by a quiet splendor offered to anyone willing to take a stroll among them: Not a hike, though you can do that in the Jura, too, but a sweatless, pokey amble on a well-marked route. One warm day a few years ago my wife, Heidi, and I took our young daughter on a seven-mile walk from Avenches to Murten, two villages near the Jura foothills. The terrain suited us well. The farmers’ path was stroller-friendly, and we wandered along great patches of flowering rapeseed, through murky forests and next to an 11th-century chapel built from stones the Romans had cut. Here on the border dividing three Swiss cantons the languages mix like kirsch in a fondue: a rue melts into a strasse that ends at a table with brats and bières.

The German abstract artist Blinky Palermo lived and worked in New York from 1973 until the spring of 1976, the year before he died, at 33. While in New York, he made many of his works on paper, several of which will be on view at David Zwirner’s Chelsea gallery starting Thursday . 
 
The show, “Works on Paper 1976-1977,” features pieces drawn from museum and private collections, including “1-7 Untitled (for Babette),” from the Museum of Modern Art, a seven-part geometric work in vibrant red acrylic, and “1-12 12 Monate,” from a private collection, which features 12 painted drawings that refer to the 12 months of the year.

To pursue a career as an actor requires steely perseverance, an ability to keep picking yourself up after the latest dispiriting audition or bad review knocks you down. But few actors have had to recover from the kind of hard fall taken by Tristan Sturrock, the British actor best known for his starring role in Emma Rice’s celebrated stage adaptation of “Brief Encounter.” 
 
In 2004, after touring with another production from Ms. Rice’s company, Kneehigh Theater, Mr. Sturrock returned to the troupe’s home base, Cornwall, England, just in time to join in the city’s May Day festivities welcoming the advent of summer. The party ended in tragedy for Mr. Sturrock, when he fell off a wall and broke his neck. “Mayday Mayday,” written and performed by Mr. Sturrock and directed by his wife, Katy Carmichael, is a solo show in which he recounts the story of the accident — which initially left him paralyzed — and his long journey back to well-being, and back to the spotlight. (Opens Monday; St. Ann’s Warehouse, 29 Jay Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn, 718-254-8779, stannswarehouse.org ; $25-$45.)

TV on the Radio is inarguably one of the great Brooklyn bands of the last decade, and also one of the most reclusive, going dark for long stretches in between albums. So its headlining performance on the final night of the Crossing Brooklyn Ferry festival is something to cheer. It’s part of the second-annual installment of this festival, which is organized by the twins Bryce and Aaron Dessner of the band the National, and features a combination of pop, experimental and modern classical performers, as well as short films. 
 
It all takes place over three nights in many different spaces at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The Roots headline on Friday night and Solange on Saturday, but the festival will also feature, among others, the snotty punks Parquet Courts, jazz from the Matthew Shipp Trio, the composed space-pop of Julia Holter and unsettling drone-rock from Pure X. (5 p.m., Thursday-Saturday, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, 718-636-4100, crossingbrooklynferry.com ; $50 a night, $120 for all nights.)

Elegiac moments pervade Richard Lester’s “Robin and Marian” (1976), part of the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s Family Films series . While displaying his signature wit and the historical derring-do of his middle period (including his definitive, two-part “Three Musketeers” adaptation ), “Robin and Marian” is Mr. Lester in a minor key, a tempered swashbuckler drawing pathos and poignancy from its portraits of heroes in decline.
 
An aging Robin Hood (Sean Connery) has spent almost two decades fighting for a plundering Richard the Lionheart (Richard Harris) in pointless Crusades. Now he returns to Sherwood Forest to face the Sheriff of Nottingham (Robert Shaw) over the objections of Marian (a luminous Audrey Hepburn), who has become an abbess. She is tired of the brawling vanity of these longtime combatants and takes action in a twist as surprising as it is heartbreaking. “Robin and Marian,” in today’s era of muscle-bound screen spectaculars and video-game blood baths, challenges illusory notions of heroism itself. (Sunday at 2 p.m., Film Center Amphitheater, Lincoln Center, 212-875-5601, filmlinc.com .)

Three picture captions last Sunday with an article about the director Terrence Malick and his new movie, “To the Wonder,” carried erroneous credits for scenes from his movies. The photograph of Q’orianka Kilcher in “The New World” was provided by New Line Cinema, not by Magnolia Pictures. The picture of Ben Affleck and Olga Kurylenko in “To the Wonder” was from Magnolia Pictures, not from Merie Wallace/Fox Searchlight Pictures. And the photograph of Jessica Chastain and Tye Sheridan in “The Tree of Life” was provided by Merie Wallace/Fox Searchlight, not by New Line Cinema.

Close your eyes and think of Tuscany. Do you see hillsides bathed in golden sunlight? A patchwork quilt of vineyards? Small villages, with their terra-cotta roofs, perched on distant hilltops? 
 
The quintessential Tuscan landscape is etched in the minds of many thanks to decades’ worth of idyllic images cast on the silver screen. But there’s no substitute for lacing up your walking shoes and experiencing the scenery firsthand. A favorite route that takes less than two hours links the medieval hilltop towns of Radda in Chianti and Castello di Volpaia in central Tuscany. Starting in Radda, head west down the town’s main street, with its stone walls and valley views, and bear right onto the narrow road immediately after the sign for Castellina. Olive groves and vineyards line this leafy lane, from which a backward glance will reveal a glimpse of ocher-hued Radda. Turn off at the sign for Sassaiola, and follow the path alongside the woods to emerge on the main road toward Castello di Volpaia.

The visitor who happens upon Madrid’s Cava Baja on a weekend evening could be forgiven for thinking a public celebration of the sort that accompanies World Cup championships or overturned dictatorships was under way. In fact, for the joyous hordes of young people who stroll its length while flirting, singing, smoking and occasionally stopping into a bar for a drink or a snack, it is just another Saturday night. Cava Baja is ground zero for that most Spanish of rituals, the tapeo. 
 
The reason tapas restaurants outside Spain never have the right vibe is that they mistake a means for an end. A proper tapeo, in which you stand at one bar with your friends, order a drink and a snack to share, then move on to the next, repeating as long as your wallet and equilibrium hold out, is more about socializing than small plates. Cava Baja, which has dozens of tapas bars along its two-block length, compresses the process.

They nicknamed it the “wobbly bridge” when it opened, in 2000, because an engineering miscalculation caused it to sway so badly that people who tried to walk across it grew dizzy and even fell down. But after it was modified and opened again two years later, the Millennium Bridge, a pedestrian-only suspension bridge across the Thames, connecting Bankside on the south side to the City of London financial district on the north, became one of the great walking experiences in a city that might have been invented for strolling. 
 
At 1,006 feet long, the bridge takes just five minutes to cross, and can be a destination in itself. At one end is St. Paul’s Cathedral, and that is where I like to start; you climb up to the top, and get someone to whisper at you from across the Whispering Gallery, and then climb down again. Then you walk straight down to the Thames and the bridge, slender and elegant in gleaming steel.

Most writers come to loathe their most popular piece of writing, but in 2008, when BBC Four asked John le Carré to name his best books, the first title out of his mouth was “The Spy Who Came In From the Cold” (1963). This was wisdom on his part. The novel remains the crucial introduction to le Carré’s cool moral universe — his bald, adjective-free prose style, his penetrating insight into human character, his ethical inquisitiveness and, perhaps best of all, his ability to tell a story in such a way that you’re forever just one step behind a tripping kind of jazz beat. It set the tone for the procession of antiheroes in his books. “What do you think spies are: priests, saints and martyrs?” his hero, the West Berlin intelligence station chief Alec Leamas, asks. “They’re a squalid procession of vain fools, traitors too, yes; pansies, sadists and drunkards, people who play cowboys and Indians to brighten their rotten lives.”
 
After this you’ll want to devour “Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy” (1974), the best of his George Smiley novels.

Much of Prague’s art scene is moving out to the rough-hewed Zizkov neighborhood, where the year-old Drdova Gallery and the tiny 35m2 exhibition space will soon be joined by the new location of Hunt Kastner Artworks. Other art attractions hide in the Holesovice or Karlin districts. But in the city center, travelers can link several thought-provoking public installations into an art walk without leaving Old Town.
 
Start out on Dlouha Street, where a giant golden sculpture of a human femur hangs over the intersection with Rybna Street, installed last year by the artist Jiri David. Continue west on Dlouha, turning right on V Kolkovne Street until you come to the Spanish Synagogue, where Jaroslav Rona’s memorial to Franz Kafka has the young author riding on the shoulders of an empty suit.

6. War of the Worlds (2005) 
 
End-of-the-world movie that cunningly casts Cruise not as slick action hero but as a semicompetent Everyman.

The Big Profile By Dave Itzkoff
 
The apocalypse that Nick Cave’s music has hinted at might really be coming, now that he has name-checked Miley Cyrus and her former alter ego, Hannah Montana, on a song from his new album, “Push the Sky Away.” “The benign image of her lying in a swimming pool in Toluca Lake has a dark, resonating idea that’s synonymous with spiritual collapse, at least to me,” Cave explains. “The journey in this particular song is witnessing a series of spiritual collapses in the world, up until the present day. Although, obviously, Hannah Montana isn’t the present present anymore.”

Turkey is a majority Muslim country, but Istanbul’s religious history remains multicultural. Evidence of this is visible during a two-and-a-half-hour walk along the Halic, or Golden Horn, which separates the Old City from the more contemporary Beyoglu. At the Fener (“lighthouse”) bus stop, cross Abdulezelpasa Caddesi — the main shore road — and walk past the trinket shops to the walled compound that includes the Church of St. George, seat of the Eastern Orthodox Church. Inside, you’ll find the ivory-inlaid throne of the patriarch, Bartholomew, and a wall of gilded icons. Farther up the main avenue is the golden-domed Church of St. Stephen of the Bulgars, constructed of iron panels that were cast in Vienna, barged down the Danube and pieced together here in the late 1800s.
 
Continue along Murselpasa Caddesi for a meatball break at Kofteci Arnavut (look for a Mavi Kose sign), then duck into the Jewish neighborhood of Balat (above) to reach the intersection with Leblebiciler Sokak (the Sellers of Roasted Chickpeas Street). Straight ahead is the Yanbol Synagogue, named for a town in Bulgaria. Continuing deeper into Balat takes you to the Ahrida Synagogue, with its restored wooden interior dome.

Ford Motor and General Motors announced on Monday that they would jointly develop new transmissions with 9 speeds for front-wheel-drive vehicles and 10 speeds for rear-drive cars and trucks. The new transmissions, with more forward gear ratios than either company now offers, are expected to reach the market beginning in 2016. 
 
The transmissions are considered vital components of the companies’ efforts to meet upcoming standards for fuel efficiency and carbon dioxide emissions in the United States and Europe. The transmissions will “drive fuel economy improvements into both company’s future product portfolios,” said Jim Lanzon, G.M.’s vice president of global transmission engineering.

In the 2004 film “Before Sunset,” Jesse, an American (Ethan Hawke), and Celine, a Frenchwoman (Julie Delpy), spend an afternoon traversing Paris as they flirt with love. At one point they ascend a staircase to an elevated park called the Promenade Plantée.
 
The 2.8-mile-long parkway, inaugurated in 1993, follows the abandoned Vincennes railway line; it was the inspiration for New York City’s High Line. In the film, Mr. Hawke and Ms. Delpy use the staircase midway along the promenade. I prefer to start at the staircase entrance at the promenade’s western end, which rises from the Viaduc des Arts, the red-brick arches filled with boutiques and galleries.

WARSHAW--Robert S. The Brain & Behavior Research Foundation, formerly the National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression (NARSAD), mourns the passing of our long term member of the Board of Directors. Bob Warshaw provided support and guidance in our program to enhance the lives of people suffering from mental illness through research. He was honored with our 2010 Visionary Philanthropist Award, especially for his work with the Hofmann Trust. His leadership role went beyond offering his skills as a lawyer to his articulate reviews of our staff and structure. He will be missed as a vital force for our mission. Jeffrey Borenstein, M.D., President Constance E. Lieber, President Emerita Stephen A. Lieber, Chairman, Board of Directors

WARSHAW--Robert. The Directors and staff of Ameringer l McEnery l Yohe mourn the loss of their colleague Robert Warshaw. Robert was a trusted friend and wise advisor whose presence will be deeply missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Elaine and to the entire Warshaw family.

WEINER--Bernard P.,of Walnut Creek, CA, passed on April 16 at age 90. One of the original "Mad Men" working on Madison Avenue for 20 years, Bernie "Red" Weiner was then President and CEO of Miller Automatic in Monticello, NY for 35 years. He is survived by son Ken (Kathy); daughter Amy (Debi), and grandson Josh (Lily).

WEINSTEIN--William, 84, formerly of Ridgewood, NJ on April 6, 2013. Founder of services for disabled children. CLU for New York Life for 55 years. Ever the optimist, lover of poetry and sport and wilderness, celebrant of life. So devoted to family. Memorials to www.thearc.org.
