STONE--Robert G.,Jr. In loving memory of dear Bob. You are always in our hearts. Love always, Nancy

SIEGEL--Samuel R. July 31, 1909 - April 21, 2012 Dr. Siegel had a lifelong commitment to civil rights and social justice. He cared deeply about people both those close to him as well as the disenfranchised, and he made every effort to create a more humane world. Dr. Siegel graduated from the Tufts University School of Dental Medicine in 1933, and started his practice in dentistry moving into the field of orthodontics. He pioneered the practice of early childhood intervention, and published two papers in the New York State Dental Journal in 1956 and '59 on his approach. In World War II, Dr. Siegel served as a Captain with the 58th Air Service Group, 5th Air Force from 1943 -l946 with combat service in the Asiatic Pacific Campaign in New Guinea and the Philippines. He was a cofounder of the local branch of The Medical Committee for Human Rights, and went south during the Civil Rights struggle in the 1960s. He and his son, Larry, a Freedom Rider who predeceased him, worked at the same time in the south although in different states: Larry worked on voter registration and Dr Siegel tended to the injured. Upon retiring from private practice in 1968, Dr. Siegel worked for the next 18 years as an Assistant Clinical Professor in the Pediatric Dentistry Department at New York University School of Dentistry teaching graduate students in the preventive aspects of early treatment in developing malocclusions. In 1975, Dr. Siegel was invited to Cuba to lecture on early childhood intervention and to visit the Havana School of Stomatology, dental clinics, and training schools throughout the country. His article on his visit was published in Dental Survey: The Journal of Dental Practice in 1975. In 1982 when he was 72, Dr. Siegel was arrested for his act of civil disobedience, joining an antinuclear demonstration in front of the United States Mission to the U.N. He is quoted in the Times of June 15th as saying: "This is my first time for me but I feel that I have to do this for my grandchildren." He treated thousands of patients before his retirement, and arranged a sliding scale of payment or no payment for those with hardships. Dr. Siegel was also an orthodontic consultant to several unions including Local 1199. Throughout his life, Dr. Siegel was a devotee of physical exercise and athletics. He tried out for professional baseball as a very young man, played a fierce game of tennis, liked golf, and bicycled all over New York City until well into his 80s. Four years ago he moved with his wife, Beatrice who also predeceased him, from New York to Maryland to be near his stepdaughter and son-in-law. He never missed his twice -weekly poker games. He is survived by his stepdaughter, Andra; his son-in-law, Jon; his son, Michael; his granddaughter, Julia and her husband Christophe; his granddaughter, Sumi and her husband Max, and his great-granddaughters, Willa and Zoey.

REINBERG--Rhoda (nee Glassel), 82. Wife of Louis, mother of Lisa and David, sister of Morton, grandmother of Benjamin, Leora and Shira. She will be remembered for her caring and generous spirit, her optimism, sense of humor, curiosity, fortitude, and the things she did to make the world a kinder place.

PHILLIPS--Gifford. The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art is saddened to learn of the passing of our distinguished member Gifford Phillips. A member since 1961, he was a true advocate of the role of modern art in transcending national barriers. Among his many key associations with the Council and The Museum of Modern Art was his chairmanship of the Council's Program Committee, which he led with great intelligence and energy. He and his wife Joann travelled widely with the International Council, making friends throughout the world. Our most sincere condolences are expressed to Gifford's wife Joann Phillips; his children James, Alice Swistel, and Marjorie Elliott; and eight grandchildren. Duke Franz von Bayern, Brian Urquhart, Chairs Emeriti Agnes Gund, Chair Jo Carole Lauder, Jeanne C. Thayer, Presidents Emerita Sharon Percy Rockefeller, President Lewis B. Cullman, Beatrix Medinger, Vice Chairs William L. Bernhard, Secretary The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

PHILLIPS--Gifford. After a long and delightful life, we say goodbye to Gifford Phillips, who died April 17, in Palm Desert California, where he was wintering with his wife of 60 years, Joann Phillips. Gifford was an active force for good and equality. Gifford was born June 30 1918 in Chevy Chase, Maryland, the son of James Laughlin Phillips and Alice Conyngham Gifford. His father died suddenly from influenza just four months after his only child's birth. Alice Phillips subsequently remarried to Charles Alfred Johnson. Gifford was raised with his younger brother, Charles Johnson, in Charlford Castle, a residence south of Denver. Phillips attended Stanford University but transferred to Yale University, from which he graduated in 1942. Pursuing a life long activism, Gifford founded Frontier magazine, a liberal West Coast political monthly, with editor Phil Kerby in 1949 after moving to Los Angeles. In 1954, Frontier published its blacklist expose, "The Hollywood Story" by Elizabeth Poe Kerby. The expose's appearance signaled the passing of the "red scare" era. Phillips published the magazine until 1966 when it was folded into The Nation magazine. Phillips served as Associate Publisher of that magazine from 1966 to 1970. He married Joann Kocher in 1953 after they met at a Democratic Party function. His deep involvement in California politics had started with being Treasurer for Helen Gahagan Douglas' congressional campaign against Richard Nixon in 1948. Phillips would serve as a delegate from California to Democratic National Conventions in 1952, 1956, 1960, and 1964. He was an early supporter of Eugene McCarthy in 1968, co-chairing McCarthy's California campaign with future governor Jerry Brown. Phillips was an ardent supporter of George McGovern's presidential campaign, which eventually earned him a place on President Richard Nixon's 1972 'enemies list', much to Gifford's delight. From the 1950s, he was a partner in Pardee Phillips, a real estate corporation that built houses and shopping malls in Southern California and Nevada. However, art and politics were to always remain at the forefront of his interests. Gifford and Joann became great friends and supporters of southern California artists including Richard Diebenkorn, Emerson Woelffer, Lee Mullican and Claire Falkenstien. As one of Diebenkorn's earliest patrons, Gifford introduced Diebenkorn's figurative paintings to his uncle, Duncan Phillips, head of the Phillips Collection in Washington DC. Gifford also commended his uncle to the work of Mark Rothko leading to the acquisitions that form the celebrated Rothko Room at the museum. Phillips was founding chairman of the Contemporary Art Council at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (LACMA) in 1961. He joined the Board of Trustees of the Museum of Modern Art in New York in 1966 where he served for four decades including eight years as Chair of the Painting and Sculpture Committee. Gifford served on the Phillips Collection Board for over 30 years. Gifford was a member of the Board of Governors of the Yale University Art Museum from 1985 to 1999. He was also a member of the Mark Rothko foundation when that group resolved the complicated and protracted legal battle over that artist's estate. He was a Trustee and President of the Pasadena Art Museum from 1970 to 1974, a period during which that institution would become the Norton Simon museum and serve as the setting for a landmark case on the rights of museum donors. In 1987, Joann and Gifford moved permanently to Santa Fe, New Mexico, where as summer residents they had been involved in local arts efforts since 1968. He chaired the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival for several years. He and Joann with wise counsel from Ohkay Owingeh elder and scholar, Alfonso Ortiz, and writer and scholar, Edward T. Hall founded the Chamiza Foundation in 1989 to support and stimulate Pueblo culture. Recognized by a resolution in the New Mexico House of Representatives for its work in 2009, the foundation is nationally renowned for its innovative grant support guided by a board with a majority of Pueblo members. In this and so many other efforts, Gifford touched many people, leaving us all much happier for having known him. Besides his wife, Phillips is survived by his son, James, of La Quinta, California, daughters, Alice Swistel of New York City, and Marjorie Elliott of Princeton, New Jersey, and eight grandchildren, Claire Elliott, Rosalind Elliott, Gifford Elliott, Sophia Phillips, Jackson Phillips, Lily Swistel, Nina Swistel, and Zazu Swistel.

PHILLIPS--Gifford. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the death of longtime Trustee Gifford Phillips. Gifford joined the Board of Trustees in 1966 and served on a myriad of committees over his four decade association with the Museum. He served first as Vice-Chair, then as Chair of the Painting & Sculpture Committee (1977-1989), and served on the Executive, Building and Exhibitions Committees. Additionally, Gifford was a member of the International Council since 1961. Together with his wife, Joann, Gifford was not only a generous philanthropist, but an active and passionate collector of art. Over this extraordinary period Gifford also helped build MoMA's collection by giving important works of art to the Museum such as Richard Diebenkorn's "Berkeley, 46", Willem de Kooning's "Valentine" and Ad Reinhardt's "Abstract Painting, Red". We send our condolences to his wife, Joann, their son James and daughters Marjorie Elliot and Alice Swistel. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

SHERMAN--A. Joshua. Foundation trustee, consultant and author, died on Saturday, April 6, 2013. He was 78 years old. Mr. Sherman was born in Jerusalem in 1934, came to the US as a child, and was educated in New York City public schools, the Jewish Theological Seminary College of Jewish Studies, and Columbia College, from which he graduated with honors in 1954. After graduating from Harvard Law School in 1957, and completing service in the U.S. Army, he was employed in New York and London by Kuhn, Loeb & Co., investment bankers, of which he was appointed a Vice President in 1964. He left the firm in 1967, joining St. Antony's College, Oxford, where he completed a doctorate in history in 1970, and continued as Research Fellow and tutor in politics and history, until his return in 1974 to New York. From 1975 to 1978, he was Executive Director of the Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture, and subsequently was for two years Executive Director of the C.G. Jung Foundation for Analytical Psychology. From 1983 to 1985, he was Visiting Lecturer in history and Assoc. Fellow of Davenport College, Yale University, and from 1984 to 1985, served as Chaplain Intern in the clinical pastoral education program at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York. After receiving his M.S.W. from Yeshiva University in 1987, he was active in clinical settings including the Prog. for Humanistic Medicine of NYU Medical School at Bellevue Hospital; GMHC, where he worked with groups of AIDS patients and their caregivers; and the Psychiatric Inst. at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Upon moving to Vermont in 1994, Mr. Sherman was appointed Visiting Assistant Professor at Middlebury College, teaching courses in European history, civil society, and philanthropy. For several years he was a volunteer clinician with the Counseling Service of Addison County, and subsequently volunteered at Elderly Services in Middlebury. Mr. Sherman was a trustee of several trusts and foundations, including the Cricket Foundation of Boston, and consultant on philanthropy to a number of families. For many years he was a Director of Thames & Hudson, Inc., publishers. Among his published books are, "Mandate Days: British Lives in Palestine, 1918-1948;" "Island Refuge: Britain and Refugees from the Third Reich, 1933-1939;" "M.M. Warburg & Co., 1798-1938;" "The Raven of Zuerich, the Memoirs of Felix Somary;" and three pseudonymous thrillers about international banking, published in London, New York and Paris. A frequent contributor of reviews to the TLS, London, he also published reviews and essays in the New England Review, The New York Times, and The Sun, Baltimore. He was a keen amateur violinist, regularly played chamber music, and also enjoyed gardening. With wide-ranging interests and fluent in several languages, Mr. Sherman enjoyed good talk, often lightened with humor. He was at home in many settings, but remained loyal to his origins, and to friends of all ages and backgrounds. Though he moved to Vermont only in his 60th year, he took particular pleasure in the welcome he and his partner found there. Survivors include his beloved life-mate of 28 years, Jorge Martin, whom he married in 2008; his sister, Varda Lev of Providence, R.I.; three nieces; two grandnieces and a grandnephew; and an international circle of friends.

RIDDER--Jane Delano, of Ocean Ridge, FL and San Mateo, CA died April 10th at the age of 94 after a short illness. She was at home surrounded by her five loving children. Jane raised all of her children in Duluth MN and St. Paul MN and looked back on those years with great affection. Jane attended The Brearley School in NYC and Greenwood School in Baltimore. She was raised in NYC and at the family residence, Steen Valetje on the Hudson River near Rhinebeck, NY. Her father, Lyman Delano was Franklin Delano Roosevelt's first cousin. She was predeceased in 2002 by her husband of 63 years, Bernard H. Ridder Jr. He was CEO of Ridder Publications at the time of their merger with Knight newspapers in 1974. Her greatest pleasure was spent being with her family of four generations. She is survived by her children Robin Ridder of Healdsburg, CA, Tony Ridder of Pebble Beach, CA, Jill Ridder of Healdsburg, CA, Peter Ridder (Cathy) of Long Beach, CA and Laura Evans (Ned) of Ocean Ridge, FL and Grosse Pointe, MI, nine grandchildren and 23 great grandchildren all of whom looked to her for guidance and support. There has been a private memorial gathering. Contributions may be made to the charity of one's choice.
KRAMER--Morris J. A great friend, we will always miss you and always love you. David and Doreen Hurwitz

O'ROURKE--Mary E.,68, of Manhattan, formerly of Scituate MA, passed away on April 12, after a short illness. Mary is survived by two children, Jennifer O'Connor-Parmelee and her husband Craig Parmelee of Eastchester, NY; Ted O'Connor and his partner Mary Amanda Reinauer of Washington DC; and two grandchildren, Maeve Parmelee and Matthew Parmelee. A private memorial service will be held in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations to honor Mary can be made in her name to City Harvest, the ACLU and SPLC.

PERLMUTTER--Walter Marc, died on Thursday, April 12th in Highland Park, Illinois. He was 86 years old. Walter was born to Grace and Arthur Perlmutter of Long Beach, New York on October 26, 1926, and is survived by his brother David Perlmutter, his three children, Amy Frankel, Nell Kisiel and Andrew Perlmutter and his three grandchildren, Grace, Arthur, and Jane Frankel. Walter served in the US Navy during WWII. He graduated from Utica College and enjoyed a long and successful career in the toy business. In his retirement, Walter returned to his long time loves of boating and journalism. Memorial donations can be directed to the Grace and Arthur Perlmutter Scholarship Fund (Utica College Office of Advancement, 1600 Burrstone Road, Utica, NY 13502.)

KUPCHAN--Beverly (Meister), 88, wife of the late Dr. Jerome Kupchan, of Yonkers, N.Y., died Tuesday, March 26, 2013. Donations may be made to the Beverly and Jerome Kupchan Fund at LPJC, 311 Central Park Ave, Yonkers, NY 10704.

MONTGOMERY--Robert Langford Jr.,85, died at his home in Newport Beach, CA on February 26, 2013 after a long illness. Raised in Connecticut, he graduated from St. Paul's School and served in the Navy during World War II. He graduated magna cum laude from Harvard College in 1950, and after a Fulbright Fellowship in France, returned to Harvard where he received his PhD in 1956. He then taught at the University of Texas at Austin, and at Williams College, before joining the University of California Irvine, two years after its founding, as a professor of English and comparative literature. He retired in 1994. He leaves his wife of almost 62 years, Margaret (Peggy) Kimball, a daughter Alexandra, two sons, Robert III and Carleton, four grandchildren and his sister, Diane Ferris. Memorial gifts in his name may be made to the Pinelands Preservation Alliance, 17 Pemberton Rd, Southampton NJ 08088; or to Harvard Graduate Student Support Fund for the English Department Attn: Neida Jimenez, 124 Mt. Auburn Street, 4th floor, Cambridge MA 02138.

LEINFUSS--Paul, 91, passed peacefully on April 19 at home. Survived by his beloved wife of 63 years, Adele, devoted daughters Ellen and Emily, son-in-law Myles, and grandchildren Ian and Ben. His wit and charm will be sorely missed.

NIELSON--Rev. Msgr. Thomas A.,Jr., 80, of Whiting, NJ, passed away Thursday, April 18, 2013 at home. He was born and raised in New York City, NY. He moved to Whiting in 2003. Msgr. Nielson was ordained a priest on May 30, 1959. He served as parochial vicar and Master of Ceremonies at St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York City, NY for 29 years, retiring in 2003. He also served as parochial vicar of St. Joseph's, Greenwich Village, 1959-1967; Sacred Heart, Staten Island, 1967-1969; Our Lady of Good Counsel, Manhattan, 1969-1974. From 1974 to 1976, Msgr. Nielson served as Spiritual Director of the Legion of Mary, Archdiocese of New York. He served as Chaplain for St. Ansgar's Scandinavian Catholic League and was a 4th Degree member of the Knights of Columbus, New York City. He is survived by one sister, Joan Locasio of New Bern, NC; one niece; one nephew and his dear friend, Eileen Callaghan of Whiting. Msgr. Nielson will lie in repose from 2 to 6pm, Monday, April 22nd and from 9am to 10:30am, Tuesday, April 23rd at St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Church, 30 Schoolhouse Road, Whiting, NJ. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at 10:45am, Tuesday at St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Church. Interment will follow at St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Services are under the direction of Manchester Memorial Funeral Home, Whiting, NJ. For information, visit us at: manchestermemorial.net

LYNCH--Dennis, formerly of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, died on Friday, April 12 with his family by his side after battling cancer. Dennis is predeceased by his sister Mary Ann Coyle and survived by his brothers Eddie and John and brother-in-law Ed Coyle. He was the loving uncle of Edward Lynch, Kelley Lynch, Jimmy Lynch, Mary Ann Kearns, Jeannine Bardo, Edward Coyle, Catherine Moran and 12 grandnieces and grandnephews. Dennis' love for the arts, theatre and music continued throughout his life. He was a long-standing member of The Heights Players and was a strong believer in the arts as a positive force in the community. In this spirit donations may be made in Dennis' name to The Heights Players, 26 Willow Place, Brooklyn, NY 11201. There will be no services at the request of the deceased. Condolences may be sent to John Lynch, 80 N. Moore Street, Apt 25-G, New York, New York, 10013.

MALLORY--Pauline. The Mystic Seaport Board of Trustees, staff, and community mourn the loss of Pauline Mallory, longtime friend and benefactor, and widow of the late Clifford D. Mallory, Jr. Like no others, the Mallory family have been the core of Mystic Seaport from its beginning, and the legacy continues through the extended Mallory family. Pauline, a true gentlewoman. Our heartfelt condolences to the family.

MILLARD--Anne Lalor, age 78, died peacefully at home after a brief illness. She leaves her husband of 51 years, Peter deFlorez Millard, their four children, Richard, Hugh, Peter (Katrina) and Minnie (Brewster Carroll) and five grandchildren. Anne was warm, loving, smart and amazing with people. She gave and got a lot of love. Funeral private. Memorial Service at St Jean Baptiste - Lexington and 76th - Tuesday May 28 at 4:00pm. Memorial donations may be given to Friends of the Upper East Side Historic Districts and/or Park Avenue Armory.

MCCAUSLAND--Robert G.,passed April 13. Loving husband to Marilyn; his daughter, two sons, two step-daughters and six grandchildren. Born in Philadelphia's main line in 1928; graduated Gettysburg College, Naval Intelligence School and flew USN as a naval aviator. 35+ years in Financial services IT (NY and Bermuda). He excelled in tennis, paddle and golf and will be remembered always with great love.

KRAMER--Morris J. A true New Yorker, eminent attorney, and loving father and grandfather passed away on April 19th, at the age of 71. Morris grew up in Bay Ridge, and went on to Dartmouth College and Harvard Law. A 40-year partner of Skadden, Arps, Morris was an international leader in mergers and acquisitions, working on many famous deals. He divided the late '80s between London and New York, and spent months in Berlin at the Treuhandanstalt in the newly unified German government. A longtime resident of Carnegie Hill, Morris read the complete works of Anthony Trollope and watched every New York sports game. He is survived by his two sons, Jeremy and Oliver, daughter-in-law Kaye, grandchildren Maxime, Jules, and Oscar, brother Stephen, and his second former-wife Nancy who went to every doctor's appointment. His intellect, humor, and generosity will be missed by all. Funeral Service: April 21, 1:15pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Memorial gifts in his name may be made to: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Attn: Hugh B. Kelly. 633 Third Avenue, 28th Fl. New York, NY 10017.

KRAMER--Morris J.,On April 18, 2013. With great sadness, the partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the loss of our partner Morris Kramer, a cornerstone of the firm's M&A practice for more than 40 years. He was 71. Mr. Kramer joined Skadden in 1972. Working closely with Joe Flom, he was a principal player in the development of the modern takeover era. He helped the firm capture a large share of this new market, working on many of our defining takeovers. A strong advocate for the globalization of Skadden's practice, Mr. Kramer helped launch the firm's London office. A brilliant tactician, Mr. Kramer was known for his incisiveness. Over his four-plus decades at Skadden, he represented clients such as Allied Signal, Inc., ALLTEL Corporation, American General Corporation, Norfolk Southern Corporation, Prudential plc and XM Satellite Radio Holdings Inc. He advised many investment banks in the development of their M&A practices, including most notably First Boston (now Credit Suisse). Mr. Kramer grew up in Brooklyn and attended Dartmouth College ('63) and Harvard Law School ('66). He also served on the board of American General. Mr. Kramer is survived by his sons, Jeremy and Oliver; daughter-in-law, Kaye; and grandchildren, Jules, Maxime and Oscar. We extend our deep condolences to Morris's family.
MITTENTHAL--Donna, 63, of Atlanta, died April 11, 2013. She was the wife of Dr. Mark J. Mittenthal and is also survived by three children and four grandchildren. Services were held in Atlanta.

ISELIN--Herbert M.,February 21, 1921--April 8, 2013, of Pound Ridge, NY. Survived by his wife of 57 years, Lily (nee Gantz); daughters Julie (Tony) Turjoman, Diane, and Jenny; and grandchildren Rachel, Tess, and Moses. Graduate of Brown University and Columbia Law School. Always in our hearts.

HARBOUR--Gail S.,of Sandy Springs, passed away March 28th at the age of 62. She was her own most demanding taskmaster. First she took honors at Simmons College; then, at Columbia Law School, where she was Articles Editor of the Columbia Law Review; then she was one of the first female corporate associates at the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore in New York. Later she served for over 16 years as permanent law clerk for the Honorable J. L. Edmondson of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. In between she raised two children, with cheer and stops for ice cream on Monday afternoons. Her great pleasures were, in no particular order, live theater; her devotedly irascible dogs, Pumpkin and Peanut; betting the pass line at the craps table at the Harrah's Lake Tahoe; Simon & Garfunkel; marzipan; a good argument; a glass of white wine at Sunday brunch; and finding a bargain. She is survived by her best friend and husband of 36 years, Steven E. Harbour of Sandy Springs; her daughter and son-in-law, Jessica and Mike Doyle, and her granddaughters, Sheena and Janet Doyle, all of Dunwoody; her son and future daughter-in-law, Michael Harbour of Cambridge, Mass., and Stephanie Northen of Los Angeles; her brother and sister-in-law, Steven Gutstein and Kitty Brown of New York City; and her mother, Vita Gutstein of Boca Raton, Florida. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the American Kidney Fund, or treating yourself to a few Thin Mints and a glass of milk. Arrangements by Dressler's Jewish Funeral Care, Atlanta (770) 451-4999

JOSEPH--Leepee, 96, a left-wing activist and longtime theatrical assistant, died of lung cancer on April 2nd in her Greenwich Village apartment. The youngest of four sisters in a deeply radical family, she was first arrested for picketing at age 12. She worked as a secretary for the theater section of the WPA, The Group Theater, the publicist Ben Washer, theatrical producers Cheryl Crawford and Irene Selznick, and performers Perry Como and Mary Martin. In 1940, Ms. Joseph married songwriter and lyricist Arthur Herzog, Jr. (God Bless' The Child). They divorced in 1953. In 1961 she married J. J. Joseph, who had been blacklisted. With Mr. Joseph she traveled to Cuba to help deliver humanitarian supplies. Ms. Joseph later volunteered for Congresswoman Bella Abzug. Through her 90s, Ms. Joseph could be found leafleting in Union Square. Recently, she became known to theater audiences through the plays "After The Revolution" and "4000 Miles", written by her granddaughter, Amy Herzog. Her frank talk stood out in more guarded times. Ms. Joseph is survived by her sister Jessie Smith, her son Gregory Herzog, her step children Paul, Andrei, and Anne Joseph, their spouses Elaine Herzog, Linda Schiffman, Pam Rogers, and Phil McGlave, her nephew Russell Smith, her nieces Shirley Kirsten, Susan and Ilse Mende, and Jane Fire. A memorial will be held 4:00pm, May 26 at the Judson Memorial Church, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations to jeffersonmarketgarden.org, The Rosenberg Fund for Children (rfc.org/) or peace-action.org suggested.

GOLDBLATT--Dr. Larry S. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our member, Dr. Larry S. Goldblatt. We will miss his integrity and courage, his devotion to family, friends and community. Our deepest condolences are extended to his beloved wife, Betty, their children Laura and Brian, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, DD, Senior Rabbi Karen L. Berman, President
GOODWIN--Stewart, on April 16, 2013. Loving brother of Rhona and the late Howard. Graveside services will take place on Tuesday, April 23, 11am, at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

HORVATH--Karen R. of Reston, VA passed away peacefully on April 14 after a valiant battle with cancer. Surrounded by her loving family, she accepted her fate with great dignity and inner peace. Karen was born on April 6, 1940 to the late Charlotte and Raphael Rosenberg of Teaneck, NJ. She attended Teaneck High School, earned an English degree from University of Wisconsin, did graduate work in broadcast journalism at Indiana University (IU) and worked as a writer for the forerunner of the Public Broadcasting System. At IU, Karen met her husband and soul mate, Jules, and married in 1971. Karen retired from the U.S. Government's Foreign Broadcast Information Service in 2007 after a career as an intelligence analyst, writer/editor and training officer. She worked and traveled with her family extensively in Asia, Africa and Europe. Aside from her love of travel and great sense of adventure, Karen was an amazing and creative gourmet cook who greatly enjoyed entertaining her wide circle of international friends. She was an avid reader of English literature who introduced her children to all manner of cultural delights, including theater and fine arts. A devoted wife and loving mother, Karen was the core and heart of her family. She was most generous with her time and attention in helping others, adding style and grace to all things she touched. Her joie de vivre, cheerful vitality, sense of humor and subtle elegance will be deeply missed. She is survived by her beloved husband and best friend, Jules; loving sons Jonathan of Washington, D.C. and Adam and his wife, Chia, and grandchildren Julia Jane and "Smiley" Wiley of Chevy Chase, MD. She is also survived by dearest sister Susan Martins and her son; and the families of Joan Farber Topkis, Leila Rosenberg; numerous cousins; sister-in-law Kriszta Van Arsdale and brother-in-law Attila Horvath and their families. An interfaith service celebrating Karen's life will be held at 11am, May 4, 2013 in the Chevy Chase Presbyterian Church (1 Chevy Chase Circle, NW, Washington, DC 20015). Inurnment will be at a later date in The Columbarium, Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donation may be sent to support WETA Public Television & Radio (www.weta.org) in memory of Karen Horvath.

GUTMAN--Peter, 91 of Great Neck, New York passed away peacefully in his home on April 18. He was happily married to his beloved Eva Loewenthal for 61 years. Devoted father to Ronny and Warren; father-in-law to Ellen Heuman. Adoring grandfather to Spencer and Drew. Forever bonded to his twin brother Kurt.

HODAS--Sheila (Glantz). Beloved mother and mother-in-law, grandmother, sister, aunt and great-aunt died April 11 after a long illness. A retired social worker, she was a lifelong lover of words and wordplay, puns and puzzles. Klal Yisroel has lost a great lover. A private service was held. Donations to https://philanthropy. mountsinai.org/visitingdoctors

HABER--Herbert. The partners, principals and staff of Marks Paneth & Shron LLP mourn the passing of Herbert M. Haber, a Founding Partner of Paneth, Haber & Zimmerman LLP, a predecessor of today's firm. Mr. Haber was widely recognized as a leader in the industry and was well regarded, and will be fondly remembered, by his partners, colleagues and friends. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Haber family.

HARRIS BAYNE--Eulalie G. The Board of Directors and staff of Henry Street Settlement mourn the death of Eulalie Harris Bayne who, in her 33 years on the Board of the Settlement, served as a quiet force and a tireless advocate for youth programs, homeless services, and the arts. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family.

JARDINE--Evangeline Vassiliades On Thursday, April 11, 2013 at Kline Hospice House, Mt. Airy, MD. Eve was 70 years young. An ESL teacher before Parkinson's disease forced retirement, Eve graduated from Vassar and earned her PhD from NYU in Musicology. She spoke, read and wrote English, Greek, Russian and Spanish! Born and raised in Washington, D.C., Eve was a world traveler and lived in Russia, Greece and Peru. Her students and their parents loved her because of her patience and empathy. She loved classical music, reading and Scrabble. Recently living in Frederick, MD, Eve was an overachiever, loving mother and wonderful wife. She is survived by her husband, Cyril Jardine; son, Nikos Montesatos, and mother, Mary Freeman. Her father, George Panos Vassiliades passed in 1984. No funeral or viewing. A Celebration of her life is being planned. To contribute funny stories or mementos to Eve's Celebration, contact Cyril Jardine at 301-662-1217. cjardine77@verizon.net

DAY--John William, 80, passed away on April 20, 2013, New York City, with his wife, Barbara Cline, at his side. They met at Northwestern University in 1952 and were married upon graduation in 1955. John was NROTC and was commissioned in the Marine Corps, where he served two years in Quantico, VA, and Cherry Point, NC. Upon discharge in 1957 he joined Chrysler Corporation and was part of the Missile Division, which took him and his family to Italy and Turkey. He then joined Chrysler International and he and his family lived in eight countries in Latin America and Europe. He retired from Chrysler as an Executive Vice President in 1984. He then joined Bendix/Allied Signal, and retired from there in 1993. In addition to his wife, he is survived by daughter Karen Day and her son Patrick Day Tine; daughter Lisa Day and her husband Tony Roberts and their daughters, Hannah, Rachel and Philippa; and his sisters Vicki Kozlowski and Debby Vandiver. Memorial service 11:00am Saturday, April 27, St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, New York City.

FIELD--Frank Henry, Was born on February 22, 1922, in Keansburg, NJ, the son of Frank Aretus Field and Mary Louise Fleischmann. His father died soon after his birth and he was raised by his mother until her death in 1933 and then by his aunt, Anna Fleischmann, in Cliffside Park, NJ. He attended Duke University, graduating in 1948 with a PhD in Chemistry. After five years of teaching at the University of Texas he joined the Humble Oil and Refining Co, at their research laboratory in Baytown, TX, and embarked on a distinguished career in mass spectrometry. He is the author of 175 scientific papers, the co-author of an important book in his specialty and the recipient of awards from the American Chemical Society, the American Society for Mass Spectrometry and other professional societies. In 1970 he was invited to form a laboratory at The Rockefeller University from which he retired in 1989 as Camille and Henry Dreyfus Professor. After retirement he and his wife moved to Oak Ridge, TN, where he took flying lessons, played tennis and spurred the construction of a new building for the Unitarian-Universalist Church. In 2005 the couple moved to The Forest at Duke, a retirement community in Durham, NC, where he died on April 12, 2013 at the age of 91. Throughout his life he delighted in music, playing the violin as an amateur in chamber ensembles and orchestras and in fine wine and good company. He is survived by his wife, the former Carolyn Bryan of Houston, TX; by two sons, Jonathan and Christopher; three step-daughters, one grandson and several step-grandchildren. A memorial service will take place later at The Forest at Duke.

ESTILL--Fedra S.,1912-2013. For my mother who died on Saturday, April 13th, at 100, 4 months, 26 days old. Her radiant smile and beauty graced everyone with love. She was the most fabulous mother and my best friend. Every moment her heart, her spirit, her soul are with me. Loved and missed for an eternity. Dobie
GOLDBLATT--Dr. Larry, died April 17. Our dear friend for over thirty years. You will be missed. Diana and David

GOLDBLATT--Larry Stewart, MD, devoted husband, loving father, adoring grandfather, and dedicated psychiatrist, passed away Wednesday April 17, 2013 after a long battle with cancer. He is survived by his wife of 37 years, Betty; son Brian; daughter Laura; son-in-law Caleb Clark; grandson Shaw Clark; sister Joni Krieg, and niece Nicole Pique. Dr. Goldblatt brought passion to all his endeavors, from cattle farming to a genealogical search taking him around the globe. His devotion to his family was matched only by his commitment to his patients. Funeral at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., at Amsterdam, on Tuesday, April 23 at 1:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donate to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, New York.

GEARHART--Golda Wood, 97, died on January 19, 2013. We fondly remember her on her birthday. Golda was born in La Jose, PA to Harold and Mary Wood. She attended the University of Pittsburgh and graduated cum laude from Thiel College with a B.S. in biology. Golda married Dr. Robert P. Gearhart in 1940 and moved to NYC in 1943, where Dr. Gearhart had a private practice and was an attending physician at Lenox Hill Hospital for 45 years. Dr. Gearhart died on December 27, 2000, at 88. We are best defined in life by the people and things that we love. Golda and Bob were together for 60 years, living in Forest Hills. Sophisticated New Yorkers on the one hand, they spent weekends at their rustic house on the Delaware River, watching birds and searching for wildflowers. With a vibrant and sharp mind, Golda was an avid reader of books, The New York Times and The New Yorker--to name a few. She often recited snippets of poetry. She was stylish, had an eye for antiques and studied painting. Her interests and enthusiasm enriched the lives of her family and those around her. Golda and Bob are survived by their daughter Susan Olshinski of NC, son Robert P. Gearhart, Jr. of CO, son Reid H. Gearhart and his wife Tiziana Mohorovic of NY, three grandchildren and five great grandchildren.

DeVITO di PORRIASA--Ilona, on April 15, 2013, born Countess Teleki de Szek on April 23, 1939 in Zsibo, Transylvania. Predeceased by her husband Marchese Lino DeVito di Porriasa. Loving mother to Elisa and grandmother to Anna Elena. An extraordinary woman cherished by family and friends. Memorial mass to be held at St. Stephen of Hungary in New York City on April 26 at 11am. In lieu of flowers please make a donation to the Central Park Conservancy or the American Cancer Society.

GALLAGHER--Charles "Chick" E.,88, died on April 14, in his home in Cold Spring, NY. He is survived by his wife Stephanie of 46 years, son Blakeney Gallagher and daughter-in-law Catherine Eddy Gallagher of The Plains, VA, daughter Margaret Winston (Megan) Gallagher of The Plains and son John Peter Gallagher of Manitou Springs, CO. Mr. Gallagher was predeceased by his eldest son, Charles Edward Gallagher, Jr. A memorial service is planned Saturday, April 27 at 3pm at The Episcopal Church of St. Mary-in-the-Highlands, 1 Chestnut Street, Cold Spring, NY, with reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested contributions to the Genitourinary Oncology Research Fund at Weill Cornell Medical College, in care of Dr. David Nanus, 1305 York Avenue, Box 403, New York, N.Y. 10021 or The Episcopal Church of St. Mary-in-the-Highlands, 1 Chestnut Street, Cold Spring, NY 10516.

DePAOLA--Dominick P.,DDS, PhD. It is with profound sadness that the faculty, students, and staff of the New York University College of Dentistry record the passing of one of its most distinguished, respected, and beloved alumni, Dr. Dominick P. DePaola, Class of 1969. Dr. DePaola served most recently as academic dean of Nova Southeastern University College of Dental Medicine. He served previously as president and CEO of The Forsyth Institute in Boston. Dr. DePaola was the first person to serve as president of both the American Dental Education Association (ADEA) and the American Association for Dental Research (AADR). Earlier in his career he served as dean of three of our nation's dental schools, dean of a graduate school of biomedical sciences, and president of two academic campuses. Dr. DePaola was widely regarded as a visionary leader in health professions education and was a frequent consultant to non-profit boards, the academic community, the public sector and private industry. Beyond all of his professional accomplishments, Dom DePaola was an inspiring, captivating, and gracious person, whose kindness, warmth, and collegiality touched all who were privileged to know him. To his wife Rosemary and their entire family, we extend profound sympathy on his loss. Charles N. Bertolami, DDS, DMedSc Herman Robert Fox Dean New York University College of Dentistry

FEDER--Barbara (Robinson), formerly of New York City, age 84, passed away on April 18, 2013. Funeral services will be held 11:30am, Tuesday, April 23rd at Glendale Cemetery in Des Moines, Iowa. She was the beloved wife of the late M. Clifford Feder and was an interior designer and real estate broker in New York City for many years. Memorial contributions may be made to the Flint Public Library, 1026 E. Kearsley St., Flint, MI 48502 or to the National Council of Jewish Women, Audrey R. and Cyndee Klein Scholarship Fund, 26400 Lahser Rd., Southfield, MI 48033.
BARST--Robyn. Your grace, courage and dignity inspired us. Our lives will never be the same without you. Eternal love, Debra & Andy

BARST--Robyn, 62, of Scarsdale. Survived by her loving husband Samuel of 32 years; was the adoring mother of Nomi (David) Berenson, Lindsey (Jason) Gumer and grandson Tobias Berenson; her sister Lynn Hofstra and mother Ruth. Professor Emeritus at Columbia University, Robyn was recognized in her lifetime as the pre-eminent leader in the field of Pediatric Pulmonary Hypertension. Funeral services will be held Sunday April 21 at 1pm at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd, Scarsdale, NY. The family request, in lieu of personal gifts, contributions be made to the Robyn J Barst, Pediatric Research and Mentoring Fund for Pulmonary Hypertension at PHA, 801 Roeder Road, Suite 1000, Silver Spring, MD 20910.

AGNESE--Ruth. Our hearts are broken by the loss of Ruth Agnese who has been a part of our family for 33 years. Our deepest sympathy to her husband Tony, son John and daughter Erica and all who loved and will miss her. She started her career with Appraisers & Planners Inc. as a receptionist and became President and one of the most respected appraisers in the country. Her insight, knowledge and warmth endeared her to all who knew her. Her leadership qualities were recognized as she became President of most of the professional organizations she was involved with. She will be in our hearts forever. Jim and Leslie Levy

CONNERAT--Virginia Hopper With deepest sadness, we announce the passing of our mother, Virginia Reed Hopper Connerat, 94, on April 4, 2013, at the Margaret McLaughlin McCarrick Care Center in Somerset, NJ. Mrs. Connerat was born in Mt. Sterling, KY on November 2, 1918 to Garnette (Robinson) and Walter Owsley Hopper. She graduated in 1940 from Mt. Holyoke College in South Hadley, MA with a BA in English Composition. While her life's primary focus was providing a loving home for her husband George and their children, her charitable work enriched the communities where she lived. When she lived in Manhasset (Long Island), NY (1954-1966), her volunteer activities included translating English into Braille and working at Abilities, Inc, an organization dedicated to preparing adolescents and adults with all types of disabilities for entry into the workforce. When she lived in Essex, CT (1966-2003), she was an active member of the Essex Garden Club, taking a term as its president, the Old Lyme Art Academy, the League of Women Voters, and the Junior League of New Haven. She was an avid bridge player who brought home trophies from tournaments at the Old Lyme Country Club. Surviving Mrs. Connerat are her daughter, Robin Connerat, of Pennington, NJ, son, George, his wife Jeanne, and granddaughters Kristen and Elizabeth of New Providence, NJ. She was predeceased in 2006 by her husband of 60 years, George Hillyer Connerat. Interment will be on June 29 at the Connerat family plot in Bonaventure Cemetery in Savannah, GA. Memorial contributions are suggested to the Alzheimer's Association of NJ, 400 Morris Avenue, Denville, NJ, 07834, www.alznj.org.

CRARY--Calvert Douglas, 69, died on Saturday April 6th, 2013 in Waccabuc, New York. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, and friend, he was born in New York City on October 11, 1943. He grew up in Scarsdale, New York, attended Edgemont High School and Deerfield Academy, received a bachelor's degree from the University of Michigan, and a law degree from Northwestern Law School. Crary was the sole litigation analyst on Wall Street for many decades, producing the highly-influential newsletter "Litigation Review" and later "Litigation Notes" continuously for over 30 years. He is survived by his wife, Deborah Schmidt Crary; three children, Gretchen P. Crary, John F. Crary and Calvert H. Crary II; and six grandchildren. A private memorial service will be held at the Mead Memorial Chapel in Waccabuc. Memorial donations may be made to the Prostate Cancer Foundation.

CHAMBERLAND--Roger, 84, died November 30, 2012, and wife Evelyn Chamberland, 79, died March 21, 2013 both of Oakdale, CT. They leave two children, Susan F. Chamberland Essex, CT, Donald B. Chamberland of Jersey City, NJ, grandchildren Andrew Austin, Texas, Gabriella of Spartanburg, South Carolina. A religious service will be at St. Josephs', New London, CT April 27 at 10:00 am. Reception directly following at the Essex Yacht Club, Essex, CT
Victims of the Boston Marathon bombing were remembered Sunday at churches, makeshift shrines and a funeral home.
A view of the day in sports, from the London Marathon to the Monte Carlo Masters in Monaco.
Hollywood blockbusters, which fared well in Chinese movie theaters last year, fell on hard times in the first quarter. “Iron Man 3,” filmed partly in China, is the next test case.
“The Last Will,” directed by and starring Austin Pendleton, is Robert Brustein’s speculation on the death, and bequests, of William Shakespeare.

The European Union’s Emissions Trading System was intended to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by setting a market price on them. The system, set up in three phases, requires polluters to acquire credits to offset their emissions. A glut of credits, combined with lower demand because of the weak economy, has driven down the price to close to zero.
A Chechen family that settled in the suburbs of Boston over a decade ago is particularly disheartened to hear that the marathon bombing suspects have been linked to Chechnya.
London Marathon runners observed a moment of silence on Sunday to honor the victims of the Boston Marathon bombings.
Television highlights.
Kim Jong-un’s nuclear act fails to convince China or the U.S.
North Korea has moved two missile launchers in an indication that it is pushing ahead with preparations for a test launching, a South Korean news agency reported on Sunday.
Emirates Team New Zealand won both fleet races to take a 5-point lead over Oracle Team USA Slingsby heading into the final day of the America’s Cup World Series.
Researchers have found a nearly 100-year-old home movie of a baseball game in Georgia, a piece of film they say may represent the earliest moving images of the sport in the state.
The Mercedes driver Nico Rosberg took the pole position at the Bahrain Grand Prix, an event held amid antigovernment protests in the divided nation.
Salt Lake City marathoners paused for a moment of silence Saturday, then joined in a rousing rendition of “Sweet Caroline” to honor Boston’s bombing victims.
The bride is an actress; the groom is a playwright and teaches screen and playwriting to high school students.

The bride, the company manager for the Broadway production of “Lucky Guy,” and the groom, an actor, met in 2002 when he was in the Broadway revival of “Man of La Mancha” and she was its company manager.
The bride is a pediatrician on Long Island, and the groom is a lawyer in New York.
The bride is a media manager for an advertising agency, and the groom is a content manager for a company that writes articles for real estate Web sites and magazines.
The bride is the Sierra Club’s political director; the groom is an information technology consultant.
The groom liked a photo of the blond bride; he also liked one of her bald.
The bride and groom work in New York, she as a lawyer and he as an investment manager.
The bride is a directorat a foundation that finances documentaries on social issues; the groom is an agent for athletes, musicians and actors.
The bride researches and writes about energy, water and climate interactions; the groom helps colleges increase energy efficiency and reduce their environmental impact
A rabbi who is the spiritual leader at Colby College marries the communications associate of Keshet, a Boston-based advocacy group for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender Jews.
The bride works for an art gallery; the groom, an accounting firm.
The bride is an executive assistant; the groom is in the national touring company of “The Book of Mormon.”
The bride and groom are both residents in emergency medicine.
The executive director of Lyndhurst in Tarrytown, N.Y., is married there to an events marketer for Time Inc.
An independent executive coach and a breast-cancer surgeon marry in Seattle.
The bride designs handbags; the groom trades corporate bonds.
The bride is an associate at a Manhattan law firm; the groom is a lawyer for the New York City Administration for Children’s Services.
The bride and the groom are lawyers in New York.

Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 21
Suzann Pettersen won the L.P.G.A. Lotte Championship in Kapolei, Hawaii, beating Lizette Salas with a par on the first playoff hole after Salas’s approach shot went into the water.
Thousands of mourners gathered at a suburban Dallas church to pay tribute to the sportscaster Pat Summerall.
Winning Cause won the $200,000 Lexington Stakes at Keeneland to give the trainer Todd Pletcher another possible Kentucky Derby qualifier.
The Nets jumped out to an early lead and dominated the Bulls as their pregame party became a nightlong event.
Dax McCarty and Fabian Espindola scored in the first half to lead the Red Bulls to a 4-1 victory over the New England Revolution.
Five snowboarders died after apparently setting off a snow slide in the mountains west of Denver, bringing the nationwide toll this season to 24.
Andre Miller scored 28 points and sank a layup with 1.3 seconds left that lifted the Nuggets to a 97-95 victory over the Golden State Warriors.

John Tavares’s shootout goal gave the surging Islanders a key 
5-4 victory over Winnipeg. The Maple Leafs clinched a playoff spot for the first time since 2004.
Kenyon Martin, in his return from a sprained ankle, had a strong second half as Tyson Chandler struggled to find his rhythm in his return from a neck injury.
When he isn’t advocating for political change in Russia, Garry Kasparov is leading a campaign to include chess classes in schools around the world.
After an emotional start to the playoff series between the Knicks and the Celtics, the Madison Square Garden crowd quickly returned to hating their Boston rivals.
Winning numbers for April 20, 2013, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

It all starts here, as Hopkinton likes to say. A new cop is poised to join the Wall Street beat, as the Securities and Exchange Commission prepares to change the leadership of its enforcement unit.
 
 Mary Jo White , who took over the S.E.C. as chairwoman this month, is expected to name Andrew J. Ceresney as co-head of the commission’s enforcement arm, according to people briefed on the matter. Mr. Ceresney has served as Ms. White’s longtime lieutenant as both a corporate defense lawyer at the Debevoise & Plimpton firm and earlier in his career as a federal prosecutor in Manhattan.

The celebrity tabloids continue to pick apart Tom Cruise; moviegoers continue not to care . “Oblivion,” Mr. Cruise’s latest big-screen adventure , was a stronger-than-expected No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, with ticket sales of about $38.2 million. 
 
The PG-13 film, a dystopian science fiction thriller, has already taken in $112 million overseas, giving Mr. Cruise another global hit. “Oblivion” was expensive to make, however. Universal Pictures said it cost $120 million, but the Hollywood trade news site Deadline.com reported that the total budget may have been sharply higher.

DEAR DIARY:
 
On the first day of spring, I was walking across Central Park, nearing the West Side, in the low 80s just below the Pinetum. It was very still, with a sharp chill holding the bare tree branches fast against a pale blue sky. A woman came walking toward me on the narrow, curvy asphalt path, both of us moving briskly, minding the time. Just as we came within nodding distance, a soft fluttery call drifted faintly down from the high trees.

Dear Diary:
 
When the daffodils bloom in my neighborhood, I think of spring 2002, when suddenly daffodils appeared everywhere; it seemed the smallest bare patch of earth had a few blossoms to share.

The Brooklyn side of the first installment of TransCultural Express: American and Russian Arts Today , a three-year collaboration between the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the Mikhail Prokhorov Fund will include screenings of contemporary Russian films, a literary evening with the Russian authors Masha and Keith Gessen, and an art installation by Irina Korina, from May 31 to June 13.
 
The Russian side, which takes place mostly in Krasnoyarsk and Novosibirsk, Siberia, includes performances and outreach programs by Illstyle & Peace Productions, a hip-hop dance company based in Philadelphia, April 19-28; an appearance by the writer and humorist Ian Frazier at the Krasnoyarsk Book Fair (Oct. 31 to Nov. 4) and an exhibition by Brooklyn artists at the Krasnoyarsk Biennial, in September. The artists whose work will appear in the exhibition have not yet been named.

Performances from the BBC Proms – an eight-week explosion of daily summer concerts, mostly at the Royal Albert Hall in London – will be broadcast by WQXR , the New York classical radio station, for the first time this summer, in an arrangement made possible by the station’s membership in the European Broadcasting Union.
 
For devoted fans of the proms, which have often offered important new works as well as standard repertory in starry performances, the station’s series is likely to be frustrating. Unlike BBC Radio 3, the BBC’s classical music arm, which broadcasts all 92 of this year’s concerts, WQXR is being selective: it is broadcasting only eight full concerts, on Saturday evenings at 5 p.m., starting on July 20. Highlights from other performances will be broadcast daily at 4 p.m.

New York City is invited to a poetry reading.
 
There is no velvet rope to traverse, no waiting in line and no entrance fee. Instead, the poets take their works to New Yorkers: on trains and ferries, in stores, on the street, and in parks and laundromats.

Dear Diary:
 
My beloved New York Knickerbockers, Whom I do adore. You have the kind of talent, Not bought in any store. You make LeBron quiver, And Kobe breaks into a sweat. Melo buries a three, Like nobody is as wet. J.R. hits a game-winner, And stares you in the eye, Every time he does this, You should just say goodbye. When Raymond throws an alley-oop And Tyson slams it home, They do this almost every night, It chills you to the bone. When J. Kidd steals the ball from you It jumps right out of your hand, He shoots a three and nails it, And your momentum is not grand. When Shump throws a pass to you, It’ll burn off both your hands. He’ll also steal the ball from you, And do a creative jam.

SIROTA--Sheldon, DO, on April 21st, 2013. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Harold and Geri, Suzanne and Barry, Larry and Paige and Craig and Stefi. Loving grandfather of Joshua and Alyse, Shoni, Fani and Jonathon, Jesika, Beka, Jared, Cori, Lexi, Sara, Jason, Adam, Sydney, Shani and Jordan. Proud great-grandfather of Gavriel and Pinchus. Dr. Sirota was Vice President of osteopathic medical affairs for Touro College and founding father of their three osteopathic medical schools. He also helped found New York College of Osteopathic Medicine. His passion in life was his wife, Ruth, family, surgery and teaching thousands of medical students and residents. He was an ardent advocate of osteopathic medicine. He will truly be missed. Services today, 10am at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway Hewlett, NY.

When two bombs exploded at Monday’s Boston Marathon, good Samaritans of all sorts rushed in, from off-duty medical personnel to residents who opened their homes to evacuees. Tim Jones, the chief executive of Buzzient , a Boston-area social media management start-up, felt a similar urge to help, using his company’s ability to search Web history on forums, comments and social media, to focus on specific topics —  like explosives.
 
Mr. Jones also happens to be the former head of an explosives-detection company. Given his background, he jumped in when this week’s news broke — as a kind of virtual bystander. Nearly two years ago, he had offered his company’s social media monitoring tools to the Boston Police Department, pro bono. This week, his first thought was to tweak his company’s search algorithms to target online chatter about explosives, in case the police department would seek that kind of data as their investigation continued. The following is condensed and edited from an interview with Mr. Jones about his company’s volunteer efforts to assist with the investigation.

Dorothy Taubman, who developed a method to help pianists strengthen their techniques and avoid repetitive strain injuries, died on April 3 in Brooklyn. She was 95.
 
The cause was pneumonia, said her son, Mark.

SLUTZKY--Orville A. 96 year old co-founder of Hunter Mountain Ski Bowl. Born and raised in Hunter, NY, Orville and his late brother Izzy were ski industry pioneers and driving forces of Northern Catskill Mountains tourism and economic development. Also predeceased by his wife of 67 years, Ethel, and two sisters, Orville is survived by three children and their spouses, nine grandchildren, five great grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. He will be deeply missed.

But one of Mr. Nadella’s competitors – Amazon – is not like the others.

According to a new study released by NPD Group, the market research firm, in 2012 Amazon accounted for 22 percent of paid music downloaded in the United States. This is up from 15 percent in 2011.

SAUNDERS--Osmond E.,90, of Somers, NY died April 20, 2013. Osmond was a partner at Colahan-Saunders Printing Corp. of NYC. He served in the Coast Guard during World War II. Osmond is survived by his wife of 64 years: Eileen (Lappin) Saunders; four children: Osmond E., Jr., Ronald T., Patricia Dishinger and Brian M. Saunders, and four grandchildren. Services by Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY 914-232-3033. In lieu of flowers, donations to Phelps Hospice, Sleepy Hollow, NY.

Zao Wou-ki, a Chinese émigré who merged Eastern and Western aesthetic traditions in his abstract paintings — helping to shape avant-garde art in postwar Europe and attracting a newly wealthy Asian following that made him one of the most commercially successful living artists in either hemisphere — died on April 9 in Nyon, Switzerland. He was 92. The cause was complications of Alzheimer’s disease, said a spokesman for his wife, Françoise Marquet, a former curator of the Museum of Modern Art of Paris.
 
Mr. Zao’s paintings, which are in the collections of the Museum of Modern Art, the Guggenheim and the Tate Modern, among others, have sold at auction in recent years for between $1 million and $2 million each. Since 2011, when sales of his paintings totaled $90 million, art journals and art dealers have frequently referred to him as the top-selling living Chinese artist.

Dear Diary:
 
The scene: the Morgan Library exhibition in honor of the 100th anniversary of Marcel Proust’s novel “Swann’s Way,” the first in his seven-volume series “In Search of Lost Time.”
GOODWIN--Stewart, on April 16, 2013. Loving brother of Rhona and the late Howard. Graveside services will take place on Tuesday, April 23, 11am, at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

KRAMER--Morris J. A true New Yorker, eminent attorney, and loving father and grandfather passed away on April 19th, at the age of 71. Morris grew up in Bay Ridge, and went on to Dartmouth College and Harvard Law. A 40-year partner of Skadden, Arps, Morris was an international leader in mergers and acquisitions, working on many famous deals. He divided the late '80s between London and New York, and spent months in Berlin at the Treuhandanstalt in the newly unified German government. A longtime resident of Carnegie Hill, Morris read the complete works of Anthony Trollope and watched every New York sports game. He is survived by his two sons, Jeremy and Oliver, daughter-in-law Kaye, grandchildren Maxime, Jules, and Oscar, brother Stephen, and his second former-wife Nancy who went to every doctor's appointment. His intellect, humor, and generosity will be missed by all. Funeral Service: April 21, 1:15pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Memorial gifts in his name may be made to: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Attn: Hugh B. Kelly. 633 Third Avenue, 28th Fl. New York, NY 10017.
KRAMER--Morris J.,A tour de force of intellect, Morris was not only brilliant, but a kind and generous friend for over 30 years whom I will forever miss. Nancy A. Lieberman

KRAMER--Morris J.,On April 18, 2013. With great sadness, the partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the loss of our partner Morris Kramer, a cornerstone of the firm's M&A practice for more than 40 years. He was 71. Mr. Kramer joined Skadden in 1972. Working closely with Joe Flom, he was a principal player in the development of the modern takeover era. He helped the firm capture a large share of this new market, working on many of our defining takeovers. A strong advocate for the globalization of Skadden's practice, Mr. Kramer helped launch the firm's London office. A brilliant tactician, Mr. Kramer was known for his incisiveness. Over his four-plus decades at Skadden, he represented clients such as Allied Signal, Inc., ALLTEL Corporation, American General Corporation, Norfolk Southern Corporation, Prudential plc and XM Satellite Radio Holdings Inc. He advised many investment banks in the development of their M&A practices, including most notably First Boston (now Credit Suisse). Mr. Kramer grew up in Brooklyn and attended Dartmouth College ('63) and Harvard Law School ('66). He also served on the board of American General. Mr. Kramer is survived by his sons, Jeremy and Oliver; daughter-in-law, Kaye; and grandchildren, Jules, Maxime and Oscar. We extend our deep condolences to Morris's family.

NEWMAN--Dr. Helene Johan, a spirited and bright light, loving mother, an engaged and esteemed therapist, has passed leaving our hearts and the world with a great void. Her beloved husband of 63 years, the late David Newman, will be there to catch her spirit. She is survived by her two daughters, Meg Dana Newman, MD, of San Francisco and Jill Newman, Producer/Curator, of New York. The summer and the ocean will never be the same without Helene.

JARDINE--Evangeline Vassiliades On Thursday, April 11, 2013 at Kline Hospice House, Mt. Airy, MD. Eve was 70 years young. An ESL teacher before Parkinson's disease forced retirement, Eve graduated from Vassar and earned her PhD from NYU in Musicology. She spoke, read and wrote English, Greek, Russian and Spanish! Born and raised in Washington, D.C., Eve was a world traveler and lived in Russia, Greece and Peru. Her students and their parents loved her because of her patience and empathy. She loved classical music, reading and Scrabble. Recently living in Frederick, MD, Eve was an overachiever, loving mother and wonderful wife. She is survived by her husband, Cyril Jardine; son, Nikos Montesatos, and mother, Mary Freeman. Her father, George Panos Vassiliades passed in 1984. No funeral or viewing. A Celebration of her life is being planned. To contribute funny stories or mementos to Eve's Celebration, contact Cyril Jardine at 301-662-1217. cjardine77@verizon.net
KRAMER--Morris J. A great friend, we will always miss you and always love you. David and Doreen Hurwitz

HANSON--Bernadette. April 14, 1960, died April 19, 2013. Beloved wife of Paul and Aunt to Gillian, Cristina, Julia, and Nina, and daughter-in-law to Aldo. Bernadette was a very loving and caring person who always thought of others first. She was raised in Middle Village Queens, NY and attended St. Francis Preparatory School where she was a member of the national Honor Society. She also attended Hunter College in Manhattan. Bernadette began her career as a secretary and rose to the position of Print Production Manager in the advertising and publishing businesses. She looked forward to donating her time to the Putnam Valley Community Food Pantry each Saturday morning. Her warm smile and loving nature will be missed by all. She is survived by her loving husband Paul Accorsini. Services are Tuesday 11am at St. Elizabeth Ann Seton R.C. Church, Shrub Oak, New York.

HALPERN--Abraham Leon, M.D. Born February 2, 1925 in Warsaw, Poland. Died April 20, 2013 after an earlier fall. His family emigrated to Canada in 1927. He joined the Royal Canadian Navy serving in WWII and Korea and discharged as Lieutenant Surgeon Commander. After University of Toronto medical school, he practiced psychiatry for over 50 years helping pioneer the subspecialty of forensic psychiatry. Awards from many medical organizations reflect a life dedicated to human rights. He marched with Dr. King in Selma, fought against China's torture of the Falun Gong, illegal organ transplantation, the misuse of the insanity defense, involuntary hospitalization without judicial review, and physician involvement in capital punishment and participation in coerced interrogations of prisoners. All were subject of his prolific publications. He is survived by his beloved wife Marilyn, and his loved children (and spouses) Howard, Lon (Barbara), Marnen (Herdis), Chaia (Adam), Mark (Tomoko), Emily, and John. He was an adoring grandfather of eleven and great-grandfather of five. Services will be at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 E. Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY on Tuesday, April 23, 2013 at 11am with interment to follow at King David Cemetery, Putnam Valley, NY.
KAZLOW--Sol E.,April 28, 1910 - April 20, 2013. Lived a very long, happy life. We will miss your humor, wisdom and love. Forever in our hearts. With all our love, Your Family

MILLARD--Anne L. The Board of Directors and staff of Park Avenue Armory mourn the passing of our board member Anne Millard and extend our heartfelt sympathies to her devoted husband Peter and her family. Anne was an ardent preservationist who was dedicated to her city and her neighborhood. Anne joined our board in 2000 with a drive to save this great landmark building and create a revitalized arts center for the public. She was proud of the accomplishments we made with her support and her generous gift of time and energy. We will miss her warmth and her great sense of fun. Elihu Rose, Chairman, Adam R. Flatto, Vice Chairman, Marjorie L. Hart, Vice Chairman, Rebecca Robertson, President and Executive Producer of Park Avenue Armory

MILLARD--Anne Lalor. FRIENDS of the Upper East Side Historic Districts mourns the passing of our beloved President. She will be missed for her indomitable leadership, affectionate friendship, ebullient humor and demonstrated love of her neighborhood.

FINGER--Chet. Gone but never forgotten. Husband, lover, partner of Harriet. Caring, giving father of Lauren. Proud grandfather of Adam, Brian, Allie, Scott and now reunited with his son Kenny. Chet your wit, smile and kindness will never die. Your family.

DAVID--David Salim, MD, a brilliant physician, a loving husband to Vera and father to Lisa and Eric, grandfather to Veronica, Simon and Nathanial, and dear brother to Sami and Karen. Dr. David graduated Summa Cum Laude from Columbia College and Columbia Medical School and headed the first kidney dialysis unit in New York at St. Luke's Hospital. He joined the Rogosin Labs at New York Hospital and was considered there "a once in a lifetime genius in medicine." Taken from us too soon. His brilliant mind and wonderful, gentle heart will be very deeply missed by all of us who love him.

DAVID--David S.,MD, Dearest David, now you are in Hashem's embrace and with our parents and Harry. The mysteries of the universe are now revealed to you. Have a beautiful journey home. We will love you forever. Rena and Sami

DAY--John William, 80, passed away on April 20, 2013, New York City, with his wife, Barbara Cline, at his side. They met at Northwestern University in 1952 and were married upon graduation in 1955. John was NROTC and was commissioned in the Marine Corps, where he served two years in Quantico, VA, and Cherry Point, NC. Upon discharge in 1957 he joined Chrysler Corporation and was part of the Missile Division, which took him and his family to Italy and Turkey. He then joined Chrysler International and he and his family lived in eight countries in Latin America and Europe. He retired from Chrysler as an Executive Vice President in 1984. He then joined Bendix/Allied Signal, and retired from there in 1993. In addition to his wife, he is survived by daughter Karen Day and her son Patrick Day Tine; daughter Lisa Day and her husband Tony Roberts and their daughters, Hannah, Rachel and Philippa; and his sisters Vicki Kozlowski and Debby Vandiver. Memorial service 11:00am Saturday, April 27, St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, New York City.

ABBOTT--Gordon, Jr. A conservationist, journalist, World War ll Navy Veteran, and life-long outdoor enthusiast died on April 17, 2013. He was 85. He leaves his wife, Katharine Oliver Stanley and four children and five grandchildren. A celebration of Mr. Abbott's life will be held on Saturday, April 27, 2013 at St. John's Episcopal Church, Beverly Farms, Massachusetts at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to Maine Coast Heritage Trust, www.mcht.org. For complete obituary or information please visit www.campbellfuneral.com

DAVID--Dr. David Salim, of Beverly Hills, CA passed away peacefully at home on Friday, April 19. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Vera David, PhD; his daughter, Lisa David and granddaughter, Veronica David; his son, Eric (Lacy) David, MD and grandsons Simon and Nathaniel David; his brother Sami David, MD, and sister Karen Chilowicz; and numerous nieces and nephews. Born in Baghdad in 1938, he immigrated with his family to New York City, arriving in 1948. He completed his undergraduate degree at Columbia College, received an MD from Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons and completed his residency in internal medicine at St. Luke's Medical Center, where he was chief resident. He was subsequently attending physician and faculty member at New York Hospital/Cornell Medical Center and the Rogosin Institute in the departments of medicine, surgery and biochemistry. A nephrologist who published more than 100 articles in peer-reviewed journals, he was a member of the team of professionals who cared for the first dialysis and kidney-transplant patients in New York. After moving to Los Angeles, Dr. David was a nephrologist and internist in private practice and a clinical professor of medicine at UCLA School of Medicine. Dr. David was revered as a stellar practitioner of clinical medicine and beloved by his patients, who sought him out for his intuitive and compassionate care. As a boy in Baghdad, Dr. David exercised daily by swimming across the Tigris River; in the US, he played placekicker for the Columbia College football team and served in the United States Army Reserves, from which he was honorably discharged following a brief call to active duty. He was devoted to his family and adored as husband, brother, father, and grandfather, as well as beloved uncle and cousin to the many generations of his family members across the country. Services of Jewish Burial to be held April 22, at Hillside Memorial in Los Angeles. Contributions may be made in his name to the Cedars-Sinai ALS Research Program at giving.cedars-Sinai.edu/makeagift.

DRUMMOND--Dean, April 13. The New York Consortium for New Music honors the memory of a brilliant colleague, composer and co-founder/director of Newband. Dean's vital innovations and his championing of Harry Partch's legacy are lasting gifts.

AGNESE--Ruth. Our hearts are broken by the loss of Ruth Agnese who has been a part of our family for 33 years. Our deepest sympathy to her husband Tony, son John and daughter Erica and all who loved and will miss her. She started her career with Appraisers & Planners Inc. as a receptionist and became President and one of the most respected appraisers in the country. Her insight, knowledge and warmth endeared her to all who knew her. Her leadership qualities were recognized as she became President of most of the professional organizations she was involved with. She will be in our hearts forever. Jim and Leslie Levy
