An article on Thursday about the funeral for former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher misstated the age of Queen Elizabeth II, who attended. She was 86 on the day of the funeral, not 87. (She turned 87 on Sunday.)

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about errors in the revised testing for gifted and talented programs in New York City public schools misidentified, in some copies, the official who commented on the goal of the new assessments. It was Shael Polakow-Suransky, the chief academic officer for the Education Department — not Public Advocate Bill de Blasio — who said the purpose is to do “a better job of identifying kids’ giftedness without respect to whether they had prior academic preparation.”

Eight days ago — about 2:50 p.m. last Monday, just over four hours into the race — the first of two bombs exploded near the finish line of the Boston Marathon. This image, taken from the NBC broadcast of the race, shows the flash of the explosion and the finalsplit-second of normalcy before the area turned into what witnesses described as a war zone. Below, six stories of those who were there.

Let’s rename it the eBay loophole.
 
For more than a decade, Amazon led a ferocious lobbying campaign in Washington against a law to force online merchants to collect state and municipal sales tax from their customers. Local and national retailers with brick-and-mortar stores complained that online merchants were enjoying a tax-free ride — they don’t have to collect state sales tax unless they have operations in the state — and getting an unfair advantage. The tax treatment was widely known as the Amazon loophole, until Amazon dropped its opposition of the tax. (More on why Amazon did that in a moment.)

A picture caption with the City Room column in some editions on Friday about wooden pipes from the early 1800s that were conveyed to the New-York Historical Society misidentified the type of metal used in the connector ring that was shown still intact. The connector is wrought iron, not steel.

An article on Saturday about the Manhattan district attorney’s decision not to file criminal charges against two New York Police Department deputy inspectors over their actions during Occupy Wall Street protests misidentified which of the inspectors pepper-sprayed the protester Kaylee Dedrick. He is Anthony Bologna, not Johnny Cardona.

A music review on Monday about a program of semi-staged French Baroque opera selections at the Brooklyn Academy of Music misstated a word in the title of a canon by Rameau. It is “Ah! Loin de rire,” not “Loi.” (The English translation, “Ah! Far From Laughter,” was rendered correctly.)

The Securities and Exchange Commission ushered in a new era of leadership on Monday, appointing a former federal prosecutor turned defense lawyer to help run the unit that polices the front lines of financial fraud.
 
While the shake-up comes as the financial misdeeds of 2008 fade from view, the S.E.C.’s enforcement team will soon confront a fresh batch of challenges under its new leader, Andrew J. Ceresney.

He browsed the books like a giant looking for something to read. Some were small enough to fit into a fold of his hand. Many of the books were illegibly small, and he didn’t know what they were all about. But reading them was never the point.
 
Neale Albert, 75, is a collector of miniature books, and he may be the most serious collector living in New York. By definition, miniature books are properly printed and bound, and for the most part no larger than three inches. Mr. Albert has over 4,000 of them, some the size of matchboxes and others smaller than a tab of chewing gum. Some of the books are worth many thousands of dollars.

The clothing retailer Ralph Lauren has agreed to pay about $1.6 million to resolve charges that it made illegal payments and gifts to foreign officials, including perfume, dresses and handbags, in the latest case highlighting the government’s aggressive crackdown on overseas bribery by American companies.
 
Federal authorities announced on Monday the settlement of actions against Ralph Lauren Corporation related to bribes paid to officials in Argentina from 2005 to 2009. The company discovered the misconduct in an internal audit and reported violations of the law, called the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, to the government, according to court filings.

The man who inadvertently set off a sweeping police investigation when he hid his pistol under a cushion in a World Trade Center hotel lobby — minutes before the Boston Marathon bombing — was a tourist simply in a hurry to stow it and get back to his tour group, a relative said on Monday. 
 
The man, Bobby Glen Jackson, 59, was arrested on Saturday in Fayetteville, N.C., and was scheduled to be brought to New York City on Monday to face charges of criminal possession of a weapon and reckless endangerment, the police said. Mr. Jackson owns a pressure-washing business in Fayetteville and does security work, which is why he owns a pistol, said the relative, who asked to remain anonymous.

Marvin Tolkin was 83 when he decided that the unexamined life wasn’t worth living. Until then, it had never occurred to him that there might be emotional “issues” he wanted to explore with a counselor.
 
“I don’t think I ever needed therapy,” said Mr. Tolkin, a retired manufacturer of women’s undergarments who lives in Manhattan and Hewlett Harbor, N.Y.

A group of protesters who tried to attend a premiere screening of the documentary “Gasland Part II” at the Tribeca Film Festival was denied admission on Sunday, leading to a disagreement on Monday over the reason: protesters say they were thrown out for asking difficult questions about the film, and the festival’s organizers say the screening was full.
 
“Gasland Part II,” directed by Josh Fox, is a sequel to his 2010 documentary, “Gasland,” which explores the environmental impact of natural gas drilling and hydraulic fracking, and which was nominated for an Academy Award for best documentary feature.

High levels of cortisol — the so-called stress hormone — have been associated with cardiovascular disease in some studies, but not in others. This may be because measuring cortisol in blood or saliva at one point in time may pick up acute stress, but it fails to account for long-term stress. 
 
Now Dutch researchers have assessed cortisol levels over several months by analyzing scalp hair samples. Their results appeared online in The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism.

THE FACTS: 

 
The federal guidelines on drinking during pregnancy are clear: stick to abstinence.

The Metropolitan Opera released the performers, dates and places on Monday for the free park recitals it sponsors every summer in lieu of full-scale opera performances, which were suspended after 2007 because of the cost. The soprano Erin Morley, the mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonard and the tenor Stephen Costello, accompanied by the pianist Bradley Moore, will sing at Central Park’s SummerStage on July 16 and at Brooklyn Bridge Park on July 19.
 
In four more concerts, the soprano Ying Fang, the tenor Mario Chang and the bass-baritone Brandon Cedel, again accompanied by Mr. Moore, will appear at Crotona Park in the Bronx on July 23; Clove Lakes Park in Staten Island on July 25; Jackie Robinson Park in Manhattan on July 30; and Socrates Sculpture Park in Queens on Aug. 1. The Met will also repeat outdoor screenings in Lincoln Center of its high-definition theater broadcasts starting on Aug. 24. It will present 10 screenings.

7:35 p.m. | Updated Standard Poor’s, accused of inflating its ratings to win business during the boom in mortgage investments, urged a judge on Monday to dismiss the federal government’s civil case against it, saying the Justice Department had built a faulty complaint on “isolated snippets” of conversations rather than evidence of real wrongdoing.
 
S.& P., the largest ratings agency in the United States, was responding to civil fraud charges filed in February in the first significant federal action against the ratings industry since the mortgage bubble burst. The Justice Department’s lawsuit accused S.& P. of knowingly giving complex packages of mortgages higher ratings than they deserved, stoking investor demand for the securities and driving up prices to where they crashed, setting off the global financial crisis.

Soon, medical practice will be practically perfect.
 
Or so one can only assume from the quantities of flow sheets, protocols and guidelines being churned out these days, all intended to transform health care into an instrument as sleek and reliable as a new transcontinental jet, floating through cloudless blue skies from Point Sick to Point Well.

The new Broadway musical “Matilda,” which arrived from London this spring with exceedingly high expectations – and opened April 11 to some of the best reviews of the season – joined the million-dollar club of top-selling shows last week with a gross of $1,129,419, according to box office data provided by the Broadway League, a trade association of theater owners and producers. The show, based on the Roald Dahl children’s novel about a young girl persevering against cruel parents and a sadistic headmistress, sold nearly $2 million in tickets the day after opening and now has advance sales totaling nearly $20 million.
 
“Matilda” also edged out two other Broadway musicals that appeal to families and children, especially girls: “Cinderella,” which opened in March and grossed $976,098 last week, and “Annie,” which opened in November and took in $813,203. Ticket sales for “Annie” have been softening a bit, but the show has also been running longer than its two competitors – and is bound to see a surge at the box office next month when Emmy Award winner Jane Lynch (“Glee”) starts an eight-week run as Miss Hannigan.

One spring morning during the second year of my surgical residency, I learned that two of my classmates, junior residents like me, had suddenly been fired. 
 
Their dismissal left just four of us to cover two hospitals and the work of six junior residents. I quickly did the math in my head. We would have to split up into pairs, and we would have to work through every other night for the rest of the year.

Trust in government, thy name is not Albany.
 
After two New York State legislators were charged in unrelated corruption scandals this month, more than 80 percent of voters say they believe that additional lawmakers are likely to be accused of ethical malfeasance in the near future, according to a poll released on Monday .

Bob Dylan will be touring with My Morning Jacket and Wilco this summer, an unusually strong lineup for what the influential songwriter has dubbed the AmericanaramA Festival of Music . 
 
Though the tour is skipping the major arenas and stadiums in the New York City area, he will play an outdoor concert in Hoboken on Pier A on July 26.

The hit Broadway musical “Once” announced some unexpected casting news on Monday – the sort of news that tends to disappoint aspiring actors in New York theater. The musical’s lead performers, Ben Hope and Laura Dreyfuss, who were named to the roles of Guy and Girl in March, are being replaced by two British newcomers to Broadway, Arthur Darvill and Joanna Christie, who will make their debuts in the show on Tuesday.
 
What makes the announcement unusual is that the producers of “Once” had not indicated that Mr. Hope and Ms. Dreyfuss would be temporary when naming them as the show’s stars last month.

Besedka Johnson, who was plucked from obscurity and made a star by a movie producer who had spotted her swimming one summer in Southern California — when she was 85 — died on April 4 in Glendale, Calif. She was 87.
 
The cause was complications of a bacterial infection, her son Jim said.

A new study, published in Heart , suggests that a higher resting heart rate is an independent predictor of mortality — even in healthy people in good physical condition.
 
Danish researchers gave physical exams to 5,249 healthy middle-aged and elderly men beginning in 1971. In 1985 and 1986, they tracked survivors, of whom there were 3,354. Of these, 2,798 had sufficient data on heart rate and oxygen consumption for the analysis. Researchers followed them through 2011.

Inadequate levels of vitamin D may increase the risk for uterine fibroids, a new study reports.
 
Vitamin D has been associated with reduced risk for various diseases, but this is the first to examine the connection to fibroids, benign tumors of the uterus that can cause pain and bleeding.

Three springs ago, Joe Ciriano was living in a fog. He had just lost his wife of 21 years to breast cancer . He was now the sole parent of a son and three daughters, one with Down syndrome . The children, ages 6 through 19, all had different needs and levels of understanding.
 
Mr. Ciriano, 51, an accounts manager in Burlington, N.C., was riddled with doubts about his ability to carry on as a single parent and was struggling to keep his head above water. While deeply mourning his wife, he was unsure of how good a parent he could be.

WYMAN--Frank H. Frank H. Wyman passed away on April 21, 2013 at his home in New York, surrounded by his family. He was an inspiration for his generosity, his wit, his pluck, and his love for his friends and family. He will be missed by all those fortunate enough to have known him. He was born on December 19, 1921. He attended Cambridge University and graduated from Harvard University in the class of 1947. With his knowledge of multiple languages, he was an active participant in the business world, achieving success in real estate, construction of container ships, and money management. Since his youth he was an avid sportsman, collecting prizes in golf, tennis, and skiing competitions. He was a member of The Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, The National Golf Links of America, The Meadow Club, The Southampton Bathing Corporation, and the Lyford Cay Club, and he was one of the longest-standing active members of The River Club. He supported the Southampton Dune Church and numerous other causes to which his heart made a commitment. He is survived by his wife Victoria, his brother Thomas, his son and daughter Frederick and Carol, whom he had with his deceased wife Ann, as well as his three grandchildren, Victoria, Nicola, and Andrew. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York City on Thursday, April 25, 2013, 11:00am.

de GRAZIA--Edward. The Law & Humanities Institute mourns the loss of Edward de Grazia, a founding member of its Board of Governors, and a founding co-Editor of Cardozo Studies in Law and Literature. His life and work were devoted to the literary imagination, protecting it as a lawyer from the forces of censorship and contributing to it as a playwright and critic. May his influence endure. Richard Weisberg, President, LHI Daniel Tritter, Vice President, LHI

LIVERMORE--Shirley, died on April 22 at 94. Shirley was a fun-loving, free spirit who never hesitated to speak her mind or to give of herself. After the death of her three beloved husbands David, Bunny and Richard, Shirley reinvented her life with gusto. She traveled the world, danced on cruise ships with her friends Simy, Steven, and Robert, and made a home in Florida where her grandchildren loved to vacation, swim, eat Mallomars, and play bartender at her festive New Years' Eve celebrations. Shirley truly embraced all that life has to offer and her courageous, generous spirit will be missed and emulated by her children, Terry Shargel and Steven Krapes, her son and daughter-in-law Jerry and Lorraine, her grandchildren Johanna, David, Dillon, and Genevieve, and their spouses Jared, Lee and Allen and her eight great-grandchildren Casey, Miles, Theo, Tatum, James, Eli, Liam, and Hayden. Shirley was fortunate in her last years to have been cared for by Jacqueline Francis and Saffie Jobe, whose generosity, kindness and patience know no bounds.

VIGILANTE--Florence. A celebration of the life and accomplishments of our friend and colleague, Florence Vigilante, who passed away on September 12, 2012, will take place at the Silberman School of Social Work at Hunter College, 2180 Third Avenue at 119th Street, Manhattan on Monday, May 6th at 5:30 pm. A reception will immediately follow. In memory of Dr. Vigilante, her family has established a scholarship in her name and asks that donations be made to the Hunter College Foundation/ Silberman School of Social Work.

NEWMAN--Dr. Helene Johan, a spirited and bright light, loving mother, an engaged and esteemed therapist, has passed leaving our hearts and the world with a great void. Her beloved husband of 63 years, the late David Newman, will be there to catch her spirit. She is survived by her two daughters, Meg Dana Newman, MD, of San Francisco and Jill Newman, Producer/Curator, of New York. The summer and the ocean will never be the same without Helene.
HAMILTON--E. Douglas. December 23, 1900 - April 23, 1993 Beloved Father. Eternally missed. Faithfully and lovingly remembered. Connie and Doug

KAY--Jack. Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc. is deeply saddened at the passing of Guardian of Zion donor, Jack Kay, beloved husband of Barbara, and cherished father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Jack was devoted to his family, and carried this passion to his work on behalf of Hadassah. May his memory be for a blessing, and may the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marcie Natan, National President

KAY--Jack. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of it's member, Jack Kay, and extends sincere sympathy to his children, grandchildren and other members of his family. William L. Mack, President Alan Curtis, Secretary

DAY--John William, 80, passed away on April 20, 2013, New York City, with his wife, Barbara Cline, at his side. They met at Northwestern University in 1952 and were married upon graduation in 1955. John was NROTC and was commissioned in the Marine Corps, where he served two years in Quantico, VA, and Cherry Point, NC. Upon discharge in 1957 he joined Chrysler Corporation and was part of the Missile Division, which took him and his family to Italy and Turkey. He then joined Chrysler International and he and his family lived in eight countries in Latin America and Europe. He retired from Chrysler as an Executive Vice President in 1984. He then joined Bendix/Allied Signal, and retired from there in 1993. In addition to his wife, he is survived by daughter Karen Day and her son Patrick Day Tine; daughter Lisa Day and her husband Tony Roberts and their daughters, Hannah, Rachel and Philippa; and his sisters Vicki Kozlowski and Debby Vandiver. Memorial service 11:00am Saturday, April 27, St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, New York City.

KAY--Jack, on Sunday, April 21, 2013, Jack Kay of Chevy Chase, Maryland. Community leader and major philanthropist in the Washington metro, Israel, and Palm Beach Florida communities. He touched the lives of thousands, leaves a lasting legacy and will forever be missed. Beloved husband of Barbara Kay and the late Ina Kay. Devoted father of Lauren Kay Pollin (Richard), and the late Shelley Kay (Al Policicchio). Loving stepfather of Susan Pertnoy (Ronnie), Nina Saslove (Joshua), and David Shulman (Jill). Loving brother of Sylvia Greenberg. Jack is also survived by his grandchildren Julie Ann Michelina (Victor) Kennis Ann Hawkins, Alyssa Kay Perper and Sander Kay Hawkins, Jacob Pollin, Matthew Pollin and Nicole Policicchio. Jack was also an adored step-grandfather of Alexandra (Eric), Samantha (Brenden), Harris (Michal), Brett, Michael, Whitney, Adam, Jacob, Amanda, Andrew, Sydney, Isabella, Jonathan, Alexander, Elijah, Charlotte, and step-great-grandfather to Payton, Rowan, William, and Ella. Funeral Services will be held Tuesday, April 23, 2013 at 1pm at Adas Israel Congregation, Connecticut and Porter Streets, NW Washington. Interment to follow at Judean Memorial Gardens, Olney Maryland. The family will be observing Shiva at the Kay residence on Tuesday at 7pm, and on Wednesday and Thursday at 6:30pm Minyan services will be held on all three nights at 7:30pm. Contributions in Jack's memory may be made to Adas Israel Congregation or the charity of your choice. Services entrusted to DanzanskyGoldberg Memorial Chapels, 1170 Rockville Pike, Rockville MD 20852. www.danzanskygoldberg.com

SHAPIRO--Charlotte Peetluk, Born August 8, 1923, died April 22, 2013. She was predeceased by her husband, Sam, and by Robert Cohen. She is survived by her children, Eugene and Nancy, her grandchildren, Seth and Leah, sister Doris Rotker, brother Morton Peetluk, and by Madeleine and David Albert, Spencer and Harry Jennings, and by all of her loving nieces and nephews. Just as she touched each of us, she will be deeply missed.

KAY--Jack. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) are saddened by the loss of Jack Kay of Chevy Chase, MD and West Palm Beach, FL. Together with his wife, Barbara, he was a Technion Guardian, reaching the highest level of support for the Technion. Their belief in the advancement of higher education in Israel led them to establish The Barbara and Jack Kay Endowed Doctoral Fellowship Fund and provide support for numerous Technion projects. A founding member and past president of the ATS Washington, D.C. Chapter, Jack was a member of the ATS National Board of Directors. We offer our heartfelt condolences to Barbara and the entire Kay family. American Technion Society Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President
WARSHAW--Robert S. The Trustees and Director of the Parrish Art Museum note with sorrow the passing of Robert S. Warshaw, a tireless champion of Esteban Vicente and visionary supporter of the arts.

BUTLER--Donald. SAR mourns with deep sorrow the passing of Donald B. Butler, beloved husband of Chantze, father and father-in-law of esteemed SAR community leaders Dr. Giti and Jack Bendheim, grandfather of Yoni and Zevi, Shifra and Dani, Shuli and Avi, Esther and Yonatan, Tamar and Reuven, Sarah and Etan, and Gilad. May the family be comforted among the mourner of Zion and Jerusalem. Ludwig Bravmann, Vice Chairman, Board of Trustees

CONNERAT--Virginia Hopper With deepest sadness, we announce the passing of our mother, Virginia Reed Hopper Connerat, 94, on April 4, 2013, at the Margaret McLaughlin McCarrick Care Center in Somerset, NJ. Mrs. Connerat was born in Mt. Sterling, KY on November 2, 1918 to Garnette (Robinson) and Walter Owsley Hopper. She graduated in 1940 from Mt. Holyoke College in South Hadley, MA with a BA in English Composition. While her life's primary focus was providing a loving home for her husband George and their children, her charitable work enriched the communities where she lived. When she lived in Manhasset (Long Island), NY (1954-1966), her volunteer activities included translating English into Braille and working at Abilities, Inc, an organization dedicated to preparing adolescents and adults with all types of disabilities for entry into the workforce. When she lived in Essex, CT (1966-2003), she was an active member of the Essex Garden Club, taking a term as its president, the Old Lyme Art Academy, the League of Women Voters, and the Junior League of New Haven. She was an avid bridge player who brought home trophies from tournaments at the Old Lyme Country Club. Surviving Mrs. Connerat are her daughter, Robin Connerat, of Pennington, NJ, son, George, his wife Jeanne, and granddaughters Kristen and Elizabeth of New Providence, NJ. She was predeceased in 2006 by her husband of 60 years, George Hillyer Connerat. Interment will be on June 29 at the Connerat family plot in Bonaventure Cemetery in Savannah, GA. Memorial contributions are suggested to the Alzheimer's Association of NJ, 400 Morris Avenue, Denville, NJ, 07834, www.alznj.org.

DAVID--David Salim, MD, a brilliant physician, a loving husband to Vera and father to Lisa and Eric, grandfather to Veronica, Simon and Nathanial, and dear brother to Sami and Karen. Dr. David graduated Summa Cum Laude from Columbia College and Columbia Medical School and headed the first kidney dialysis unit in New York at St. Luke's Hospital. He joined the Rogosin Labs at New York Hospital and was considered there "a once in a lifetime genius in medicine." Taken from us too soon. His brilliant mind and wonderful, gentle heart will be very deeply missed by all of us who love him.

DAVID--David S.,MD, Dearest David, now you are in Hashem's embrace and with our parents and Harry. The mysteries of the universe are now revealed to you. Have a beautiful journey home. We will love you forever. Rena and Sami

N.F.L. draft picks get a lesson on public displays of affection from Commissioner Roger Goodell.
Max Baucus was elected to the House from Montana in 1974 and to the Senate four years later. He said Tuesday that he would not seek a seventh term.
A lust triangle is the framework for “Apple,” a play by Vern Thiessen fueled by bathos, tragic illness, coincidences, alcoholism and tearful confessions of star-crossed love.
“At Any Price” is a critical exploration of modern agribusiness and its cutthroat ways, but it is also an allegory of American hubris in the 21st century.

Last year, the Lahontan cutthroat trout became the first confirmed catch of a fish that for decades was believed to have gone extinct.

The Advanced Technology Vehicles Manufacturing (A.T.V.M.) loan program provides loans to automotive companies for the development of energy-efficient vehicles, like hybrid or electric cars and trucks, and the systems and infrastructure to support them.

New York basketball has been down for a while, and it certainly has never had two N.B.A. title contenders. William C. Rhoden thinks a hoops version of a subway series would be a great remedy.
Vali Nasr, a former senior State Department policy expert, talks to The Times’s Marcus Mabry about America and China’s role in the Middle East.

A maker, tinkerer and online celebrity, Sylvia Todd has attracted more than a million views on YouTube of the show she produces and hosts, called “Sylvia’s Super-Awesome Maker Show.” Not bad reach for an 11-year-old.

For years, Wall Street’s top enforcers lacked the firepower to thwart financial misdeeds like Bernard L. Madoff ’s Ponzi scheme . But now that the Securities and Exchange Commission has turned to sophisticated statistical tools and financial experts, one of the most effective weapons in its new enforcement arsenal may be a more traditional one: whistle-blowers.
 
Already, a whistle-blower program has bolstered an investigation into a trading blowup that nearly toppled Knight Capital , the largest stock trading firm on Wall Street, according to lawyers briefed on the case.

The This Land column on Monday about the signs of change along the Boston Marathon route after the bombing misidentified the device used to signal the start of the race. It was an air horn, not a starter’s pistol.

An article on Tuesday about the study of children’s play and the role of play in human evolution misstated the surname of the lab manager at the University of California, Berkeley, who played a game called Blickets with young lab participants. She is Sophie Bridgers, not Bridges. The article also misstated the age of two of the participants, twins named Esther and Benny. At the time they were observed for the article, they had recently turned 5; they were not 4. The errors were repeated in an accompanying picture caption.

Walking up the granite stairs of the Metropolitan Museum of Art from the Great Hall on Tuesday, Alison Watts immediately thought about how she had taken the same steps as the luckiest brother and sister duo in literature. 
 
“What was that book where the kids stayed overnight at the museum?” she wondered to herself. She is 30, and read the book when she was 8, growing up in Minnesota. And then the memories, like fantasies, flooded back.

An article on Tuesday about the arrest in Canada of two men who the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said had been planning to derail a passenger train in a plot linked to Al Qaeda reversed, in some editions, the cities in which the suspects, Chiheb Esseghaier and Raed Jaser, were living. Mr. Esseghaier has been living in Montreal, and Mr. Jaser in Toronto.

An article in some editions on Monday about the poverty rate in New York City misstated the city rate that would result if food stamps were to be eliminated. It would be nearly 25 percent, not nearly 31 percent.

An obituary on Saturday about the newspaper executive Al Neuharth misidentified the position for which he was hired at The Detroit Free Press in 1960. It was assistant executive editor, not executive editor.

An article last Wednesday about a report that found a sizable increase in the amount of meat contaminated with antibiotic-resistant forms of bacteria misstated part of the name of the organization that issued it. It is the Environmental Working Group, not the Environmental Work Group.

Because of editing errors, an article on Monday about Boston residents’ beginning to say goodbye to those killed in the marathon bombings rendered incorrectly, in some copies, the name of one of those killed and misidentified the university she attended. She was Lu Lingzi, not Lingzi Lu, and she went to Boston University, not to Brown. The article also misstated the reason the university closed on Friday. It was shut during the search for the bombing suspects, not to honor Ms. Lu.

An article on Tuesday about charges against Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the surviving suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings, described incorrectly the exception to the Miranda rule that allowed him to be questioned without being told that he had a right to remain silent. It is the public safety exception, authorized by a 1984 Supreme Court decision; it is not a special Justice Department public safety exception. The article also referred incorrectly to the location of Watertown, Mass., in relationship to Boston. While the suspects were found in Watertown, several miles from the site of the marathon’s finish line in Boston, the two cities are contiguous at points; Watertown is not “about seven miles west of Boston.” And a front-page article on Sunday about the investigation into the suspected bombers erroneously stated that the cities are 10 miles apart.

AU REVOIR, PARIS The billionaire hedge fund manager Marc Lasry will not be moving to the ambassador’s mansion in Paris. Mr. Lasry, below, the chief executive and chairman of Avenue Capital, told his investors in a letter on Tuesday that he would remain at the hedge fund, ending speculation that President Obama was considering him for the role of ambassador to France. The investor had been a prominent supporter of Mr. Obama during the presidential campaign. WILLIAM ALDEN
 
THAI DEAL In the biggest Asian deal so far this year, CP All, the Thai operator of 7-Eleven convenience stores, is paying about $6.6 billion to acquire the discount retailer Siam Makro. It is the second recent big acquisition for a company controlled by the billionaire Dhanin Chearavanont. In February, his Charoen Pokphand Group completed the $9.4 billion purchase of a 15.6 percent stake in the Ping An Insurance Group of China from HSBC. NEIL GOUGH

A picture caption on Friday with a review of “Ain’t in It for My Health: A Film About Levon Helm,” using information from the movie’s distributor, carried an erroneous credit for the photograph of Mr. Helm. It was taken by Ahron R. Foster — not by the distributor, Kino Lorber.

The Broadway-bound musical “Flashdance,” based on the 1983 movie about a female welder who wants to be a dancer, is being delayed again as its producers continue to work on the show. The musical, which has received mixed reviews in cities on its current national tour, was scheduled to have a $12 million production on Broadway starting in August, after being delayed twice earlier. 
 
One of the musical’s producers, Thomas Viertel, said on Tuesday that the musical is now being aimed for Broadway later in the 2013-14 season. “Broadway is and has always been a tough place for new shows to succeed, and we want to get this right,” he said. “We have an incredible title and several established songs from the movie, but there may be a few too many subplots, and moments that haven’t been weighted correctly.” He said no one on the creative team is being replaced; the musical features a book by Tom Hedley and Robert Cary, music by Robbie Roth, lyrics by Mr. Cary and Mr. Roth, and direction and choreography by Sergio Trujillo (“Jersey Boys”).

Pasta with clams, one of the recipes in Mark Bittman’s new Flexitarian column , is one of my favorite dishes and is easy as can be when it comes to wine. The combination of olive oil, garlic and clam broth boiled in a rich, briny sauce practically demands a lively, lean, high-acid, somewhat austere white. Italy is full of good examples; just distinguish between mundane industrial bottles and those made with care. Good pinot grigio, Soave or Orvieto, to name three frequently abused wines, are fine choices, as are fianos and falanghinas from Campania. Avoid oakiness and lush textures; the wines want to have snap. Alternatives from farther afield? Chablis comes immediately to mind: a fresh, young modest Chablis. You have beauty in all these combinations.
 
What would you pair with this dish? Post your suggestions in the comments below.

The private equity firm Blackstone Group has exited the stage for Dell , abruptly bringing down the curtain on a budding takeover contest. It has the elements of a farce, and Dell’s board has no one to blame but itself.
 
The fizzled bidding for Dell is a result of the board’s extreme reliance on a process known as a go-shop and how it ran the initial sale. If this episode does not change the way companies sell themselves, perhaps it should.
An article last Wednesday about Pakta, a new restaurant in Barcelona, Spain, misspelled the given name and the surname of one of its three head chefs. She is Kyoko Ii, not Kioko Li.

Federal regulators are poised to crack down on payday loans — the short-term, high-cost credit that can mire borrowers in debt. But instead of taking aim at storefront payday lenders, the banking authorities are focusing on the small operations’ big bank rivals, like Wells Fargo and U.S. Bank, according to several people briefed on the matter.

Within minutes, Jay Carney, Mr. Obama’s press secretary, confirmed that the president was unharmed, and Julie Pace, the chief White House correspondent for The A.P., announced at a White House briefing that the account had been hacked.

A federal judge scolded Lauryn Hill on Monday for failing to pay back taxes but put off for two weeks her sentencing for tax evasion, The Associated Press reported .
 
Ms. Hill, 37, a Grammy-winning singer, rapper and songwriter, pleaded guilty last year to failing to pay taxes on $1.8 million in income earned between 2005 and 2007. Though she promised at the time she would pay about $554,000 in restitution before she was sentenced, she has only paid about $50,000 to date.

This year, the organizers of the Midsummer Night Swing concert series at Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center are taking few chances with the program: they have announced a lineup heavy with New York’s established big bands, including the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, Vince Giordano & the Nighthawks and Arturo O’Farrill and the Afro-Latin Jazz Orchestra.
 
The concert series, now in its 25th year, will run for 15 nights from June 25 through July 13, with shows and dance lessons every night of the week except Sunday and Monday. Wynton Marsalis and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra will start off the series.

WASHINGTON — Under friendly fire in the Capitol and squeezed politically at home, Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the powerful chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and a man often at odds with fellow Democrats, announced Tuesday that he would retire in 2014 after four decades in Congress.
 
The decision by Mr. Baucus, 71, to forgo a seventh term brings to six the number of Senate Democrats who will not seek re-election next year, including many of the party’s most popular and venerable senators. Mr. Baucus, though, was known for frustrating Democratic leaders by opposing major party initiatives as well as his solo attempts to cut deals with Republicans. Leadership efforts to go around Mr. Baucus may have contributed to his determination that it was time to exit the Senate, although he firmly denied that in an interview.

BERLIN – The headline on the German 24-hour news channel n-tv read simply: “Earthquake in the Bundesliga.” Bayern Munich opened the team’s ample coffers once more and paid a reported $48 million to nab the brilliant young midfielder Mario Götze from archrival Borussia Dortmund.
 
For the past several days the talk of the country had been a financial scandal shaking the club. Uli Hoeness, Bayern’s president and in many ways its heart and soul, had turned himself in to authorities and could face a prison term for tax evasion.

Richard Meier, Thom Mayne, Steven Holl, Hugh Hardy and Robert A.M. Stern are among the prominent architects who on Monday called for the Museum of Modern Art to reconsider its decision to demolish the former home of the American Folk Art Museum. 
 
“The Museum of Modern Art—the first museum with a permanent curatorial department of architecture and design—should provide more information about why it considers it necessary to tear down this significant work of contemporary architecture,” the letter said.

WYMAN--Frank H. Frank H. Wyman passed away on April 21, 2013 at his home in New York, surrounded by his family. He was an inspiration for his generosity, his wit, his pluck, and his love for his friends and family. He will be missed by all those fortunate enough to have known him. He was born on December 19, 1921. He attended Cambridge University and graduated from Harvard University in the class of 1947. With his knowledge of multiple languages, he was an active participant in the business world, achieving success in real estate, construction of container ships, and money management. Since his youth he was an avid sportsman, collecting prizes in golf, tennis, and skiing competitions. He was a member of The Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, The National Golf Links of America, The Meadow Club, The Southampton Bathing Corporation, and the Lyford Cay Club, and he was one of the longest-standing active members of The River Club. He supported the Southampton Dune Church and numerous other causes to which his heart made a commitment. He is survived by his wife Victoria, his brother Thomas, his son and daughter Frederick and Carol, whom he had with his deceased wife Ann, as well as his three grandchildren, Victoria, Nicola, and Andrew. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York City on Thursday, April 25, 2013, 11:00am.

WASSERMAN DAVIS--Kathryn. Wellesley College mourns the passing of Kathryn Wasserman Davis, class of 1928. At 106, Kathryn was Wellesley's oldest known alumna; she was also one of our most beloved. For nearly 85 years, she was committed to higher education and service to her community. A passionate and thoughtful advocate, Kathryn's philanthropy supported all aspects of the College, including professorships, financial aid, global education initiatives, and building and landscape improvements. Kathryn and her late husband, Shelby Cullom Davis, gave the cornerstone gift for Wellesley's Davis Museum and Cultural Center, which is named in their honor. Her vision also enabled Wellesley to return land that had been converted into a parking lot back to its original beauty. On her 100th birthday, Kathryn established the 100 Projects for Peace to fund student peace-building initiatives around the world. She was a Trustee Emerita who served on the Wellesley Board from 1984 to 2002. Her generosity touched many generations of Wellesley women, and will continue to make a difference for many generations to come. Kathryn is remembered, and will be missed, by her Wellesley sisters throughout the world.

WOLF--John C.,passed away Monday night April 22, 2013. Survived by his loving wife Sharon Manevitz Lauer-Wolf; his son Benjamin D. Wolf; his loving daughter-in-law Andi Wolf and his first grandson, Max Wolf born just last month; his step-daughter Suzanne Lauer; sister-in-law Sheila, and nephews Kehat and Hannania and brother-in-law Dr. Alan Manevitz and Dr. Larry Manevitz and wife Jenny, and their three children, the other love of his life his dog, Boo. He had another daughter from a previous marriage Alexandra. Graveside burial New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I., 631-249-7000 at 2pm, Wednesday. The family will sit Shiva at his home, Wednesday following the Funeral, Thursday 3-9pm, Saturday after Shabbat, Sunday to Wednesday 3-9pm.

Henry A. Prunier taught Vo Nguyen Giap, the Vietnamese general who withstood the armies of France and the United States, how to throw a grenade.
 
The lesson came in July 1945, after Mr. Prunier and six other Americans had parachuted into a village 75 miles northwest of Hanoi on a clandestine mission to teach an elite force of 200 Viet Minh guerrillas how to use modern American weapons at their jungle camp.

Morris J. Kramer, who as a longtime partner at the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom helped revolutionize the practice of advising on mergers and acquisitions, died on Friday morning in Manhattan. He was 71. 
 
The cause was complications from prostate cancer, said a son, Oliver Kramer.

KESTLER--Georgette. To My Beloved Mother Georgette Kestler May 23, 1911 - April 24, 2005 With My Endless Love, With My Endless Thanks. Robert (You are Cherished Everlastingly : Pummerka , Elisabeth , and Elizabeth)

Can 16 ounces of vegetable juice really help “cleanse” your body of toxins? And which toxins are we talking about? What are “live enzymes,” anyway, and should you be ingesting more of them? If you’ve got gobs of fruit (and the sugar that comes from it) squeezed into your cold-pressed juice, is that ultimately a good thing or a bad thing? What’s up with wheatgrass and liquid chlorophyll? Should fresh juice be pasteurized? Can a juice cleanse really make your skin as glowingly radiant as Gwyneth Paltrow’s? 
 
You want to know.

SCIBETTA--Sandra "Sandi" Lee, 63, on April 14, 2013. Daughter of the late Joseph and Olga Scibetta, Sandi was born on August 2, 1949. A graduate of St. Jean Baptiste High School, she was a lifetime resident of NYC. She was employed by the A.C. Nielsen Co. Sandi was a loyal colleague and a loving and caring friend. She will be missed and remembered always. Donations in her memory may be made to The Doe Fund of New York City.

LIVERMORE--Shirley, died on April 22 at 94. Shirley was a fun-loving, free spirit who never hesitated to speak her mind or to give of herself. After the death of her three beloved husbands David, Bunny and Richard, Shirley reinvented her life with gusto. She traveled the world, danced on cruise ships with her friends Simy, Steven, and Robert, and made a home in Florida where her grandchildren loved to vacation, swim, eat Mallomars, and play bartender at her festive New Years' Eve celebrations. Shirley truly embraced all that life has to offer and her courageous, generous spirit will be missed and emulated by her children, Terry Shargel and Steven Krapes, her son and daughter-in-law Jerry and Lorraine, her grandchildren Johanna, David, Dillon, and Genevieve, and their spouses Jared, Lee and Allen and her eight great-grandchildren Casey, Miles, Theo, Tatum, James, Eli, Liam, and Hayden. Shirley was fortunate in her last years to have been cared for by Jacqueline Francis and Saffie Jobe, whose generosity, kindness and patience know no bounds.

HOLMES--H. Sidney III.,on April 15, 2013. Beloved husband of the late Albertha Clarice, devoted father and father-in-law of Monique E. Holmes and Eric Odera, fiancee of MaryAnn Liberatore, will be dearly missed by many other relatives and friends. Friends may call Sunday, April 28, 2013, from 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81st Street. Funeral service Monday, April 29, 2013, 10am at St. Philip's Episcopal Church, 204 E. 134 St.

KAY--Jack. The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family in mourning the loss of Jack Kay--Washington DC real estate pioneer, award-winning business and communal leader, dedicated philanthropist, and longtime JTS supporter--who embodied the spirit of Judaism. Along with his wife, Barbara, and Harold (z"l) and Sylvia Greenberg, he honored the memory of his and Sylvia's parents with, among many other undertakings and scholarships, the annual JTS Abraham and Minnie Kay Memorial Lecture, which is held at Adas Israel Congregation in Washington DC. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold M. Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair

LEVERTE--Jean Mitchell, 80, of La Quinta, CA died peacefully on April 20, 2013 after a long battle with Parkinson's Disease. She is preceded in death by her beloved husband of 49 years Thomas J. Leverte, and survived by daughters Kara Farley (Dan) and Cristin Leverte and son T.J. Leverte (Mikelynn), and five loving grandchildren. A graduate of The Ursuline School and Rosemont College, Jean enjoyed a successful Madison Avenue advertising career in the New York of the 1960s, during which time she met Tom on the sand in Westhampton Beach, NY. The rest, as they say, is history. After the family moved to Belvedere, CA in 1974, she spent time in various volunteer pursuits, before she and Tom retired to La Quinta in 1993. A Funeral Mass will be held Friday, April 26, 2013 at 10am at St. Francis of Assisi Church in La Quinta, CA. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to Martha's Village and Kitchen, 83791 Date Avenue, Indio, CA 92201.

MILCAREK--Dr. Barry Ivor, left this world suddenly and peacefully at home on April 20, 2013, doing what he loved most, tending to his garden. Dr. Milcarek is leaving behind his devoted wife, Mary McLean, and his parents, Shirley and Ivor Milcarek; Barry also leaves behind his daughter, Heather (Michael Miller) and son Rory, both of whom he loved more than any words can express. He will be missed by his sister, Doreen Milcarek (Kenneth Burke), brother Kevin, niece Katharine and nephew Neil. Barry enjoyed his work and colleagues at the University of Delaware where he served as Senior Biostatistician in the College of Heath Sciences. Barry was an avid sports fan - he loved college basketball and football, but had a special love for youth hockey, where he once coached children, including his beloved son Rory. A private service is being planned. In lieu of flowers, if you would like to make a donation in Barry's memory, please give to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, P.O. Box 1000, Memphis, TN 38148, Tribute Account #

DAVID--David Salim, MD, a brilliant physician, a loving husband to Vera and father to Lisa and Eric, grandfather to Veronica, Simon and Nathanial, and dear brother to Sami and Karen. Dr. David graduated Summa Cum Laude from Columbia College and Columbia Medical School and headed the first kidney dialysis unit in New York at St. Luke's Hospital. He joined the Rogosin Labs at New York Hospital and was considered there "a once in a lifetime genius in medicine." Taken from us too soon. His brilliant mind and wonderful, gentle heart will be very deeply missed by all of us who love him.

FRASER--Regina Fay. Fay Fraser (nee Spratt) died peacefully at home the morning of April 22, 2013. Fay was the beloved wife of Richard Fraser (deceased), the caring mother of Elizabeth Oestreich, Pamela Gerlich and Margaret Fraser. She is also survived by her grandchildren Lois Katcher, Thomas Moore, Richard Moore, Emily Fay Flaherty and her great-grandson Reid Katcher. Fay was a lifelong resident of Port Washington NY and graduated from Port Washington High School in 1952. She was active in tennis, sailing and golf at Manhasset Bay Yacht Club and North Hempstead Country Club. She was a member of the Port Washington Library Nautical Committee, the Port Washington Historical Society, Child and Family Services and helped organize the Planting Fields Designer Showcase. Fay also served on the board of the Long Island Council of Alcohol and Drug Dependence and was a member of the North Shore Junior League. Fay will be greatly missed by her family and friends but we take joy in her lifetime of good works. A funeral mass will be held at St. Peter of Alcantara, Port Washington NY on Friday April 26 at 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Long Island Council of Alcohol and Drug Dependence, 114 Old Country Road, Suite 114, Mineola NY 11501.

DAVID--David S.,MD, Dearest David, now you are in Hashem's embrace and with our parents and Harry. The mysteries of the universe are now revealed to you. Have a beautiful journey home. We will love you forever. Rena and Sami

BUTLER--Donald B. The Yeshiva University family mourns the loss of Donald B. Butler of Pittsburgh, PA, a revered communal leader who served in the US Army assisting Army chaplains in North Africa and Italy to help Jewish and non Jewish soldiers. He later helped survivors of the concentration camps transferred through Italy, where he designed and supervised the first new synagogue in Rome in more than 50 years. An ardent Zionist, he was sent to Palestine in 1945 to secure religious articles for Jewish soldiers. Heartfelt condolences to his beloved children: Dr. Giti (and Jack) Bendheim, YU Guardians; David J. (and Sharon) Butler; Rabbi Raphael (and Pessy) Butler; and Lani (and Dr. David) Pelcovitz and his grandchildren and great grandchildren. BUTLER--Donald. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Donald Butler, a passionate supporter of the Jewish people. You will live on in all of our hearts. Contributions in her memory should be made to Amit. Graveside services private.

The City Room column on Wednesday, about visitors to the Metropolitan Museum of Art who fondly recalled the children’s novel “From the Mixed-Up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler,” written by E. L. Konigsburg, who died last week, rendered incorrectly the name of an award for the book, which is set in the museum. It is the Newbery Medal, not the Newbury Award.

An article on Tuesday about the Taliban’s abduction of 11 foreign engineers whose helicopter had to make an emergency landing misspelled, in some editions, the eastern Afghanistan district where the helicopter went down. It is Azra, not Azar.

A movie review on Wednesday about “At Any Price,” a narrative exploring the lives of farmers in an era of modern agribusiness, described the legal protection of seeds incorrectly. They are covered through patenting, not copyrighting.

An article on Tuesday about Rutgers’s hiring of Eddie Jordan as its men’s basketball coach misstated the location of Archbishop Carroll High School, Jordan’s alma mater, where he coached the freshman boys basketball team last year. It is in Washington, D.C., not in Maryland.

An article in some editions on Wednesday about the City University of New York’s hiring of the former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, David H. Petraeus, to serve as a visiting professor omitted one of his academic credentials. Besides holding a master’s from Princeton, he also earned a doctorate there.

An article on Wednesday about the disputed fate of two kidnapped Syrian archbishops misidentified, in some editions, the Syrian province where they were abducted on Monday. It is Aleppo Province, not Idlib.

A music review on Friday about a show by the Broadway star LaChanze that paid tribute to Diana Ross referred incorrectly to Ms. Ross’s song “Touch Me in the Morning.” It was recorded on the Motown label; it was not a “post-Motown” hit.

A music review on Friday about a New York Philharmonic performance at Avery Fisher Hall misidentified an instrument that offered what was described as a “left-right accompaniment” to the violin in Leonard Bernstein’s “Serenade.” It was a timpani, not a tuba.

Howard J. Phillips, a pillar of conservative activism who ran for president three times on the ticket of a political party he helped found, died on Saturday at his home in Vienna, Va. He was 72.
 
The cause was temporal frontal lobe dementia , his sister, Susan Phillips Bari, said.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Apple’s second-quarter earnings misstated the company’s projections for its gross profit margins in the third quarter. It expects its margins to drop to between 36 and 37 percent, not to fall by that percentage amount.

The Broadway musical “Nice Work if You Can Get It,” a venture involving the heirs of George and Ira Gershwin and several veteran theater producers to showcase famous songs by the brothers, will close on June 15 after 27 preview performances and 478 regular performances, the producers announced on Wednesday. The Jazz Age-style show, which originally paired Tony Award winner Matthew Broderick as a playboy with Tony nominee Kelli O’Hara as a bootlegger, opened last April to mixed reviews and never caught real fire at the box office. (Ms. O’Hara’s role is now played by Tony nominee Jessie Mueller.) 
 
The musical, which cost approximately $10 million to mount on Broadway, will not recoup that original capitalization by its closing date; a spokesman for the producers said that “Nice Work” will earn back a majority of its investment, but he did not have precise figures. The show’s lead producers – Scott Landis, Roger Berlind, Sonia Friedman and Roy Furman – also announced that a national tour of the show will begin during the 2014-15 theater season.

Updated, 6:08 p.m. | New Yorkers, your days of expending precious brain cells trying to determine whether that yogurt cup or plastic takeout container goes in the trash or the recycling bin have come to an end. 
 
The city announced the biggest expansion of its recycling program in 25 years on Wednesday, saying all hard plastics would be accepted. This includes shampoo bottles and clothes hangers as well as countless toys and other household objects.

A few hours before President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke at a ceremony in the Bolshoy Ice Dome in Sochi in February, marking a year to the start of the Winter Olympics, I was watching pensioners strip to the waist and bask in the midday sunshine on a beach a few miles from the Olympic Park.
 
Sochi offers a delicious respite from the cold of Russia. For a Moscow resident like me, the city is a luscious feast of green, with no hint of winter on its palm-lined avenues while snow still blankets the capital.

The Race for City Hall
 
Critics of Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, on Wednesday released an attack ad asserting that Ms. Quinn allowed St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village to close three years ago. The critics’ political committee, called NYC Is Not For Sale 2013 , says that its mission is to defeat Ms. Quinn’s mayoral bid and that it does not represent any particular candidate. Its leaders are from Local 1180, which represents communications workers; an animal rights group which opposes horse-drawn carriages; and Wendy Kelman Neu, chief executive of Hugo Neu Corporation, a recycling company. The ad is to air on television.

Setting Rhode Island on a clear path to same-sex marriage , the State Senate on Wednesday approved a bill to allow it by a vote of 26 to 12. Since the House has already approved a similar bill and Gov. Lincoln Chafee has pledged his support, it appeared almost certain that Rhode Island would join the nine states, and the District of Columbia, that allow same-sex marriage. The House is expected give final approval next week after considering amendments adopted by the Senate.

Federal regulators on Wednesday accused Capital One and two of its executives of understating millions of dollars in auto loan losses suffered during the financial crisis.
 
The case, which the Securities and Exchange Commission agreed to settle with Capital One and the executives, illustrated a common financial misdeed during the crisis. As losses mounted in 2007 and 2008, some Wall Street firms covered up the woes from the public, prompting a wave of federal actions against Countrywide Financial and other lending giants.

The N.F.L. will distribute to its teams in the next few weeks an information sheet that will reinforce its antidiscrimination policy and will lay out in detail what constitutes discrimination based on sexual orientation and what team members can do about it. The distribution of the information sheet comes after players said they were asked during the Scouting Combine if they liked girls. 
 
During a league investigation, the players could not recall which teams asked the questions and the league determined the comments were made in the form of informal banter and were not asked in an attempt to discern the players’ sexual orientation. But the New York Attorney General’s office asked for a meeting with league officials to discuss the matter and after those meetings, the N.F.L. decided to send out the information sheet.

Two months ago, Billboard began incorporating YouTube views in the formula for computing its all-important Hot 100 singles chart, allowing viral-video smashes to reach No. 1 even if they trailed other songs in sales and airplay, two of the chart’s other criteria. Sure enough, Baauer’s “Harlem Shake,” a huge hit online, sailed to No. 1 in the first week of the new chart.
 
If one artist embodies viral video smashes, it is Psy, the South Korean singer and rapper of “Gangnam Style.” His new song, “Gentleman,” was released two weeks ago, and immediately racked up big numbers on YouTube. It hit 100 million views in four days , and is now at about 218 million. Sounds like a shoo-in for No. 1, right?

WINKELRIED RETURNS, SORT OF Jon Winkelried, the former Goldman co-president, has joined Thrive Capital, the three-year-old venture capital firm, as a strategic adviser to provide guidance as the firm continues to expand. Mr. Winkelried, who joined the firm last month, is the most prominent addition yet by the firm, which has raised $200 million since its inception. And it is perhaps the biggest perch yet for Mr. Winkelried since retiring from Goldman in 2009.
 
MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

As a child, Angela Goethals had a fantasy about the 7,100-foot-long structure between Staten Island and Elizabeth, N.J., that she still calls “my bridge,” even though it no more belonged to her than the George Washington Bridge belonged to Washington’s heirs or the Lincoln Tunnel belonged to Lincoln’s.
 
The fantasy was that she and her sister would set up their own tollbooth. “It was sort of like a lemonade stand on the side of the road,” said Ms. Goethals, 35, a great-great-granddaughter of George Washington Goethals, the Army general and civil engineer for whom the bridge is named. “We thought we’d just sit there and people would pay a toll that would go into our piggy banks.”

LONDON — As European policy makers push financial institutions to cut back on their risky trading activity, some of the region’s largest banks are becoming more reliant on their investment banking operations to bolster performance.
 
On Wednesday, the British bank Barclays and a Swiss rival, Credit Suisse , both reported strong first-quarter earnings for their investment banks that helped to offset some sluggish growth in other divisions like retail banking and wealth management.

No question that the new neoprene collection from the swim label Basta Surf would look smashing in the Beverly Hills Hotel’s legendary pool cabanas. It was conceived, after all, as a homage to the hotel, which celebrated its 100th anniversary last year. For the company’s first foray into Italian neoprene, which is more versatile and comfortable than that used for traditional scuba wear, it fashioned the luxe synthetic into tropical-print pieces to wear day to night, with sandals and heels. There are bikinis, a strapless zip-front maillot, a long-sleeve shorts bodysuit and this cropped top with a contrast white zip up the back (very cool with jeans shorts), $255, and flare skirt, $370 — any of which would make 
 
a major poolside moment.

Because of an editing error, the Skin Deep column last Thursday, about employees who feel the need to conceal their tattoos at work, misstated one of the findings of a Pew Research poll from 2010 about Americans with tattoos. It found that 32 percent of people aged 30 to 45 have a tattoo, not that 32 percent of Americans with tattoos are 30 to 45 years old. The error was repeated in a capsule summary in the Inside The Times index last Thursday on Page A2.

Roundabout Theater Company is planning a revival of the famed musical “Cabaret” at Studio 54 in early 2014 with Alan Cumming starring as the M.C. – the role for which he won a Tony Award in 1998 for a “Cabaret” revival by Roundabout that ended up running at Studio 54 as well.
 
The composer of “Cabaret,” John Kander, confirmed on Wednesday that the production was in the works, although he said that the details had yet to be finalized.

A report last Thursday in the Front Row column about the designer Walter Van Beirendonck misidentified the designer who collaborated on the leather masks in his fall 2012 show, “Lust Never Sleeps.” She is Thomasine Barnekow — not Stephen Jones, who designed the hats in the show.

Thierry Mugler is stepping down as artistic director of Thierry Mugler Parfums. The superhero-proportioned designer had kept a hand in the fragrance business even as the Mugler fashion label was being directed by Nicola Formichetti. Mr. Formichetti just jumped to Diesel, so Mugler (the company) is looking for a designer to oversee both divisions. Mugler (the man) will continue to consult as a “creative adviser.”
 
After 16 years of designing popular C-logo handbags, though not for Chanel, Reed Krakoff will not renew his contract as creative director of Coach. Mr. Krakoff plans to focus on the signature label he started in 2010.

Gary Shteyngart will follow up his three best-selling novels with a memoir, his publisher, Random House, announced on Wednesday. Mr. Shteyngart’s editor, David Ebershoff, described the book as the “candid and deeply poignant story of a Soviet family that comes to America in 1979 to find its future.” 
 
The memoir, “Little Failure,” is scheduled for release in January 2014.

It seemed an easy fix to prevent the excesses of the housing market: make home buyers put more money down.
 
But as the housing market starts to return and the subprime mess fades from memory, the issue is up for debate.

For this in-between season — alternately warm then cold, allergies acting up — culottes are a great transitional garment. Capacious, they create dramatic proportions when worn with a shrug or layered under a big knit for still-cool days. Later on, switch to soft tailoring for a more refined look. At the recent fashion shows, style-setters like Yasmin Sewell (in jewel tones) and Ada Kokosar (in tan leather) gave the look minimalist appeal. Note that culottes for women came about in the Victorian era so that they could ride horseback astride a man’s saddle. Now they make super-chic bottoms for the stylish women who get around town on bikes. 
 
From top: Margaret Howell sailor culottes, $520 at Creatures of Comfort, 205 Mulberry Street, creaturesofcomfort.us ; Rag & Bone pleat-front culotte shorts, $395 at Rag & Bone, rag-bone.com ; Aloha Rag cotton eyelet

Saturdays Surf NYC, known for its beach-cum-big-city cool, is brightening up men’s rain gear for spring — without getting too loud. “Colors for rain jackets can be dull and traditional,” said Josh Rosen, one of the company’s founders. Not so this clean-cut jacket, which has a removable hood and is taped at the seams for added waterproofing. In fresh green or powdery blue, it’s that pop of color a lot of men fear, but done right.
 
Saturdays rain jacket, $299 at Saturdays Surf NYC, 31 Crosby Street; saturdaysnyc.com.

“What am I doing here?” a smiling former President Bill Clinton asked the plush, volubly appreciative crowd packed into Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening. He may have been the effective warm-up act for his friend Barbra Streisand, to whom he was about to present the 40th annual Chaplin Award. Yet when Mr. Clinton sauntered in, taking over host duties with the silky ease of a man accustomed to working the biggest stage in the world, there was no doubt who the biggest star in the room was. For almost anyone else, he would have been a tough act to follow.
 
But this was her night and soon after Ms. Streisand took the stage, this very special FOB (friend of Barbra) slipped into the shadows behind her, perched on a seat like a sideman waiting for his next cue. That came when, a little later, Mr. Clinton introduced Tony Bennett, whose warmly embracing rendition of “Smile” turned the hall into an intimate club, capping an evening that included Wynton Marsalis ‘s playing “Hello, Dolly!,” the very tune Louis Armstrong crooned with Ms. Streisand in the 1969 movie of the same title. Mr. Marsalis brought the cool, Mr. Bennett brought the warmth. But it was Alan Bergman , who with his wife, Marilyn, wrote some of Ms. Streisand’s signature songs, who brought the tears with his gently personalized rendition of “The Way We Were.”

The Ribbon — Microsoft’s tabbed, consolidated command bar for its Office programs — can be overwhelming to new users, but a little customization can make it feel more comfortable. In Office 2010 and Office 2013 for Windows, you can create a personal tab on the Ribbon and add all your favorite most-used commands to it for quicker access.
 
In Office 2010 and later, right-click on any tab on the Ribbon and choose “Customize the Ribbon” from the contextual menu. In the Options box, you can create your custom tab and choose the commands you want to add. Microsoft’s site has instructions (and a demonstration video) for Office 2010 users here. Microsoft Office 2011 for Mac has its own customization options , including the ability to rearrange and hide tabs.

An outfit called Martian Watches has created one of the most advanced options yet to put smartphone technology on your wrist.
 
The three lines of Martian Watches control your Apple or Android phone through a Bluetooth connection, but with a difference — the device has a microphone so you can speak voice commands to your watch that your phone will carry out.

WYMAN--Frank H. Frank H. Wyman passed away on April 21, 2013 at his home in New York, surrounded by his family. He was an inspiration for his generosity, his wit, his pluck, and his love for his friends and family. He will be missed by all those fortunate enough to have known him. He was born on December 19, 1921. He attended Cambridge University and graduated from Harvard University in the class of 1947. With his knowledge of multiple languages, he was an active participant in the business world, achieving success in real estate, construction of container ships, and money management. Since his youth he was an avid sportsman, collecting prizes in golf, tennis, and skiing competitions. He was a member of The Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, The National Golf Links of America, The Meadow Club, The Southampton Bathing Corporation, and the Lyford Cay Club, and he was one of the longest-standing active members of The River Club. He supported the Southampton Dune Church and numerous other causes to which his heart made a commitment. He is survived by his wife Victoria, his brother Thomas, his son and daughter Frederick and Carol, whom he had with his deceased wife Ann, as well as his three grandchildren, Victoria, Nicola, and Andrew. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York City on Thursday, April 25, 2013, 11:00am.

It’s been 30 years since Rupert Pupkin made his notorious debut on “The Jerry Langford Show,” a moment that exists only within the reality of “The King of Comedy,” Martin Scorsese’s dark satire about a struggling standup (played by Robert De Niro) who kidnaps his favorite talk-show host (Jerry Lewis). But it’s also a more tangible milestone for the film’s co-star Sandra Bernhard , who played Masha, an equally unhinged fan who helps Pupkin carry out his twisted show-biz schemes: for Ms. Bernhard, “The King of Comedy” was a breakthrough (for which she was cast from the comedy-club scene in Los Angeles) that garnered critical praise and led her to a wider stage and screen career.
 
“It was a total sea change in my life,” she said recently. “All the dreams that I had were coming true.”

Kindoma Storytime combines e-books with video sharing features. So now you can share a bedtime story with your child or grandchild from anywhere, if you both have iPads, good Wi-Fi, and have downloaded the free app from iTunes .
 
Originally a research initiative at Nokia , the project has been spun off as an independent company with the project leader, Tico Ballagas. According to Mr. Ballagas, the iPad was not around when the project was conceived, but has become the ideal device for delivering synchronous storytimes.

STORRS--Frances Rousmaniere Of Oyster Bay, NY died April 22 peacefully at home at the remarkable age of 100. Her charitable life began in 1929 at the age of 16, when she worked for the summer in Hyden, KY, where her mother's family had funded the Frontier Nursing Service three-room hospital, and rode horses through the back hills to help provide medical care. For the rest of her life, she devoted much of her energy to helping others through a multitude of charities, including Planned Parenthood, Visiting Nurse Services, the Oyster Bay-East Norwich Boys and Girls Club, the Oyster Bay Waterfront Center, Friends of the Bay and many others. She and her husband Richard ("Dick") were leaders in creating Oyster Bay's East Woods School in 1946 and she served the school for many years. Her inquiring mind led to travel all over the world, plus regular courses at Long Island's Hutton House even into her nineties. "Frinnie" graduated from Chapin School in New York City and was one of Chapin's longest-serving Class Secretaries. From its purchase in 1956 to 2013, she opened her home in Cove Neck to all, welcoming anyone who asked to use the house for a fundraiser or wedding. A devoted wife to her late husband, she was a loving mother to her six children: the late Richard Jr. "Nick" (Jeanie) of Lunenburg, MA, Ayer Bellerman of Oyster Bay, David (Landon) of Southport, CT, Ginny Akabane (Gige) of Lenox, MA, Nancy (Jack) of St. Catharines, Canada, and Cleveland, of San Diego, CA, and enjoyed tremendously their stories of travel, sports and academic achievements. She cherished her seven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren and in her nineties was often on hands and knees playing games with them. The Storrs family expresses its appreciation to Hospice of Woodbury, whose superb and compassionate care permitted her to stay in the house she loved so much until her passing, and to the aides who gave her such support. A Memorial Service will be held June 8. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to the Oyster Bay Waterfront Center or East Woods School.

SUTHERLAND--John C.,born September 21, 1928 died peacefully on April 20 at his Brooklyn home surrounded by his brother David and his friends Barbara and Gabe Plumer. He was preceded in death by his two sisters, Mollie Reeve and Janet Sutherland and by his partner and friend Martin Stanford. He is survived by his brother, his brother-in-law William Reeve, his nephews Michael and Timothy Reeve, and by Timothy's children. He received B.A. and M.A. degrees from Yale University in 1950 and 1952 and served in an intelligence unit in the U.S. Army in Germany during the Cold War. His later professional career included work as a trust officer for Irving Trust, as a senior portfolio manager for Lord Abbett, and as a private consultant for Nakagama and Wallace. He generously supported many Brooklyn and Park Slope charities, and served as treasurer of the Montauk Club. He enjoyed spending time at his second home in Honolulu, Hawaii. Contributions may be made to the John Sutherland Memorial Scholarship Fund at the Brooklyn Music School, 126 Saint Felix Street, Brooklyn, NY 11217, a fund whose purpose is to defray tuition expenses for music students at the school. www.brooklynmusicschool.org

SCHARF--Aaron, passed away at the age of 96 on April 23, 2013 at his home in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL, where he and his late beloved wife Blanche lived since 1978. He is survived by his sons Gilbert and Michael (Fiona) and his treasured grandsons, Andrew, William and Benjamin. Before moving to Florida, he was a long-time resident of Sands Point, Long Island, where he was active as head of the Zoning Board, the founder of the Sands Point Civic Association, and an officer of the Community Synagogue. In Florida, he served as the President of the Jacksonville Jewish Federation and as a leading tennis player and umpire, who officiated at many important tournaments. His life was a true American success story. Born in Brooklyn, he lost his father when a teenager. A brilliant student, from grade School through Tilden High School, Brooklyn College, and St. Lawrence Law School, he never received any grade other than an A, except for a C in Contracts at law school, which rankled him for many years. To support himself and his family during the Depression while in college and law school, he worked for the US Postal Service on its mail trains, and during WWII, he trained USAF pilots in radio usage at an air base in South Dakota. After law school, he became a distinguished International patent attorney at Ladas & Parry, where as Senior Partner his roster of clients included Pfizer, Phillips Petroleum, BF Goodrich, Coca Cola, American Home Products, Rohm & Haas Chemical, and General Foods. He was an extremely brilliant, precise and thoughtful person. He possessed clarity of thought and intellectual curiosity throughout his life. He was an extremely generous and wise man who helped many relatives, friends, and charitable organizations with significant financial assistance, contributions, and sage advice. He was a father and grandfather ne plus ultra, and he will be missed by all who knew him. Funeral services will be held at 10am on Thursday, April 25 at Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67th Street, New York.

ETTINGER--Austen A.,90, passed away on April 21, 2013. He was referred to by almost everyone he knew as a "true gentleman." That reflected the small things in his life--holding doors, assisting the elderly across the street, insisting on taking a breath mint while visiting the eye doctor, and saying "thank you" (and meaning it)--as well as all other things in his professional and personal dealings. His interests were expansive, as the Chairman of Jameson Advertising Inc., a media executive, a writer and an occasional historian. He could be very precise--he served in the Air Force when it was still the "Air Corps" he would note, and "cleave" means both "to cling" and "to split". But in many other matters being close enough was good enough, singing being a notable example. He was an observer of convention and a keen student of tradition, and yet a contrarian at times. As he wrote in The New York Times Magazine, in an article entitled "Mum's the Word", he and his wife (of 70 years) almost never quarreled due "to our homegrown, unorthodox formula for tranquility...I never did believe that every question has an answer, even when professed with kindness....few issues are as important as the relationship itself, so why give them significance by giving them focus." Or as he wrote on another occasion in the pages of the same magazine, when continuously asked after retirement if he was keeping busy, "No, was my standard reply, 'keeping indolent." Then he would quietly proceed with his review of the news, films, Broadway, the arts, research on the life of John Peter Altgeld or myriad other interests. He is survived and celebrated for his life by his wife, Shirley Riche Ettinger, his mother-in-law, Marjorie (Marnie) Riche Lewis, his sister, Joan Pastor, his son, John Riche Ettinger, his daughter-in-law, Linda A. Simpson, and his grandchildren, Katharine (Kaki) Simpson, John Tyler and William (Wills) Riche Ettinger. Arrangements will be private and, in lieu of flowers, contributions may be made if you wish to your favorite charity or to one of his, the Austen A. Ettinger Scholarship Fund at Yale University, P.O. Box 2038, New Haven, CT 06521.

BANKER--Pamela Sullivan, an acclaimed interior designer, died of melanoma on April 22. Her career began in London dealing in antiques. In 1964 she returned to the US and launched her own interior design firm, Pamela Banker, Inc. She joined McMillen, Inc. in 1988 as a principal designer and in 1992 became affiliated with Parish-Hadley. When Parish-Hadley closed in 1999 she re-launched her firm, renamed Pamela Banker Associates, which continues under her daughter, Leslie Banker. Pamela is the co-author, with her daughter, of two books, The Pocket Decorator and The Pocket Renovator. Born Pamela Gerli Sullivan in NYC, she attended The Greenwich Country Day School, The Spence School, Manhattanville College and The New York School of Interior Design. Pamela was on the boards of the Preservation League of New York State, The Royal Oak Foundation, the Alumnae Board of The Spence School, and was an officer and active member of the Decorators Club. Pamela is survived by her husband of 46 years, David Banker; her daughter, Leslie Banker Mullins; her granddaughter, Harriet Mullins; her sisters Leslie Sullivan Horn and Christine Sullivan Witker, and her brother, John M. An article on Tuesday about the study of children’s play and the role of play in human evolution omitted the names of two researchers who helped to develop the variation of a game known as Blickets. While Alison Gopnik, the Berkeley psychology professor in whose lab the game was played, invented the main Blickets model with the psychologist David Sobel, a version of the game that the reporter observed was developed later by Dr. Gopnik in collaboration with her colleagues Christopher Lucas and Tom Griffiths.
