An article on Wednesday about the retirement of Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, misstated the number of states that do not have a state sales tax. There are five, not four. Besides Montana, Delaware, New Hampshire and Oregon, Alaska also does not have such a tax. (Mr. Baucus has been fighting his party’s efforts to pass an Internet sales tax.)

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about konzo, a disease that comes from eating bitter cassava that has not been soaked to break down its natural cyanide, described incorrectly the status of efforts to create cassavas with less cyanide. While such cassavas have not become commonly planted around the world, they have been created in the lab and grown on test farms; it is not the case that these efforts “have yet to succeed.”

An article on Tuesday about charges against Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the surviving suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings, using information from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, misstated the age of Sean Collier, a police officer on the campus, who the authorities said was killed in an encounter with Mr. Tsarnaev and his brother, Tamerlan. Mr. Collier was 27, not 26. The error also appeared in two articles and a picture caption on Saturday, and in an article on Monday.

J. C. Penney doesn’t have many fans on Wall Street. But a big one emerged on Thursday: George Soros .
 
Mr. Soros, the hedge fund billionaire, on Thursday disclosed a 7.9 percent stake in Penney, with 17.4 million shares, according to a securities filing. The stake is passive, meaning Mr. Soros will not try to exert influence on the embattled retailer.

John Freeman, the American-born editor of the London-based literary quarterly Granta , has announced that he is departing the magazine, effective July 15. Mr. Freeman, 38, became Granta’s American editor in 2008 and assumed the top post in 2009. He most recently oversaw the publication of the decennial “Best of Young British Novelists” issue , with 20 writers 40 years of age or younger, which has become the magazine’s global calling card.
 
“I loved this job, but I always felt five years would be a kind of marker, and it was,” Mr. Freeman wrote in an e-mail sent on Thursday while he was flying from Seattle to New York. “There’s a next stage now, though,” he added. “And as the books I’ve been meaning to write are beginning to crowd to the front of my mind, it felt time to leave.”

The American Repertory Theater’s recent production of “The Glass Menagerie,” starring the Tony Award-winning actress Cherry Jones as Amanda Wingfield and Zachary Quinto as her son Tom, will transfer to Broadway this September for a 17-week run, the show’s New York producers confirmed on Thursday. 
 
This revival of the Tennessee Williams play received strong critical acclaim during its wintertime run at the theater in Cambridge, Mass.; the New York producers – Jeffrey Richards and John N. Hart – quickly began eyeing a move to Broadway, but theater availability and the actors’ schedules dictated a fall 2013 opening. The production, directed by the Tony winner John Tiffany ( “Once” ), will begin preview performances on Sept. 5 at a Shubert theater to be announced later; opening night is set for Sept. 26, and the run is scheduled through early January 2014.

A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about the effect pollution in China is having on the lives of children gave an incorrect impression of the circumstances under which a 4-year-old boy was shown wearing a face mask. His parents had put the mask on him so a photographer could take a picture of him wearing it, but he normally uses the mask only outside, not while playing indoors at home. The article also misspelled the given name of the grandfather of another 4-year-old in Beijing who wears a mask when he plays outdoors and must have his sinuses washed daily. The Pinyin transliteration of his name is  Zhang Xiaochuan, not Xiaochun.

Apparently those late first-round picks were not as valuable for trade bait as everyone believed.

U.S. URGES CURBS ON PAYDAY LOANS Federal regulators on Thursday urged some of the nation’s largest banks to put restrictions on payday-style loans tied to customers’ checking accounts. The guidance from the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation urged the banks, including Wells Fargo and U.S. Bank, to ensure that borrowers can repay the loans, which otherwise can mire customers in debt and result in a fees that can push interest rates above 300 percent. “For too many consumers, payday and deposit advance loans are debt traps,” Richard Cordray, above, the director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, said in a report on Wednesday. When Ed Sbragia started Sbragia Family Vineyards, it was an accomplishment that was nearly a century in the making.
 
His grandfather moved from Italy to California in 1904 to work in the wineries just north of San Francisco. In the 1940s, Mr. Sbragia’s father bought property in the Dry Creek Valley near Healdsburg and planted zinfandel grapes, which he sold to local winemakers and used for his own home wine.

“Collapse” is quite a bold title for a play that proves so trite. Built on unbelievable situations and uninspired jokes, the script holds enough humor to sustain a sitcom. But as this comedy stretches toward an hour and a half, the only thing that the title invites is an easy attempt to sum up the show.
 
As the story opens, we find the pants-less Hannah (Hannah Cabell) bent over in front of her husband, David (Elliot Villar), in what looks to be a sex act. Oh, ha ha, it’s not — after a string of sophomoric double-entendres we learn that David is giving Hannah fertility drugs. Within minutes they are interrupted by Susan (Nadia Bowers), Hannah’s wacky sister. She’s arrived from halfway across the country, unannounced, with plans to move into the couple’s home, uninvited.

Asif Kapadia, the director of an acclaimed documentary about the race-car driver Ayrton Senna, will next turn his attention to another life lived in a very different fast lane with a film about Amy Winehouse . 
 
 The Associated Press reported that Mr. Kapadia, whose film “Senna” won documentary prizes at the Bafta Awards and the Sundance Film Festival, will work with the producer James Gay-Rees (“Exit Through the Gift Shop”) to tell the story of Ms. Winehouse, the troubled soul singer who died at 27 from accidental alcohol poisoning in 2011.

Shakuntala Devi, an Indian mathematical wizard known as “the human computer” for her ability to make incredibly swift calculations, died on Sunday in Bangalore, India. She was 83.
 
The cause was respiratory and cardiac problems, said D. C. Shivadev, a trustee of the Shakuntala Devi Educational Foundation Public Trust.
TISHMAN--Marcia Wucker. Mom, we miss you dearly and think of you every day. Your love and wisdom is always with us. Kisses to Dad. Love, Steven, Andy, Michael and Robert

The Race for City Hall
 
Some politicians avoid a smoke-filled room. This week, Joseph J. Lhota held a fund-raiser in one.

The first Library of Congress Prize for American Fiction has been awarded to Don DeLillo, the author of “Underworld,” “White Noise,” “Libra” among numerous other works.
 
The prize was inspired by a 2008 award for lifetime achievement in fiction given to Herman Wouk . Starting in 2009, the award, then called the Library of Congress Creative Achievement Award for Fiction, went to John Grisham, Isabel Allende, Toni Morrison and Philip Roth.

Robert Earl Holding, a Western entrepreneur who made his first fortune in the 1950s running a 24-hour service station in an otherwise desolate stretch of Wyoming and became a billionaire whose assets included oil refineries and ski slopes, among them Sun Valley Resort in Idaho, died last Friday in Salt Lake City. He was 86. 
 
The cause was continuing complications of a stroke he suffered in 2002, said Clint Ensign, a senior vice president at Sinclair Companies.

Neil Diamond says he will donate the royalties from this week’s surge in sales of his song “Sweet Caroline” to a fund for victims of the Boston Marathon bombing . He made the announcement on Twitter on Wednesday afternoon .
 
The 1969 hit song is regularly played at Boston Red Sox games and became an unofficial anthem for the rattled city in the aftermath of the bombings on April 15. Sales of the single rose nearly 600 percent last week, to 19,000 copies, up from 2,800 the week before.

The Tribeca Film Festival on Thursday inaugurated its Nora Ephron Prize , for a “woman writer or director with a distinctive voice,” by awarding it to a very surprised Meera Menon, the director of the road-trip comedy “ Farah Goes Bang .”
 
The award, bestowed at a brunch for female filmmakers, includes $25,000 for the winner, and that would be very helpful, Ms. Menon told the crowd, which included Glenn Close, Anna Wintour and Ms. Ephron’s sister Delia. “I have soooo much credit card debt,” Ms. Menon said.

SKOLNICK--Allen H.,on April 24, 2013. Beloved husband of the late Connie. Loving father of Mitchel, Barry and the late Rand. Cherished grandfather of Ryan, Matthew and Jacob. Devoted brother of Edward. Services Friday, 10am at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. www.BoulevardRiverside Chapel.com

MEYERS--Herbert M. Friends of Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design, Jeru- salem mourns the passing of Herbert M. Meyers, longtime friend and supporter of Bezalel, sponsor of the annual Herbert and Edith Meyers Prize in Package Design and grandfather of Bezalel graduate Arielle Shekel. Herb was passionate about design and inspired generations of our design students. We are permanently touched by his love of Israel, of Bezalel and of his wonderful family. Our thoughts are with the Meyers family at this difficult time. Ilan Kaufthal, Chairman Bathsheva Rifkin, President

SKOLNICK--Allen, died on Wednesday, April 24th, after a brief illness. He was 84 years old. Allen Skolnick was a successful business executive, a devoted family man, a major philanthropist and a lover of horses and horseracing. He was born in New York City and received his bachelor's degree in chemistry and biology from New York University. In 1970 he first became associated with the Solgar Company, a pioneering developer and marketer of dietary supplements which was originally established in 1947. He maintained a lifelong interest in the science of nutrition and wellness. Allen was the President of Solgar in 1998 when it was sold to American Home Products Corp. In 1995, Allen and his wife Connie established the CAMBR Foundation which has supported numerous national not-for-profit organizations for nearly fifteen years, including the American Jewish Committee, Hillel Foundation, Birthright Israel, the Weizmann Institute of Science and American Friends of Hebrew University. He and Connie were the principals of Southwind Farms, headquartered in Pennington, New Jersey which remains a premiere breeding farm for standard bred horses. The Skolnick family was involved in the ownership, training and racing of several championship standard bred race horses. Allen was predeceased by his wife Connie and by one of their sons, Rand Skolnick. Survivors include his brother, Edward, of Atlanta; his sons, Mitchel and Barry Skolnick; grandsons Ryan, Matthew and Jacob Skolnick, as well as many dear friends of long good standing who knew Allen and Connie in their varied interests and activities. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the CAMBR Foundation, 410 Ocean Avenue, Lynbrook, New York 11563. Services to be private.

SCHARF--Aaron. We mourn the loss of our beloved Grandpa, Aaron M. Scharf. We will never forget the great times we shared together and the many lessons we learned from you. While we have lost our grandfather, teacher, mentor, coach and friend, we will make sure that your memory lives on forever. Perhaps the most valuable lesson that we can learn from your remarkable 96 year life is the importance of living life to the absolute fullest and making every day count. You are the best and we will always miss you. Love, Andrew, Will & Ben Scharf

KUTNO--Blanche, 93, of Floral Park, NY and Boca Raton, FL., died peacefully on April 24, 2013. Adored wife of Sam, beloved mother of Michael Kutno and Denise Kreitzman, caring mother-in-law of Louis and loving grandmother of Joshua and Jillian. She leaves behind many wonderful relatives and friends as well as a remarkable legacy as an intelligent, creative, generous and stunning individual. Cherished by all who knew her. May her memory live on in all the lives she touched. Services Friday 12 Noon at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opp LIRR), Great Neck, NY.
LEWIS--Leonard, 84, passed away April 25th. Services will be held at Riverside Cemetery Rochelle Park, NJ.

LEE--Elaine, age 99, died April 23rd, 2013 at home in Hartsdale, NY. She was devoted to her family, loving deeply her husband Edward (d. 1986), children Donald (Ronni) and David (Cathy), grandchildren (Andrea, Brandon (Liza), Rachel, and Matthew), as well as her late sister and parents, Sylvia Boehm and Martha and Louis Link. The funeral will be at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains at 10:30am on Friday.

STEIN--Diana M.,85, of Glen Rock, passed away on Wednesday, April 24, 2013. She was a resident of Glen Rock for over 60 years and was a founding member of Temple Israel in Ridgewood and an active member of the community. Prior to her retirement she was a 35 year plus veteran of Amica Insurance Company. Her husband Norton predeceases her. She will be sadly missed by her son David (Rebecca), her daughter Perri (Mario) Procida, grandchildren Dylan, Peter, Michael, Parker, and Thomas. She was a source of strength for all her friends and family, and will be terribly missed. Funeral services will be 10:30am, Sunday, April 28, 2013 at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, w-150 Route 4, Paramus, NJ. http:// www.schoemschapel.com/.

SCHARF--Aaron. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of the beloved father of Michael Scharf, our esteemed President and benefactor, but most of all, our cherished friend. Decades ago, Michael, Fiona and family endowed the Aaron & Blanche Scharf Institute of Advanced Jewish Studies as a lasting tribute to his parents. The Scharf Institute, where the lofty ideals of our sacred Torah heritage are studied in depth, was a most meaningful way to honor Michael's parents since they personified these values. Their honesty, integrity and noble character earned them the crown of a shem tov, a good name, which will endure as a lasting legacy for the Scharf family and a blessing for all. May G-d console them amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Josh S. Weston, Honorary Chairman Robert Kaswell, Chairman Rabbi Ronald Gray, Exec. VP

MALLORY--Pauline Cropper, 92, died peacefully at home in Mystic, CT on April 17. She was born December 8, 1920 to Paul and Airini Carr Cropper in Auckland, New Zealand. On May 11, 1943, in Auckland, she married Clifford Day Mallory Jr., a US Navy Lieutenant. After WWII she and her husband moved to New York City where he launched his career in the shipping business, a family tradition for five generations. Pauline was an accomplished pianist, a student of distinction at The Royal Academy of Music in Piano Performance and a lifetime enthusiast of classical music. More importantly, she devoted her life to her family and many friends worldwide and will be remembered by all as a paragon of selflessness, grace, beauty, humor and kindness. Predeceased by her husband in 2000 and by two siblings, James Cropper and Errol Lovering, she is survived by a brother, John W. Cropper of Auckland and her three children, Diana Mallory Hawes of Pasadena, CA, Veronica Mallory Stubbs (Michael) of New York City and Charles Mallory (Georgette) of Greenwich, CT in addition to seven grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. A gathering in Pauline Mallory's Memory will be held May 31, 12:30pm at Mystic Seaport, Mystic, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Mystic Seaport, P.O. Box 2000, Mystic, CT 06355.

MEYERS--Herbert M. It is with deepest regret that I am mourning the passing of my very dear friend and business partner, Herb Meyers. Herb died on Wednesday at the age of 92. His wife, Edith, and his children were at his bedside. Herb was a wonderful husband, father, grandfather, business leader, inspiration and friend. He had boundless energy, honesty and kindness and we will miss him very much. Herb was a pioneer in package design. In 1970, he joined me to form Gerstman+Meyers, which grew to become a leading international design consulting firm. Herb gained over 100 design awards during his professional career including several Lifetime Achievement awards. After retiring in 1998, Herb co-authored four professional books with me, which kept us closely intertwined: "Branding @ the digital age" (2002), "The Visionary Package" (2005), "CREATIVITY- Unconventional Wisdom from 20 Accomplished Minds" (2007), and "Business Ours" (2012). Jo Ann and I offer our deepest sympathy to Herb's wonderful family. Richard Gerstman

ROSENBLUM--Susan Ullmann, born August 26, 1918 in New York City; died peacefully on April 16, 2013 in Lenox, MA. Previous resident of Hartsdale and Somers, NY, Susan was predeceased by her parents, Joseph and Violet Ullmann; her brothers, Vincent and Joseph 3rd; and her husband of 53 years, H. William Rosenblum. She is survived by her sons, John and Robert; daughter-in-law Carolyn Jones Rosenblum; grandchildren, Kathryn Rosenblum Moxhay and Christopher, Nicholas, Sarah, Jesse and Kaitlin Rosenblum; and great-grandchildren, Olwyn, Imogen and Nikolai Moxhay and Ted and John Michael Rosenblum. A private service and interment will be at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

DAVID--David Salim, MD, a brilliant physician, a loving husband to Vera and father to Lisa and Eric, grandfather to Veronica, Simon and Nathanial, and dear brother to Sami and Karen. Dr. David graduated Summa Cum Laude from Columbia College and Columbia Medical School and headed the first kidney dialysis unit in New York at St. Luke's Hospital. He joined the Rogosin Labs at New York Hospital and was considered there "a once in a lifetime genius in medicine." Taken from us too soon. His brilliant mind and wonderful, gentle heart will be very deeply missed by all of us who love him.

DAVID--David S.,MD, Dearest David, now you are in Hashem's embrace and with our parents and Harry. The mysteries of the universe are now revealed to you. Have a beautiful journey home. We will love you forever. Rena and Sami
HARAP--Frederick. April 11, 2013. Beloved husband, father, grandfather. Honorable man. We love you, always.

ETTINGER--Austen A.,90, passed away on April 21, 2013. He was referred to by almost everyone he knew as a "true gentleman." That reflected the small things in his life--holding doors, assisting the elderly across the street, insisting on taking a breath mint while visiting the eye doctor, and saying "thank you" (and meaning it)--as well as all other things in his professional and personal dealings. His interests were expansive, as the Chairman of Jameson Advertising Inc., a media executive, a writer and an occasional historian. He could be very precise--he served in the Air Force when it was still the "Air Corps" he would note, and "cleave" means both "to cling" and "to split". But in many other matters being close enough was good enough, singing being a notable example. He was an observer of convention and a keen student of tradition, and yet a contrarian at times. As he wrote in The New York Times Magazine, in an article entitled "Mum's the Word", he and his wife (of 70 years) almost never quarreled due "to our homegrown, unorthodox formula for tranquility...I never did believe that every question has an answer, even when professed with kindness....few issues are as important as the relationship itself, so why give them significance by giving them focus." Or as he wrote on another occasion in the pages of the same magazine, when continuously asked after retirement if he was keeping busy, "No, was my standard reply, 'keeping indolent." Then he would quietly proceed with his review of the news, films, Broadway, the arts, research on the life of John Peter Altgeld or myriad other interests. He is survived and celebrated for his life by his wife, Shirley Riche Ettinger, his mother-in-law, Marjorie (Marnie) Riche Lewis, his sister, Joan Pastor, his son, John Riche Ettinger, his daughter-in-law, Linda A. Simpson, and his grandchildren, Katharine (Kaki) Simpson, John Tyler and William (Wills) Riche Ettinger. Arrangements will be private and, in lieu of flowers, contributions may be made if you wish to your favorite charity or to one of his, the Austen A. Ettinger Scholarship Fund at Yale University, P.O. Box 2038, New Haven, CT 06521.

HULL--Philip G.,88, died at his home in Hightstown, NJ, on April 5, 2013 after a long illness. He served with the U.S. Army, 1943-46, and then in the active Army Reserve until retiring as Major in 1963. He was a 1949 graduate of Middlebury College and a 1952 graduate of Columbia University Law School. In 1951 he was a staff member of the King Subcommittee of the House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee, investigating IRS laws. From 1952-63 he was an Associate in the firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts (now Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman), a Partner from 1964-97, and Senior Counsel, 1998-2002. He was a member of the New York State Bar Association, the Florida Bar Association, and the American College of Trust and Estate Counsel. Service on many charitable boards included the Board of National Missions of the United Presbyterian Church, 1967-73, the Latin America Mission, 1969-79, and the Fellowship of Christians in Universities and Schools, 1983-90. He served various Presbyterian churches as Elder and also Trustee, lastly at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, New York City. A long time member of the American Guild of Organists, he also served on the Board of the People's Symphony Concerts, New York City, 1977-2000, and was a founding Director of the Long Island Philharmonic, 1979-81. For over sixty years he was a loving husband to his wife, Gretchen, who survives him, and a loving father to his children Jeffrey, Sanford, and Meredyth Hull Smith, who also survive him, as do his daughters-in-law Bonnie and Belinda, son-in-law Brooks Smith, and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Meadow Lakes Retirement Community, Hightstown, NJ, at 2:30pm on Sunday May 19, 2013.

JEFFERS--Mary Walden Bell ("Wally"), beloved daughter, sister, wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, died April 19, 2013, at the age of 99, in Bloomfield CT. Wally was born in Asheville NC in 1914, the eldest child of Mary Walden (Williamson) Bell and Landon Covington Bell. She grew up with six younger brothers in Columbus OH, and graduated from Wellesley College in 1936. In 1940, Wally married Walter W. Jeffers, an officer of what is now Citibank, whom she had met on a blind date while in college. They resided in Plandome and were active in the Manhasset Congregational Church and in civic affairs. When Walter died, in 1989, she moved to Bloomfield. Wally is survived by three children: Christopher Jeffers, of Hartford CT; Landon Jeffers, of South Huntington NY; and Louise Jeffers Brami of Lexington MA. A second daughter, Gabrielle W. Mangion, died in 1979. She is also survived by six grandchildren: Jonathan Mangion of Galway, Ireland; Sarah Mangion of Fairfax CA; Alex Jeffers of New York NY; Natalie Jeffers of Copenhagen, Denmark; Penelope Jeffers of Cambridge MA; Julia Brown of Merrick NY; and Elisabeth Brami of Lexington MA. Another grandson, Joel Mangion, pre-deceased her. In addition, she is survived by six great-grandchildren. One of Wally's early and lifelong interests was travel. Her adventurous spirit took her, by boat and plane, to the British isles and continental Europe, Greece and Turkey, Latin America, Africa, and India and Nepal. She was an avid painter and devotee of good music and crossword puzzles. Just months ago, culminating a lifetime of reading and fulfilling a long-held ambition, she read "War and Peace". Above all, throughout her life Wally devoted her time and attention to her family and friends, and she died content and peaceful surrounded by them. Of her entire full and happy life, she often declared, simply, "I'm a very lucky lady". A memorial service was held in Bloomfield on April 25. The family asks that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to Doctors without Borders.

BUTLER--Donald B. The Yeshiva University family mourns the loss of Donald B. Butler of Pittsburgh, PA, a revered communal leader who served in the US Army assisting Army chaplains in North Africa and Italy to help Jewish and non-Jewish soldiers. He later helped survivors of the concentration camps transferred through Italy, where he designed and supervised the first new synagogue in Rome in more than 50 years. An ardent Zionist, he was sent to Palestine in 1945 to secure religious articles for Jewish soldiers. Heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Chantze, and their devoted children: Dr. Giti (and Jack) Bendheim, YU Guardians; David J. (and Sharon) Butler; Rabbi Raphael (and Pessy) Butler; and Lani (and Dr. David) Pelcovitz and his grandchildren and great grandchildren. May they all be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor

KLEINMAN--Stuart, 57, of NYC. Brilliant lawyer and filmmaker. Former president Egg Pictures, VP ICM and partner Frankfurt Kurnit. Missed by brother Andrew, sister-in-law Noela, niece Julia, nephew Alex. Service April 28, 10am Plaza Jewish.

DAVIS--Kathryn W. A Memorium of Thanks from students in the Kathryn W. Davis Master's Degree in Peacebuilding. From Afghanistan, "She will be remembered as a great peacebuilder". From Tanzania, "She will continue to live in our hearts". And from Haiti, "someone who trusted young idealist students". A life that lives on through her charge to "prepare for peace, not war". Future Generations Graduate School (future.edu).
ARONAUER--Irwin. Husband of the late Beatrice. Father of Susan, Elyse and Joseph (Peri). Grandfather and great-grandfather. He will be missed.

HAAS CLARK--Irene, of Manhattan, NY, passed away on April 22, 2013, at the age of 83. By her bedside were her children, Jo (Matt) Cohen and Jim Clark. Born and raised in New York, the daughter of Louis and Fifi; protective sister to Alan (Joan); aunt to Ed and Julie (Haas), and very devoted and proud "Grammy" to Marie-Charlotte and Marie-Celeste Clark, Miranda and Mitchell Cohen. Loving wife of 52 years to Philip Clark (deceased, May 2009). Award-winning children's book illustrator/author, admired by and influential to many other artists, and witty and compassionate friend of many more. Memorial Service will be held at the Campbell Funeral Chapel (Madison Ave. and 81st Street) on Friday, April 26th at 11:30am, with a Shiva immediately afterwards at 351 East 84th St., Apt 11E.

An article on Friday about the threat of spreading recession in Europe erroneously included Estonia among the European Union countries that do not use the euro. Estonia adopted the euro in early 2011.

An article on Wednesday about reactions to a New York City proposal to raise the minimum age for buying cigarettes to 21 misstated the military service of one of the people interviewed. A picture caption with the article misspelled that person’s surname and repeated the error about his military service. As the article correctly noted, he is Raul Gonzalez, not Gonzales. Mr. Gonzalez served in the United States Army in the late 1990s, not in the Persian Gulf War, which occurred before he was old enough to serve.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about a legal battle between two financiers, Warren G. Lichtenstein and Andrew Cader, over child support payments to Annabelle Bond, Mr. Lichtenstein’s former girlfriend and Mr. Cader’s current one, misidentified, in some copies, the day on which Mr. Lichtenstein filed suit against Mr. Cader. It was Wednesday, not Thursday.

An article on April 6 about Unicef’s warning that the United Nations will soon have to start cutting off lifesaving aid to people fleeing the civil war in Syria because the exodus has far outstripped support from international donors referred imprecisely to groups that the government of President Bashar al-Assad says it is fighting. A prominent adviser to Mr. Assad accused a well-known Sunni Muslim cleric in Qatar of inciting Sunnis in Latakia, Syria, to revolt in March 2011. In addition to foreigners and Al Qaeda,  Mr. Assad and other government officials say Syria is battling members of extremist sectarian ideologies including Wahabism and takfirism. They have not publicly cited Sunni extremists as the enemy.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about the lawyer Edward de Grazia misidentified the government agency whose censorship of books he challenged in the 1950s. It was the Post Office Department — not the Postal Service, which was created in 1971 to replace it.

An article on Friday about a technical malfunction that halted trading at the Chicago Board Options Exchange for hours on Thursday misspelled the surname of a trader who commented on the uncustomary silence on the trading floor. He is Brian Gilbart, not Gilbert.

An article in some editions on Wednesday about a plan to turn the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx into an indoor ice sports center referred incorrectly to money paid by the developer KNIC Partners to James F. Capalino & Associates for lobbying. In all, $197,500 was paid to lobby the Bronx borough president, Ruben Diaz Jr.; the mayor’s office; and other officials. It is not the case that $182,500 was paid to lobby Mr. Diaz exclusively and $15,000 to lobby the mayor’s office exclusively.

An article on Page 36 this weekend about breast cancer awareness misidentifies the reduction in the chance that a woman in her 50s will die from breast cancer over the next 10 years if she undergoes screening.  Is it .07 percentage points, not .07 percent.

LivingSocial, the daily deals site, told its employees Friday that it had been breached, and said that data for 50 million users might have been compromised.
 
In a memo to employees, the company, based in Washington, said online criminals had gained access to user names, e-mail addresses and dates of birth for some users and encrypted passwords for 50 million people. The company’s databases that store user and merchant credit card and banking information were not compromised in the attack, it said.

A television entry this weekend in the Week Ahead column on Page 4 misidentifies the date that PBS plans to broadcast on its “Frontline” program the documentary “Never Forget to Lie,” which features firsthand accounts of the Holocaust. After the section went to press, PBS moved the broadcast date to May 14 from this Tuesday, April 30.

Public safety has been a major issue in the campaign for mayor of New York this year, and for weeks the candidates have talked at length about whether they would replace the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, whether they would continue to allow the Police Department’s stop-and-frisk practice, and whether the department should be monitored by an inspector general. But on Friday, during a forum on technology, the candidates got a question that posed a new test of their views on police practices: Should the department be allowed to use unmanned drones? 
 
The Race for City Hall

Hardly anybody would have looked for an “I ♥ NY” bumper sticker on George Jones’s tour bus. “The story of him and New York was he just didn’t want to come here,” said Jack Grace, a singer and songwriter who books performers for the Rodeo Bar in Manhattan.
 
Mr. Jones, a country singer with a plaintive voice and a complicated life who died on Friday at 81, told people he did not like Manhattan. But maybe he needed a geography lesson. He did not seem to understand that Manhattan was in New York or that, to many New Yorkers, Manhattan just was New York.

“The Rocket,” Kim Mordaunt’s feature about a 10-year-old Laotian boy who seeks refuge from his difficult life by participating in a rocket-building contest, won two top prizes at this year’s Tribeca Film Festival, claiming the festival’s Founders Award for best narrative feature and its best actor award for Sitthiphon Disamoe, who plays the film’s young protagonist.
 
The festival awards were announced at a ceremony on Thursday night, where the prize for best actress went to Veerle Baetens, a star of Felix van Groeningen’s “Broken Circle Breakdown” ; that film, about the unlikely love between a bluegrass musician and a tattoo-parlor operator, also won the festival’s best screenplay award for the script written by Mr. van Groeningen and Carl Joos.

No straight line connects Benjamin Quarles and Dzhokhar A. Tsarnaev, or stretches from Bayside, Queens, to Copley Square in Boston, or links a largely forgotten gun charge in 1980 to a terrorist bombing this month that inflicted mass casualties and left three people dead.
 
But one knotty legal thread does tie them together: the “public safety exception” to the Miranda warning against self-incrimination that the police are supposed to issue before questioning a suspect.

The four child actresses who rotate in the title role of the Broadway musical “Matilda” will not be eligible for a joint Tony Award nomination for best actress in a musical this spring, the Tony administrative committee ruled on Friday. The decision, the most newsworthy result of a busy committee meeting, sets aside a controversial precedent from 2009 when the three teenage boys sharing the lead role in “Billy Elliot” were deemed eligible for a joint best actor nomination — and went on to win that June.
 
The producers of “Matilda,” itself a front-runner for the best musical Tony this year, had sought joint eligibility for the four girls — Sophia Gennusa, Oona Laurence, Bailey Ryon and Milly Shapiro. Instead of granting that request, the Tony committee announced in a statement that the actresses would receive a special award — Tony Honors for Excellence in the Theater — “to recognize their outstanding performances this season.” As a result, none will be eligible in the best actress category.

“Here Lies Love,” the new David Byrne-Fatboy Slim musical about Imelda Marcos, which opened on Tuesday at the Public Theater to some of the best reviews of the season, has added four weeks of performances through June 30, the theater announced on Friday. The run of the musical, directed by the Tony nominee Alex Timbers (“Peter and the Starcatcher”), had already been extended twice. The 90-minute production at the Public’s LuEsther Hall has quickly become a tight ticket, in part because the space – in which most audience members stand, move and occasionally dance during the show – holds only 160 people.
 
Given the strong reviews, some New York theater producers have been predicting that the Public will run “Here Lies Love” through the summer and then try to move the musical to another, perhaps larger venue. A transfer to Broadway would be trickier, since the show’s 360-degree staging would not fit with the traditional proscenium layout of most Broadway theaters. A spokeswoman for the Public had no comment on the musical’s future beyond the latest extension.

“Duck Dynasty” only gets bigger. It season finale Wednesday night set new ratings records for the A&E network and in the process made even “American Idol” shrink under its growing wingspan.
 
The finale was watched by 9.6 million viewers, the show’s biggest audience yet. Only two shows on broadcast television, “Idol” on Fox (12.5 million) and “Survivor” on CBS (10.3 million), had more viewers Wednesday night.

Propelled by Deron Williams’s dribble penetration and Brook Lopez’s touch inside, the Nets’ scoring flowed steadily in their Game 1 blowout of the Chicago Bulls. But since that game’s final buzzer, the Nets’ offense has been reduced to a trickle. The Bulls have constricted Brooklyn’s options and diverted the action to its least potent offensive players.
 
 In their loss in Game 3 on Thursday , the Nets managed only 76 points and shot 34.6 percent from the field, their second worst shooting output of the season. After shooting 35.4 percent in Game 2 on Monday, it is fair to say the Nets’ offense is in a state of crisis.
HAZAN--Leslie Beth. To my daughter on her 50th Birthday. You are in my heart today and always.
LERNER--Jack Newton. 7 years lovingly remembered. Evelyn, Iris, Richard, Ana, Jennifer & Adam.

Here is my deep, dark secret from high school: I didn’t go to the prom.
 
It’s a long story, filled with teenage angst. But suffice it to say, I missed an American rite of passage — and I survived.

Recently, I got something in the mail that I haven’t seen in awhile: an offer of a credit card with a zero percent introductory rate that stretched for 18 months — for both new purchases and balance transfers.
 
Apparently, I’m not alone. In fact, if you have a strong credit rating and are in the market for a new card — or perhaps have a big purchase you want to pay off over time, with no interest costs — now may be the time to consider applying for one.

This past Saturday, I wrote my Shortcuts column on why people don’t respond to e-mails. And boy, did I get a lot of responses. Clearly many readers out there are fuming over their in-boxes.
 
One reader, Marc Allan of Indianapolis, e-mailed to tell me that when he didn’t get a response, “I would send another one with the subject line: ‘Are you still alive?’ I would then say: ‘When someone doesn’t respond to my e-mails, I worry that they suffered an untimely death. Please reassure me you are still alive.’ That always got a response. Now, though, I’m just going to send them Alina Tugend’s article, using the headline as the subject. So, thanks for that.”

POLLACK--Stanley. It is with great sadness that the Rosenthal family mourns the loss of their dear friend, Stanley Pollack. For forty years, Stanley served first as General Counsel and more recently as Senior Executive Vice President of Rosenthal & Rosenthal, Inc. Throughout his career, Stanley distinguished himself as not only an outstanding attorney, but also as an innovative thinker and deal maker. His door was always open, whether you were seeking legal counsel or personal advice. Stanley made an indelible mark on the company that he served so loyally during his career, but he will be remembered most for being a mentor and trusted friend to so many in the Rosenthal family. Our thoughts and prayers go out to Stanley's daughter, Jane.

ROSS--Jimmy Lee Born on March 7, 1952 in Darlington, South Carolina, he graduated from Roosevelt Jr. Sr. High School in Roosevelt NY. In 1972, he joined the US Armed Forces where he served two years, being honorably discharged in 1974. He was gainfully employed by the New York Times Newspaper retiring after 30 years. He returned to Darlington, SC where he became a dedicated member of Salvation Temple in Hartsville SC. Left to enjoy his memories, are his mother, Thelma Gilliard, wife Betty J. Ross, his nine children, Patricia Howard, Jimme Howard, Jacqueline Ross Merchant and her husband Jacob Merchant, Xavier Johnson and Leia Little of Nassau County, NY. Michelle Ross of Lamar SC, Elizabeth Ross Robinson and her husband Demetrius Robinson of Florence, SC, Jillian Ross Young (Ret. Vet) and her husband Ricardo Young (active military) of Clarksville, TN, Julius Ross of Florence SC, 25 grandchildren, two sisters and five brothers. He departed this earth on April 10, 2013. We, the family of the late Jimmie lee Ross, thank everyone for all the acts of love and Christian concern extended to us during our time of bereavement. Please know that each act of kindness was greatly appreciated.

Nussbaum--John, 91, renowned stained glass painter, designer, and restorer on April 24, 2013. He was the loving husband of Annette Wysocki and father of Richard. His stories of the Bohemian life in Greenwich Village, challenging queries, and talent as a painter was and is unrivaled. He loved books and his intellectual curiosity never waned. His ability to see things in new ways and insight were remarkable. He was the Founder of Glassmasters, Inc. and was a member of the National Arts Club. He will always be remembered for his humility and willingness to mentor other developing stained glass artists. His life's work will be viewed in church windows, museums, public buildings, and private homes for centuries to come.

HESS--Susan Berman, of New York City died on April 25th after a long battle with cancer. She is survived by her devoted husband of 32 years, Mortimer (Terry) Hess, her beloved brother, Michael Berman, his wife Sally, and her two nieces, Laura and Stephanie Berman. Susan was born and raised in New York City where she worked for JP Morgan Chase for 23 years. Funeral services will be held Sunday, April 28th at 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

NARASIMHAN--Robin Rose, passed away on 25th March 2013. She married Lakshmi Narasimhan and had a happy, loving and exciting life for 20 years. Robin and Lakshmi have a loving beautiful and precious 14 year old daughter Patrice Narasimhan. Patrice and Lakshmi find this loss profound and are at a loss for words. Robin was the daughter of Howard Keen and Patricia Keen. Robin was predeceased by her mother, Patricia Keen, and her grandmother, Bunny. Robin attended New York University and completed her Bachelor of Arts, majoring in Psychology. She is loved and missed by her father, step-mother Karen Keen, in-laws Singarachari Ranganathan and Chandra Ranganathan. Robin was a wonderful lady with a great sense of humor and a selfless love for life. She will be greatly missed by a wide circle of family, friends and colleagues.

DAVID--David Salim, MD, a brilliant physician, a loving husband to Vera and father to Lisa and Eric, grandfather to Veronica, Simon and Nathanial, and dear brother to Sami and Karen. Dr. David graduated Summa Cum Laude from Columbia College and Columbia Medical School and headed the first kidney dialysis unit in New York at St. Luke's Hospital. He joined the Rogosin Labs at New York Hospital and was considered there "a once in a lifetime genius in medicine." Taken from us too soon. His brilliant mind and wonderful, gentle heart will be very deeply missed by all of us who love him.

DAVID--David S.,MD, Dearest David, now you are in Hashem's embrace and with our parents and Harry. The mysteries of the universe are now revealed to you. Have a beautiful journey home. We will love you forever. Rena and Sami
HARAP--Frederick. April 11, 2013. Beloved husband, father, granddad. An honorable man. We love you, always.

LEE--Elaine, age 99, died April 23rd, 2013 at home in Hartsdale, NY. She was devoted to her family, loving deeply her husband Edward (d. 1986), children Donald (Ronni) and David (Cathy), grandchildren (Andrea, Brandon (Liza), Rachel, and Matthew), as well as her late sister and parents, Sylvia Boehm and Martha and Louis Link. The funeral will be at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains at 10:30am on Friday.

GALLANTZ--George G.,passed away on April 24, 2013, the day after his 100th birthday. All of us at Proskauer Rose LLP mourn his passing. George will be remembered as a "lawyer's lawyer," known for his outstanding legal skills, wealth of experience and insight and special touch for teaching younger lawyers. A Proskauer partner since 1963, George mentored an extraordinary group of lawyers who have had an enduring impact both on our Firm, as well as on the legal and sports world including Michael Cardozo, New York City's Corporation Counsel; David Stern, Commissioner of the National Basketball Association and Gary Bettman, Commissioner of the National Hockey League. The founding father of Proskauer's Sports Law Practice, George leaves behind a legacy of commitment, brilliance, friendship and uncompromising integrity. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. He will be missed by all who knew him family, friends, colleagues and clients alike. Joseph M. Leccese Chairman Proskauer Rose LLP

GRUMBACH--Leonard, October 3, 1923 - April 24, 2013, of Roslyn, NY, after a brief illness. Devoted husband of Sandra and Aileen (both deceased) and father of Diane Selinger (Neil), Carol Grumbach (Michael Cohen) and Lillian Nayder (Matt Johnson). Grandfather of William, Sam, Nate and George. WWII Army veteran, two bronze stars. Proud graduate of CCNY and Hofstra Law. Dedicated labor law attorney. He will be missed for his wit, sharp intellect, concern for others, and passion for social justice. Funeral services Sunday, April 28 at noon at Schoem's Chapel in Paramus, NJ.

KLEINMAN--Stuart, 57, of NYC. Brilliant lawyer and filmmaker. Former president Egg Pictures, VP ICM and partner Frankfurt Kurnit. Missed by brother Andrew, sister-in-law Noela, niece Julia, nephew Alex. Service April 28, 10am Plaza Jewish.

BULMAN--Carole K. age 70, died April, 18th at her home in Wainscott, NY after a long courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Raymond F. Bulman, she is survived by her son Raymond K. Bulman and siblings Barbara, Elaine (George), Virginia, Paul and Michael (Mary). Carole was a born leader and founded a successful manufacturing business in 1973, Carole Kasbar Inc. She was widely regarded as a role model for women in business of her generation. Carole brought ardent resolve to everything she did, big and small, -- always with impeccable grace, style and genuine kindness. As a mother and wife, her love knew no bounds; she was the axis on which her family revolved. She will be in our hearts forever.

ABORN--Hermine Friedman 98, passed away on Friday, April 12, 2013 at Greenwich Hospital. Hermine was born in New York City on March 8, 1915. She was predeceased by her husband of 59 years, Louis Aborn, in 2005. She is survived by her son, Sargent Aborn, daughter-in-law, Audrey Aborn, daughter, Nancy Aborn Duffy and son-in-law, Kenneth Duffy, six grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Hermine was a matriarch and an inspiration for her generosity and joie de vivre. Memorial gifts in Hermine's name may be made to Greenwich Hospital.

BRANDRETH--John Breckenridge, died peacefully on April 23rd, 2013 in his home in Cliffside Park, NJ. after a long and difficult illness which he bore with great courage and patience. He is survived by his wife, Elisabeth Gatterburg Brandreth, his children John B. Brandreth, Lee T. Brandreth, Barbara Brandreth Zuerrer and Geoffrey L. Brandreth, three grandsons and one great-granddaughter. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, April 27th at the Macagna Funeral Home in Cliffside Park at 3 o'clock. After having served in the U.S. Army during World War II, John Brandreth began a career in international business which took him all over the world. After retirement, he founded Condor Corporation, in which he was active until two years ago. Fluent in Spanish, he loved to travel and enjoyed the company of his many friends. He will be deeply missed by all.

BARNETT--James L.,of Rye Brook, passed away on April 25, 2013 at age 79. Jim was born in New York City to the late Ben and Helen Barnett. He was a graduate of the Wharton School of Finance, University of Pennsylvania class of 1955 and went on to obtain a MBA degree from the Bernard Baruch School of Business. He worked most of his career as the chief executive officer for Publix Shirt Corp. Beloved husband of Sue, devoted father to David Barnett (Beth), Amy Spadafino (Frank). Pop pop to Jonathan, Peter, Mia Spadafino and Danielle and Julia Barnett. Loving brother to Alice Schachter (Sherman). Jim will be deeply missed and forever in our memory. Funeral services will be held on Sunday at 11:45am at Congregation B'Nai YIsrael in Armonk. Interment will follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery. For more information or to place an online condolence, www.zionchapel.com.

Our next online meeting will be this Monday evening, to discuss Daniel Okrent’s “Great Fortune: The Epic of Rockefeller Center.”
 
When Rockefeller Center opened in 1939 after a decade of construction, it was not received with the glory we shower on it now. Newspapers were filled with letters calling it one of the ugliest complexes in the city. The building of what today is considered one of the crown jewels of the Manhattan skyline is a saga of big money, intriguing power brokers and one of the most glamorous periods in the city’s history.

An article on Feb. 10 about the resignation of Germany’s education minister over plagiarism allegations and about the German obsession with academic and professional titles, misstated the professional qualifications of Germany’s vice chancellor, Philipp Rösler. He is a medical doctor, not an ophthalmologist; he did not complete the requirements for that specialization. Americans as well as Germans would still call him “doctor.” The error was first pointed out on Wednesday, by a reader.

An entry in the Video column on April 14 about the 1984 film “Repo Man” misattributed a well-known quotation about driving and misstated a word in that quotation. It was Miller (played by Tracey Walter), not Bud (Harry Dean Stanton) who said, “The more you drive, the less intelligent you are” — not “the less intelligent you get.”
An article on April 14 about the fashion designer Riccardo Tisci described incorrectly the location of Cermenate, Italy, where he was born. It is in northern Italy, not southern.

An article on April 14 about the portrayal of Washington on television misidentified the TV commentator who played himself in the movie “Olympus Has Fallen.” It was Lawrence O’Donnell who reported on a terrorist attack on the White House in the film, not Chris Matthews. And an accompanying picture caption misstated the given name of the actor shown with Kerry Washington in the TV show “Scandal.” He is Tony Goldwyn, not Sam.

An article on April 14 about the Milanese town house owned by Claudio Luti, the chief executive officer of the Italian furniture company Kartell, and his wife, Maria, misidentified the interior designer who worked for the house’s previous owner. It was decorated by Verde Visconti — not by Renzo Mongiardino, who worked on another house for the previous owner.
A report last Sunday, about the marriage of Donna Kerr and Patricia Dawson, misspelled the location of Allegheny College. It is in Meadville, Pa., not Neadville.
An article on April 14 about Cicely Tyson, who is on Broadway in the current revival of “The Trip to Bountiful,” misstated the year “Bountiful” was adapted for film. It was 1985, not 1987.

Here’s a fact that may not surprise you: the children of the rich perform better in school, on average, than children from middle-class or poor families. Students growing up in richer families have better grades and higher standardized test scores, on average, than poorer students; they also have higher rates of participation in extracurricular activities and school leadership positions, higher graduation rates and higher rates of college enrollment and completion.
 
Whether you think it deeply unjust, lamentable but inevitable, or obvious and unproblematic, this is hardly news. It is true in most societies and has been true in the United States for at least as long as we have thought to ask the question and had sufficient data to verify the answer.

Mary Thom, a renowned writer, editor and intellectual in the feminist movement, died on Friday in a motorcycle accident in Yonkers. The Women’s Media Center, where Ms. Thom was the editor in chief, announced her death on Saturday.

A museums and galleries listing in the Long Island Calendar in some editions last Sunday gave an outdated closing date for the exhibit “Portraits of Our Past: Greek Jews and the Holocaust,” at the Holocaust Memorial and Tolerance Center in Glen Cove. It has been extended through Aug. 15; it did not end last Sunday.

Perched high in the south tower of the Time Warner Center at 25 Columbus Circle, a glassy corner condominium with unobstructed northern and eastern views of Central Park and the cityscape from every room sold for $13 million, the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.
 
This seven-room residence, No. 69B, sold for $12.25 million in 2008 and had bounced on and off the market since 2011. It had been listed for as much as $16.9 million, but sold quickly after its asking price was reduced by $1 million to $13.98 million. That, apparently, is the difference a million dollars makes at this juncture in an active market; though the 2,317-square-foot unit offered the option of buying the modernist furnishings along with the property, it was sold unfurnished.

An article last Sunday about the refusal by relatives of nine people killed during a 2010 Israeli raid of a Gaza-bound, Turkish-led flotilla to accept compensation promised by Israel until the Israeli government fully removes its restrictions on people and goods moving in and out of Gaza misidentified the country under whose flag the flotilla’s lead ship, the Mavi Marmara, was flying. It was the flag of Comoros, not Turkey. (The ship had flown under the Turkish flag at one time.)
 
Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the nature of the fighting aboard the Mavi Marmara, and it paraphrased incorrectly the Israeli assertion about how the attack had begun. It was a deadly fight; it was not a firefight because those aboard the ship were armed with weapons that included knives and sticks, but not guns. The Israelis said its commandos were attacked first; they did not say they were “fired on” first.

In honor of this week’s celebration of Earth Day, T is feeling for the Swiss jeweler Gilbert Albert’s rings with interchangeable stones. The bands, available in silver or gold, hold pearl-shaped gemstones that can be swapped out on a whim. There are more than 80 different precious stones to choose from, ranging from the standard amethyst, tiger’s-eye and lapis lazuli to the more grand leopard jasper, chrysoprase and mother-of-pearl. This collection gives “recycle, reuse, reduce” a whole new meaning.
 
Gilbert Albert interchangeable ring collection, from $700 (stones from $30); gilbertalbert.com .

Sometimes the most buzz-worthy and best dressed on the red carpet are the miniature offspring of fashion-forward moms and dads (Suri Cruise, Harper Beckham) sporting the same labels as their parents are. Today Colleen and Roberto Crivello, the husband-and-wife partners behind the New York-based creative brand consultancy FDS Design Studio, are turning the tables with the debut of their edgy collection of kids’ wear that they’re touting as “Clothes for Kids That Moms Want Too.” Chalk NYC , the line made for and inspired by their two-and-a-half-year-old daughter, Alba, is for the discerning 2-10-year-olds who prefer their pants in stretch leather and their tees in Pima cotton.
 
Chalk NYC collection, $48-$698; available now on chalknyc.com and in July at Barneys.

Though her filigree doodles of deceptively innocent-seeming flora and fauna were a fixture on the downtown gallery scene a decade ago, the artist Simone Shubuck has had only one solo show in the last six years — in 2009, at Corbett vs. Dempsey in Chicago. During that time, she married Adam Rapoport, the editor in chief of Bon Appetit magazine; became a mother; oversaw a protracted apartment renovation; and stepped away from her other career as a floral designer. Though she’s slowed her formerly frenetic output, she has continued to privately hone her technique, integrating abstract forms in pure, vibrant color. “My pace changed dramatically; I had to get to a new place in my life,” she says. “Having different identities brought me to a different place in my work.”
 
The effervescent result — the April 27 opening of “Do You Like Old Things or New Things That Look Old?” in Taylor de Cordoba’s new space in Los Angeles — is worth the wait. The show’s title is a question Shubuck once overheard from the mouth of a teenage boy, and it continues to haunt her. Working on the backs of vintage lithographed book pages, Shubuck forgoes the birds she was once known for, collaging drawings and photographs from her own past alongside loose, gestural brushwork inspired by her art-school beginnings. For the first time, some of her works also appear on large-scale sheets, intimate detail intact. The interplay between abstraction and figuration feels deeply personal, because it is. “It’s a happy and exciting tension,” Shubuck says.

The state of Georgia may soon execute Warren Lee Hill, Jr., an intellectually disabled man with an I.Q of 70. Under a 2002 Supreme Court ruling it is unconstitutional to execute him or anyone in that category — but the Constitution, in this case, may not win out.
 
Three experts concluded in 2000 that Mr. Hill was not intellectually disabled. But they have since reviewed the evidence about his mental capacity and have changed their minds. The doctor whose evaluation heavily influenced the prior finding said his work was “rushed,” “unreliable” and “in error.” He and other experts have all said that Mr. Hill is disabled, beyond a reasonable doubt. There is no question that Mr. Hill will spend his life in jail: He was convicted of murder. He is merely trying to get off death row. This week, however, by 2-1, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit denied Mr. Hill’s request to confirm his disability in court with new evidence. It did so because his appeal did not fit the restrictive terms of the Anti-Terrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act — in particular, that new evidence must raise doubt as to guilt, rather than the appropriateness of the punishment.

Peacocking, the preening of fastidiously dressed males of the fashion flock, has been exhaustively documented of late by international street fashion photographers who track willing prey in their natural habitats: outside fashion shows, fabulous parties and glitzy store openings where the rare birds tend to gather. The origin of this dandy species, Beau Brummel (1778-1840), and his fanciful progeny are the subject of the exhibition “Artist/Rebel/Dandy: Men of Fashion” at the Museum of Art Rhode Island School of Design , opening April 28. The curators, Kate Irvin and Laurie Brewer, from the school’s department of costume and textiles, have capitalized on this recent surge of interest in the artistry and craftsmanship of men’s wear with their study of clothing and ephemera honoring the aesthetic provocateur. Aided by an archive that includes the personal wardrobe of Richard Merkin, a legendary RISD professor, painter and dandy-in-residence, the curators constructed a thematic, rather than chronological, exploration into what they term the “always provocative dandy stance.” Delving deeper than the decorative surface, they contrast the social subversion of dandy “revolutionaries,” who express political views through their personal wardrobes, with a dandy “historian’s” appreciation of tailoring tradition, while a “connoisseur” prides self-expression over societal conformity. Thom Browne says in the accompanying catalog’s preface that “Rebellion comes from being perfectly comfortable doing my own thing and having the drive to make challenging statements in men’s wear.” According to the curators, by “kicking at the boundaries of taste,” the dandy is indeed much more than the commonly criticized “superficial person devoted only to the outer shell.”

Sketching in Pastels The glories of spring are at a peak, and the tulips and hyacinths reflect the diversity of present-day fashion. The green of the trees is as fresh as the grass on a Swiss mountainside, forming a lacy canopy over all. Cherry blossoms are ready to bloom, and art students set up their easels in the parks. Women (bottom row) headed to a lecture on ecosystems at the American Museum of Natural History. On Earth Day , 100 young volunteers, all employees of Macy’s, spread mulch around the trees surrounding the museum and painted its fence. And what would spring be without balloons, their bright colors reflected in a red pleated shawl.

An article last Sunday about 38 Studios, the video game company of the former baseball star Curt Schilling, misstated the given name of the director of the Rhode Island Economic Development Corporation who voted against investing in the company in 2010. He is Karl Wadensten, not Kurt. The article also referred incorrectly to another director (not named in the article) who served during that period. The director, Alfred J. Verrecchia, was the chairman and a past chief executive of Hasbro, not the C.E.O. at the time.
 
The article also misattributed the statement that the development corporation’s various committees held 63 meetings from September 2010 to May 2012 without discussing 38 Studios’ financial health. It was reported on GoLocalProv.com , not in The Providence Journal. And the article referred incorrectly to work on a highway running through the Providence “knowledge district” for new businesses. The highway was relocated but was not buried underground.

“It started in a really strange way,” said Joseph Altuzarra, recalling a day last summer on Fire Island when the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon invited him to design costumes for a new ballet that he was presenting at the New York City Ballet ’s spring gala, on May 8. Although Mr. Altuzarra was friendly with the choreographer, he admitted that, out of courtesy, he had never asked too many questions and so didn’t fully know what Mr. Wheeldon did. “He said, ‘Oh, I’d love to do a ballet together,’ ” Mr. Altuzarra recalled, with a sheepish grin. “I was like, ‘Sure.’ ”
 
Suffice it to say, after more than a month of observing rehearsals and much sketching, Mr. Altuzarra is up to speed. Mr. Wheeldon will present two ballets for the gala: a reworking of his “Soirée Musicale,” with costumes by Holly Hynes, and a new pas de deux, set to “Interlude” from André Previn’s “Sonata for Clarinet and Piano” and Leonard Bernstein’s “Sonata for Clarinet and Piano,” featuring Tiler Peck and Robert Fairchild. Mr. Altuzarra has designed their costumes.

Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday, about the marriage of Rabbi Rachel Isaacs and Melanie Weiss, referred incorrectly to Ms. Weiss. She is neither a rabbi nor the spiritual leader of Beth Israel Congregation in Waterville, Me., titles held by Rabbi Isaacs. The report also misstated Rabbi Isaacs’s role at Colby College. She is the campus rabbi, not the spiritual leader.

An article last Sunday about the Kenguru, an electric neighborhood car marketed by Community Cars for wheelchair users, misspelled the given name of the chief executive. She is Stacy Zoern, not Stacey.

Clinton Co-op

 
$845,000

A smoke-breathing dragon made of about 400,000 Lego bricks is just one of the amenities at the Legoland Hotel (above) that opened this month in Carlsbad, Calif. The 250-room hotel, the first in the United States, is just steps from the Legoland theme park. It is designed with a shorter clientele in mind: its rooms, decorated according to themes like adventure, pirate and kingdom, feature bunk beds and a trundle bed with night lights, and its restaurant’s buffet is low enough for children to serve themselves.

Rhode Island’s Senate — including all five Republican members — voted 26-12 on Wednesday in favor of legislation to allow same-sex couples to marry. Once Gov. Lincoln Chafee signs the bill, which is expected to happen next week, marriage equality will be the law in every New England state (Rhode Island plus Massachusetts, Connecticut, Vermont, New Hampshire, and Maine) — a meaningful victory for civil rights and a proud distinction for the region.
 
Rhode Island’s advance adds to the building sense of momentum for marriage equality. But it in no way obviates the need for action from the Supreme Court, which is of course currently weighing decisions on California’s Proposition 8 and the federal Defense of Marriage Act.

Woodbury Contemporary

 
$1,475,000

Fewer and fewer people are left who can give us firsthand accounts of their experiences with the Holocaust. “Never Forget to Lie,” a presentation of PBS’s “Frontline” on Tuesday (check local listings), presents some of those voices. One belongs to the filmmaker, Marian Marzynski . Mr. Marzynski, the documentary relates, was 5 when his Jewish parents handed him over to Christians, and he ended up in a Roman Catholic orphanage.
 
“My childhood still seems to be my psyche’s unfinished business,” he says in the film, one of several he has made about his experiences. “They told me that to stay alive, I must forget who I was.”

Mineta San Jose International Airport , Silicon Valley’s launchpad in San Jose, Calif., received the city’s approval this month to negotiate a lease with Signature Flight Support to build an elite corporate jet center. Five of the seven hangars in the 29-acre, $82 million facility will be reserved for planes owned by Google executives, including Eric Schmidt (above).

Harrington Park Center-Hall Colonial

When I finally saw the show for the first time in 2011, it turned out to be one of the most intense theater experiences of my life. There were no over-the-top sets, no special effects, just a couple of chairs, two tables, a few props and two incredible actors: Christian Alexander Müller and Joana Fee Würz. The production was held in a tiny basement theater in Germany, the Chemnitzer Kabarett, with less than 150 seats. It felt wonderfully intimate, almost a bit voyeuristic, as if I was sitting in Cathy and Jamie’s living room watching their relationship unfold right in front of me. 
 
Annegret Hintze, 26, Dresden, Germany

I wanted to propose to Alex, my girlfriend, with something public or fun, with a lot of our friends. I’m not a great singer, but I love to ham it up. Her favorite song from the show is “The Schmuel Song.” We went to a karaoke bar in New York, where most of our friends live, and I changed the lyrics at the end of the song to make it a proposal.  The original goes: “Say goodbye to wiping ashtrays at the bar/Say hello to Cathy Hiatt, big-time star.” I changed it to: “Be more than just my girlfriend on this day/Say hello to Alex Cook my fiancée.” That’s when I pulled out the ring. 
 
When we got married our rings were inscribed, above, with the words “How lucky I am,” from the last line of “The Schmuel Song.”

For the better part of a year, the country has survived, somehow, without a House Tea Party Caucus. A group that once boiled with anti-government furor went dormant last summer as the Tea Party’s popularity plummeted and its leader, Michele Bachmann, struggled to get re-elected. Ten caucus members lost their jobs in November. The sniping about the House Republican leadership — not to mention President Obama — quieted down, and so did the tweets championing Barry Goldwater’s still-radioactive support of extremism .
 
(The caucus also brought us gems like this one, from the caucus’s Twitter stream last July : “This week’s featured Member is @RepToddAkin. Click here to learn more about him: http://tiny.cc/00o6gw #tcot #TeaParty.” Hint: don’t bother to click.)

The car-sharing unit of the rental car company Hertz is expanding in the coming months, the company said. The service, Hertz 24/7 , will extend a car-sharing model that had been available in urban areas and college campuses in the United States, and in five other countries, to suburban and rural areas. It also will improve ease of use, with self-service features including keyless entry and a flexible rental term. Hertz said that the rollout, which will eventually provide service to “the vast majority of Americans,” will begin in late summer in the United States, followed soon after in Europe, and later in China.

Movement Electronic 

 
Music Festival, Detroit

Truth, principle and the secular Indian way come in for a drubbing in Feroz Abbas Khan’s “Dekh Tamasha Dekh,” the opening-night feature of the 13th-annual New York Indian Film Festival. Mr. Khan’s film — like the festival’s centerpiece, “Shahid” (about Shahid Azmi , a human-rights activist and lawyer who was killed in 2010), and its closer, “Filmistaan” — concerns Hindu-Muslim relations, and the news is mostly bad. In “Dekh,” a battle plays out over a poor man’s dead body. Was the man — killed by the falling effigy of a politician, no less — a Muslim or a Hindu? Was he Hamid, as he died, or Kishan, as he was born? Should he be buried or cremated? Based on a true story, Mr. Khan’s kaleidoscopic movie finds that fertile Indian place where farce meets tragedy, with neither quite getting the upper hand. 
 
The festival also features a small sidebar celebrating the 100th anniversary of Indian film, which includes a rare chance to see the sui generis “Kalpana” (1948), a film about classical dance, told through classical dance and directed by Uday Shankar, a classical dancer (and Ravi’s brother). (Tuesday through May 4; schedule and information: iaac.us/nyiff2013 .)

Since prehistoric times, visionaries have looked beyond the limitations of mortality toward realms of regeneration and new life. The Stephen Petronio Company is doing such searching, choreographically, in Mr. Petronio’s new “Like Lazarus Did (LLD 4.30),” inspired by myths and concepts of resurrection. Mr. Petronio has been appointed the Joyce Theater’s first artist in residence, a post that gives him opportunities to focus entirely upon artistic matters. His collaborators on the evening-long “Lazarus” include Janine Antoni, a visual and performance artist, and Son Lux, whose score draws upon spiritual music and texts, from American slave songs to the meditative drones of Eastern mysticism. 
 
It will be performed live by an ensemble that includes members of the Young People’s Chorus of New York City. Mr. Petronio will also do some choreographic resurrections. Although most of his movement material is new, he has incorporated into it fresh treatments of choreography created over his company’s 28-year history. (7:30 p.m. Tuesday and Wednesday, 8 p.m. Thursday-Saturday, 2 p.m. and 7:30 p.m. on May 5, Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, 212-242-0800, joyce.org ; $10-$59.)

The across-the-board spending cuts known as the sequester may have vanished from public consciousness a couple of news cycles ago, but travelers visiting national parks and monuments and museums in Washington this summer will find sporadic reminders of them, testimony at a recent Congressional hearing suggests.
 
The Smithsonian Institution will occasionally close some galleries in its art museums beginning May 1. “We’re trying to juggle things to have less impact on the public,” said Linda St. Thomas, a spokeswoman. “But every museum will be open every day for normal hours,” she said of the museums and the National Zoo.

I made a mix CD for my girlfriend, now my wife, when we started dating. She went to Indiana University and I was at the University of Kentucky at Lexington, about a three-hour distance. I compiled a set of songs that I thought she would appreciate from recent musical theater she hadn’t heard of. From “The Last Five Years” I included “Shiksa Goddess.” She’s not Jewish. She’s of Indian descent and I’m of Western European lineage.  The humor of the song was the point. Since then we’ve seen it about five times, including productions in London; Cincinnati; and Oxford, England.   
 
Doug Reside, 34, New York City (With his wife, Marilyn, left, and their mementos.)

It was especially fulfilling to do the production at East West Players in Los Angeles, which traditionally promotes Asian-American talent in nontraditional casting. We didn’t play it with any kind of gimmicks. The one thing I do remember having to justify was believing Jamie was Jewish, since we had a Korean-American actor, Michael K. Lee, playing him. In our research we found there are quite a number of Korean Jews. 
 
Jennifer Paz, 39, Chicago (left, with Mr. Lee as Jamie)

International motor shows offer some of the best opportunities for auto manufacturers to strut their stuff, both in terms of what is and what could be. In the latter vein, the world’s car designers showed off an impressive array of bold-looking concepts at the Shanghai auto show over the weekend, bringing revered nameplates back to life in modern skin and introducing wild new ideas that could someday become automotive norms.
 
We’ve already told you what we know about the Mercedes-Benz Concept GLA and the Volkswagen CrossBlue Coupé concept, so here are some of the other noteworthy entries introduced at the show.

The Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College has been closed for renovations for the last 10 months. This Sunday it reopens with a free celebration from 1 to 4 p.m. and the exhibition “Pre-Columbian Remix: The Art of Enrique Chagoya, Demián Flores, Rubén Ortiz-Torres and Nadín Ospina,” featuring four contemporary artists from Latin America who were inspired by ancient Aztec, Mayan and Incan cultures.
 
The overall mood of the show might be summarized by the title of Mr. Ortiz-Torres’s black-and-white photo series, “The Past Is Not What It Used to Be.” The works document imitations of pre-Columbian art and artifacts, some of them installed at nightclubs and amusement parks. Mr. Ospina’s carved-stone caryatids and gold-plated statues also nod to pre-Columbian icons, but closer inspection of their heads reveals features from Goofy, Mickey Mouse and other cartoon characters. And in paintings and works on paper by Mr. Flores and Mr. Chagoya, superhero figures who might be from comic strips or pre-Hispanic codices act out episodes from Mexican history. (Through July 14, 914-251-6100, neuberger.org .)

An article and an accompanying picture caption last Sunday about the composer and singer Gabriel Kahane referred imprecisely to the debut of his “Gabriel’s Guide to the 48 States.” The performance at Carnegie Hall on Saturday was to be its New York debut, not its world premiere. (Its debut was at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H., on April 19.) The article also quoted incorrectly from comments by Mr. Kahane about the purpose of art. He said we make art “to propose an alternative path,” not “an alternative past.”

The New York music promoters Search & Restore and Boom Collective have teamed up with the monthlong Red Bull Music Academy series for “A Night of Improvised Round Robin Duets.” The evening has a simple, inherently generative framework, with roots in acting classes as much as experimental music of the ’70s and ’80s: Musician A starts with a five-minute solo improvisation; Musician B joins Musician A for a five-minute duet; A leaves, and C arrives to play with B for five minutes. And so on, through a list of more than 20 players. 
 
The list is broad: Thundercat (a k a Stephen Bruner), the virtuosic future-funk bassist; Glenn Kotche, drummer of Wilco; Andrew W. K., the rock singer with a sideline in improvised music; the cellist and composer Erik Friedlander; the great jazz saxophonist Joe Lovano; the P-Funk keyboardist Bernie Worrell; Kim Gordon of Sonic Youth; the no-wave Roots drummer Questlove; and so on. (8 p.m., Wednesday, Brooklyn Masonic Temple, 317 Clermont Avenue, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, redbullmusicacademy.com ; tickets $15.)

The major orchestras, opera companies and halls in a musical capital like New York overshadow a more obscure bounty: its conservatories. They are rich repositories of young talent, and that talent often goes on display in performances that gain less attention than the big boys like the Metropolitan Opera and New York Philharmonic. The Juilliard School, especially, presents fine opera productions featuring student musicians, often led by a major conductor. 
 
This week Juilliard presents Janacek’s pungent fable “ The Cunning Little Vixen ,” conducted by a previous visitor, the highly regarded Anne Manson . Ms. Manson, who made her New York City Opera debut in 2007, is long overdue across Lincoln Center Plaza, at the Met. Emma Griffin directs. (2 p.m. Sunday, 8 p.m. Tuesday and Thursday, Peter Jay Sharp Theater, 212-721-6500,

In a recent interview , the actor Rocco Sisto was asked what an audience attending “Old-Fashioned Prostitutes (A True Romance),” could expect. “I am at that point in rehearsal where I don’t even have an idea what the audience will see,” he said. This is probably a common sentiment among actors about to open in a play by Richard Foreman, the downtown auteur whose singular shows are known for being as meticulously designed as they are enigmatic. Like most of his works, this play was written, directed and designed by Mr. Foreman. It opens on Tuesday at the Public Theater, which presented Mr. Foreman’s “ Idiot Savant,” with Willem Dafoe, in 2009.
 
Plot summaries are always simplifications, but they are particularly irrelevant for Mr. Foreman’s works, which can be dreamlike, surreal, indulgent and rigorous at the same time. If that doesn’t clarify things, well, you would not be the first person baffled by a show of his. Even so, he’s a one-of-a-kind artist always worth checking out. (425 Lafayette Street, 212-967-7555, publictheater.org .)

The Big Profile By Dave Itzkoff
 
Kevin Bacon may be half of a serial-TV household — he stars on Fox’s serial-killer drama “The Following,” and his wife, Kyra Sedgwick, led the TNT procedural “The Closer” — but he was a latecomer to a classic entry in the genre: “The Wire.” “I became one of these crazy people locked in a room for three days, watching hour after hour after hour,” says Bacon, who started recommending the show to others. “My wife accused me of ‘Wire’-rrhea. So I keep it to myself.”

We know that stretching before exercise tends to be counterproductive because, in loosening muscles, it also temporarily weakens them. But whether you should stretch at other times — after exercise, for instance, or first thing in the morning or just before bed — is murkier, in part because studies of stretching have not been standardized. Some have had young, healthy volunteers stretch for 20 minutes or more; others for 5 minutes or less. Still others have used older, stiffer volunteers or people with existing injuries. Not surprisingly, the results have been inconsistent. Even within the same study, people respond quite differently to stretching, with some showing increased flexibility and others not.

Andy Johns, a record producer and engineer who was involved in several canonical albums of 1970s rock, including the Rolling Stones ’ “Exile on Main St.,” Television ’s “Marquee Moon” and a string of recordings by Led Zeppelin, died on April 7 in Van Nuys, Calif. He was 62.
 
The cause was a bleeding ulcer, said his wife, Annette.
