By the Book An expanded version of our interview with Jonathan Franzen, the author of “The Corrections,” “Freedom” and, most recently, “Farther Away: Essays.”

Tourists have long flocked to the big-name designer stores along Zurich’s ritzy shopping street Bahnhofstrasse, situated on the left bank of the postcard-pretty Limmat River. But another river flows through the city — the rough and rugged Sihl, once a spectacle for its bouts of heavy flooding that lasted until the early 20th century. Today, it’s a lure for nature-loving residents thanks to the paved Sihlpromenade walking path lined with magnificent plane trees. Recently, a new crop of high-minded shops, a spirited mix of the homespun and worldly, have sprung up along or near the Sihl, turning its riverbank into a haven for shoppers looking for an alternative to Bahnhofstrasse. RATHA TEP

WELS--Lorin, of Old Tappan, NJ passed away suddenly, Friday morning, April 19, 2013. Lorin is survived by his devoted wife, Susan; his sons and their spouses, Steven and Shari, David and Nerissa; his brother, Bobby, sister-in-law Linda; step-daughters and their spouses, Jill and Evan, Kelly and Scott, and his eight adoring grandchildren, Alex, Max, Jordan, Dylan, Kayla, Tyler, Ava and Stella, and all his loving nieces and nephews. A seven-time golf club champion, an accomplished businessman, and avid outdoorsman; Lorin was forever the optimist. His infectious smile and never ending source of jokes, stories, and golf swing advice will be missed by all who knew him. Donations in Lorin's memory should be made to The Department of Cardio Thoracic Surgery, New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center.

WOLF--John C.,passed away Monday night April 22, 2013. Survived by his loving wife Sharon Manevitz Lauer-Wolf; his son Benjamin D. Wolf; his loving daughter-in-law Andi Wolf and his first grandson, Max Wolf born just last month; his step-daughter Suzanne Lauer; sister-in-law Sheila, and nephews Kehat and Hannania and brother-in-law Dr. Alan Manevitz and Dr. Larry Manevitz and wife Jenny, and their three children, the other love of his life his dog, Boo. He had another daughter from a previous marriage Alexandra. Graveside burial New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I., 631-249-7000 at 2pm, Wednesday. The family will sit Shiva at his home, Wednesday following the Funeral, Thursday 3-9pm, Saturday after Shabbat, Sunday to Wednesday 3-9pm.

WASSERMAN DAVIS--Kathryn. Wellesley College mourns the passing of Kathryn Wasserman Davis, class of 1928. At 106, Kathryn was Wellesley's oldest known alumna; she was also one of our most beloved. For nearly 85 years, she was committed to higher education and service to her community. A passionate and thoughtful advocate, Kathryn's philanthropy supported all aspects of the College, including professorships, financial aid, global education initiatives, and building and landscape improvements. Kathryn and her late husband, Shelby Cullom Davis, gave the cornerstone gift for Wellesley's Davis Museum and Cultural Center, which is named in their honor. Her vision also enabled Wellesley to return land that had been converted into a parking lot back to its original beauty. On her 100th birthday, Kathryn established the 100 Projects for Peace to fund student peace-building initiatives around the world. She was a Trustee Emerita who served on the Wellesley Board from 1984 to 2002. Her generosity touched many generations of Wellesley women, and will continue to make a difference for many generations to come. Kathryn is remembered, and will be missed, by her Wellesley sisters throughout the world.

WHITEHEAD--E. Douglas Age 73, of New York. Formerly of Yorkshire, England. Born in Galashiels, Scotland, died on April 23, 2013. It is with sadness that we note the passing of this devoted husband to his former wives, Patricia A Robbins and Batya Kahane, partner in life - Mary Goldman, and loving and proud father of his daughter, Robin. He is survived by his daughter, two brothers, two grandchildren, two nieces, three nephews, three cousins, his former wives and his life partner, Mary Goldman. He graduated from Long Beach High School, Vanderbilt University, and Indiana University School of Medicine; served his Internship in Surgery at Mount Sinai Hospital, New York, one year Surgical Residency at Presbyterian-St. Luke's Hospital, Chicago, and his Urology Residency at New York University Medical Center, New York. He spent three months in London, England studying urological surgery and received a Certificate of Post-Graduate Urological Instruction from the Institute of Urology, University of London. Dr. Whitehead served as a Captain in the USAF (Medical Corps) including one year in Vietnam. In 1973 Dr. Whitehead entered the private practice of Urology in New York. During the last 10 years of his practice he was a mentor to several post baccalaureate students desirous of entering medical school. He was an Associate Clinical Professor of Urology at Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, New York and later at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, New York. He was Board Certified in Urology and a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons and Sexual Medicine Society of North America. Dr. Whitehead was on the Attending Staff of Beth Israel Medical Center, New York for 36 years and on the Attending Staff of New York Downtown Hospital, New York. He presented Grand Rounds on Penile Enlargement Surgery at Plastic Surgical Grand Rounds, St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital, New York; Urological Grand Rounds, Beth Israel Medical Center, New York; and Surgical Grand Rounds, New York Downtown Hospital, New York. Dr. Whitehead belonged to and contributed to many professional organizations and societies including the: American Cancer Society, American College of Surgeons, American Urological Association, International Society of Artificial Organs, American Fertility Society, AASECT, SSSS, SIECUS, AMA, Sexual Medicine Society of North America, International Society for Sexual Medicine, Societe Internationale d'Urologe, New York Academy of Medicine, New York Academy of Science, American Academy of Phalloplasty Surgeons, Society of Genitourinary Reconstructive Surgeons, and Sexual Medicine Society of North America. He served on: medical and editorial advisory boards, as a reviewer and referee for several medical journals, and participated in national and international workshops and symposia. He was a member of the Medical Board of Beth Israel Hospital, New York, Founder of MEDCALLS and Director of the Association for Male Sexual Dysfunction, Continence Restored, ClassicCare, Geri-Care; Association for Urinary Continence Control, the Prostate Health Program of New York and the American Academy of Phalloplasty Surgeons. He also was President of the American Academy of Phalloplasty Surgeons. Dr. Whitehead was an investigator of several drugs and was an investigator of the research study, "Efficacy and Safety of Penile Lengthening and Widening Techniques" at Beth Israel Medical Center, New York. Together with Drs. A. A. Ehrhardt and H. F. L. Meyer-Bahlburg he was a co-investigator of a grant funded study on "Long-Term Mental Health Effects of Prenatal DES Exposure." He was a consultant to industry. He was a member of the Consensus Conference on Penile Augmentation at the European Society for Male Genital-Surgery in Italy. In 1990 he was Visiting Professor at Christian Medical College in Vellore, India and performed live surgery of the first penile prosthesis insertion in Southern India and in 1991 performed the Whitehead Technique of Penile Widening with Allograft Dermal Matrix Graft in Rome, Italy. Dr. Whitehead gave more than 300 lectures, panel discussions, grand rounds, presentations, post-graduate courses, symposia and videos. He was invited to speak at many professional and lay organizations. He also has over 100 publications of articles in medical journals and book chapters for professionals and the lay public. He was quoted in numerous books, magazines and newspapers, and interviewed for TV and the Internet.His first text book: "Current Operative Urology" was published in 1975 and a second edition, with Dr. Elliot Leiter, was published in 1984. This was followed for several years by an Annual Edition. He edited: "Atlas of Surgical Techniques in Urology," published in 1998. With Dr. Harris M. Nagler he co-edited: "Management of Impotence and Infertility", published in 1994. Starting in 1985 with Dr. Shirley Zussman he produced a TV series titled: "Conversations on Male Sexuality". In 1999 he wrote the book titled: "Viagra-- the Wonder Drug for Peak Performance," and along with Dr. Zussman edited a Newsletter titled: "Sex over 40". He has two patents for penile prosthetic devices. Throughout his professional career he has been a leader in Erectile Dysfunction and Aesthetic and Reconstructive Genital Surgery. He was a pioneer in the field of pericavernosal allograft dermal matrix grafting for glandular enhancement and primary, secondary and revisionary aesthetic penile girth enhancement. From 1987-1989 with his wife Patricia he was Co-Chair of Clark University Parents Association. Several years ago he donated an excellent collection of old urological instruments and books, dated to the 1700's, to The William P. Didusch Center for Urologic History. He was a supporter of the Francis H. Burr Proton Therapy Center at Massachusetts General Hospital (Norbert J. Liebsch, M.D., PhD) and Hadassah. He was an avid glider pilot and held Diamond Badge #

About the Best Sellers: These lists are an expanded version of those appearing in the April 28, 2013 print edition of the Book Review, reflecting sales for the week ending April 13, 2013. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above it. A dagger (†) indicates that some retailers report receiving bulk orders. For an explanation of our methodology, visit http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers.

SACHTER--Dov, on April 26. Beloved husband of the late Franka, loving father of Dr. Joseph Sachter. Memorial service will be held Wednesday, May 1st, 2013 at "The Riverside", 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY.

ROSENBLUM--Susan Ullmann, born August 26, 1918 in New York City; died peacefully on April 16, 2013 in Lenox, MA. Previous resident of Hartsdale and Somers, NY, Susan was predeceased by her parents, Joseph and Violet Ullmann; her brothers, Vincent and Joseph 3rd; and her husband of 53 years, H. William Rosenblum. She is survived by her sons, John and Robert; daughter-in-law Carolyn Jones Rosenblum; grandchildren, Kathryn Rosenblum Moxhay and Christopher, Nicholas, Sarah, Jesse and Kaitlin Rosenblum; and great-grandchildren, Olwyn, Imogen and Nikolai Moxhay and Ted and John Michael Rosenblum. A private service and interment will be at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

SCHARF--Aaron. We mourn the loss of our beloved Grandpa, Aaron M. Scharf. We will never forget the great times we shared together and the many lessons we learned from you. While we have lost our grandfather, teacher, mentor, coach and friend, we will make sure that your memory lives on forever. Perhaps the most valuable lesson that we can learn from your remarkable 96 year life is the importance of living life to the absolute fullest and making every day count. You are the best and we will always miss you. Love, Andrew, Will & Ben Scharf

STORRS--Frances Rousmaniere Of Oyster Bay, NY died April 22 peacefully at home at the remarkable age of 100. Her charitable life began in 1929 at the age of 16, when she worked for the summer in Hyden, KY, where her mother's family had funded the Frontier Nursing Service three-room hospital, and rode horses through the back hills to help provide medical care. For the rest of her life, she devoted much of her energy to helping others through a multitude of charities, including Planned Parenthood, Visiting Nurse Services, the Oyster Bay-East Norwich Boys and Girls Club, the Oyster Bay Waterfront Center, Friends of the Bay and many others. She and her husband Richard ("Dick") were leaders in creating Oyster Bay's East Woods School in 1946 and she served the school for many years. Her inquiring mind led to travel all over the world, plus regular courses at Long Island's Hutton House even into her nineties. "Frinnie" graduated from Chapin School in New York City and was one of Chapin's longest-serving Class Secretaries. From its purchase in 1956 to 2013, she opened her home in Cove Neck to all, welcoming anyone who asked to use the house for a fundraiser or wedding. A devoted wife to her late husband, she was a loving mother to her six children: the late Richard Jr. "Nick" (Jeanie) of Lunenburg, MA, Ayer Bellerman of Oyster Bay, David (Landon) of Southport, CT, Ginny Akabane (Gige) of Lenox, MA, Nancy (Jack) of St. Catharines, Canada, and Cleveland, of San Diego, CA, and enjoyed tremendously their stories of travel, sports and academic achievements. She cherished her seven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren and in her nineties was often on hands and knees playing games with them. The Storrs family expresses its appreciation to Hospice of Woodbury, whose superb and compassionate care permitted her to stay in the house she loved so much until her passing, and to the aides who gave her such support. A Memorial Service will be held June 8. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to the Oyster Bay Waterfront Center or East Woods School.

SKOLNICK--Allen. American Friends of The Hebrew University (AFHU) and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn the passing of our dear friend Allen Skolnick, loving husband of the late Connie Skolnick, cherished father of Mitchel, Barry and the late Rand Skolnick, devoted brother of Edward Skolnick, and proud grandfather to Ryan, Matthew and Jacob. A dynamic leader in the health and nutrition industries, Allen founded Solgar Vitamin and Herb Company. He was equally committed to Israel and the nation's scientific achievement, establishing Cambr Foundation Fellowships in Nanoscience and Nanotechnology at Hebrew University's Harvey M. Krueger Family Center for Nanoscience and Nanotechnology. Inscribed on the Wall of Life at Mount Scopus, the Cambr Foundation reflects the ideals of Allen and Connie, whose love for each other and concern for humanity illuminated their shared lives. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mitchel, Barry and the entire Skolnick family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson, President American Friends of The Hebrew University George A. Schieren, Chairman Martin E. Karlinsky, President Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director

TARLOW--Glenys L.,died peacefully at home in Stamford, CT on April 25 after a recent diagnosis of cancer. Born in 1923 in Portland, Maine, she was the widow of her adoring husband, William F. Tarlow who predeceased her in 2000. She is survived by children Reuven (Nechama), Lawrence, and Lee Miller (Leslie), and was pre-deceased by son Andrew (Adrienne) in 1988 and grandsons Jeffrey and Yossi. Also surviving are grandchildren Rachel Yaggy (Samuel), Henry Tarlow (Traczie), Chanie Perelstein (Meir) and Zalman Tarlow, two great-grandchildren, sister Judith Halpert (Stephen) of Portland, ME, many loving nieces and nephews and dear friends from her years in Roslyn, NY and Somers, NY. Glenys was a rare book collector and noted lecturer on the author Kate Douglas Wiggin, and her collection is housed in the Maine Women Writers Collection, University of New England, Portland, ME. Funeral services were held and the family will be sitting Shiva at the Tarlows in Morristown, NJ, and Sunday - Wednesday, 11-2 and 5-8 at the home of Lee Miller, 169 East 78 Street, Manhattan.

SLUTZKY--Orville A. 96 year old co-founder of Hunter Mountain Ski Bowl. Born and raised in Hunter, NY, Orville and his late brother Izzy were ski industry pioneers and driving forces of Northern Catskill Mountains tourism and economic development. Also predeceased by his wife of 67 years, Ethel, and two sisters, Orville is survived by three children and their spouses, nine grandchildren, five great grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. He will be deeply missed.

SUTHERLAND--John C.,born September 21, 1928 died peacefully on April 20 at his Brooklyn home surrounded by his brother David and his friends Barbara and Gabe Plumer. He was preceded in death by his two sisters, Mollie Reeve and Janet Sutherland and by his partner and friend Martin Stanford. He is survived by his brother, his brother-in-law William Reeve, his nephews Michael and Timothy Reeve, and by Timothy's children. He received B.A. and M.A. degrees from Yale University in 1950 and 1952 and served in an intelligence unit in the U.S. Army in Germany during the Cold War. His later professional career included work as a trust officer for Irving Trust, as a senior portfolio manager for Lord Abbett, and as a private consultant for Nakagama and Wallace. He generously supported many Brooklyn and Park Slope charities, and served as treasurer of the Montauk Club. He enjoyed spending time at his second home in Honolulu, Hawaii. Contributions may be made to the John Sutherland Memorial Scholarship Fund at the Brooklyn Music School, 126 Saint Felix Street, Brooklyn, NY 11217, a fund whose purpose is to defray tuition expenses for music students at the school. www.brooklynmusicschool.org

SCHARF--Aaron M. The Yeshiva University family laments the passing of Aaron M. Scharf, husband of the late Blanche Scharf, of blessed memory, and the revered father of Gilbert Scharf and Michael J. and his wife Fiona Scharf, who are Benefactors of Yeshiva University, and the deeply cherished grandfather of Andrew, William and Benjamin. He was a man for all seasons. Aaron M. Scharf was brilliant, independent and determined to excel in all his endeavors. Recognized as a distinguished patent attorney, he was kind, compassionate and exceedingly generous to individuals in need and to institutions which reflected his own values of integrity and concern for the welfare of civic and Jewish communal issues which caused him to preside over major organizations and Jewish communal organizations in New York and Florida. His noble deeds have been emulated by Michael J. and Fiona Scharf whose leadership in the Park East Synagogue in New York and munificent support for Yeshiva University established the Michael J. Scharf Publication Fund which supports and encourages erudite Jewish scholarship and research by our faculty and they named the Holy Ark in the magnificent new Study Hall in the Jacob and Dreizel Glueck Center for Jewish Studies where the beauty and sanctity of advanced Jewish study and inspiring prayer is experienced daily by many hundreds of students. As the Scharf family perpetuates the legacy of their beloved father and grandfather we pray they will find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Dr. Norman Lamm, Rosh Hayeshiva and Chancellor

ROSEN--Roslyn. A force of nature was stilled April 21, 2013, when Roslyn Rosen, nee Greenberg, died peacefully at home in Ukiah, CA. Roz was born February 12, 1928, graduating from Erasmus Hall High School and Brooklyn College. A Special Ed teacher for 25 years, she was an impassioned advocate for the developmentally and learning disabled, taught at Brooklyn College, and served as President of the New York State Teachers of the Handicapped. She volunteered with Friends of Marine Park/Gerritsen Creek, American Littoral Society, Sebago Canoe Club and the Aquarium. On moving to Ukiah she volunteered at a pre-school and the Friends of the Library, and was active with American Association of University Women and the Senior Center. Roz married the love of her life, Jack Rosen, in 1948. She is survived by daughters Janet Rosen of Ukiah, CA and Judi Frinstein of Georgetown, TX, a smattering of relatives and untold numbers of friends, because Roz could walk into a roomful of strangers and emerge with a whole new circle of dear friends. No services per her request. Donations in her honor may be made to American Littoral Society NE Chapter or to AHRC NYC Foundation. For full obituary please go to eversolefs.com.

STEIN--Diana M.,85, of Glen Rock, passed away on Wednesday, April 24, 2013. She was a resident of Glen Rock for over 60 years and was a founding member of Temple Israel in Ridgewood and an active member of the community. Prior to her retirement she was a 35 year plus veteran of Amica Insurance Company. Her husband Norton predeceases her. She will be sadly missed by her son David (Rebecca), her daughter Perri (Mario) Procida, grandchildren Dylan, Peter, Michael, Parker, and Thomas. She was a source of strength for all her friends and family, and will be terribly missed. Funeral services will be 10:30am, Sunday, April 28, 2013 at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, w-150 Route 4, Paramus, NJ. http:// www.schoemschapel.com/.
MURPHY--William J.,77, April 27th of Briarcliff and East Hampton, NY. Retired from Allstate. Beloved by wife Dell Egan, children Doreen, Suzanne, Lynn, Kathleen, and their families.
POLLACK--Stanley P. We mourn the death of our cherished member and extend deepest sympathies to his family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

REMEZ--Stanley M. on April 19, 2013 at 90. Husband of Harriet (Abosch) for 65 years, beloved father of Robert, Andrea, Adam and James, grandfather of Laura, Margot, Lila and Sofia, and brother of Jesse. Raised in Brooklyn, he was a decorated veteran of the United States Army serving in Europe during WWII, and received degrees from Long Island and Columbia Universities. A resident of Mount Vernon since 1961, he was a psychotherapist in private practice in New York. He retired in 1984 after many years of service to the New York State Department of Labor; he also served as a longtime consultant at the Goshen Secure Center. Interment at Mount Hebron Cemetery.

NININGER--Constance Moore, on April 18, 2013. Beloved wife, mother, and sister. Raised in Kansas City, MO, resident of Westchester, NY since 1956, Connie was an artist and a retired Latin teacher at Greenwich Academy. She earned a BA from the University of Kansas, an MA in Greek and Latin from Columbia University, studied at the American Academy in Rome, and at Cambridge University in England. She is predeceased by her son Mark, and her husband of 43 years, E. Scott, MD. She loved the Renaissance as well as simple pleasures. Her irrepressible spirit and capacity for beauty and delight, her warmth, her brilliance of mind, and dazzling smiles transformed us. Your exquisite love, your tenderness and strength, live in me. Lovingly, Your Daughter, Gail

Nussbaum--John, 91, renowned stained glass painter, designer, and restorer on April 24, 2013. He was the loving husband of Annette Wysocki and father of Richard. His stories of the Bohemian life in Greenwich Village, challenging queries, and talent as a painter was and is unrivaled. He loved books and his intellectual curiosity never waned. His ability to see things in new ways and insight were remarkable. He was the Founder of Glassmasters, Inc. and was a member of the National Arts Club. He will always be remembered for his humility and willingness to mentor other developing stained glass artists. His life's work will be viewed in church windows, museums, public buildings, and private homes for centuries to come.

POLLACK--Stanley P.,of New York City on April 25, 2013 at the age of 85. Beloved husband of the late Susan. Devoted father to Jane. He loved the practice of law, the New York Times, a good steak and his family, friends and colleagues. He will be missed. Services Monday April 29, 12 noon, Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave at 65th St. Donations may be made to the NYU Clinical Cancer Center, 160 East 34th St. New York, NY 10016.

NEUHAUS--Philip Ross, Philip Ross Neuhaus of Houston, Texas, passed away on April 23, 2013 at the age of 93. He graduated from St. Mark's School and Yale University, class of 1942, and was president of Wolf's Head. Captain, U.S. Army, 124th Cavalry Regiment, a horse cavalry squadron of more than 700 men. As Captain, he was responsible for all tactical plans of the long march along the Burma Road. He was co-founder, and CEO of Underwood Neuhaus & Co, remaining in the business for 66 years to the present. A more detailed notice is available through the obituaries tab at www.geohlewis.com.

NARASIMHAN--Robin Rose, passed away on 25th March 2013. She married Lakshmi Narasimhan and had a happy, loving and exciting life for 20 years. Robin and Lakshmi have a loving beautiful and precious 14 year old daughter Patrice Narasimhan. Patrice and Lakshmi find this loss profound and are at a loss for words. Robin was the daughter of Howard Keen and Patricia Keen. Robin was predeceased by her mother, Patricia Keen, and her grandmother, Bunny. Robin attended New York University and completed her Bachelor of Arts, majoring in Psychology. She is loved and missed by her father, step-mother Karen Keen, in-laws Singarachari Ranganathan and Chandra Ranganathan. Robin was a wonderful lady with a great sense of humor and a selfless love for life. She will be greatly missed by a wide circle of family, friends and colleagues.

POLLACK--Stanley. It is with great sadness that the Rosenthal family mourns the loss of their dear friend, Stanley Pollack. For forty years, Stanley served first as General Counsel and more recently as Senior Executive Vice President of Rosenthal & Rosenthal, Inc. Throughout his career, Stanley distinguished himself as not only an outstanding attorney, but also as an innovative thinker and deal maker. His door was always open, whether you were seeking legal counsel or personal advice. Stanley made an indelible mark on the company that he served so loyally during his career, but he will be remembered most for being a mentor and trusted friend to so many in the Rosenthal family. Our thoughts and prayers go out to Stanley's daughter, Jane.

PEAK--Kenneth R. Kenneth R. Peak, passed away Friday, the 19th of April 2013, at age 67 after a courageous battle with brain cancer. Ken was the son of Harold Raymond "Dutch" and Mary Rose Peak. He was born the 17th of July 1945, in Cleves, Ohio, and grew up in nearby Frogtown. Ken was a 1963 graduate of Taylor High School and went on to earn a BS in Physics from Ohio University in 1967 and a MBA from Columbia University in 1972. He proudly served as an Officer in the United States Navy from 1968 to 1971. Ken Peak was much more than an accomplished businessman. Ken began his energy career in 1973 as a Commercial Banker in First National Bank of Chicago's energy group. His biggest success was Contango, an Oil & Gas Company that Ken started in 1999 with nothing but a desire to build a successful business for himself and his shareholders. From this idea, he built a very successful oil and gas exploration and production company, which he served as the CEO and Chairman. Prior to Contango, Ken served as a Treasurer at Tosco Corporation in 1980 and CFO at Texas International Company ('TIC') in 1982. Ken's tenure with TIC included serving as the President of TIPCO, the domestic operating subsidiary of TIC's natural gas and oil operations. Ken served as the CFO of Forest Oil Corporation from 1988 to 1989 and as an Investment Banker with Howard Weil from 1989 to 1990. He served as the President of Peak Enernomics Inc., an oil and gas consulting firm that Ken formed in 1990. Ken was also appointed to serve on the Board of Directors of AKM Enterprise Inc., NL Industries Inc., Amerac Energy Corp., and Patterson-UTI Energy. In more recent years, Ken served as the President and CEO of Contango ORE and as the Chairman of the Board for OnKure, an oncology drug company that he helped create. Besides building businesses, he built friendships that lasted a lifetime; once you were a friend of Ken's, his loyalty, good counsel, and companionship would become your biggest asset. Ken was widely known as a "character" in the business. He loved going to work and never had a bad day. He thought for himself and never had to check with others to make decisions as he instinctively knew what was right. Ken was a wise man, a lifelong learner and an avid reader of books, newspapers and economics newsletters. He was born with a funny bone and always tried to see a funny side of everything. His heart was the purest. Ken used his fortune to help others, and he never gave in a showy way. As a symbol of his generosity Ken and Donna Peak made a substantial donation to Methodist Hospital in Houston to established the Kenneth R. Peak Brain and Pituitary Tumor Treatment Center to continue the fight with brain illness. Ken was a man who chose to be happy all the time and he will be remembered as such. Ken Peak is irreplaceable. Ken is survived by his loving wife, Donna; daughter Mariclare Elko and husband, Chris; son Joe Peak; grandchildren Jack, Madeline, and Charlie Elko; sister Sandy Peak; brother Mike and wife, Jane Peak; four nieces; seven nephews; two aunts; and numerous cousins. The family asks that in lieu of flowers or other donations, a donation can be made to support the Kenneth R. Peak Brain and Pituitary Tumor Treatment Center by making a contribution to the Methodist Hospital Foundation. Donations should be sent to David Baskin, M.D. at 1656 North Blvd., Houston, TX 77006. Services in Houston are with Geo. H. Lewis & Sons-The Funeral Directors Since 1936, 713-789-3005. www.geohlewis.com.

MILCAREK--Dr. Barry Ivor, left this world suddenly and peacefully at home on April 20, 2013, doing what he loved most, tending to his garden. Dr. Milcarek is leaving behind his devoted wife, Mary McLean, and his parents, Shirley and Ivor Milcarek; Barry also leaves behind his daughter, Heather (Michael Miller) and son Rory, both of whom he loved more than any words can express. He will be missed by his sister, Doreen Milcarek (Kenneth Burke), brother Kevin, niece Katharine and nephew Neil. Barry enjoyed his work and colleagues at the University of Delaware where he served as Senior Biostatistician in the College of Heath Sciences. Barry was an avid sports fan - he loved college basketball and football, but had a special love for youth hockey, where he once coached children, including his beloved son Rory. A private service is being planned. In lieu of flowers, if you would like to make a donation in Barry's memory, please give to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, P.O. Box 1000, Memphis, TN 38148, Tribute Account #

POLLACK--Stanley. We mourn the passing of our dear friend, Stanley. We will miss his absorbing stories, astute opinions, and insightful judgment of character, as well as his friendship of nearly forty years. Our thoughts go out to his devoted daughter, Jane. Arthur and Trish Toback

RACIES--Lawrence. November 23, 1916 - April 12, 2013. Beloved husband of Gail Williams. Father of Robin Hammond, Lawrence, and Phillip Racies, grandfather of nine, uncle to three nieces and a nephew. Left the University of New Hampshire to go on the road with comedian Red Skelton. A veteran of WWII, a CBS News cameraman, and an inveterate teller of jokes. He was a longtime fighter for a universal healthcare system in the USA. A celebration of his life will be held at St. Paul's Church, 315 West 22nd Street, on May 9th at 3pm.

KAY--Jack. Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc. is deeply saddened at the passing of our most generous friend, Jack Kay, beloved husband of Barbara, and cherished father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Jack was devoted to his family, and was a passionate supporter of the State of Israel and the work of Hadassah. Jack Kay's generosity spread from his native Maryland, where he established the Abraham S. and Jack Kay Chair in Israel Studies, to the very heart of Jerusalem, where he and his family embraced the mission of Hadassah. With his wife, the late Ina Kay, he established the first Jewish hospice in Israel, the Ina and Jack Kay Hospice Center at Hadassah's Mount Scopus Hospital. When told of Hadassah's new project, the Sarah Wetsman Davidson Hospital Tower, Jack and his wife Barbara established the Barbara and Jack Kay Welcome Garden, a serene and welcoming garden which provides an enclave of calm and caring to embrace both patients and visitors. May his memory be for a blessing, and may the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marcie Natan, National President

KLEINMAN--Stuart, 57, of NYC. Brilliant lawyer and filmmaker. Former president Egg Pictures, VP ICM and partner Frankfurt Kurnit. Missed by brother Andrew, sister-in-law Noela, niece Julia, nephew Alex. Service April 28, 10am Plaza Jewish.

HULL--Philip G.,88, died at his home in Hightstown, NJ, on April 5, 2013 after a long illness. He served with the U.S. Army, 1943-46, and then in the active Army Reserve until retiring as Major in 1963. He was a 1949 graduate of Middlebury College and a 1952 graduate of Columbia University Law School. In 1951 he was a staff member of the King Subcommittee of the House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee, investigating IRS laws. From 1952-63 he was an Associate in the firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts (now Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman), a Partner from 1964-97, and Senior Counsel, 1998-2002. He was a member of the New York State Bar Association, the Florida Bar Association, and the American College of Trust and Estate Counsel. Service on many charitable boards included the Board of National Missions of the United Presbyterian Church, 1967-73, the Latin America Mission, 1969-79, and the Fellowship of Christians in Universities and Schools, 1983-90. He served various Presbyterian churches as Elder and also Trustee, lastly at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, New York City. A long time member of the American Guild of Organists, he also served on the Board of the People's Symphony Concerts, New York City, 1977-2000, and was a founding Director of the Long Island Philharmonic, 1979-81. For over sixty years he was a loving husband to his wife, Gretchen, who survives him, and a loving father to his children Jeffrey, Sanford, and Meredyth Hull Smith, who also survive him, as do his daughters-in-law Bonnie and Belinda, son-in-law Brooks Smith, and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Meadow Lakes Retirement Community, Hightstown, NJ, at 2:30pm on Sunday May 19, 2013.

MEYERS--Herbert M. Pratt Institute Board Chair Bruce Gitlin, the Board of Trustees, and President Thomas F. Schutte mourn the death of Pratt alumnus and Trustee Emeritus Herbert M. Meyers (Advertising Design '49). Receiving more than 100 design awards, Herb helped advance his alma mater as a Trustee (1994-2004) and as Trustee Emeritus since 2005. Herb's pioneering spirit, commitment to excellence, and visionary leadership helped Gerstman + Meyers, which he co-founded in 1970, become a foremost brand identity and design consultancy with many Fortune 500 clients. Herb shall be deeply missed by all who knew him. Our sincere condolences to his wife, Edith; his son, David; his daughter, Sandra; and their families.

LONSDALE--Nancy Roberts. Raised in Beaumont and resident of Oakland, California, obituary enthusiast, mother, wife, and beloved friend, who attended all Stanford Rose Bowl games in the last 30 years, Deadhead, court commissioner, officiator of adoptions, lover of baseball, soup maker, labor lawyer, avid reader, passed away on April 21 surrounded by her family at age 59. Flowers no, charity yes.

JEFFERS--Mary Walden Bell ("Wally"), beloved daughter, sister, wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, died April 19, 2013, at the age of 99, in Bloomfield CT. Wally was born in Asheville NC in 1914, the eldest child of Mary Walden (Williamson) Bell and Landon Covington Bell. She grew up with six younger brothers in Columbus OH, and graduated from Wellesley College in 1936. In 1940, Wally married Walter W. Jeffers, an officer of what is now Citibank, whom she had met on a blind date while in college. They resided in Plandome and were active in the Manhasset Congregational Church and in civic affairs. When Walter died, in 1989, she moved to Bloomfield. Wally is survived by three children: Christopher Jeffers, of Hartford CT; Landon Jeffers, of South Huntington NY; and Louise Jeffers Brami of Lexington MA. A second daughter, Gabrielle W. Mangion, died in 1979. She is also survived by six grandchildren: Jonathan Mangion of Galway, Ireland; Sarah Mangion of Fairfax CA; Alex Jeffers of New York NY; Natalie Jeffers of Copenhagen, Denmark; Penelope Jeffers of Cambridge MA; Julia Brown of Merrick NY; and Elisabeth Brami of Lexington MA. Another grandson, Joel Mangion, pre-deceased her. In addition, she is survived by six great-grandchildren. One of Wally's early and lifelong interests was travel. Her adventurous spirit took her, by boat and plane, to the British isles and continental Europe, Greece and Turkey, Latin America, Africa, and India and Nepal. She was an avid painter and devotee of good music and crossword puzzles. Just months ago, culminating a lifetime of reading and fulfilling a long-held ambition, she read "War and Peace". Above all, throughout her life Wally devoted her time and attention to her family and friends, and she died content and peaceful surrounded by them. Of her entire full and happy life, she often declared, simply, "I'm a very lucky lady". A memorial service was held in Bloomfield on April 25. The family asks that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to Doctors without Borders.

LEE--Elaine. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Elaine Lee, beloved wife of the late Edward. Elaine's generosity and compassion helped improve the lives of countless people in need. We extend our deepest sympathies to her sons, Donald (Ronni) and David (Cathy); her grandchildren; and the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President; Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

LIFTON--Richard Zane, passed away early Saturday morning, April 27, 2013 in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida at the age of 73. He joined LB Electric Supply Co. Inc. in 1963 and served as President from 1978 to 2004. Richard was well-respected in the electrical industry in NYC and was known for his integrity, loyalty, and good fellowship. He is survived by his wife Lorraine, his children, Lisa Laub and her husband Jeff, Cheryl Brandwein and her husband David, his brother Harvey Lifton and his wife Francine, and four grandchildren, Ryan and Andrew Laub, and Liliana and Abigail Brandwein. His endearing presence will be missed by all. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, April 30 at 11:45am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

LEVY--Ethel Green, on April 26, 2013. Beloved Mother of Andrew, cherished Grandmother of Douglas and Alexa. Designed the homes of several generations of delighted clients as an interior designer for over seventy years. Services will be held 12 Noon Monday, April 29 at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.
KANTER--Gerald (Jerry), 93, beloved husband of the late Irma; father of Merrill Weiss and Robin Heller; grandfather of Adam, Josh and Benjamin; WWII Vet; salesman extraordinaire. Merry Xmas Jerry.

KOREN--Morris April 25, 1923 April 23, 2013. It is with great sadness we announce the passing of Morris Koren. Born in Lithuania, a survivor of the Holocaust, Morris immigrated to America in 1952. Together with his wife Rose, they rebuilt their lives in New York City and later Bal Harbour, FL. Morris is survived by his wife Rose, son Phillip (Jackie), daughter Susan (Jack) and grandchildren Joshua, Adam, Charlene, Ariella, Marcus, Jacob and Gabriella and predeceased by his son Harvey. As a survivor, the example of what he built and inspired will be his legacy for generations to come.

MALLORY--Pauline Cropper, 92, died peacefully at home in Mystic, CT on April 17. She was born December 8, 1920 to Paul and Airini Carr Cropper in Auckland, New Zealand. On May 11, 1943, in Auckland, she married Clifford Day Mallory Jr., a US Navy Lieutenant. After WWII she and her husband moved to New York City where he launched his career in the shipping business, a family tradition for five generations. Pauline was an accomplished pianist, a student of distinction at The Royal Academy of Music in Piano Performance and a lifetime enthusiast of classical music. More importantly, she devoted her life to her family and many friends worldwide and will be remembered by all as a paragon of selflessness, grace, beauty, humor and kindness. Predeceased by her husband in 2000 and by two siblings, James Cropper and Errol Lovering, she is survived by a brother, John W. Cropper of Auckland and her three children, Diana Mallory Hawes of Pasadena, CA, Veronica Mallory Stubbs (Michael) of New York City and Charles Mallory (Georgette) of Greenwich, CT in addition to seven grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. A gathering in Pauline Mallory's Memory will be held May 31, 12:30pm at Mystic Seaport, Mystic, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Mystic Seaport, P.O. Box 2000, Mystic, CT 06355.
HARAP--Frederick. April 11, 2013. Beloved husband, father, granddad. An honorable man. We love you, always.

HEYE--Harold Ferdinand, prominent local business man, passed away on April 22, 2013, in Clearwater, FL with his loving family by his side. Mr. Heye was born in Dusseldorf, Germany son of Margarete and Hans Heye. His family later moved to the Hague. Mr. Heye attended St. George's and St. John's Military Academies. He was a member of the armed forces in World War II and proudly served in the Pacific Theatre on Kwajalein and the initial assault on Leyte Island and Okinawa. He attended Babson College in Wellesley, MA and the Wharton School of Business. Mr. Heye served on the Boards of Morton Plant Hospital, Gerresheimer Factories and subsidiaries in Germany and Holland as well as Ruth Eckerd Hall, The First National Bank of Clearwater and Carlouel Yacht Club. He was a Director and co-owner of the High and Dry Marina, Island Yacht Harbor and Pier 60 in Clearwater. He was also a part of the original team of developers for Island Estates and one of the original benefactors of Ruth Eckerd Hall. Mr. Heye who resided in Belleair and Dorset, VT was a long standing member of the Belleair Country Club, Carlouel Yacht Club, was a member of the Rotary Club, Privateers Men's Club and Ekwanok Club of Manchester, VT. Mr. Heye is survived by his loving wife, Diane Gerlach Heye and children, Deborah Neal, Rick Heye, Christopher Heye and Kingsley Gerlach III, Mary Gerlach Hickok, John Gerlach, Stephen Gerlach and twelve cherished grandchildren. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to Ruth Eckerd Hall and Morton Plant Hospital.

HAAS CLARK--Irene, of Manhattan, NY, passed away on April 22, 2013, at the age of 83. By her bedside were her children, Jo (Matt) Cohen and Jim Clark. Born and raised in New York, the daughter of Louis and Fifi; protective sister to Alan (Joan); aunt to Ed and Julie (Haas), and very devoted and proud "Grammy" to Marie-Charlotte and Marie-Celeste Clark, Miranda and Mitchell Cohen. Loving wife of 52 years to Philip Clark (deceased, May 2009). Award-winning children's book illustrator/author, admired by and influential to many other artists, and witty and compassionate friend of many more. Memorial Service was held at the Campbell Funeral Chapel (Madison Ave. and 81st Street) on Friday, April 26th at 11:30am, with a Shiva immediately afterwards at 351 East 84th St., Apt 11E.

HESS--Susan Berman, of New York City died on April 25th after a long battle with cancer. She is survived by her devoted husband of 32 years, Mortimer (Terry) Hess, her beloved brother, Michael Berman, his wife Sally, and her two nieces, Laura and Stephanie Berman. Susan was born and raised in New York City where she worked for JP Morgan Chase for 23 years. Funeral services will be held Sunday, April 28th at 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

DAVIS--Kathryn W. A Memorium of Thanks from students in the Kathryn W. Davis Master's Degree in Peacebuilding. From Afghanistan, "She will be remembered as a great peacebuilder". From Tanzania, "She will continue to live in our hearts". And from Haiti, "someone who trusted young idealist students". A life that lives on through her charge to "prepare for peace, not war". Future Generations Graduate School (future.edu).

FISHER--Conrad. High Ridge Country club acknowledges will sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Conrad Fisher. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Edie, and their family. Stuart Albrecht, President H. Lawrence Fein, Secretary

GRUMBACH--Leonard, October 3, 1923 - April 24, 2013, of Roslyn, NY, after a brief illness. Devoted husband of Sandra and Aileen (both deceased) and father of Diane Selinger (Neil), Carol Grumbach (Michael Cohen) and Lillian Nayder (Matt Johnson). Grandfather of William, Sam, Nate and George. WWII Army veteran, two bronze stars. Proud graduate of CCNY and Hofstra Law. Dedicated labor law attorney. He will be missed for his wit, sharp intellect, concern for others, and passion for social justice. Funeral services Sunday, April 28 at noon at Schoem's Chapel in Paramus, NJ.

GALLANTZ--George G.,passed away on April 24, 2013, the day after his 100th birthday. All of us at Proskauer Rose LLP mourn his passing. George will be remembered as a "lawyer's lawyer," known for his outstanding legal skills, wealth of experience and insight and special touch for teaching younger lawyers. A Proskauer partner since 1963, George mentored an extraordinary group of lawyers who have had an enduring impact both on our Firm, as well as on the legal and sports world including Michael Cardozo, New York City's Corporation Counsel; David Stern, Commissioner of the National Basketball Association and Gary Bettman, Commissioner of the National Hockey League. The founding father of Proskauer's Sports Law Practice, George leaves behind a legacy of commitment, brilliance, friendship and uncompromising integrity. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. He will be missed by all who knew him family, friends, colleagues and clients alike. Joseph M. Leccese Chairman Proskauer Rose LLP

GRUNE--George. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America (BGCA) wish to express their profound sorrow over the passing of Mr. George Grune, a great friend of Boys & Girls Clubs, and champion advocate for America's children. Mr. Grune's involvement with BGCA covers 31 years, including Board Chairman. Under Grune's leadership, the nonprofit appointed its first female President/CEO Roxanne Spillett. Grune strengthened the board and his personal conviction was an inspiration to all. He was also a staunch supporter of BGCA's premier academic and leadership recognition program Youth of the Year. Grune served on various board committees including Executive, Nominating & Membership, and Human Resources & Compensation. He was presented the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian Award, BGCA's most coveted honor. Even after his retirement, Grune remained active, serving on the board of the Boys & Girls Clubs of Jacksonville, FL. This tough, no-nonsense business leader will be sorely missed by the entire Boys & Girls Club family.

HAUSLER--Bob. On April 26, 2013, at home with his partner of 52 years, Richard E. Stout. Donations can be made, in lieu of flowers, to the White Plains Beautification Foundation, as well as the Downtown Music Foundation. Services will be held on Monday, April 29, 2013 at Congregation Kol Ami at 9:30am, followed by an entombment at Rose Hills Memorial Park, Putnam Valley, New York.

DRUCKER--Marcel. Marcel Drucker, 86 passed away March 31, 2013. Founder and president of Marcel Watch Corp., he led a successful watch company which provided moderately priced fashionable watches and clocks to the major U.S. retailers. His business acumen, foresight and enthusiasm for his work was admired in the watch industry. His sincerity and enthusiasm traversed well into the television home shopping arena and his watch brand became more widely recognized after years of appearing on TV in the United States and Europe. Marcel was a devoted father and grandfather; he guided his children and grandchildren with his strong beliefs which valued education, perseverance, confidence, self- improvement, and passion for work. He shared many stories about his upbringing, and was particularly proud to come from a rabbinical family. He also had a great appreciation for the opportunities the United States offered, and wore an American flag pin on his lapel which stated, "A grateful American." He will be deeply missed and will always be in the hearts and memories of those he touched. Marcel is survived by his daughters, Claire and Heather, his sons-in-law, Nathan and Jeffrey, and his grandchildren, Megan, Ruby, Joe, Denise, Ray, Jessica and Andrew. Memorial donations may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, www.jdrf.org.

DAVIS--Kathryn Wasserman. The Westchester Children's Association mourns the passing and celebrates the life of our former President and long-time friend and supporter. She inspired us to be more passionate, work harder, and dream bigger to build a safer, more peaceful and nurturing world for all our children. We will miss her gentle yet indomitable spirit. Catherine Draper, President Cora Greenberg, Executive Director

DAVID--David S.,MD, Dearest David, now you are in Hashem's embrace and with our parents and Harry. The mysteries of the universe are now revealed to you. Have a beautiful journey home. We will love you forever. Rena and Sami

DAVID--Dr. David Salim, of Beverly Hills, CA passed away peacefully at home on Friday, April 19. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Vera David, PhD; his daughter, Lisa David and granddaughter, Veronica David; his son, Eric (Lacy) David, MD and grandsons Simon and Nathaniel David; his brother Sami David, MD, and sister Karen Chilowicz; and numerous nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his brother Dr. Harry David, MD. Born in Baghdad in 1938, he immigrated with his family to New York City, arriving in 1948. He completed his undergraduate degree at Columbia College, received an MD from Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons and completed his residency in internal medicine at St. Luke's Medical Center, where he was chief resident. He was subsequently attending physician and faculty member at New York Hospital/Cornell Medical Center and the Rogosin Institute in the departments of medicine, surgery and biochemistry. A nephrologist who published more than 100 articles in peer-reviewed journals, he was a member of the team of professionals who cared for the first dialysis and kidney-transplant patients in New York. After moving to Los Angeles, Dr. David was a nephrologist and internist in private practice and a clinical professor of medicine at UCLA School of Medicine. Dr. David was revered as a stellar practitioner of clinical medicine and beloved by his patients, who sought him out for his intuitive and compassionate care. As a boy in Baghdad, Dr. David exercised daily by swimming across the Tigris River; in the US, he played placekicker for the Columbia College football team and served in the United States Army Reserves, from which he was honorably discharged following a brief call to active duty. He was devoted to his family and adored as husband, brother, father, and grandfather, as well as beloved uncle and cousin to the many generations of his family members across the country. Services of Jewish Burial to be held April 22, at Hillside Memorial in Los Angeles. Contributions may be made in his name to the Cedars-Sinai ALS Research Program at giving.cedars-Sinai.edu/makeagift.

BULMAN--Carole K. age 70, died April, 18th at her home in Wainscott, NY after a long courageous battle with cancer. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Raymond F. Bulman, she is survived by her son Raymond K. Bulman and siblings Barbara, Elaine (George), Virginia, Paul and Michael (Mary). Carole was a born leader and founded a successful manufacturing business in 1973, Carole Kasbar Inc. She was widely regarded as a role model for women in business of her generation. Carole brought ardent resolve to everything she did, big and small, -- always with impeccable grace, style and genuine kindness. As a mother and wife, her love knew no bounds; she was the axis on which her family revolved. She will be in our hearts forever.

DAVID--David Salim, MD, a brilliant physician, a loving husband to Vera and father to Lisa and Eric, grandfather to Veronica, Simon and Nathanial, and dear brother to Sami and Karen. Dr. David graduated Summa Cum Laude from Columbia College and Columbia Medical School and headed the first kidney dialysis unit in New York at St. Luke's Hospital. He joined the Rogosin Labs at New York Hospital and was considered there "a once in a lifetime genius in medicine." Taken from us too soon. His brilliant mind and wonderful, gentle heart will be very deeply missed by all of us who love him.

COHEN--Carole G. The leadership, staff and extended family of The Arnold P. Gold Foundation mourn the loss of Carole G. Cohen, wife of the Chair of our Board of Trustees, Jordan J. Cohen, MD. Carole, who spent her career in university advancement work and non-profit management, was a great friend to the Foundation. She believed deeply in the values and mission of The Gold Foundation, which strives to ensure that healthcare professionals are as caring as they are scientifically excellent. As a volunteer for the Foundation, she had a unique ability to see opportunities and pursue them with great, good-natured persistence. She lit up the room with her joy, and when she laughed, we all laughed with her. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Jordan, their children, Deborah Rappaport (Andy), Joel Cohen (Mavis Prall Cohen), and David Cohen (Suzy Friedman Cohen), their eight grandchildren and the entire Cohen family. Donations in her name can be made to the Carole G. Cohen Fund for Humanism in Medicine at The Arnold P. Gold Foundation. Richard I. Levin, MD, President &CEO

BERTHOLD--Arthur J.,86. Outstanding educator, teacher and coach for over 35 years at Harrington Park, NJ, Marlboro & Suffern, NY elementary schools. Loving husband, father, grandfather, & brother. Decorated WWII veteran. "Artie" died April 25, 2013 after a valiant fight against brain cancer. Visitation 4-8pm Thursday, May 2 Riewerts Memorial Home, Bergenfield, NJ. Graveside service 11am Friday, May 3 Hackensack Cemetery.

DAVIS--Kathryn Wasserman, The Women's National Republican Club mourns the passing of our Vice-President, Kathryn Wasserman Davis, a visionary, a leader in International Affairs and an important benefactor. She was an inspiration to all of us. Catherine Lenihan, President

BIDWELL--Lisa, of Newport, RI, died peacefully at home on April 6th, a year after her incurable cancer had been diagnosed. Lisa was born January 12, 1952, Lisa Kerr Grimmelmann, in New York City and grew up in White Plains, New York. A graduate of Bradford College and the New School for Social Research, from which she also received her master's degree, Lisa was for many years the director of development at the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House in New York City. In 1995 she and her husband, Miles Bidwell, founded an economics consulting firm which they ran until last summer. Lisa and Miles sailed their boat across the Atlantic three times, accompanied only by their beloved Maine coon cat, Craig. Lisa was an accomplished sailor, skier, and figure skater. Lisa was a member of The Colonial Dames of America, The Daughters of the American Revolution, The National Society Magna Charta Dames, The Plantagenet Society, and the Colonial Order of the Crown. Lisa was greatly loved and admired and will be deeply missed by her family and her many friends. She is survived by her husband, her parents, Frances and Ihler Grimmelmann, her brother, Erik Grimmelmann, her sister, Ellen Adler, and by her nephew and her two nieces. No memorial is planned. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that contributions be made in Lisa's memory to the Redwood Library and Athenaeum, an organization that Lisa cherished. Contributions to the Redwood (50 Bellevue Ave., Newport, RI 02840) will be placed in the Lisa Bidwell Memorial Fund.

BROOKS--Anita Helen, on April 24, 2013, of New York City. Latin and Greek Teacher, librarian, model, author, on-air radio and TV personality, provider of public relations and services for many authors and organizations and was a friend to many. Graveside services were held at Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

DAVIS--Kathryn Wasserman. Scenic Hudson deeply mourns the passing of Kathryn Wasserman Davis, a visionary philanthropist, environmentalist and champion for world peace. Universally admired for her fearlessness, love of learning and eagerness to tackle new challenges, Mrs. Davis held a special place in her heart for the Hudson River. She was committed to sharing her ardor for the Hudson by providing new places for people to experience its majesty and power. Scenic Hudson is grateful for her giving spirit and the inspiration she always will provide to us. Scenic Hudson offers heartfelt condolences to Mrs. Davis's family, including her daughter Diana Davis Spencer, son Shelby M.C. Davis, grandson Chris Davis and other grandchildren.

COHAN--Leonard, lifelong New Yorker born July 20, 1930, passed away April 22, 2013. Survived by wife Elizabeth, daughter Robin, son-in-law Alan, stepchildren Tom and Pam, Kathleen and Kevin, grandchildren Ryan, Riley and Nolan. Korean War service. Graduate of CCNY and Columbia University. Professor Emeritus, Director of Libraries at Polytechnic Institute. Active member of New York State Archaeological Society.

ABORN--Hermine Friedman 98, passed away on Friday, April 12, 2013 at Greenwich Hospital. Hermine was born in New York City on March 8, 1915. She was predeceased by her husband of 59 years, Louis Aborn, in 2005. She is survived by her son, Sargent Aborn, daughter-in-law, Audrey Aborn, daughter, Nancy Aborn Duffy and son-in-law, Kenneth Duffy, six grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Hermine was a matriarch and an inspiration for her generosity and joie de vivre. Memorial gifts in Hermine's name may be made to Greenwich Hospital.

BARSEL--Jan. We mourn the loss of our dear cousin, Jan Barsel. She was the sweetest, kindest, most thoughtful person. Everyone who knew her loved her. Our sympathy to her wonderful husband, Eli, and her children. Gladys Alpert and Jerry Levy and the Alpert Family

ADAIR--Eleanor Reed, 86, of Hamden CT, on April 20 2013, leaving husband Robert, children Douglas McV. Adair and Margaret Adair Quinn, two grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A 1948 graduate of Mt. Holyoke College, which awarded her an honorary D.Sc. Degree in 2007, she received her Ph.D in sensory psychology from the University of Wisconsin in 1955. Working as a fellow of the John B. Pierce Laboratory in New Haven, CT and later as Senior Scientist at the Air Force Research Laboratory in San Antonio, TX, Ellie's researches illuminated the process of thrmoregulation in primates and human beings. The extraordinary thermal regulation of humans, nearly as superior among vertebrates as human intelligence, is central to the emergence of man, the naked ape, from his furred anthropoid cousins. From her use of microwaves in the heating of experimental animals and humans in her thermoregulation researches, Ellie became expert in the physiological consequences of electromagnetic radiation. Her work in that area was noted especially in her 2007 award of the D'Arsonval Medal of the Bioelectromagnetic Society. Her lifelong love of the mountains and deep generosity of spirit were combined in her years as a board member of the American Himalayan Foundation, where she worked to better the lives of the peoples of the Himalaya. The Beecher and Bennett Funeral Home, 2300 Whitney Ave., Hamden is in charge of the services.

ANELLO--Kerin Anne Gilmore, 44, of Malverne and Bayport, NY, died after a short illness on April 22, 2013 in Stonybrook University Hospital. She is survived by her husband, John Anello and her sons, Thomas John Francis, age nine and Connor Matthew Francis, age eight. She is the daughter of Kathleen and Thomas Gilmore of Blue Point, NY and sister of Brendan and Jennifer Gilmore, Lorin Gilmore and Kristen Gilmore and granddaughter of Winifred Carrocetto. Service to be held on Tuesday, April 30, 2013 at Our Lady of the Snow Church in Blue Point, New York.

BARNETT--James L.,of Rye Brook, passed away on April 25, 2013 at age 79. Jim was born in New York City to the late Ben and Helen Barnett. He was a graduate of the Wharton School of Finance, University of Pennsylvania class of 1955 and went on to obtain a MBA degree from the Bernard Baruch School of Business. He worked most of his career as the chief executive officer for Publix Shirt Corp. Beloved husband of Sue, devoted father to David Barnett (Beth), Amy Spadafino (Frank). Pop pop to Jonathan, Peter, Mia Spadafino and Danielle and Julia Barnett. Loving brother to Alice Schachter (Sherman). Jim will be deeply missed and forever in our memory. Funeral services will be held on Sunday at 11:45am at Congregation B'Nai YIsrael in Armonk. Interment will follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery. For more information or to place an online condolence, www.zionchapel.com.
Want to see Einstein’s family tea set? How about scripts from “The Carol Burnett Show”? Archivists are the specialists who protect and display these objects for posterity, now more online than ever.
The Celtics blew a 19-point lead, but Jason Terry scored Boston’s final 9 points in overtime to deliver a victory and force a Game 5.
Kevin Krigger, who will ride Goldencents in the Kentucky Derby, will be attempting to become the first black jockey to win the race since Jimmy Winkfield won in 1901 and 1902.
Luis Octavio López Vega was once a powerful police chief in Mexico and a valued D.E.A. informant. Today he lives on the run, set adrift by the United States and sought by the Mexican government.
Luis Octavio López Vega era vez un poderoso jefe de policía en México, y un valioso informante de la DEA. Hoy vive huyendo, dejado a la deriva por Estados Unidos y buscado por el gobierno mexicano.
A look at the link between two D.E.A. informants: one, a character played by Benicio Del Toro in the movie “Traffic,” the other, a former adviser to Mexico’s drug czar, now living as a fugitive.
A group of roboticists has developed a robot arm that moves and finds objects by touch, a vital ability if robots are ever to begin to undertake tasks in human environments.
The Queensboro Motorcycle Club, founded in 1910, has had its clubhouse for 70 years wedged among the auto salvage shops in the Willets Point section of Queens.
Television highlights.
Forty Tales won the Derby Trial in Louisville, Ky., and has enough points to enter Saturday’s Kentucky Derby.
Contestants in the Eastern Surf Association’s state championships Saturday in Rockaway found a neighborhood in recovery, as well as a different — and some say improved — pattern of waves.
The bride is a senior manager at Ernst & Young, and the groom is a vice president at Credit Suisse.

The bride and groom met at Duke, and were married at the university’s chapel.

The bride works at the Lebanese American University in Beirut; the groom is a correspondent for Al Jazeera in Qatar.

They met in Russia, and he later proposed to her there.
The couple work in Chicago, she as the editor of Plate, a magazine for chefs, and he as an information technology project manager for a mortgage company.

An owner of Field Decorative Finishes in Brooklyn marries the general manager of design and development at the Soho House Group of London.

The president ribbed his critics at the annual White House Correspondents Association gala.
Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 28.
The Washington Capitals have signed goaltender Michal Neuvirth to a two-year, $5 million contract extension.
Detroit defeated Dallas, 3-0, and qualified for the playoffs for the 22nd consecutive season. Minnesota edged out Columbus for the other berth.
The United States set a national record in winning the women’s 3,200-meter relay at the Penn Relays in Philadelphia with a time of 8 minutes 4.31 seconds.
Louisiana State running back Jeremy Hill, already on probation in connection with a 2011 arrest, was arrested again early Saturday.
Lucas Glover increased his lead to two strokes in the Zurich Classic in Avondale, La.
In the wake of their revolution, Egyptians must determine for themselves what their capital should look like: not just politically and socially, but also architecturally.
Tim Cahill scored twice in the Red Bulls’ victory over host Toronto.
Rafael Nadal moved one victory from his eighth Barcelona Open title in nine years when he thrashed fifth-seeded Milos Raonic to set up a final against fourth-seeded Nicolas Almágro.
A full list of N.F.L. draft picks with teams, schools and positions.
Russian authorities never explained the reason for their concern until after the Boston Marathon bombings.
Ms. Begum was one of the first female playback singers in Hindi cinema — she was heard but not seen on screen, as other actresses lip-synced her work.
The Braves lost to the Tigers, 7-4, on Saturday and have won just three of seven since starting the season 12-1.
Mr. Branton successfully defended the activist and academic Angela Davis in 1972, and also argued cases on behalf of the Black Panthers and the Communist Party.
Winning numbers for April 27, 2013, for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
The Jets took the would-be franchise quarterback Geno Smith in the second round of the N.F.L. draft but did not select a dynamic newcomer to pair with him.
The Alekhine Memorial tournament merges chess and art by holding games at both the Tuileries Garden in Paris and the Russian Museum in St. Petersburg.
Marc Gasol and Zach Randolph each scored 24 points to lift the Grizzlies over the Clippers and ensure a Game 6. The series is tied, 2-2.
An elbow to Jason Terry’s face in Game 3 led to the suspension of the Knicks’ J.R. Smith, and renewed emotion from the reeling Boston Celtics.
The Knicks, who have dominated the Celtics for three games, will play Game 4 without their second leading scorer, J.R. Smith, who was suspended for his flagrant foul on Boston’s Jason Terry.
The 5-foot-9 Nate Robinson, a backup point guard to the injured Derrick Rose, became an unlikely hero in a memorable game against the Nets.
A 787 carrying top executives from Boeing and All Nippon took off from Haneda Airport on Tokyo’s waterfront Sunday morning, without incident.
Feral pigs — the ill-tempered eating machines that have long been a bane in the South — are invading the North, often having escaped private shooting ranches, which are fighting efforts to ban them.
The quarterback’s decision not to enter the N.F.L. draft last year, when he was highly rated, will serve as a cautionary tale for underclassmen. He fell to the fourth round Saturday.
Ethnic Hazaras, who have borne the brunt of recent violence in Pakistan, are increasingly seeking refuge in Australia, but they must travel a long and perilous path to get there.
State senators passed a bill to change how school districts and courts handle truancy, which some say are unfair and overly punitive.
