On Tuesday, in a hushed sixth-floor reading room in New York University’s Bobst Library packed with students cramming for final exams, the answer might have seemed to be: nothing much.

An article on Tuesday about federal authorities’ scrutinizing the activities of Katherine Russell, wife of the Boston Marathon bombing suspect who was killed, misstated the name of the Rhode Island town where she grew up. It is North Kingstown, not North Kingston.

LONDON — As Big Oil increasingly becomes Big Gas, no major petroleum player may have more at stake in the shift than Royal Dutch Shell .
 
More than any of its rivals, Royal Dutch Shell, which will report its quarterly results on Thursday, is betting its future on the business of bringing natural gas from remote locations like Qatar to energy-hungry destinations like China and Japan.

Arthur Pita’s award-winning interpretation of Kafka’s “Metamorphosis,” originally staged by the Royal Ballet in London, will open the fall dance season at the Joyce Theater on Sept. 17, with the Royal Ballet principal Edward Watson dancing the role of Gregor Samsa, and Frank Moon performing his own score live. The production, which runs through Sept. 29, is the first of 16 that the theater has scheduled through February 2014. 
 
Cloud Gate 2, the Taiwanese company that made its New York debut at the Joyce last year, returns with “On the Road,” a piece by Cheng Tsun-lung, the ensemble’s associate artistic director (Oct. 2-6). The piece is set to a varied score that includes Taiwanese folk songs, Islamic music and recordings by Tom Waits.

As more of the very young reach for their parents’ smartphones, toy companies are responding with motion-sensing, app-infused toys like the Fisher-Price Apptivity Gym ($35, www.fisher-price.com). 
 
Here’s how this particular toy works. After you download one of the free Apptivity apps and adjust the timer and music settings, you snap your phone or iPod Touch into a child-proof container attached to the plastic “gym’’ on which the child plays. If you search iTunes for “Apptivity” you can find several free apps, including B ‘n W High Contrast in which interesting animals peek from the sides of the screen with large faces. You can speed things along with any bump or a random touch of the screen.

I recently had a conversation with someone who is starting a social enterprise to connect corporate sponsors with the social networks of activists, athletes, musicians and others. He was asking me for advice on learning to code so that he could start to build his site.
 
I recommended that he learn the fundamentals of coding so that he could find a great technical co-founder and that he test the idea without building the whole concept. Through the conversation, I ended up sharing a list of tools that I thought might help him get started. With the hope that they may be helpful to others as well, here are my favorite start-up tools. And of course, please share your favorites in the comment section below. TO TEST AN IDEA

A picture caption last Thursday with the Scene City column misidentified a guest shown with Lena Dunham and Molly McNearney at the dinner honoring Time magazine’s 100 influential people. He is Jimmy Kimmel, not Jimmy Fallon.

Last week, we published a case study about an entrepreneur, new to the furniture business, who had expanded his business selling patio and deck furniture to $7 million in annual sales. Instead of selling through sales representatives, Gerald Shvartsman, founder and chief executive of Source Outdoor , which is based in Miami, employed a multichannel sales strategy.
 
He sold to South Florida furniture retailers, fulfilled orders taken by Internet merchants, cut deals with local decorators and designers, and did not overlook an opportunity right under his nose — the beachfront march of condos, all needing outdoor furniture around their pools. But Mr. Shvartsman hit a speed bump when he started enjoying much higher profits through a fifth sales channel: selling his goods at retail prices at local home shows.

When Dr. Charles McBurney, an eminent 19th-century surgeon, was given the opportunity to create the ideal operating room, he insisted that there be lots of light and air. That’s not a bad arrangement for precocious schoolchildren, either.
 
Dr. McBurney’s legacy, the landmark William J. Syms Operating Theater of Roosevelt Hospital, at Ninth Avenue and 59th Street, is to reopen this fall as the new home of the four-year-old Speyer Legacy School, now at 15 West 86th Street.

An article on Saturday about the likely passage of a federal bill to require some online retailers to collect out-of-state sales tax described incorrectly which retailers would be required to collect the tax. It would apply to merchants with more than $1 million in out-of-state sales, not more than $1 million in revenue.

Change comes slowly to the venerable halls of “Downton Abbey,” but it does eventually arrive. On Wednesday the producers of that popular British period drama announced a new addition to its roster of characters, played by the first black actor who will appear on the series. ITV, the television network that broadcasts “Downton Abbey” in Britain said on its Web site that Gary Carr, a London-born actor who has appeared on the television series “Bluestone 42″ and “Death in Paradise,” would join “Downton Abbey” in its coming fourth season as Jack Ross, a jazz singer who is described as “a charming and charismatic young man.”

An article on Monday about venture capitalists’ interest in food-related start-ups misstated the restaurant experience of Chris Muscarella, a co-founder of the site Kitchensurfing. While he has worked in restaurants, he has not been a chef. The article also referred incorrectly to the investment history of Google Ventures. It has indeed made food-related investments, providing venture capital to Blue Bottle Coffee, a specialty retailer; it is not the case that it has not yet put money into such companies.

Michael Bublé stormed to the top of the Billboard 200 chart on Wednesday with his new album “To Be Loved” (Reprise), which sold 195,000 copies and gave the Canadian crooner his fourth No. 1 set.
 
The runner-up slot this week belonged to another new album — Fantasia’s “Side Effects of You” (RCA). The album, which sold 91,000 copies, is the R&B singer’s most personal recording so far, as she co-wrote seven of the 12 songs.

An article on Tuesday about ways in which universities are blending online courses into their curriculum misidentified the alma mater of Rachel Meltzer, a mentor for students taking classes with the online provider Udacity. She graduated from Washington University in St. Louis — not from Stanford, where she worked as a clinical research manager.

Sol Republic, maker of headphones with swappable parts, recently expanded its offerings with the release of its Master Tracks line, which incorporates over-ear headphones for the first time. 
 
Like the company’s on-ear headphones, the Master Tracks components are interchangeable. You can swap out the headband or cables for parts of different colors, allowing you to customize the look, and the Master Tracks are compatible with Sol Republic’s on-ear headphone lines.

An article on Tuesday about the philosopher Daniel Dennett, whose new book, “Intuition Pumps and Other Tools for Thinking,” comes out next week, misstated a word in Mr. Dennett’s “Philosophical Lexicon” that is defined as “an artificial enzyme used to curdle the milk of human intentionality.” It is “dennett,” not “Dennettation.”

The Frieze, NADA, Pulse and PooL art fairs will arrive in New York next week, with countless attendant gallery openings and parties. Even if you are detached from the art world, it’s a fitting time to dress the part. After all, gallerinas, and the women who frequent art openings, have a statement-making style of dress that can be artwork in itself. Case in point: China Chow, art world habitué and onetime host of “Work of Art: The Next Great Artist” on Bravo, in an elliptical Viktor & Rolf dress from next fall’s collection, looked like a walking sculpture at a Museum of Contemporary Art gala in Los Angeles (far left). The key is simply a great dress, beautifully draped, in a modern cut. For color, it’s black or an arty (read: not trendy) print. Here are a few by designers who do that kind of thing well. 
 
From second from left: Tsumori Chisato gathered-front cotton-blend dress with pockets, $565 at Kisan, 125 Greene Street, (212) 475-2470; Christophe Lemaire speckle-print T-shirt dress $550 at Bird, 203 Grand Street, Brooklyn, shopbird.com ; Rachel Comey one-shoulder silk dress, $472 at rachelcomey.com ; Zero + Maria Cornejo sleeveless jersey dress with draped detail, $425 at Zero + Maria

It was 2009, not 2007.

GLICKMAN--Albert Brenner, family man, philanthropist and business genius, died peacefully on April 27th in Los Angeles. Born in Portland, Maine, Al was raised by his widowed mother Mildred Brenner. Millie later married Joe Glickman and the family moved to California. Al's greatest love was his wife Judy. They met at UCLA where Al was close friends with her brother Richard. Al skillfully wooed her away from all other suitors. Al and Judy were partners in life, family, travel, and tennis. They were married for 54 years of romance and laughter, loyalty and love. He is missed by a large and loving family: children Jeff (Mindy), Tigraw, David (Paige), and Brenner (Elaine); and many grandchildren; brother Bob; and loving nieces, nephews and cousins. Al eschewed the practice of law to become a real estate broker. Soon he established his own company pioneering the community shopping center. He built islands of retail in towns throughout California and the West. The idea and the company flourished. Al had a great zeal for life. He enjoyed traveling the world, sunset cruising on his boat L'Chaim and skiing from the top of the mountain to the bottom without stopping. Through extraordinary charm and chutzpah, Al convinced the staff at Aspen Mountain to allow him to ride up the gondola each morning before the mountain opened. For years, he and four friends would enjoy the first tracks down the mountain. Wherever he lived, Al was always surrounded by friends. His magnetism was contagious while family and friends flocked to his side. Because of his sincerity, caring and insights, many, many people considered Al their best friend. Al loved action and cherished being an insider among decision-makers. He was a friend and advisor to presidents, senators, and governors. Dedicated to his community, Al had a tremendous impact on dozens of boards of charities, universities, hospitals and museums including: Cedars Sinai Hospital, Federal Home Loan Bank Board of Boston, International Council of Shopping Centers, Jewish Community Alliance, The Kennedy Center, Maine Public Broadcasting Network, Natural History Museum of Los Angeles, Portland Museum of Art, Portland Symphony, Spring Harbor Hospital, Spurwink School, UCLA, University of Maine System, University of New England and the University of Southern Maine. As a leader in the Michael J. Fox Foundation, Al focused his energies and resources in the pursuit of finding a cure for Parkinson's Disease, knowing the benefit was for future generations, not himself. Notwithstanding his immense accomplishments, family was always his highest priority. Al prided himself on being home for dinner with the family every night. He created a family retreat on Great Diamond Island in Maine, where his kids and grandkids reunite every summer. From humble beginnings, Al created a life that was extraordinary. He leaves a legacy of generosity and goodness. His family, friends, and community will forever feel blessed. Please send your support to the Michael J. Fox Foundation.

ROBOFF--Stanley B.,91. Beloved husband of Phyllis, father of Gary, Sari, and Annie, grandfather of Mark and Daniel, father-in-law to Farron and Joe, and fast friend to many. Stan was born in Rochester, NY, graduated from MIT, and served in WWII at Oak Ridge, on the Manhattan project. He was an expert (and author) on nuclear fuels and worked to advance the peaceful and safe use of the atom throughout his career. Later, Stanley was a pioneer in producing, brokering, and consulting on advanced metals and composite materials. Graveside service Thursday, May 2 at 11am at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla. Donations in lieu of flowers to the AFTD Drug Discovery Partnership.

GRAHAM--Jean Lyons, on May 1, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving mother of Neal and Jeannette (Stewart), Hugh and Gordon (Clark), and Candy and Richard Mandel. Cherished grandmother of Jessica, Damon, David, Isaac and Janine. Services 11:30am Friday, May 3rd, 2013 at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. boulevardriversidechapel.com

PLEVAN--Jeffrey Barasch. Our hearts go out to our partner, Betsy Plevan, and her husband, Ken, on the untimely passing of their beloved son, Jeffrey Barasch Plevan. We know their loss is unimaginable, and we extend our deepest sympathies to them and their family. A graduate of the Dwight School, the University of Arizona and Gratz College, where he received two masters degrees, Jeff was working as the Development Associate at Hunter College Hillel, and recently returned from a trip to Israel. He will be remembered by those who knew him for his infectious personality and positive spirit. Betsy is a dear friend and a source of inspiration to us. Her women partners wish Betsy and the Plevan family peace at this devastating time.

LAFER--Fred. The Shalom Hartman Institute mourns the passing of our friend and supporter Fred Lafer. Mr. Lafer was Chairman of the Executive Committee of the SHI Board of Directors and instrumental in facilitating the Institute's work in North America.

LAFER--Fred S. American Friends of The Hebrew University (AFHU) and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Fred S. Lafer, whose commitment to Israel and The Hebrew University spanned more than three decades. The loving husband of Barbara, treasured father of Diana, Deborah, and Gordon, and proud grandfather to six grandchildren, Fred will long be remembered for his inspired leadership and successful efforts to foster human progress. Fred, an esteemed national Scopus Award recipient, served as both Honorary Chairman and Honorary President of AFHU, having fulfilled both leadership roles in the service of AFHU's mission. He was an Honorary Governor of The Hebrew University International Board of Governors and received an Honorary Doctorate from Hebrew University in tribute to his achievements and humanitarianism. Fred and his beloved Barbara established the Lafer Center for Women's Studies and Gender Research at Hebrew University and advanced visionary research at the Lautenberg Center for General and Tumor Immunology. We extend our deepest sympathies to Barbara and the entire Lafer family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson, President; American Friends of The Hebrew University George A. Schieren, Chairman Martin E. Karlinsky, President Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director

LAFER--Fred. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the passing of Fred Lafer of Wayne, NJ. An advocate for education, he will be remembered for his exceptional service to the Technion as a member of the board of trustees for the Henry and Marilyn Taub Foundation. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Barbara, daughters Diana Lafer and Deborah Lafer Scher, son Gordon Lafer, and the entire Lafer family, and members of the Taub Foundation board. American Technion Society Scott Leemaster, president Joel S. Rothman, chairman of the board Melvyn H. Bloom, executive vice president
ROSEN--Louis. Our condolences go out to the Rosen family. We mourn the loss of our cousin and great friend who will be truly missed. Herb and Sandi
LAFER--Fred, Deeply devoted to causes he cared about. Fred Lafer's friendship, guidance and encouragement will be sorely missed and always remembered. Hanna and Ron Zweig
ROGERS--H. Pete. ROGERS--Reita. Two gentle souls meet, marry, have children. We all love you, and carry you always in our hearts. Your family, B. J. J. T.

NATHAN--Edgar J.,III. The American Jewish Historical Society mourns the passing of our friend and esteemed former chairman Edgar J. Nathan III. The Nathan family's involvement with the Society began with his father, Judge Edgar J. Nathan II. Descended from the Sephardic families who were the first Jews to settle in North America, Edgar Nathan was related to the distinguished Cardozo, Lazarus and Touro families. He was admired for remarkable skill as a negotiator and beloved for his gracious and gentle manner. The Trustees of the Society extend their sympathy to his wife Ruth, children Sara and David, his brother Fred and to all members of the Nathan family. Paul Warhit, President; Dan Kaplan and Sid Lapidus, Co-Chairs; Jonathan Karp, Executive Dir.
KINSBRUNER--Florence. 12/25/1909-5/3/2008 5 years, forever in our hearts. Your family

PLEVAN--Jeffrey Barasch. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP extend our deepest sympathy to our friend and partner Ken Plevan and our colleague Betsy Plevan for the untimely loss of their beloved son Jeffrey, who died unexpectedly this week at the age of 36. Our thoughts are with Ken, Betsy and their family as they mourn Jeff's passing and cherish his memory.

SCOURBY-D'ARC--Stephanie. Singer and singing teacher, age 92, taught her last lesson April 11th and died at home on April 25th surrounded by the voices of her family. Stephanie's passion for music began early in life and was encouraged by her loving Greek family. Her father James had The Bay Ridge Dining Room and he and his wife Katherine (Sidereas) could not do enough for their children. While her friends played outside on Saturday afternoons, Stephanie stayed indoors listening to opera under the guise of doing chores for her beloved mother. After attending the Mannes School of Music, Stephanie began a singing career which spanned opera, lieder, Greek Folk Songs and Negro Spirituals on BBC Radio. She sang in the US and Europe including debuts in New York's Town Hall and London's Wigmore Hall and gave many concerts for wounded WWII soldiers. Her happiest years were raising her daughters and they both survive her. Karen Scourby D'Arc who immortalized her mother in a children's book, "My Grandmother Is a Singing Yaya" and Pamela D'Arc Corwin with her husband Andrew Corwin gave her the cherished grandchildren who adored her and in whose lives she was deeply involved: Katherine and Alexander Corwin. Generations of students will carry on the life's work of their loving teacher and mentor, Miss Scourby. She used her brilliant technique not only to teach opera singers and Broadway actors, but to restore speaking to survivors of strokes and Parkinson's. In the 1960's, she was also the underground teacher for students from the Juilliard and the singing teacher for 20th Century Fox's program to develop young artists. The last five years of her life she was able to remain at home, still teaching, looked after by her daughter Karen. We'd love to hear from people with memories to share. Please call or go to www.legacy.com. Funeral to be held Monday, May 6, Viewing 11am, Service 12 noon at Sts Constantine & Helen Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 64 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201. Followed by Burial at Cypress Hills Cemetery, Queens.
GARDNER--Elinor W. 25 years. We miss you. We Love You. Peter and Ken

PLEVAN--Jeffrey. The Board of Directors and team of the National Center for Learning Disabilities extend heartfelt condolences to Ken & Betsy Plevan and family during this time of sadness. Jeffrey will always be remembered for his generosity of spirit and strong connection to his community. He was and will be an inspiration to us all. Fred Poses, Chairman James Wendorf, Executive Director

SEGERS--Richard G.,84, Mathematics Professor, of Mendham, NJ passed away peacefully on April 30, 2013 at home with his family. Richard received his Ph.D. in mathematics from Purdue University after earning his undergraduate degree in mathematics from the University of Dayton. Richard taught mathematics for over 25 years at Fairleigh Dickinson University in Florham Park, and was a visiting professor of mathematics at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business in 1969-1970. Richard is survived by his beloved wife of 56 years, Elizabeth (Harrison), of Mendham and his four children: Richard Carl (and wife Judy) of Flemington, NJ, Beth of Brookline, MA; Alix DeRosa (Segers) and husband Joseph of Ashburn, VA, and Stephanie of Queens, NY, as well as grandchildren, Natalie and Charlie Segers of Flemington, NJ and Anne Marie and Katharine DeRosa of Ashburn, VA. Services by the Bailey Funeral Home, Mendham, NJ. www.baileyfuneralhomes.com

BERLINER--Joan Anderson, died January 1, 2010, age 74, leaving a sister, Velma Anderson and a loving husband. Most of Joan's family had passed away, mostly to cancer, and Joan seemed convinced that it was now her turn. Joan was a teacher, a student of American history, a lover of music, art, poetry and literature. She had empathy for humanity in all its guises, but particularly, young people just learning how the world works. Her spirit remains with us.

NATHAN--Edgar J.,III The Yeshiva University family and the Board of Overseers of the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law are grieved by the passing of Edgar J. Nathan III, a distinguished attorney and member of an illustrious Sephardic family, who served as a founding member of the Board of Overseers from 1977 until 1985 and as an honorary member from 1985 until his death. His kindness, gentle manner, aristocratic refinement and wisdom inspired the respect and admiration of all who knew him. He enthusiastically supported the establishment of Yeshiva University's Sephardic Studies Program in 1964. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his beloved wife and partner in noble deeds, Ruth G. Nathan and their children, Sara E. and Joel and David J. and Rebecca, their grandchildren, and his cherished brother, Frederic S. Nathan and the entire family. Min hashamayim tenuhamu. May they all find comfort among those who mourn from Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor

PLEVAN--Jeffrey Barasch, died suddenly and unexpectedly at the age of 36. He will be terribly missed by his parents Betsy and Ken Plevan, his grandmother Tina Barasch, his brother and sister-in-law Rabbi William Plevan and Sara Shapiro Plevan, his nephew Ariel Plevan, and his aunts, uncles, cousins, colleagues, and numerous friends all over the world. Jeff attended the Gateway School, Stephen Gaynor School, Eagle Hill School in Greenwich, and graduated from the Dwight School. He graduated from the University of Arizona and received two masters degrees from Gratz College. A Jewish professional, he was working as the Development Associate at Hunter College Hillel, and had recently returned from a trip to Israel. He will be remembered by those who knew him for his infectious personality and positive spirit. He was President of the MetroCats, the New York chapter of the University of Arizona Alumni Association, and was devoted to his University as well as his college fraternity, Phi Kappa Psi. He was a lifelong collector of vinyl records and an avid student of folk music. He volunteered each year for the Clearwater folk festival. Funeral services will be held at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue, New York, on Friday, May 3 at 9:30am. The family will be sitting Shiva at the home of Betsy and Ken Plevan on Friday afternoon from 3:00pm to 6:00pm, Sunday from 11:00am to 3:00pm and 5:00pm to 9:00pm, and Monday evening from 5:00pm to 9:00pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in Jeff's memory may be made to Hunter College Hillel or the Clearwater Foundation. May his memory be a blessing.

TUTCHINGS--Pirie (aka Pirie MacDonald), theatre and television actor and director, died in New Milford, CT on April 19, 2013 from complications of Parkinson's disease. He was 81. A memorial service will be held on June 29, at 2pm in the Congregational Church of Bridgewater, CT. Donations to The Ensemble Studio Theatre, Development Office, 549 West 52 Street, New York, NY, 10019 may be made in Pirie's honor.

ZACCARIA--Joseph J.,on Wednesday, May 1st. Beloved brother and uncle. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, 10am at St. Anthony's Church, Sullivan Street. Interment, Calvary Cemetery. Friends may call Saturday, 2-5 and 7-9pm and Sunday 2-6pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

Performances of the Broadway play “The Nance” will be extended by eight weeks through August 11, Lincoln Center Theater announced on Thursday, aiming to capitalize on the Tony Award nomination this week for lead actor Nathan Lane. 
 
The show received four Tony nominations for design contributions as well, though not a best play nomination for the playwright, Douglas Carter Beane. The play, which opened to good reviews in April, is about the personal and professional travails of a gay New Yorker (played by Mr. Lane) who performs in a 1930s burlesque theater as a nance, a brazenly effeminate stock character. The production by the nonprofit Lincoln Center Theater has been selling well; it took in $445,409 last week, or 60 percent of the maximum possible gross, a solid amount for a play.

Edward Albee’s “Laying an Egg,” announced six weeks ago as a centerpiece of the Signature Theater’s 2013-14 season, has been postponed for the second time, the company announced on Thursday. Mr. Albee’s work was originally to have had its world premiere as part of the Off Broadway company’s 2011-12 season – its first at the Pershing Square Signature Center, its new Midtown space – but was postponed when the famously self-critical playwright, now 85, decided that it needed revamping.
 
In place of Mr. Albee’s work, the company will present the world premiere of “The Old Friends,” a new work by Horton Foote. The play, about two Texas farming families who find themselves at odds, will be directed by Michael Wilson, and will have Betty Buckley, Hallie Foote and Lois Smith in its cast. Previews begin on Aug. 20; the opening is scheduled for Sept. 12.

FEIGELES--Edward. We are saddened by the sudden loss of our dear friend, Eddie. Our hearts and thoughts are with our dearest friends, Kathy, Kara, Sam and Greg. Much love, Barry, Jill, Joshua, Marissa, Peter and Casey Lafer

Who needs to wait another three years to choose America’s second-in-command? Not HBO, that’s for sure: on Wednesday, that cable network announced it was ordering a third season of “Veep,” its comedy series starring Julia Louis-Dreyfus as the vice president of the United States. In its first season in 2012, “Veep,” created by Armando Iannucci (the author of the political satires “The Thick of It” and “In the Loop”) was an Emmy nominee for outstanding comedy; Ms. Louis-Dreyfus, an Emmy winner for her performances on “Seinfeld” and “The New Adventures of Old Christine,” earned her third such award for portraying the “Veep” title character, Selina Meyer. “Veep” was just three episodes into its second season (which started on April 14) when HBO announced its latest renewal. The network said a third season of 10 episodes will be shown next year.

On Tuesday the Tony Award big shots had their say, spreading around nominations to 26 Broadway plays and musicals – and shutting out several others. Now some of the scorned are striking back: The producers of Bette Midler’s hit play “I’ll Eat You Last” and Alan Cumming’s mostly-one-man version of “Macbeth” are pulling back free tickets for many of the 868 Tony voters, and instead offering to sell them at standard prices of about $135 each.
 
While a few Tony voters have been heard grousing over drinks at theater district hangouts, a spokesman for “I’ll Eat You Last” said on Thursday that many voters were understanding and had decided to purchase seats to see Ms. Midler, in her first role on Broadway since “Fiddler on the Roof” in the late 1960s.

DURKIN--Mary Pritchard. Mary Pritchard Durkin, of New York City died on May 1, 2013 after a long battle with lung cancer. Mary was born on January 19, 1941 in Minneapolis, MN and was the daughter of Elizabeth and Manion Pritchard. She is survived by her husband of 38 years, Charles P. Durkin Jr., her son, Charles P. Durkin III, and daughter-in-law, Kristen. She had two sisters, Elizabeth and Anne (deceased), a brother, Thomas, and eleven nieces and nephews. Mary is a graduate of Sacred Heart School in Lake Forest, IL and the University of Minnesota. Following graduation Mary moved to New York where she was a teacher and an independent photographer for a number of years. Mary maintained houses in East Hampton, NY, Boca Grande, FL, and Kempton, PA. She was a member of the Colony Club, Maidstone Club, and the Gasparilla Club. Her interests included bridge, politics, travel, entertaining, water aerobics, dancing, and ice skating. Mary devoted her life to her family and many friends. She was fiercely loyal, deeply loving, principled, courageous and thankful for the many joys in life. We will miss her always. The Mary Durkin Fund for Student Life has been established in her memory at St. Andrew's School, 350 Noxontown Road, Middletown, DE 19709 to which contributions may be made in lieu of flowers. Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Monday, May 6, 2013 at 4pm at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street. Interment private.

More than a year after Ted Genoways resigned as the editor of the Virginia Quarterly Review, the literary journal has named a successor.
 
The new editor, W. Ralph Eubanks, is currently the director of publishing at the Library of Congress in Washington. His most recent book is “The House at the End of the Road: The Story of Three Generations of an Interracial Family in the American South.” He will begin at the magazine on June 3.

An article on Thursday about charges filed against three friends of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the surviving suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings, misstated the name of the school in Cambridge, Mass., attended by Mr. Tsarnaev and one of the friends, Robel K. Phillipos. It is Cambridge Rindge and Latin School, not Cambridge Ringe and Latin High School. The article also described incorrectly a visit between Mr. Tsarnaev and another friend who was charged, Dias Kadyrbayev. When the two chatted outside Mr. Tsarnaev’s dormitory two days after the explosions, it was Mr. Kadyrbayev who smoked a cigarette, not Mr. Tsarnaev.

DREYER--Randolph (Randy), 88, of Brooklyn, April 30, 2013. Randy was the loving son of the late Herman and Sophy (Goldfarb) Dreyer, and the beloved brother of Eugene. Uncle of Jon Dreyer, Gabriela Romanow and Dena Fleisher. Great uncle of Katya and Sarah Dreyer-Oren, Jake and Max Romanow, and Jack and Benjamin Fleisher. Randy fought in the European theater in World War II, and was a liberator of the Buchenwald camp. He was a paper salesman as a profession. He also spoke with school children about the Second World War and helped on a jazz radio program. A graveside service will be held at the Wellwood Cemetery in Pinelawn, New York at 11:00am on Sunday, May 5. In lieu of flowers, remembrances can be made in Randy's memory to woundedwarriorproject.org.

Temporary public art projects are plentiful in New York City but they rarely make their way to the South Bronx and almost never to the grounds of public housing projects. But beginning this month the Swiss artist Thomas Hirschhorn , with the help of the Dia Art Foundation , will build the last in a series of temporary monuments at the Forest Houses, a New York City Housing Authority development in the Morrisania neighborhood of the Bronx.
 
Called “The Gramsci Monument,” the work – which will take the form of a kind of temporary pavilion built on the grounds of the housing project – will be the fourth such monument Mr. Hirschhorn has built over the last several years, dedicated to writers and philosophers – like Spinoza, Gilles Deleuze and Georges Bataille – whose ideas have inspired him. Antonio Gramsci was an Italian political theorist and Marxist who was imprisoned for many years under Mussolini. “The Gramsci Monument” will be the first such installation in the United States by Mr. Hirschhorn, who said he had chosen the site because of his desire to “create a new form” of public art, “based on love for a ‘non-exclusive audience.’ ”

7:54 p.m. | Updated 

 
Steven A. Cohen, the founder of the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors, sat for a deposition in a lawsuit in 2011 and acknowledged that he was unfamiliar with his firm’s compliance and ethics policies on insider trading.

An article on Tuesday about a recommendation by the N.B.A. relocation committee that the league’s owners reject a request to move the Sacramento Kings to Seattle erroneously included, in some editions, one owner among the members of the committee. James L. Dolan, owner of the Knicks, is a member of the league’s advisory finance committee, which is evaluating the sale of the Kings; he is not a member of the relocation committee.

APUZZO--Joseph G. Sr.,died on May 1st, 2013 at the age of 88. He resided in Rye Brook, New York. Mr. Apuzzo was born in the Bronx, lived on Long Island for ten years and from 1965 to the present, in Westchester. He was a graduate of St. John's University, a decorated WWII veteran and a Certified Public Accountant. He was the CEO of Armenia Coffee Corporation of Purchase, New York until his retirement. He served for many years on the Boards of Directors of the Green Coffee Association of New York, the National Coffee Association, the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and of Armenia Coffee Corporation. He was a member of St. Paul's Catholic Church in Greenwich, CT where a wake will be held from 4 8pm on Sunday, May 5, 2013. A funeral mass will be held on Monday, May 6th at 11am, also at St. Paul's. He will be interred in Saint Mary's Cemetary in Port Chester, NY. He is survived by his beloved wife Jean of 64 years, four children; Janet Olszewski of Greenwich, CT; Carol Long of New Fairfield, CT; Diane Apuzzo of Pound Ridge, NY and Joseph Apuzzo of New Canaan, CT; 11 grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Jude Children's Hospital. Arrangements by Craft Memorial Home, Inc. 40 Leicester St. Port Chester, NY (914) 939-0131

An article on Tuesday about the challenges facing Sally Jewell as she assumes command of the Department of Interior, referred incorrectly to a trip Ms. Jewell and her daughter took. They went on the Tour du Mont Blanc, which took them through France, Italy and Switzerland; they did not go “to Switzerland” to climb Mont Blanc. (The mountain is on the border of France and Italy.)

An article in some editions last Friday about the Nets’ 79-76 loss to the Chicago Bulls in Game 3 of their N.B.A. playoff series misstated, in some copies, the number of shots the Nets missed before C. J. Watson’s last-second 3-point attempt. They missed 52, not 80. (The Nets had tried 80 shots before Watson’s miss, finishing the game 28 for 81 from the field.)

Izzy Young, who owned the Folklore Center in Greenwich Village during the height of the folk revival, is famous for having nurtured a young Bob Dylan when he first arrived in New York City. Mr. Dylan would hang around the back of Mr. Young’s store on Macdougal Street, listening to records and writing songs, and it was Mr. Young who organized Mr. Dylan’s first concert in the city in 1961.
 
That relationship soured after Dylan went electric in 1965 and folk purists accused him of selling out. Now Mr. Young, 85, is the one selling something: a manuscript of an unpublished song Mr. Dylan gave him in 1963 while he was working on the groundbreaking album “The Freewheelin’ Bob Dylan.” Christie’s auction house said the manuscript will be sold in London on June 26, as part of the house’s Pop Culture Sale.

An article on Wednesday about a lawsuit against Harvard that provides rare detail on the issues involving a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder misidentified the organization that sets the criteria for A.D.H.D. It is the American Psychiatric Association, not the American Psychological Association.

Columbia University has its verdant quad, New York University has Washington Square, but until recently, Baruch College, the City University of New York’s outpost in the Flatiron District, had no outdoor space to call its own.
 
The college is housed primarily in buildings that flank East 25th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues, where students would dodge traffic — an estimated 20,000 street crossings a day, not all of them legal — to get from class to class.

The Wealth Matters column on Saturday, about the intricacies of estate planning under new federal laws, misidentified a type of trust that is at issue under the new rules. It is a credit shelter trust, not a marital trust. (The two are treated differently under estate tax law, and the terms are not interchangeable as used in the column.)

An article in some editions on Saturday about the Knicks’ 90-76 victory over the Celtics in Game 3 of their N.B.A. playoff series misstated, in some copies, the year of the Knicks’ last four-game playoff sweep. It was 1999, not 1969.

Because of an editing error, an article on April 25 about a building in Hamburg, Germany, that uses algae for heating and cooling misstated the ownership of the Web site smartgeometry.org . The site describes itself as founded by leading architectural and engineering practices and educational institutions. It is not the Web site of Jan Wurm, who described bioreactors in an article posted there.

An article on Thursday about the new Mariinsky II theater in St. Petersburg, Russia, referred incorrectly to a performance of George Balanchine’s “Symphony in C” that is on one of the programs in the opening week. While that performance is part of a program honoring the ballerina Diana Vishneva, she will not be dancing in that work.
On Friday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City because of Orthodox Good Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

It is a scene that has played out over and over at the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan.
 
A once high-flying hedge fund trader stands before a judge, often apologizing for his misdeeds. A high-priced defense lawyer asks for leniency, arguing that the client has lived — outside of his insider trading crimes — an otherwise admirable life. After listening intently, the judge rejects those pleas and sends the defendant to prison.

In most years, Berkshire Hathaway ’s annual meeting is a weekend-long ode to capitalism and generally a lovefest for Warren E. Buffett .
 
But on Saturday, a hedge fund manager handpicked by the billionaire himself will try to add some skepticism to the proceedings.

Government investigators have found that JPMorgan Chase devised “manipulative schemes” that transformed “money-losing power plants into powerful profit centers,” and that one of its most senior executives gave “false and misleading statements” under oath.
 
The findings appear in a confidential government document, reviewed by The New York Times, that was sent to the bank in March, warning of a potential crackdown by the regulator of the nation’s energy markets.
It’s game-on for Karzai with C.I.A. “ghost money.”
After blowing most of a 26-point lead, the Knicks stopped the Celtics’ comeback attempt to advance to the Eastern Conference semifinals.
Quotation of the day for Friday, May 3, 2013.
The work of a Yiddish poet and a klezmer composer are combined in “The Megile of Itzik Manger.”
Mark Nadler’s “I’m a Stranger Here Myself: Musik From the Weimar and Beyond,” at the York Theater Company, broadens his cabaret show about Germany before the Nazi crackdown.
At the Frederick Law Olmsted awards luncheon of the Women’s Committee of the Central Park Conservancy, a favorite hat shape was the satellite dish, defying gravity on the side of the head.
The budget cuts imposed by sequestration are likely to hamper the Library of Congress’s efforts to copyright, digitize and store millions of books, photographs and other precious materials.
Employment for college graduates has increased by 9 percent since the start of the recession in 2007, while for those without a high school diploma, it has decreased by 14 percent.
A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.
From Mike Leigh’s “Life Is Sweet” to Elaine May’s “Ishtar,” a collection of releases to watch throughout the summer season.
New York State has set aside $140 million over the last year-and-a-half for a national advertising campaign. The following commercials were the initial productions of the campaign.
After many decades of success, the Eastman Kodak Company struggled to transition to the digital age.
Melissa Clark shows how to make a classic Middle Eastern dish featuring a spicy tomato sauce with eggs baked on top.
The fate of another planned book about New York Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, written by Fredric Dicker, is uncertain.
Married for five years, Miho Walsh and Roy Prieb kicked a video game habit and gained a toddler, with another baby on the way.
The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Something in the Air."
Photographs include a five-alarm fire in the Bronx, a motorcycle club in Queens and the cherry blossoms blooming in Brooklyn.
The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "What Maisie Knew."
In the days before the Kentucky Derby, officials will have 24-hour security surveillance of the 20 Derby horses in an attempt to restore confidence in a sport damaged by widespread drug culture.
From “Jaws” and “Star Wars” to “Hangover 3” and other sequels, David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about the summer movie season.
Richard Linklater, the director of “Before Midnight,” discusses a scene from his film featuring Julie Delpy and Ethan Hawke.
The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Iron Man 3."
The Times’s Catherine Rampell on the 165,000 jobs added to the economy ahead of what is normally a spring slump.

The recovery since the recession that ended in 2009 has been the weakest in decades, as measured by the change in gross domestic product. That is mainly due to a shrinking government sector and to relatively slow growth in consumer spending.
In “Caroline and Jackie,” a surprise birthday party starts an eventful evening that includes ugly confrontations.
The documentary “Unmade in China” shows the setbacks and power grabs that befell the writer and filmmaker Gil Kofman while he was directing the thriller “Case Sensitive” in China.
Steve Oleksy, a 27-year-old defenseman making his playoff debut, had a perfect assist against the Rangers in Washington’s 3-1 victory in Game 1. He also took a slap shot in the face.
Mike Bartlett’s “Bull,” directed by Clare Lizzimore at 59E59 Theaters, depicts desperate rivalry in an office where jobs are imperiled.
Wadada Leo Smith’s “Ten Freedom Summers,” a monumental jazz work presented at Roulette in Brooklyn, conjures the spirit and struggles of the civil rights movement.
Stephen Curry scored 22 points and David Lee made a surprising cameo in a quick return from injury as Golden State eliminated the Denver Nuggets in six games.
In “Turtle Hill, Brooklyn,” a gay couple are unsettled emotionally, as are many of their party guests, for varied reasons.
The police said the Pakistani government’s lead prosecutor in a case involving the assassination of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto has been shot to death.
In “Scatter My Ashes at Bergdorf’s,” stars dutifully pay tribute to Bergdorf Goodman, the high-end Manhattan department store.
In “The Happy House,” a young urban couple take a vacation in the country, with the ensuing terrors becoming symbolic of everything that’s wrong between them.
In “Desperate Acts of Magic,” two magicians flirt with romance and with joining forces in a show, but complications follow on both fronts.
